name: Animal Farm
summary: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting. He compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England' When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, uses blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill and dies in the hands of the best medical care. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Squealer and Napoleon indulge in the vices of humans (drinking, sleeping in beds, trading in trading accounts, etc) to alter the account in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about their society and society. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the Farm to "The Manor Farm" The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington and the animals realise that the Faces of the Pigs look like the facesof humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The original commandments are: Whatever goes upon two legs, or has wings, is an enemy.

name: A Clockwork Orange
summary: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence" Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel’s main theme before shredding the manuscript. The writer does not recognize Alex because the gang wore masks during the assault, and does not know Alex is the writer, whose name is revealed as F Alexander. Alex is also intelligent and quick-witting, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." Alex skips school the next day. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book who, keen to turn out Alex, beats him up with the help of his friends. The two policemen take Alex outside of the town and beat him up until he collapses at the door of an isolated cottage. During this sequence it is revealed that Mrs Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living in "where her horrid memory persists" despite the memories of Alexander. The first half of the story is the first half and his droogs invaded the house and his memories of Mrs Alexander are invaded. The second half is the second half and he realizes that it is too late and he is living in a "fragrant and horrid" house. The third half is when he shelters and questions him and shelters him in a shelter and asks him about the memories and questions about the horrid memories he persists in living in. The fourth and final section is when Alex is released into society and he shelters himself in the shelter and questions the memories about him and the memories he continues to live in despite the memory of her. The last half is a tragic pathos, as Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman.

name: The Plague
summary: Thousands of rats die in the streets of the town of Oran. Authorities respond by declaring martial law and imposing a curfew. When the daily number of deaths jumps to 30, the town is sealed and an outbreak of plague is officially declared. The plague begins to affect various characters, who begin to feel isolated and introverted. At the end of October, a new anti-plague serum is tried for the first time, but it cannot save the life of the Prefect, M. Othon, who has died of the plague. The text of The Plague is divided into five parts: the first, the second, the third, the fourth, the fifth and the sixth. The book is published by Picador, priced at $24.99, and is available in English, French, Spanish and Italian. It was published in France in 1864. It is published in the UK by Macmillan Books, priced £16.99 (pensioners) and £20 (non-fomers). It is also available in the U.S. for £15.99 and £18.99. It has been translated into English as "The Plague: A Tale of the Black Death" and "The Black Death: A Biography of The Black Death", published by MacMillan Books in 1998. The French version of the book has a different ending, with the ending being changed from "the black death" to "the white plague" The book was written in 1868 and published in 1869. It includes a prologue, the first part of which is written by Dr. Bernard Rieux, and the second part is by Jean Tarrou. The story is about a doctor and a civil servant who try to stop a plague outbreak in their town. It also includes the story of a man who tries to escape the city to join his lover in Paris, but is forced to stay after he is caught in the plague's clutches. In the last part of the novel, the main character, Dr. Cottard, tries to attend a performance of Gluck's opera Orpheus and Eurydice, but collapses with plague symptoms during the performance. He decides to stay, saying he would feel ashamed of himself if he left. The novel ends on a note of hope, as the plague seems to seem to be going away, but in fact it has spread to other parts of the world. It ends with a cliffhanger, ending on a promise of a cure.

name: An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding
summary: The argument of the Enquiry proceeds by a series of incremental steps, separated into chapters which logically succeed one another. After expounding his epistemology, Hume explains how to apply his principles to specific topics. For Hume, philosophy can be split into two general parts: natural philosophy and the philosophy of human nature (or, as he calls it, "moral philosophy") The latter investigates both actions and thoughts, while the former investigates both thoughts and ideas. In the first part, Hume discusses how the objects of inquiry are either "relations of ideas" or "matters of fact", which is roughly the distinction between analytic and synthetic propositions. In part two, Hume inquires into how anyone can justifiably believe that experience yields any conclusions about the world. Here he is describing what would become known as the problem of induction. For us, Hume shows that experience tells us something about world because of human habit, which forces us to assume something about human nature because of habit. He also explains that there are at least three kinds of associations between ideas: resemblance, contiguity in space-time, and cause-and-effect. He argues that there must be some universal principle that must account for the various sorts of connections that exist between ideas. (Hume 1974:322) In explaining how matters of fact are entirely a product of experience, he dismisses the notion that they may be arrived at through a priori reasoning. In this chapter, he explains how thoughts tend to come in sequences, as in trains of thought. For example, the idea of the taste of an orange is far inferior to the impression (or sensation) of actually eating one. He explains how a circular argument for the validity of experience can be based neither on demonstration (since it implies that the course of nature may change) nor on the fact that experience would be a contradiction that would be circular. But in one word, he answers the question, What is the foundation of all reasonings concerning that matter of fact? He says that it is founded on the relation of cause and effect, and it is replied, it is on relation of effect and relation to experience. In a later chapter, Hume also mentions the operations of mixing, separating, and dividing. He concludes by stating that one may experience a novel idea that itself is derived from combinations of previous impressions, such as with the body of a man upon a horse to make a centaur; augmenting (as with the case of a giant, whose size has been augmented); and diminishing.

name: A Fire Upon the Deep
summary: The novel posits that space around the Milky Way is divided into concentric layers called Zones, each being constrained by different laws of physics. The outermost zone, the "Transcend", contains most of the galactic halo and is populated by incomprehensibly vast and powerful posthuman entities. A human expedition investigates a five-billion-year-old data archive that offers the possibility of unimaginable riches for the ambitious young civilization of the Straumli Realm. The expedition's facility, called High Lab, is gradually compromised by a dormant super-intelligent entity (actually encoded within the archive) later known as the Blight. The novel starts with an imaginative description of the evolution of this superintelligence through exponentially accelerating developmental stages, culminating in a transcendent, nigh-omnipotent power that is unfathomable to mere humans. It ends with Pham Nuwen extending the Slow Zone by thousands of light-years to enclose the threat of the Bllight, at the cost of thousands of uninvolved civilizations and potentially the extinction of several galactic races. It also strands Pham and the other humans on the Tines world, now in the depths of the "Slow Zone" where rescue by an advanced civilization is impossible. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book versions for $24.99 (with an MSRP of $25). The novel is available for pre-order in the U.S. and Canada, and in the UK for £16.95 (with a UK release date of £18.99). For more information on how to order a copy of the book, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk or go to www.samaritans.com/shop/the-book/ The Book of the Book of The Book Of The Book, by Simon and Schuster, is published in the United States and Canada for £12.99 ($16.99) and £14.99 each (for UK and U.K. versions, respectively). It is also available in Australia and Europe for £9.99. For more details on the book and its plot, visit the website: http://www.simonschott.com/. For more on the novel's plot, go to http:// www.thebookofthebook.com or the website of the University of California, Los Angeles and the University of San Diego for £7.50 (for US$10).

name: All Quiet on the Western Front
summary: The book tells the story of Paul Bäumer, a German soldier who joins the German army shortly after the start of World War I. The book does not focus on heroic stories of bravery, but rather gives a view of the conditions in which the soldiers find themselves. The monotony between battles, the constant threat of artillery fire and bombardments, the struggle to find food, the lack of training of young recruits and the role of random chance in the lives and deaths of the soldiers are described in detail. In the final chapter, Paul feels that that peace is coming soon, but he does not see the future as bright and shining. When he finally dies at the end of the novel, "All Quiet on the Western Front," states the situation, "The symbolizing the cheapness of human life in war is the soldier" He feels remorse and asks forgiveness from the man's corpse. He is devastated and later confesses to Kat and Albert, who try to comfort him and reassure him that it is only part of the war. They are then sent on what Paul calls a "good job" They must guard a village that is being shelled too heavily. The men enjoy themselves but while evacuating the villagers, Paul and Albert are wounded. They recuperate in a Catholic hospital and Paul returns to active duty. By now, the war is nearing its end and the German Army is retreating. In despair, Paul watches as his friends fall one by one. It is the death of Kat that eventually makes Paul careless about living. He feels that he has no aims left in life and that their generation will be different and misunderstood. "We are not youth any longer. We don't want to take the world by storm. We are fleeing from ourselves, from our life. We were eighteen and had begun to love life and the world; and we had to shoot it to pieces," he says. "Ah! Mother, Mother! How can it be that I must part from you? Here I sit and there you are lying; we have so much to say, and we shall never say it." In the end, he concludes that he "ought never to have come [home] on leave." Paul feels glad to be reunited with his comrades. Soon after, he volunteers to go on a patrol and kills a man for the first time in hand-to-hand combat. He watches the man die, in pain for hours. He finds that he does "not belong here anymore, it is a foreign world"

name: A Wizard of Earthsea
summary: Ged is a young boy on Gont, one of the larger islands in the north of the archipelago of Earthsea. Ged discovers by accident that he has an extraordinary talent for magic. His aunt, the village witch, teaches him the little she herself knows, but his power far exceeds hers. In the rite of passage into adulthood, he gives the boy his "true name", Ged, and takes him as an apprentice. In his hubris, he attempts to summon a dead spirit - a perilous spell which goes awry. The shadow seizes the chance to escape into the world and attacks him, scarring his face. He flees to what appears to be a safe haven in the castle of Benderesk, the lord of Terranon. Serret, his wife, is the same girl who taunted Ged years ago. She tries to enslave Ged using the power of a stone which harbors one ofThe "Nameless Ones", ancient malevolent powers that predate the world. Fortunately Ged flies away in the form of a falcon and returns to Gont and Ogion to turn the tables on his enemy. In following the shadow, Ged pursues the shadowwards across the ocean, but nearly drowned when the boat lures him into his boat onto rocks, but he manages to reach a small island inhabited by only two old people, a Kargish man and his sister. Despite their initial fear of him, they provide him with food and water and he regains his strength. He is finally able to reach the safety of Roke, where he is reunited with his sister, who were abandoned as children and have forgotten there is an outside world outside of their world. He eventually realizes that he cannot both defend the islanders against the dragon and himself against the nameless thing he summoned. He takes a desperate gamble; in the old histories, he has found the true name of a dragon which might be the one he faces. His guess is right and by using the dragon's name, Yevaud, he is able to force the dragon to vow that neither it nor its offspring will ever trouble the islander. After a painful and slow recovery, he graduates from the school. He returns to the people of Gont to help them in their fight against a powerful dragon and its maturing sons, who have been seen scouting the region. He realizes that the roles of Ged and the enemy become reversed and the roles are reversed.

name: Anyone Can Whistle
summary: The story is set in an imaginary American town that has gone bankrupt. The only place in town doing good business is the local sanitarium, known as "The Cookie Jar" A mysterious stranger, J. Bowden Hapgood, arrives asking for directions to the Cookie Jar. He is instantly taken for the new assistant. As the extended musical sequence ends, the lights black out except for a spotlight on Hap good, who announces to the audience, “You are all mad!” Seconds later, the stage set has vanished, and the cast is revealed in theater seats, holding programs, applauding the audience. The musical ends with the cast in the theater seats applauding them, as well as the cast of the show. The show was directed by Robert Altman, who also directed the film version of "The Sound of Music" and "The Nutcracker" The musical was released on September 14, 1998. It is currently on tour in the U.S., Europe, and Australia. It has been released on DVD and Blu-ray in the United States, and on Blu-Ray in the UK on November 14, 2008, and in Australia on November 15, 2008. The movie version of this article is based on the novel "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time" by Stephen Sondheim and directed by Mark O'Mara. For more information on the "Cookie Jar" series, visit www.cnn.com/cnn/2013/01/29/the-cookie-jar-musical-theatre-theater-the-sound-of-music-theatrical-theaters/story.html#storylink=cpy. The cast of this version of the play has been remade for theBlu-Ray version, which is on sale now and will be released on November 16, 2013, in a limited edition of 10,000 copies of the book, The Cookie Jar: The Curious Case of the Bluebird and The Bluebird And The Blue Bird and the Blue Bird & The Bluebirds, by Steven Sonderman and Mark O’Mara, will be on sale for $25,000. The book will be published by Simon & Schuster, Inc. in the spring of 2013. It will also be published in the fall of 2013, as part of the company’s 20th anniversary commemorations of the 100th anniversary of the opening of the Sanitarium.

name: Blade Runner 3: Replicant Night
summary: Deckard is acting as a consultant to a movie crew filming the story of his Blade Runner days. He finds himself drawn into a mission on behalf of the replicants he was once assigned to kill. Meanwhile, the mystery surrounding the beginnings of the Tyrell Corporation is being dragged out into the light. The film is expected to be released on October 25, 2015. It is directed by Ridley Scott and written by Hampton Fancher and Michael Hirst. The movie is based on the book "Blade Runner: The Rise of the Red Planet" by Philip K. Dick and George R.R. Martin. For more information on the film, visit the film's official website and Facebook page. For additional information about the film and its cast, visit www.blakerunner.com.

name: Blade Runner 2: The Edge of Human
summary: Deckard has retired to an isolated shack outside the city, taking the replicant Rachael with him in a Tyrell transport container. He is approached by a woman who explains she is Sarah Tyrell, niece of Eldon Tyrell and heiress to the Tyrell Corporation. She asks Deckard to hunt down the "missing" sixth Replicant. At the same time, the human template for Roy Batty hires Dave Holden, the blade runner attacked by Leon, to help him hunt down Deckard. Deckard and Holden's investigations lead them to re-visit Sebastian, Bryant, and John Isidore (from the book Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep?), learning more about the nature of the blade runners and replicants. When Deckard, Batty, and Holden finally clash,Batty's inhuman fighting prowess leads Holden to believe he has been duped all along and that Batty is the sixthreplicant; he shoots him. However, Holden - recovering from his injuries during the fight - later finds the truth: Rachae has been killed by Tyrell agents, and the "Rachael" who escaped with Deckard was actually Sarah. She has completed her revenge by both destroying Tyrell,. and taking back Rachail's place. The film was directed by Ridley Scott and co-written by Hampton Fancher and Sam Raimi. It was released on October 25, 2013. It is the 50th anniversary of the release of the first Blade Runner film, which marked the beginning of the "Blade Runner" series. The movie was released in cinemas on October 26, 2013, and was followed by a special edition Blu-ray and DVD release on October 27, 2013 and a special-edition Blu-Ray/DVD release on December 28, 2013 (and a Blu- ray/DVD combo on December 30, 2013). The film is available in English, French, Spanish, and German, with subtitles in English and German. It has been released in the U.S. on October 28, 2014, and in the UK on October 30, 2014. It will be released in Australia on October 31, 2014 and in Australia the following day. The U.K. release date is October 29, 2014 (and the UK release date on November 1, 2014). It will also be available in the United States on November 2, 2015, and Australia on November 3, 2015 (and in the US on November 4, 2015.

name: Book of Joshua
summary: Joshua is a book about the conquest of the Promised Land. God commissions Joshua to take possession of the land and warns him to keep faith with the Covenant. The Israelites cross the Jordan through the miraculous intervention of God and his ark and are circumcised at Gibeath-Haaraloth (translated as hill of foreskins) The conquest begins in Canaan with Jericho, followed by Ai (central Canaan) and renews the Covenant (the covenant ceremony has elements of a divine land-grant ceremony, similar to ceremonies known from Mesopotamia). The narrative now switches to the south. With the south conquered the narrative moves to the northern campaign. A powerful multi-national coalition headed by the king of Hazor, the most important northern city, is defeated with Yahweh's help and Hazor captured and destroyed. The Gibeonites trick the Israelites into entering into an alliance with them by saying they are not Canaanites, but they are enslaved instead. Joshua performs the concluding covenant ceremony, and send the people to their inheritance. Chapter 11:16-23 summarises the campaign: Joshua has taken the entire land, and the land "had rest from war" Chapter 12 lists the vanquished kings on both sides of the Jordan. The Transjordanian tribes are dismissed, affirming their loyalty to YahweH. Joshua charges the leaders of the Israelite leaders to remain faithful to Yah Weh and the covenant, warning of judgement should Israel leave Yahwe H and follow other gods. The story now turns to the second, to "put the people in possession ofThe second, is a "covenantal land grant": Yahwe h, as king, is issuing each tribe its territory. The "cities of refuge" and Levitical cities are attached to the end, since it is necessary for the tribes to receive their grants before they allocate parts of it to others. The tribes are given their grants first, and then the land is given to them in a series of stages, with the final stage being the land grant. The book ends with a speech by Joshua about what must be done if Israel is to live in peace in the land. It may have used the then-recent 701 BCE campaign of the Assyrian king Sennacherib in Judah as his model; the hanging of the captured kings is in accordance with Assyrian practice of the 8th century. It is possible that the Deuteronomist author may have been inspired by this campaign.

name: Book of Ezra
summary: The Book of Ezra consists of ten chapters. chapters 1-6 cover the period from the Decree of Cyrus to the dedication of the Second Temple. chapters 7-10, dealing with the mission of Ezra, are told largely in the first person. The book contains several documents presented as historical inclusions. For the Bible text, see Bible Gateway (opens at NIV version) or see King James Version. for the Bible translation, see the Bible Gateway site. For more information on the Book of Ezra, visit: http://www.biblegateway.com/book-of-ezra/index.php?title=Ezra-Bible-King-James-Vatican-1-10-Chapters-7-10. The Bible version of this article is based on the New International Version of the King James Bible (KJV), which is published by Oxford University Press. The KJV version has been translated from the English version by the Church of England, and is available on the Internet at www.kjv.org..

name: Book of Numbers
summary: God orders Moses, in the wilderness of Sinai, to number those able to bear arms and to appoint princes over each tribe. 603,550 Israelites are found to be fit for military service. Miriam and Aaron insult Moses at Hazeroth, which angers God; Miriam is punished with leprosy and is shut out of camp for seven days. The Israelites blame Moses for the lack of water. Moses is ordered by God to speak to a rock but disobeys, and is punished by the announcement that he shall not enter Canaan. The children of Israel murmur against Moses and Aaron on account of the death of Korah's men and are stricken with the plague, with 14,700 perishing. The Levites are again appointed to help in the keeping of the Tabernacle. The land east of the Jordan is divided among the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. Moses orders the Israelites to massacre the people of Midian. The boundaries of the land are spelled out to be divided under the supervision of Eleazar, Joshua, and twelve princes. The daughters of Zelophehad, their father having no sons, are to share in the allotment. The Reubenites and the Gadites request Moses to assign them the land eastof the Jordan. Moses grants their request after they promise to help with the conquest of theLand west of theJordan. The Land is divided by lot, with the daughters of the father of one of the Reubenite princes to share the allotments. A new census gives the total number of males from twenty years and upward as 601,730. The number of the Levites from a month old and upward is 23,000. The Lord orders a second census, in which the tribe of Levi is exempted from military service and therefore not included in the census totals. The people of Israel are bitten by Fiery flying serpents for speaking against God and Moses, and a brazen serpent is made to ward off these serpent. The God-fearing Israelites set out for Moab, on Canaan's western border, on the plains of Moab. They are told that the land is abundant and is "flowing with milk and honey"; the other spies say that it is inhabited by giants, and they refuse to enter the land. Moses recalls the stations at which the. Israelites halted during their years' wander during their forty years of wander.

name: Book of Ruth
summary: During the Judges, an Israelite family from Bethlehem emigrate to the nearby country of Moab. Elimelech dies, and the sons marry two Moabite women: Mahlon marries Ruth and Chilion marries Orpah. The two sons of Naomi then die themselves. Naomi tells her daughters-in-law to return to their own mothers, and remarry. However, Ruth says, "Entreat me not to leave you, or to turn back from following you" (Ruth 1:16–17 NKJV) Boaz and Ruth get married and have a son named Obed (who by Levirate customs is also considered a son or heir to Elimeslech, and thus Naomi). In the genealogy which concludes the story, it is pointed out that Obed is the father of Jesse, and Thus the grandfather of David. This also places Ruth among David's ancestors. (R Ruth 4:7–18) Boz and Ruth have a child named Obing. (Obed is the grandfather to Jesse and thus David) (Ezekiel 16:8) (N.B. The phrase "spread your cloak" was a woman's way of asking for marriage. For a man to spread his cloak over a woman showed acquisition of that woman. For Ruth to "uncover the feet" of the sleeping Boaz, Ruth does so; Boaz awakes and asks,"Who are you?" Ruth identifies herself, then asks Boaz to spread her cloak over her. The next morning, Boaz discusses the issue with the other male relative, Ploni Almoni ("so-and-so") before the town elders. The other relative is unwilling to jeopardize the inheritance of his own estate by marrying Ruth, and so relinquishes his right of redemption. They transfer the property and redeem it by the nearer kinsman taking off his sandal and handing it over to Boaz. (Boaz 4:6–7) (NKJV) (Runk 4:8-9) (KJV) Ruth and Boaz get married. (KV: 4:9-10) ( NK: 9-10). (Kv: 10-11) (J:11-12) (kv: 11-13) ( Kv: 13-14) (kj: 14-15) ( kv: 15-16) (j:15-17) (qv: 17-18) (kk: 18-19)

name: Book of Esther
summary: Ahasuerus, ruler of a massive Persian empire, holds a lavish party, initially for his court and dignitaries and afterwards for all inhabitants of the capital city Shushan. He orders the queen Vashti to display her beauty before the guests, but she refuses. Worried all women will learn from this, he removes her as queen and has a royal decree sent across the empire that men should be the ruler of their households. One of these is the orphan Esther, whose Jewish name is Hadassah. She finds favor in the king's eyes, and is made his new queen. Esther does not reveal that she is Jewish and that Haman is planning to exterminate her people, including her. The previous decree against the Jews cannot be annulled, but the king allows the Jews to defend themselves during attacks on 13 Adar. As a result, five hundred attackers and Haman's ten sons are killed in ShUSHan, followed by a Jewish slaughter of seventy-five thousand Persians, although they took no plunder. Ahasueru remains very powerful and continues with his prominent position in the court, with Mordechai assuming a prominent position with his position in his court, and continues to rule with a prominent role. The story ends on the 13th of the month of Adar, when everyone in the empire is free to massacre the Jews and despoil their property, and the Jews are massacred by Haman and his friends. The book was first published in 7th century BC by Boudicca and is now considered one of the most important works of ancient Persian literature. It is also known as the "Book of the Kings" and "The Book of the Lost Kings" by H.A. Ghandi and H. A. Hellyer. It was written by Terence Moore and published by Macmillan & Co. in 18th century. The novel is about the downfall of the Persian king and his prime minister, Haman. The plot involves the assassination of the king and the death of the prime minister's son and heir to the throne, the son of Haman, Mordecai, and his son-in-law, the king, Ahasurus. It also tells the story of the birth of the first woman to rule the Persian Empire, the first Persian queen, and how she became a mother to Esther, the daughter of Ahaserus and the mother of the next king, Qutb.

name: Book of Job
summary: The book of Job tells the story of an extremely righteous man named Job, who is very prosperous and has seven sons and three daughters. Constantly fearing that his sons may have sinned and "cursed God in their hearts", he habitually offers burnt offerings as a pardon for their sins. The "sons of God" and Satan (literally "the Adversary") present themselves to God, and God asks Satan his opinion on Job. Satan answers that Job is pious only because God has put a "wall around" him and "blessed" his favourite servant with prosperity, but if God were to stretch out his hand and strike everything that Job had, then he would surely curse God. God gives Satan permission to test Job's righteousness. All Job's possessions are destroyed: 500 yoke of oxen and 500 donkeys carried off by Sabeans; 7,000 sheep burned up by 'The fire of God which fell from the sky'; 3,000 camels stolen by the Chaldeans; and the house of the firstborn destroyed by a mighty wind, killing Job's ten children. Still Job does not curse God, but instead shaves his head, tears his clothes, and says, "Naked I came out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return: Lord has given, and Lord has taken away; blessed be the name of Lord" The story ends with Job restored to health, with a new family and twice as much livestock, and Job's wife prompts him to "curse God" But Job answers, "You speak as one of the foolish speaks. Moreover, shall we receive good from God and shall not receive evil?" Three friends of Job, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, come to console him. The friends spend seven days sitting on the ground with Job, without saying anything to him because they see that he is suffering and in much pain. Job at last breaks his silence and "Curses the day he was born" God responds saying that there are so many things Job doesnot know about how this world was formed or how nature works, that Job should consider God as being greater than the thunderstorm and strong enough to pull in the leviathan with a fish-hook. God then rebukes the three friends and says: "I am angry with you... you have not spoken of me what is right"

name: Book of Hosea

God calls up a great storm at sea, and the ship's crew cast Jonah overboard in an attempt to appease God. A great sea creature sent by God, swallows Jonah. For three days and three nights Jonah languishes inside the fish's belly. He says a prayer in which he repents for his disobedience and thanks God for His mercy. After his rescue, Jonah obeys the call to prophesy against Nineveh and they repent and God forgives them. Ironically, the relentless God demonstrated in the first chapter becomes the merciful God in the last two chapters (see 3:10). In a parallel turnabout, Jonah becomes one of the most effective of all prophets, turning the entire population of Nineveh (about 120,000 people) to God. The book was written by H.P. Zion will be rebuilt, but by God, and based not on violence and corruption but on the desire to learn God's laws and live in peace. Although chapters 4:9-10 have said that there is "no king in Zion", these chapters predict a new military ruler will emerge from Bethlehem, the traditional home of the Davidic monarchy, to restore the security of Israel. name: Book of Haggai
summary: Haggai's message is filled with an urgency for the people to proceed with the rebuilding of the second Jerusalem temple. Haggai attributes a recent drought to the peoples' refusal to rebuild the temple, which he sees as key to Jerusalem’s glory. The book ends with the prediction of the downfall of kingdoms, with one Zerubbabel, governor of Judah, as the Lord's chosen leader. The language here is not as finely wrought as in some other books of the minor prophets, yet the intent seems straightforward. It was written in the first century BC, and is one of the oldest books in the Bible. It is written in Aramaic, which is the language of the ancient Israelites, and was written after the fall of the Babylonian Empire in the second century. It has been translated into English by several different authors, including Samuel Johnson, who wrote the first edition of the Bible, as well as the second edition, which was published in the 17th century and is published by Simon & Schuster. name: Crash
summary: The story is told through the eyes of narrator James Ballard, named after the author himself. It centers on the sinister figure of Dr. Robert Vaughan, a “former TV-scientist, turned nightmare angel of the expressways” Ballard meets Vaughan after being involved in a car accident himself near London Airport. Gathering around Vaughan is a group of alienated people, all of them former crash-victims, who follow him in his pursuit to re-enact the crashes of celebrities, and experience what the narrator calls "a new sexuality, born from a perverse technology" Vaughan’s ultimate fantasy is to die in a head-on collision with movie star Elizabeth Taylor. The Imperial high council has lost the political initiative and is powerless to control the Jihad. Leto II and Ghanima, sharing his prescience, have concluded that their guardian Alia has succumbed to possession by one of her ancestors. They (and Alia) also realize that the terraforming of Dunes will kill all the sandworms, thus destroying the source of the spice. The twins anticipate and survive the Corrino assassination plot. The seemingly immortal and omnipotent Leto is left as Emperor of the Known Universe, with Gahnima at his side. The Preacher and Leto return to the capital to confront Alia who has the Preacher murdered, revealing his true identity. He confronts Alia and offers to help her overcome her possession but she is overwhelmed by her ancestral personae and elects to commit suicide. He escapes his captors and sacrifices his humanity in pursuit of the Golden Path. This requires him to physically fuse with a school of sandtrout, gaining superhuman strength and near-invulnerability. Duncan Idaho returns to Arrakis and provokes Stilgar into killing him. With StilGar's neutrality now untenable, he seizes Ghanimah and flees. Alia recaptures Ghanime and arranges her marriage to Farad’n, planning to exploit the expected chaos when Ghanimo kills him to avenge her brother’s murder. Duncan and Jessica flee to Salusa Secundus where Jessica begins to mentor the CorRino heir Farad'sn. He enlists in his service and delivers control of the Cor Rino armies. name: Candide, ou l'Optimisme
summary: Candide contains thirty episodic chapters, which may be grouped into two main schemes: one consists of two divisions, separated by the protagonist's hiatus in El Dorado; the other consists of three parts, each defined by its geographical setting. By the former scheme, the first half of Candide constitutes the rising action and the last part the resolution. This view is supported by the strong theme of travel and quest, reminiscent of adventure and picaresque novels, which tend to employ such a dramatic structure. The plot summary that follows uses this second format and includes Voltaire's additions of 1761. Candide begins in the castle of the Baron Thunder-ten-Tronckh in Westphalia, home to the Baron's daughter, Lady Cunégonde; his bastard nephew, Candide; a tutor, Pangloss; a chambermaid, Paquette; and the rest of the Baron's family. The protagonist is romantically attracted to Cunéegonde, but is evicted from the castle for kissing her. He is captured by Bulgar (Prussian) recruiters and coerced into military service, where he is flogged, nearly executed, and forced to participate in a major battle between the Bulgars and the Abares (an allegory representing the Prussians and the French) Candide eventually escapes the army and makes his way to Holland where he was given aid by Jacques, an Anabaptist, who strengthens Candide's optimism. He and Jacques set sail to Lisbon, where they are overtaken by a vicious storm which destroys the boat. Jacques attempts to save a sailor, and in the process is thrown overboard. The sailor makes no move to help the drowning Jacques, and Candide is in a state of despair until Pang Loss explains to him that Lisbon harbor was created in order for Jacques to drown. Along the way, Cuneegonde falls into self-pity, complaining of all the misfortunes that have befallen her. She sells her life to a Jewish merchant who was threatened by a corrupt Grand Inquisitor. Her owners arrive, find her with another man, and both Candide and the two women flee the city, heading to the Americas, which included a tragic life which included her own tragic death. He waits alive for an old woman, who had been raped and disemboweled, but she tells him that she had been saved by Candide. He then kills her.

name: Carmilla
summary: The story is presented by Le Fanu as part of the casebook of Dr Hesselius, whose departures from medical orthodoxy rank him as the first occult doctor in literature. The story is narrated by Laura, one of the two main protagonists of the tale. Laura begins her tale by relating her childhood in a "picturesque and solitary" castle in the midst of an extensive forest in Styria. When she is six years old, Laura has a vision of a beautiful visitor in her bedchamber. She later claims to have been bitten on the chest, although no wounds are found on her. 12 years later, Laura and her father are admiring the sunset in front of the castle when her father tells her of a letter he received earlier from his friend General Spielsdorf. The General was supposed to bring his niece, Bertha Rheinfeldt, to visit the two, but the niece suddenly died under mysterious circumstances. Laura is saddened by the loss of a potential friend, and longs for a companion. A carriage accident outside Laura's home unexpectedly brings a girl of Laura's age into the family's care. Her name is Carmilla. Both girls instantly recognize the other from the 'dream' they both had when they were young. Carmilla and Laura grow to be very close friends, but occasionally Carmilla's mood abruptly changes. She sometimes makes unsettling romantic advances towards Laura. When a shipment of family heirloom restored portraits arrives at the castle, Laura finds one of her ancestors, "Mircalla, Countess Karnstein", dated 1698. The portrait resembles Carmilla exactly, down to the mole on her neck. When they arrive at Karnstein, the General asks a nearby woodsman where he can find the tomb of Mircalla. The woodsman relates that the tomb was relocated for the original name of the Countess. While Laura and Carmilla are left alone in the ruined chapel, Carmilla appears to both fly into a rage upon seeing each other and attacks each other with an axe. The two girls are separated by the General and the General explains to Laura that Carmilla is also an original Countess of Karnstein and that she is also a vampire. Laura comments that this information seems needless to say, and her dad laughs it off. Laura's father then sets out with Laura in a carriage for the ruined village of Karn Stein. They leave a message behind asking Carmilla to follow after once the perpetually late-sleeping Carmilla wakes up.

name: The Cider House Rules
summary: Homer Wells grows up in an orphanage where he spends his childhood "being of use" as a medical assistant to the director, Dr. Wilbur Larch. As a young man, Homer befriends a young couple, Candy Kendall and Wally Worthington, who come to St. Cloud's Orphanage for an abortion. Wally and Candy marry shortly afterward, but Candy and Homer maintain a secret affair that lasts some 15 years. Many years later, teenaged Angel falls in love with Rose Rose, the daughter of the head migrant worker at the apple orchard. She becomes pregnant by her father, and Homer performs an abortion on her. Homer decides to return to the orphanage after the death of Dr. Larch, to work as the new director. Though he maintains his distaste for abortions, he continues Dr.Larch's legacy of honoring the choice of his patients. He dreams of the day when abortions are free, legal, and safe, so he'll no longer feel obliged to offer them. A subplot follows the character Melony, who was Homer's first girlfriend in a relationship of circumstances. She eventually becomes an electrician and takes a female lover, Lorna. Melony is an extremely stoic woman, who refuses to press charges against a man who brutally broke her nose and arm so that she can later retaliate herself. She is the catalyst that transforms Homer from his comfortable but not entirely admirable position at the Apple orchard to becoming Dr. larch's replacement at the Orphans' Orchard. The film was released on September 14, 1998. It is the 50th anniversary of the birth of the first child, Homer Wells, the son of Homer Wells and his first girlfriend, Melony. The movie is based on the novel "Homer and Melony" by William S. Hartung, and was directed by Robert Altman, who also directed "The Godfather" and "The Lord of the Flies" The film is available on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray for the first time in the U.S. and the UK on September 15, 1998, and on DVD on September 16, 2008, for the UK and UK.
