name: The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch
summary: The story begins in a future world where global warming has resulted in global temperatures so high that in most of the world it is unsafe to be outside without special cooling gear during daylight hours. In a desperate bid to preserve humanity and ease population burdens on Earth, the UN has initiated a "draft" for colonizing the nearby planets. The unwilling colonists have fallen prey to a form of escapism involving the use of an illegal drug (CAN-D) in concert with "layouts". Layouts are physical props intended to simulate a sort of alternate reality where life is easier than either the grim existence of the colonist in their marginal off-world colonies, or even Earth. The illegal drug CAN-D allows people to "share" their experience of the "Perky Pat" (the name of the main female character in the simulated world) The novel opens shortly after Barney Mayerson, P.P. Layouts' top precognitive (someone who can glimpse future possibilities and sort out the most likely to actually occur), has received a " draft notice" from the UN for involuntary resettlement as a colonist on Mars. In the future, Mayerson arrives in New York two years after the death of Palmer Eldritch, who appears in holographic form to hallucinate a world where he does not control his "hallucination" Like Bulero, he finds himself in the future where he speaks with his future self, and also encounters several manifestations of Eldritch. The novel ends shortly after Mayerson returns to Earth and fires his assistant, Roni Fugate, because he was afraid he was going to be responsible for Eldritch's death. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback, e-book, and audiobook. For confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/. For support in the UK, call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, see www.samaritans.org. For help in the U.S., call the national suicide prevention Lifeline on 1-844-457-9255 or go to http:// www. Samaritans. org. For information on how to get involved in the book, go to www.sussex.org or www.Suffolk.edu. For more information on the book and the author, visit www.the author's website.

name: Time out of Joint
summary: Ragle Gumm believes that he lives in the year 1959 in a quiet American suburb. He learns that his idyllic town is a constructed reality designed to protect him. Gumm lives on a then-future Earth (circa 1998) that is at war with its colonists on the Moon. The book ends with some hope for peace, because the colonists are more willing to negotiate than the Earth government has been telling its citizens. It is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (hardcover) and £12.95 ( paperback) (with p&p) The book is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, Spanish and Portuguese. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschulder.com and www.thestar-telegram.co.uk/book-of-the-year-2009/ragle-gumm-s-fantasy-book-focuses-on-1959-by-simon-schuelder-and-says-it-is-a-fantastic-novel-titled-where-will-thelittle-green-man-be-next?utm_source=cnn.com/books/Ragle-Gumm-Fantasy-Book-Of-The-Year-2009-Focussed-On- 1959-By-Simon-Schuelder.html#storylink=cpy. In the U.S. and Canada, the book is published as "Where Will The Little Green Man Be Next?" by Simon and Schulder, priced $24.99 and $28.99 respectively (hardback). The book was published in the UK by Hodder & Stoughton, and is published in Australia by HarperCollins, and in Europe by Macmillan, and can be ordered by clicking here: http://www.harperclayonline.com/. For more details on the novel, visit the author's website: www.raglegummfockeyshirt.com. For the UK version of this article, click here: www.harpers.com /book/the-fictional-world-of Ragle Gumm Focuses on 1959 by Simon Stoughton-and Other-Writers and Harpers-Online. For the UK version, click on the link below: http:// www.harsher.com/#storylink.

name: A Scanner Darkly
summary: The protagonist is Bob Arctor, member of a household of drug-users. He is also living a parallel life as Agent Fred, an undercover police agent. Arctor's persistent use of the drug causes the two hemispheres of his brain to function independently, or "compete" The story ends with Bruce working at a New-Path farming commune, where he is suffering from a serious neurocognitive deficit after withdrawing from Substance D. The book ends with "Bruce" hiding a flower in his shoe to give to his "friends" – undercover police agents posing as recovering addicts at the Los Angeles New- path facility – on Thanksgiving. It is revealed that Donna has been a narcotics agent all along, working as part of a police operation to infiltrate New-path and determine its funding source. Without his knowledge, Arctor has been selected to penetrate the secretive organization. As part of the rehab program,. Arctor is renamed " Bruce" and forced to participate in cruel group-dynamic games intended to break the will of the patients. The story ended with Bruce hiding a. blue flowers growing hidden among rows of corn, and realizing the blue flowers are Mors. ontologica, the source of Substance D, and realizes the blue Flowers are the source. of Substance. D, a powerful psychoactive drug. It's also referred to as "Slow Death," "Death," or "D," a term used to refer to the drug's effects on the human body. The drug is also known as "Substance D" or "Mors D," a name given to a drug that is used by drug users to describe the drug that has been used to create the drug, "D" The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced $24.99, and is available in hardcover, paperback, e-book, and audiobook. It was published in the U.S. on November 14, 2013. It has been published in Australia on November 15, 2013, and in the UK on November 21, 2013 and on November 28, 2013 in hardback, £16.99. For more information on the book, go to: www.simonandschuster.com/the-book/The-Book-By-Bob-Arctor-by-Bob Arctor and-The-Author-Barry-Alfred-Baldwin-Barlow-The Book-By Barry Alford-Bilder.

name: Radio Free Albemuth
summary: In this alternate history the corrupt US President Ferris F. Fremont (FFF for 666, ‘F’ being the 6th letter in the alphabet, see Number of the Beast) becomes Chief Executive in the late Nineteen-Sixties. Ironically enough, the President's paranoia and opportunism lead to the establishment of a real resistance movement. As with VALIS, Radio Free Albemuth deals with author Philip Dick's highly personal style of Christianity (or Gnosticism) It further examines the moral and ethical repercussions of informing on trusting friends for the authorities. Also prominent is Dick's dislike of the Republican Party, satirizing Nixon's America as a Stalinist or neo-fascist police state. Dick himself is a major character, though fictitious protagonist Nicholas Brady serves as a vehicle for Dick's alleged gnostic theophany on February 11, 1974. In addition, Sadassa Silvia is a character who claims that Ferris Fremont is actually a communist covert agent recruited bySadassa's mother when Fremont was still a teenager. Dick narrates the concluding passage about his life in a concentration camp, where his supposedly latest work is actually penned by a ghost writer and regime-approved hack. He and his friends, it turns out, were just a decoy set up by VALIS to detour the government from stopping a much more popular A-List band from releasing a similar record with a better-established recording company. As Dick realizes this and hears youngsters repeating the lyrics he realizes that salvation may lie within the hearts and minds of the next generation. The novel is autobiographical, as with its successor,VALIS, this novel is partly based on Dick's own experiences with his faith and his time as a young man in the U.S. in the 1960s. It is published by Simon & Schuster, with a cover price of $24.99 (£16.99) and a print run of 1,000 copies of 2,500 copies of the book is expected to sell for $2,500 (£1,500) in the UK. The book is available in hardback and hardback, as well as on Kindle, with prices starting at £12.99 ($16) and £14.99 (both prices include a free download of the audiobook version of the novel, which includes the audio commentary by Philip Dick and the book's author's interview with Nicholas Brady. For more information on the book, visit the publisher's website.

name: Pride and Prejudice
summary: The narrative opens with Mr Bingley, a wealthy, charming and social young bachelor, moving into Netherfield Park in the neighbourhood of the Bennet family. Mr Darcy slights Elizabeth, who overhears and jokes about it despite feeling a budding resentment. At the same time, Elizabeth forms an acquaintance with Mr Wickham, a militia officer who claims to have been very seriously mistreated by Darcy's father. Elizabeth and the Gardiners go to Longbourn, where Elizabeth grieves that her renewed acquaintance with Darcy will end of of of their marriage. Disgusted by her nephew's abominable behaviour, Elizabeth warns Darcy that she may thwart the local rumour that he may be due to marry her. Mr Bingly's return and subsequent proposal to Jane, who accepts immediately, lends Elizabeth's opinion of Darcy, and she warns him against marrying her nephew. The novel ends with Elizabeth's sister Lydia, Elizabeth's older sister, having run away to elope with her younger sister, Lydia Wickham. The couple are soon found, then married by the clergy, where Lydia lets slip that Darcy was responsible for finding the couple their marriage—at great expense to himself and to Elizabeth's family. The story ends with Lydia's sister, Elizabeth, having found a husband for her brother-in-law, Mr Fitzwilliam, and the pair being married in a secret ceremony at Pemberley, the family's country home. The book is published by William Morrow and Company, and is available in hard and soft copies for £12.99 each (including p&p) and £16.99 for a copy of the unabridged version of the novel, which includes the author's notes and other appendices, as well as an extract from the novel's Prologue and an extract of the Prologue. For more information on the book, visit: http://www.bookshop.com/Jane-Bingley-and-the-Bennet-Netherfield-Pemberley-The-Nemesis-2-1-1/. For more on the plot, see: www.bookseller.co.uk/pages/bengley-nemesis.html. For the full version of this article, go to: http:/www. Bookshop.org/Bengley/The-Plot-And-Beneath-The Bennets.html and the-Pembroke-Family-Tree.

name: Pale Fire
summary: After Shade was murdered, Kinbote acquired the manuscript, including some variants, and has taken it upon himself to oversee the poem's publication. After Shade was killed, KinBote narrates how Gradus killed Shade by mistake. KinbOTE's second story deals with King Charles II, "The Beloved," the deposed king of Zembla. In the last note, to the missing line 1000, Kin bote narrate how Gradu killed Shade. Kin botes his own story, notably including what he thinks of as his friendship with Shade. One of Kinbotes annotations to Shade's poem (corresponding to line 493) addresses the subject of suicide at some length. Brian Boyd has argued that internal evidence points to Kinboting's suicide. Nabokov said in an interview that Kinboted committed suicide after finishing the book. The critic Michael Wood has stated, "This is authorial trespassing, and we don't have to pay attention to it," but Brian Boyd argues that it is a sign of Kin boting his own work, and that Kin bares all responsibility for the work he has written in the book, including the writing of the poem. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a print run of 2,500 copies at £25.99. The first edition of the book was published in September 1913, and the second edition in June 1914. The second edition is priced £15.99 and includes a copy of the first edition with 2,000 copies of the second volume. The third edition is on sale for £14.99; the fourth edition is £20; the fifth and sixth editions are on sale separately for £15, £20, £25, £30, and £35, respectively. The fourth edition has been published in the UK and the United States, and is available for £16, £15 and £25 respectively. It is available in hardback and paperback, with prices ranging from £10, £12, £14, £16 and £24.99 in the U.S. and the UK. The U.K. edition has the option of a Kindle download for £9.99 with a free Kindle download. The UK edition also comes with a PDF download of the entire book, with the option to download the book for £12.99 plus a free audiobook of the same name. The Kindle version has a download option of £8.99 including a free download of all the stories in the collection.

name: Pacific Overtures
summary: Pacific Overtures is a Japanese playwright's version of an American musical about American influences on Japan. The play is set in July 1853, and follows the story of Kayama, a minor samurai, and Manjiro, the only man in Japan who has dealt with Americans. Kayama is sent to meet with the Americans but he is rejected as not important enough. He enlists the aid of ManJiro, and disguised as a great lord, he gets an answer from them. Commodore Perry announces that he must meet the Shogun within six days or else he will shell the city. With the Shogun dead, Kayama devises a plan by which the Americans, thanks to a covering of tatami mats and a raised Treaty House, can be received without having, technically, to set foot on Japanese soil. The two men pass a Madam instructing her inexperienced Girls in the art of seduction as they prepare to "Welcome to Kanagawa" the foreign devils. The negotiations themselves are seen through the memory of three who were there: a warrior who could hear the debates but not see it from his hiding place in the floor of the house, a young boy recalling that without "Someone In a Tree", a silent watcher, history may have been incomplete. The child emperor (portrayed by a puppet manipulated by his advisors) reacts with pleasure to the departure of the Americans. He promotes Lord Abe to Shogun and Kayama to Governor of Uraga and Man Jiro to the rank of Samurai. The crisis appears to have passed, but to the surprise of Lord Abe the Americans return to request formal trading arrangements. To the tune of a Sousa march, they bid Japan "Please Hello" and are followed by a Gilbert and Sullivan-style British Admiral, a clog-dancing Dutch Admiral and a gloomy Russian. They send a politically charged gift to the Emperor, who tells a vivid, allegorical tale of a brave young emperor who frees himself from his cowardly Shogun. But there are other changes prompted by the westernization by British Sailors, a Bowler and "A Bowler Hatler" Three years later, the Emperor frees the young emperor and adopts the manners and dress of the newcomers, proudly displaying his new watch, cutaway coat and bowler hat. He returns home to find her dead from seppuku. But it is too late to save Tamate, his wife, since it will result in certain failure and shame. She expresses her feelings in dance as two Observers describe the scene.

name: Romeo and Juliet
summary: The play, set in Verona, begins with a street brawl between Montague and Capulet supporters who are sworn enemies. Later, Count Paris talks to Capulet about marrying his daughter, but Capulet asks Paris to wait another two years. Lady Capulet and Juliet's nurse try to persuade Juliet to accept Paris's courtship. Meanwhile, Benvolio talks with his cousin Romeo, Montague's son, about Romeo's recent depression. BenVolio discovers that it stems from unrequited infatuation for a girl named Rosaline, one of Capulet's nieces. Persuaded, Romeo attends the ball at the Capulet house in hopes of meeting Rosaline. However, Romeo instead meets and falls in love with Juliet. They are secretly married the next day. Romeo secretly spends the night in Juliet's chamber, where they consummate their marriage. Capulet, misinterpreting Juliet's grief, agrees to marry her to Count Paris and threatens to disown her when she refuses to become Paris's "joyful bride" On the night before the wedding, she takes the drug and, when discovered apparently dead, she is laid in the family crypt. The feuding families and the Prince meet at the tomb to find all three dead. The families are reconciled by their children's deaths and agree to end their violent feud. The play ends with the Prince's elegy for the lovers: "For never was a story of more woe / Than this of Juliet and her Romeo." The Prince, now having lost a kinsman in the warring families' feud, exiles Romeo from Verona,. with threat of execution upon return. Grief-stricken and wracked with guilt, Romeo confronts and slays Tybalt. He then buys poison from an apothecary and goes to the Capulets' crypt. He encounters Paris who has come to mourn Juliet privately. Believing Romeo to be a vandal, Paris confronts him and, in the ensuing battle, Romeo kills Paris. Still believing Juliet to be dead, he drinks the poison. Juliet then awakens and, finding Romeo dead, stabs herself with his dagger. The Prince and the families of the feuding Families and the King of Verona meet to discuss how to reconcile the families and end the violent feud, and to find the families reconciled. The King and the Queen meet to talk about how to end the feud and how to reunite the families.

name: Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead
summary: The play opens with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern betting on coin flips. The reader learns why they are where they are: the King has sent for them. A troupe of Tragedians arrives and offers the two men a show. The next two scenes are from the plot of Hamlet. The play moves beyond the scope of what the reader sees in Hamlet; characters resembling the pair are seen taking a sea voyage and meeting their deaths at the hands of English courtiers, foreshadowing their true fate. The Player returns to the stage. He is angry that the pair had not earlier stayed to watch their play. He tells them to stop questioning their existence because, upon examination, life appears too chaotic to comprehend. The Act closes with another scene from Hamlet in which they finally meet the Prince face to face. The Players is led to believe that the audience has no knowledge of how the pair got there. The stage becomes black and presumably the characters go to sleep, presumably to go to Hamlet to be killed, and presumably to sleep themselves. The Game is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £12.99, with a run-price of £16.99. It is available in hardback and hardback, and is available on Kindle for £9.99 with a download of the book for £8.99 (with a free Kindle download). The Player is released on September 1, 2014. The player is released by Simon and Schuster on September 2, 2014, and can be pre-ordered for £10.99 ($15.99) with a free download of The Player’s Book of the Month. The Book of The Month is also available on Amazon.com for £7.99 (£10.50) and on iTunes for £11.99 (~£13.99). The Game has been published on September 3, 2014 and is released in hardcover for £12 ($15). The book is available to download on the Kindle for (£10) and the iPad for (£12.50). It is published on the 14th September 2014 and the release date is September 14, 2014 (the day after the opening of the London Shakespeare Festival). The Players are released on the 15th September 2013. The book has been released on Blu-ray and DVD for £14 ($16.50, £14.99), and on the 16th September 2015 (the release date for the UK release is September 16, 2014).

name: Ringworld
summary: The novel opens in 2850. Louis Gridley Wu is celebrating his 200th birthday. He is offered one of three open positions on an exploration voyage beyond Known Space. Two other explorers, Speaker-to-Animals and Teela Brown, also join the voyage. The expedition's goal is to explore a ringworld: an artificial ring about one million miles wide and approximately the diameter of Earth's orbit. None of the crew's attempts at contacting the Ringworld succeed, and their ship is disabled by its automated meteor defense system. The ship's defences keep the crew compartment and many of the ship's systems intact, including the faster-than-light drive (hyperdrive) But the normal drive is destroyed, leaving them unable to launch back into space to use the hyperdrive. The team now has to find a way to get back to space, as well as fulfilling their original mission – learning more about the Ring world. They encounter apparently human Ringworld natives. The natives think that the crew are the Engineers of the Ring, whom they revere as gods. The crew is attacked when they commit a "blasphemy". They continue their journey during which Nessus is forced to reveal some Puppeteer secrets: they have performed indirect "breeding experiments" on both humans (breeding for luck) and kzin (breedingfor less aggressiveness) The resulting hostility forces Nessus to abandon the other three and follow them at a safe distance. The four explorers, with Seeker and Prill, use the floating police station as a vehicle to travel to the explorers' crashed ship. Along the way, Teela and Seeker choose to remain behind and remain on Ringworld. The remaining explorers and the remaining explorers collect one end of the shadow square wire that was dislodged when the ship crashed, dragging the wire behind them as they travel. Reaching the wreck, Louis uses the shadow wire to tether the ship to the police station and then continues to pull the wire up to the summit of the enormous mountain near their crash site. The mountain does not appear on the original map of the original Ringworld, leading Louis to conclude that it is in fact in the fact of a meteor impact with the underside of the ring floor, which pushed it up from the ground. The explorers then use the wire to pull up the mountain, leading them to the "Fist-of-God" site near the crash site, which is the enormous "mountain" of theRingworld.

name: Rent
summary: On Christmas Eve at 9 P.M. Mark Cohen, an aspiring filmmaker, begins a new documentary, as his roommate, Roger Davis, tunes up his guitar. Roger and Mark's friend Tom Collins, a gay anarchist and college professor, arrives at their building but is mugged. Meanwhile, a drag queen named Angel Dumott Schunard finds Collins on the street and gets him on his feet. The second act takes place over the course of the year following the first act ("Seasons of Love") Having been locked out of their apartment by Benny; Mark, Roger, and the Bohemians gather to break-in through the nightly news. The others finally break through the door just as Benny arrives to call a truce and say he's there to call there to a truce. He reveals that Mimi, a former girlfriend of his, convinced him to change his mind by making sexual advances on him. He then reveals that amidst the riot, Roger and Mimi share their first kiss ("La Vie Boheme B"). He then turns to the drug dealer for a fix for a fight, but Mimi remains upset and turns to him for help with her boyfriend's new girlfriend, a lawyer and Maureen's new boyfriend, Joanne Jefferson. The film ends with the revelation that they had once been together but the revelation of Roger's HIV-positive status leaves both of them upset and giving each other ultimatiums to end their relationship. It was released on December 25, 2013. It is available on Blu-ray and DVD. The Blu-Ray and DVD versions of the film are available on Amazon.com, iTunes, and Google Play. The DVD version of the movie is also available on Google Play, and on the iTunes Store. It has been released on DVD and the PC version of this article will be available on the PC and the Mac and Mac versions of this issue of the book, as well as the PC edition of the issue of The New York Review of Books. It will also be released on the 29th December 2013. The book will be published on the 31st December 2013, on the same day as the film. The movie will be released in the UK on the 30th September 2013, at the same time as the UK release of "The Book of Life" by Simon & Schuster. The UK release will be on September 29, 2013, in the U.S. and the UK the next day, on September 30, 2014. The U.K. release the film on the 28th September 2014, at 9 p.m.

name: Rendezvous with Rama
summary: "Rama" is an alien star ship, initially mistaken for an asteroid categorised as "31/439" It is detected by astronomers in the year 2130 while still outside the orbit of Jupiter. A manned solar survey vessel Endeavour is sent to study Rama, as it is the only ship close enough to do so in the brief period Rama will spend in our solar system. The 20+ crew, led by Commander Bill Norton, enters Rama through triple airlocks, and explores the vast 16-km wide by 50-km long cylindrical world of its interior. The nature and purpose of the starship and its creators remains enigmatic throughout the book. The astronauts discover several features, including "cities" (odd blocky shapes that look like buildings) that actually served as factories, a sea that stretches in a band around Rama dubbed the Cylindrical Sea, and seven massive cones at the southern end of Rama - believed to form part of the propulsion system. When the crew arrive at their base, they see a variety of odd creatures inspecting their camp. When one is found damaged and apparently lifeless, the team's doctor inspects it and names it "biot" or a hybrid of a biological entity and robot. The Hermian colonists have concluded that Rama is a potential threat to them and send a rocket-mounted bomb to destroy it. It is successfully defused by the United Planets Committee and both the Planets, based on both the Earth and the moon, have been monitoring events inside Rama and giving feedback to the team on the events inside the starship. The members of the Rama Committee are believed to be servants of the ship's builders and still maintainers of the spaceship. The crew of the U.S. government set up the Spaceguard system as an early warning of arrivals from deep space in 2077. The government of Earth sets up the spaceguard system in response to a major disaster caused by a meteorite falling in Eastern Italy in 2076. The book is set in the years 2130 and 2077, and follows the events of the first encounter with an alien space ship, Rama. It was published by Simon & Schuster in 1998 and is available in hardback, paperback, and e-book. It has been described as a sci-fi/fantasy novel with an emphasis on the themes of space travel and alien life. The novel is expected to be released in October 2014.

name: Sense and Sensibility
summary: When Mr. Dashwood dies, his estate, Norland Park, passes directly to his only son John, the child of his first wife. John and Fanny immediately take up their place as the new owners of Norland, while the Dashwood women are reduced to the position of unwelcome guests. In the meantime, Fanny's brother, Edward Ferrars, visits Norland and soon forms an attachment with Elinor. Marianne, out for a walk, gets caught in the rain, slips and sprains her ankle. The dashing, handsome John Willoughby sees the accident and assists her. Soon Marianne receives a curt letter enclosing their former correspondence and love tokens, including a lock of her hair and informing her of his engagement to a young lady of large fortune. The Dashwoods move their family to Barton Cottage in Devonshire, near the home of her cousin, Sir John Middleton. Their new home lacks many of the conveniences that they have been used to, however they are warmly received by Sir John, and welcomed into the local society, meeting his wife, Lady Middleton, his mother-in-law, Mrs Jennings and his friend, the grave, quiet and gentlemanly Colonel Brandon. It soon becomes apparent that Colonel Brandon is attracted to Marianne and Mrs Jennings teases them about it. Unexpectedly one day, Mr. Willougby informs the Dashwoods that his aunt is sending him to London on business, indefinitely. Mariann is distraught and abandons herself to her sorrow. As a result the Miss Steele sisters, Anne and Lucy, come to stay at Barton Park. Lucy informs Elin or of her secret four year engagement to Edward Ferrar. In sympathy for Marianne's misery, Colonel Brandon reveals to ElinOr that Mr Willough by seduced Brandon's fifteen-year-old ward, and abandoned her when she became pregnant. Lucy sees her invitation as a personal compliment, rather than what it is, and betrays the false confidence of the sisters. Edward is entreated to break the engagement on pain of disinitance, but refuses to comply and is immediately disinherited in favour of his brother, gaining widespread sympathy for his gentlemanly conduct, and sympathy from El inor and Marianne who understand how much he has sacrificed over the years. In meantime, the sisters have come to London as guests of the DashWoods, the Londoners, the Dash Woods' half-sisters.

name: Speaker for the Dead
summary: On Novinha's request for a Speaker, Andrew Wiggin leaves for Lusitania, a colony turned into a virtual prison. The colony is devoted to the work of xenologers who study the Pequeninos, the first sentient beings found since the destruction of Formics. Ender decides to leave his sister Valentine behind (she is married and pregnant) after traveling with her for many years. Ender also takes responsibility for attempting to heal the Ribeira family, and manages to adopt (or perhaps is adopted by) most of the children within their first meeting. He also takes a strong interest in the pequenino, and eventually (in direct violation of Starways Congress law) meets with them in person. The Hive Queen has also managed to make contact with the peqeninos and has told them a number of things—including that the original Speaker for the Dead is not only the original Xenocide as well, but also romantically involved with Miro. Both Zenadors (a shortened form of the word Xenocide) do not believe that the Hive Queen very emphatically wants to be revived and freed, and do not want to be called "Zenadors" The colony's charter is revoked and all humans are ordered to take twenty-two years to travel to the nearest world for a trial that would take place on that world (a journey that would also take 20 years to take place in the real world). The trial takes place on the world called Starways, which is on the planet of Ouanda, which has been deliberately introducing new technology into the piggy lifestyle. The trial is held on Starways and Miro and Ouanda are the only ones who are allowed to take part in it, and they do so in secret, in violation of the Starways congress' rules. This is the first time that the colony has been open to non-humans, and it is the only time that humans have been allowed to leave the colony for any length of time at all. It is also the last time the colony will be open to humans for any period of time, as the colony is closed off to all non-piggies except those who have been trained to be xenologists by the hive queen. The book ends on a cliffhanging cliffhanger, with the last words of the original "Xenocide" being read by Miro, who is now a member of the colony, and the first words of "Starways" read by Ender.

name: Starship Troopers
summary: Starship Troopers is one of only a few Heinlein novels set out in this fashion. It is narrated as a series of flashbacks by Juan Rico, a cap(sule) trooper in the Terran Federation's Mobile Infantry. The novel opens with Rico aboard the corvette Rodger Young, serving with the platoon known as "Rasczak's Roughnecks" Interspersed throughout the book are flashbacks to Rico's high school History and Moral Philosophy course, which describe how the rights of a full Citizen (to vote, and hold public office) must be earned through some form of volunteer Federal service. Some see Dubois as speaking for Heinlein throughout the novel; he delivers what is probably the book's most famous soliloquy on violence, it "... has settled more issues in history than has any other factor." Fleet Sergeant Ho's monologues examine the nature of military service, and his anti-military tirades seem primarily to be a contrast with Dubois. At some point during Rico's training, the "Bug War" has changed from border incidents to formal war, and Rico finds himself taking part in combat operations. The war "officially" starts with an Arachnid attack that annihilates the city of Buenos Aires (which kills Rico's mother who was visiting). Rico briefly describes the Terran. Federation's loss at the Battle of Klendathu, during which his ship is decimated and his unit is destroyed. This part of the book focuses on the relationship between non-missioned officers and non-comed officers, as well as the relationship in the book between Rico and his commanding officer, Sgt. Charles Zim. The book is chronologically placed between chapters 10 and 11, which would be placed between the beginning of the novel (which would be chronologically between chapters 11 and 11) and the end of chapter 11. It has been described as one of the best sci-fi novels of the 20th century, along with "The Matrix" and "The Lord of the Rings" The novel was written in the wake of the collapse of the "20th century Western democracies", brought on by both social failures at home (among which appear to be poor handling of juvenile delinquency) and military defeat by the Chinese Hegemony overseas. The story then flashes back to Puerto Rico's graduation from high school and his decision to sign up for Federal Service over the objections of his father, who disowns him. We learn, later, that his rants are part of a policy intended to scare off applicants signing up without conviction. Five chapters are spent exploring Rico's experience at Camp Arthur Currie.

name: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
summary: Sir Gawain, youngest of Arthur's knights and his nephew, begs for the honour instead. The giant bends and bares his neck before him and Gawain neatly beheads him in one stroke. However the Green Knight neither falls nor falters but reaches out, picks up his severed head and remounts, holding up his bleeding head to Queen Guinevere while its writhing lips remind Gawain that the two must meet again at the Green Chapel before he rides away. Many adventures and battles are alluded to (but not described) until Gawain comes across a splendid castle where he meets Bertilak de Hautdesert, the lord of the castle. He explains that the entire adventure was a trick of the 'elderly lady' Gawain saw at the castle who is the sorceress Morgan Fay, who intended to test Arthur's sisters and terrify Guinesevere. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, with a p&p of £12.99. To order a copy of the book for £11.99 call the MailOnline Bookshop on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local branch, see www.mailonline.co.uk/bookshop/gawain-and-the-girdle-of-gold-grievances-by-Gawain, or go to www.bookshop.com/g Gawain and the Girdle of Gold by Gawain. To buy the girdle, go to http://www.bookstore.co/gwain and shop/Gwain- and the-Girdle of Gold by G Gawain is now free to roam the world for the rest of his life. To purchase the girdsle, you must go to a local shop and buy it for £1.50, or you can buy it online for £2.50. To get it by mail, you can go to the nearest post office, post office or post office on the same day as the bookshop, or buy it by the post office in the UK for £3.00, or online in the US for £4.00. to £5.00 (including p&P). To buy it in the U.S., you must buy it at the Post Office, post Office, Post Office or Post Office. To pick it up in the USA, call 1-800-273-8255 or visit www.postoffice.com.

name: Stuart Little
summary: The story is episodic. First we learn of Stuart's birth to a family in New York City. He has an adventure in which he gets caught in a window-blind while exercising. A bird named Margalo is adopted by the Little family, and Stuart protects her from their malevolent cat. As the book ends, he has not yet found Margalo, but feels confident he will do so. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at $16.99. It is published in hardback, with a cover price of $12.99, and in paperback, $14.95. It has been published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster, Inc., with a copyright date of September 14, 1998. It was published in paperback by Simon&Schuster, Ltd. and in hardcover, $16, and it has a hardback cover of $14, plus a Kindle edition of the same price. The Kindle version of the book comes with a free download of the audiobook version of "Stuart and Margalo" (Simon & Schulder, 1998). For more information on the book, go to www.simonandschulder.com/stuart-and-margalo. For more on the author's other books, visit www.Simon&Schulder-Inc. and www.samaritans.org/Stuart-And-Margalo-The-Book-A-Boat-Writer-Biography-by-Barry-Bryan-Brockhoff. For other books by Bryan Brockhoff, visit http://www.bryan Brockhoff.com/. For more about the author and his family, visit the B&B Bookshop. For additional information about the book and its author, visit www.samarbackhoff.co.uk.  The book's publisher, Bantam Books, has a website at www.barrackbookshop.com.  For more details about the story, visit barrackbooks.com or www.thebarragebookshop, Inc. The author is married to a woman named Harriet Ames, who is no taller than he is. She is a substitute teacher in Ames Crossing, where he meets a girl named Harriet. They go on one date, and then Stuart leaves town. Stuart departs to see the country. A friendly dentist, also the owner of the boat Stuart had raced in Central Park, gives him use of a gasoline-powered model car. He works for a while as a substitute teachers and comes to the town of Ames Crossing.

name: The Lord of the Rings
summary: Long before the events of the novel, the Dark Lord Sauron forges the One Ring to dominate the other Rings of Power and corrupt those who wear them. Over two thousand years later, the Ring is found by a river-dwelling hobbit called Déagol. The Ring extends his lifespan and transforms him over the course of hundreds of years into a twisted, corrupted creature called Gollum. He loses the Ring, his "precious", and, as recounted in The Hobbit, Bilbo Baggins finds it. Meanwhile, Sauron reassumes physical form and takes back his old realm of Mordor. The Council of Elrond reveals much significant history about Sauron and the Ring. They decide to destroy the Ring by returning it to the flames of Mount Doom in Mordor, where it was forged. Frodo volunteers to take on this daunting task, and a "Fellowship of the Ring" is formed to aid him: Sam, Merry, Pippin, Aragorn, Gimli the Dwarf, Legolas the Elf, and the Man Boromir, son of the Ruling Steward Denethor of the realm of Gondor. They travel down the River Anduin to the hill of Amon Hen, where they are attacked by the Watcher in the Water before the gate. After repulsing an attack, they are pursued by orcs and Balrogves, but in their struggle, both fall into a deep chasm. The others escape and take refuge in the Elven forest of Lórien, where the others are counselled by Galadriel and Celeadriel. Meanwhile,. Frodo escapes and determines to continue the quest alone, though Sam guesses his intent and kills him. After agonizing over which gifts to take, Frodo succumbs to the lure and attempts to take the Ring from him, which agonizingly agonizes him over. He eventually takes the Ring and flees to Rivendell, where he is taken in by Gandalf the Grey and his company of Dwarves, and realizes the fate of Balin and his powerful company of dwarves. After a failed attempt to cross the Misty Mountains via the pass below Caradhras, the company are forced to try a more perilous path through the Mines of Moria. Once inside, they discover the fate, and realize the powerful struggle, and they are chased by an ancient, powerful, and powerful force called the Nazgûl.

name: The Doors of Perception
summary: Huxley was given 4/10 of a gram of mescaline at 11:00 am one day in May 1953. He writes that he hoped to gain insight into extraordinary states of mind. The experience, he asserts, is neither agreeable nor disagreeable, but simply 'is' He likens it to Meister Eckhart’s ‘istigheit’ or ‘is-ness’, and Plato's ‘Being’ but not separated from ‘Becoming’ He feels he understands the Hindu concept of Satchitananda, as well as the Zen koan that ‘the dharma body of the Buddha is in the hedge’ and Buddhist suchness. Huxley speculates that schizophrenia is the inability to escape from this reality into the world of common sense and thus help would be essential. He concludes that the experience represents contemplation at its height, but not its fullness. The book is characterized by the urge to transcend one's self through times and cultures. He reasons that better, healthier, ‘doors’ are needed in cultures than alcohol and tobacco. Mescaline has the advantage of not provoking violence in takers, but its effects last an inconveniently long time and some negative reactions can be found in religion, but it is unlikely that this will ever happen. The final insight is taken from Buddhist scripture: that within sameness there is difference, although that difference is not different from sameness. He finishes with his final reflections on the meaning of his experience. He feels that human affairs are somewhat irrelevant whilst on mescalin. He attempts to shed light on this by reflecting on paintings featuring people. Cézanne's Self portrait with a straw hat seems to him as incredibly pretentious, while Vermeer's human still lives (also, the Le Nain Brothers and Vuillard) are the nearest to reflecting this not-self state. He reflects that spiritual literature, including the works of Jacob Boehme, William Law and the Tibetan Book of the Dead, talk of these pains and terrors. After lunch and the drive to the WBDS he returns home and to his ordinary state of mind and returns home to his normal life. In summary, the ability to think straight is not reduced while under the influence of meshaline, visual impressions are intensified, and the human experimenter will see no reason for action because the experience is so fascinating. He mentions that four or five hours into the experience he was taken to the World's Biggest Drug Store (WBDS) where he was presented with books on art. In one book, the dress in Botticelli's Judith provokes a reflection on drapery.

name: The Time Machine
summary: The book's protagonist is an English scientist and gentleman inventor living in Richmond, Surrey, identified by a narrator simply as the Time Traveller. The narrator recounts the Traveller's lecture to his weekly dinner guests that time is simply a fourth dimension, and his demonstration of a tabletop model machine for travelling through it. He reveals that he has built a machine capable of carrying a person, and returns at dinner the following week to recount a remarkable tale, becoming the new narrator. In the new narrative, he tests his device with a journey that takes him to 802,701 A.D., where he meets the Eloi, a society of small, elegant, childlike adults. They live in small communities within large and futuristic yet slowly deteriorating buildings, doing no work and having a frugivorous diet. Later in the dark, he is approached menacingly by the Morlocks, ape-like troglodytes who live in darkness underground and surface only at night. He travels further ahead to roughly 30 million years from his own time. There he sees some of the last living things on a dying Earth, menacing reddish crab-like creatures slowly wandering the blood-red beaches chasing butterflies in a world covered in simple lichenous vegetation. He continues to make short jumps through time, seeing Earth's rotation gradually cease and the sun grow larger, redder, and dimmer, and the world falling silent and freezing as the last degenerate living things die out. Overwhelmed, he returns to his laboratory, arriving just three hours after he originally left. The original narrator takes over and that he returned the next day, finding him in final preparations for a journey. Three years later, the narrator promises to return, but three years later the narrator despairs of ever learning what became of him. The time machine is found missing, and he eventually works out that it has been dragged by some unknown party into a nearby structure with heavy doors, locked from the inside, which resembles a Sphinx. The Morlocks use the time machine as bait to ensnare the traveller, not understanding that he will use it to escape. He takes Weena with him on an expedition to a distant structure that turns out to be the remains of a museum, where he finds a fresh supply of matches and fashions a crude weapon against Morlocks. He saves Weena from drowning as none of the other Eloi take any notice of her plight, and they develop an innocently affectionate relationship over the course of several days.

name: The Shockwave Rider
summary: The novel is set in the weeks following Nick's recapture after several years on the run. It alternating between moral arguments with his interrogator, who is trying to discover why the program's star pupil had absconded. The 21st-century lifestyle produces a symptom called "overload" in many people, and most, including Nick, take tranquilizers to some degree. Nick returns to Kate and confesses that he is not what he seems, asking for her help. She conducts him to one of the "paid avoidance areas" in California, where people are paid to do without the full panoply of modern technology. After Nick risks exposure yet again in one of these places, they move to the least known one, a town called Precipice. The inhabitants include intelligent dogs that escaped from the projects that Kate's father worked on. The town is also the home of "Hearing Aid", an anonymous telephone confession service accessible to anyone in the country. People call the service and simply talk. Some rant, others seek sympathy, still others commit suicide while on the phone. The only response Hearing Aid gives to a caller is "Only I heard that, I hope it helped." Nick and Kate settle into the community. He hits her, and then fills her with remorse, when she reveals his location to the authorities. At the end of the novel, Nick responds to the leader of Tarnover by attempting to warn him of the gangs and cripples him in front of a nationwide audience. He responds by saying "Roman circus" to an audience of "all comers" which live and fight to an "all-comers" challenge to the country, which he responds to by calling them "Roman clowns" The novel is also known as the "Ten Nines" after the phone number used to call it: 999-999-9999. The nearest comparison to the novel would be an agrarian, cottage industry community designed by William Morris. It was published by Simon & Schuster on September 14, 2013. The book is available in hardback and e-book versions for £16.99 (with a suggested reading price of £18.99). It is also available in paperback for £20 (with an MS-DOS version of the book for £14.99, with a Kindle version of £12.99 for £13.99. It is published in the UK by Simon and Schuster, and in the U.S. by Macmillan.

name: The Shining
summary: In 1976, Jack Torrance is an aspiring writer who is attempting to rebuild his marriage and career, both of which have been nearly ruined by two traits inherited from his late father: alcoholism and an explosive temper. Jack eagerly accepts a job as a winter caretaker at the Overlook Hotel, an isolated resort in the Colorado Rockies. Jack hopes that the seclusion will help him reconnect with his family and give him inspiration and the peace and quiet to help him write a new play. Jack becomes susceptible to cabin fever, and the sinister ghosts of the hotel gradually begin to overtake him, making him increasingly unstable. One day, after a fight with Wendy, Jack finds the hotel's bar fully stocked with alcohol despite being previously empty. As he gets drunk, the hotel urges Jack to kill his wife and son. Danny can no longer recognize him as his father, so the unstable Jack no longer recognizes him. The novel ends with Danny and Wendy and Danny's summering at a summer resort in Maine where the Torrances are able to get back to their normal lives. In the end, Jack and Wendy reunite in the lobby, and they flee the Over Look with the ghost of Delbert Grady, a former caretaker who murdered their family and then committed suicide, releasing him. In response, Jack tells the boiler that the boiler is going to explode, destroying the building's spirit and making him and Wendy bring it off and make him kill Danny and the chef, Dick Hallorann, but he shakes them off and brings them to safety. The book was published by Simon & Schuster on September 14, 2008. The first edition of the book was released on October 1, 2008, with a special edition of $20.00. The second edition is $25.00, with an additional $10.00 for shipping and handling. The third edition will be released on November 1, 2009, and will be available for pre-order on November 14, 2009. The fourth edition will also be available on November 21, 2009 for $20, $25, $50, $60, $75, and $100, respectively. The fifth and sixth editions will be published on November 22, 2009 and November 23, 2010, for $30, $40, $55, $70, $80, $85, $90, $100 and $150, respectively, in the U.S. and Canada. The sixth and seventh editions are published in the United States on November 28, 2010 and November 29, 2010.

name: Mort
summary: As a teenager, Mort had a personality and temperament that made him rather unsuited to the family farming business. Mort's father, named Lezek, felt that Mort thought too much, which prevented him from achieving anything practical. Lezek took him to a local hiring fair, hoping that Mort would land an apprenticeship with some tradesman. At the job fair, Mort at first has no luck attracting the interest of an employer. Then, just before the stroke of midnight, a man concealed in a black cloak arrives on a white horse. He says he is looking for a young man to assist him in his work and selects Mort for the job. The man turns out to be Death, and Mort is given an apprenticeships in ushering souls into the next world (though his father thinks he's been apprenticed to an undertaker). When it is a princess' time to die, Mort, instead of ushering her soul, saves her from death, dramatically altering a part of the Discworld's reality. However, the princess, for whom Mort has a developing infatuation, does not have long to live, and he must try to save her, once again, from a seemingly unstoppable death. Both the princess and Mort end up consulting the local wizard, Igneous Cutwell, for various methods of assistance with the crisis. Conclusively, Mort must duel Death for Mort's freedom. Though Death wins the duel, he spares Mort's life and sends him back to the Disc. The princess is saved from a second death when the alternate reality Mort created is reduced to a pearl-like state. This pearl is given to Mort for safe-keeping. AtThe end of the novel, Mort marries Ysabell, Death's adopted daughter. As Mort begins to do most of Death's "Duty", he loses some of his former character traits, and essentially starts to become more like Death himself. Death, in turn, yearns to relish what being human is truly like and travels to Ankh-Morpork to indulge in new experiences and attempt to feel real human emotion. This is where Death meets Mort and marries him, and the two are together for a time. The pearl is then given to the princess for safe keeping, and is kept by the princess as a keepsake for Mort to keep her safe from another death in the future. Mort is sent back to his home world, and Death is sent to his own world.

name: The Hound of the Baskervilles
summary: Sir Charles Baskerville is found dead on the grounds of his country house. His nephew and only known heir, Sir Henry, is coming from America to claim his inheritance. Dr James Mortimer travels to London and asks Sherlock Holmes for help. Mortimer explains he had seen the footprints of a "gigantic hound" near Sir Charles's body, something not revealed at the inquest. Sir Henry is puzzled by an anonymous note delivered to his London hotel room, warning him to avoid the Devon moors. Holmes and Doctor Watson accompany Sir Henry to Baskingerville Hall and report back by telegram in detail. The baronet is excited to see it and his connection with the land is clear. Soldiers are on the lookout for an murderer named Selden Barrymore and his wife, who is only one of two women in the house. The next morning, Watson sees Mrs Barrymore in the morning and hears a woman crying that it was his wife. But it is later clear that it is only a woman who escaped, and the Hall is in a general, somber place as soon as she leaves. Holmes is the actual murderer, much to the amusement and amusement of Sir Henry and Sir Watson, and Sir Henry set off for the actual baronet's home the following Saturday. The final episode of Holmes and Watson: The Case of the Missing Boot is on BBC1 at 9pm on Saturday, November 14. For more information on the case, visit the BBC website or click here for the film's trailer. The film is based on the novel by Arthur Conan Doyle and is published by Hodder & Stoughton at a cost of around £25,000 (including p&p) and £3,000 in hard-to-buy copies of the book, which is available in hardback and hardback only. The movie is also available on DVD and Blu-ray, with an audio version of the film available on the BBC iPlayer for £16.99 (and £10.99 in paperback). For more details on the film, visit www.holmesandwatson.co.uk or watch the film trailer on BBC2 at 8pm on Friday, November 13. For the full film, click here. For a copy of the movie, visit BBC2.com or the website of the same name, but with a different name, and a link to the DVD version of this article is available at www.bbc.com/ Sherlock Holmes and Company.

name: The Hobbit
summary: Gandalf tricks Bilbo into hosting a party for Thorin and his band of dwarves, who sing of reclaiming the Lonely Mountain and its vast treasure from the dragon Smaug. When the music ends, Gandalf unveils a map showing a secret door into the Mountain and proposes that the dumbfounded Bilbo serve as the expedition's "burglar" The dwarves ridicule the idea, but Bilbo, indignant, joins despite himself. The group travel into the wild, where Gandalf saves the company from trolls and leads them to Rivendell, where Elrond reveals more secrets from the map. Passing over the Misty Mountains, they are caught by goblins and driven deep underground. Although Gandalf rescues them, Bilbo gets separated from the others as they flee the goblins. Lost in the goblin tunnels, he stumbles across a mysterious ring and then encounters Gollum, who engages him in a game of riddles. As a reward for solving all riddles Gollums will show him the path out of the tunnels, but if Bilbo fails, his life will be forfeit. With the help of the ring, which confers invisibility,. Bilbo escapes and rejoins the dwarves, improving his reputation with them. The goblins and Wargs give chase but the company are saved by eagles before resting in the house of Beorn. The company enters the black forest of Mirkwood without Gandalf. The dwarves, men, and elves band together, but only with the timely arrival of the eagles and Beorn do they win the climactic Battle of Five Armies. Thorin is fatally wounded and reconciles with Bilbo before he dies. Bilbo accepts only a small portion of his share of the treasure, having no want or need for more, but still returns home a very wealthy hobbit. The film was released in UK cinemas on November 14, 2009. The UK release date was November 15, 2009, and the US release date is November 16, 2010, but the UK release dates have yet to be announced. The U.S. release date for the film is November 21, 2011, but it will not be released in the UK until November 13, 2012. The US release dates for the UK version are November 23, 2012, and November 24, 2013, but no release date has yet been announced for the U.K. release of the film in the United States or Canada. For more information on how to watch the film, visit the official website.

name: The Great Divorce
summary: The book is about a man who finds himself in a grim and joyless city, the "grey town", which is either hell or purgatory depending on how long one stays there. He eventually finds a bus for those who desire an excursion to some other place (and which eventually turns out to be the foothills of heaven) The passengers on the bus are gradually revealed to be ghosts. Shining figures, men and women whom they have known on earth, come to meet them, and to urge them to repent and enter heaven proper. Almost all of the ghosts choose to return instead to the grey town, giving various reasons and excuses. The use of chess imagery as well as the correspondence of dream elements to elements in the narrator's waking life is reminiscent of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass. The book ends with the narrator awakening from his dream of heaven into the unpleasant reality of wartime Britain. In conscious imitation of The Pilgrim's Progress, the last sentence of the "First Part" of which is: "So I awoke, and it was a Dream" is the last line of the book's first chapter, which is titled "I behold behold a Dream." The book was written by George MacDonald, a friend of Lewis, and is published by Chatto & Windus, a division of Penguin Books, on September 25, 2009. The novel is published in hardback and e-book, with a cover price of £16.99. It is available in paperback and hardback, with the option of a Kindle edition for £12.99 (with a Kindle download of £8.99). The book is available for pre-order on Amazon.com and other online retailers such as Macmillan, which also publishes the book in hard-back, paperback, and hard-bound editions of £14.99 and £15 (with the Kindle version of £15). For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, see www.samaritans.org for details. In the U.S. call the National Suicide Prevention Line on 1-800-273-8255 or click here for details on how to contact the National suicide Prevention Lifeline (in the UK, call the helpline on 0800 555 111 or visit http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org.uk/. For confidential help in the UK call 08457 909090 or visit the Samaritans on the Internet.

name: The Screwtape Letters
summary: The Screwtape Letters is a 1941 novel by C.S. Lewis. It is a series of letters from the demon Screwtapes to Wormwood, the tempter in Hell. Lewis also wrote the sequel Screwtaped Proposes a Toast in 1959. Both books have been released on audio cassette and CD with narration by John Cleese and Joss Ackland. A dramatized audio version by Focus on the Family was a 2010 Audie Award finalist. The book is one of Lewis' most popular works, although he claimed that it was "not fun" to write, and "resolved never to write another 'Letter'"Screwtape" is a term used to refer to the demon who advises Wormwood on ways to undermine faith and promote sin in the Patient. The letters were originally published weekly in the Anglican periodical The Guardian between May and November 1941, and the standard edition contains an introduction explaining how the author chose to write his story. An omnibus edition with a new preface by Lewis was published by Bles in 1961 and MacMillan in 1962, and a sequel was published in 1959, with a preface written by Lewis in the first edition of the omnibus. The sequel was a critique of certain trends in public education (state schooling) and has been released in audio cassettes and CD, with narration from Cleese, Ackland, and Bles. It was a dramatization of the book by Focus On The Family in 2010, and was a finalist for the Audie award for best dramatizations of children's books and young people's literature. It has also been made into a film, starring Tom Hanks and John Cusack, which was released in 2012. The film is based on Lewis' novel The Screwtaping of Wormwood and the Patient, which is released in October 2013. The movie is directed by Tim Burton, who also directed the film version of the ScrewtAPE Letters, directed by Ridley Scott, and starring David Walliams and Kate Winslet, among other actors. It will be released in cinemas on October 25, 2014. The novel is available in hardback, paperback, and audiobook versions, as well as on CD and DVD. The first edition was published on November 1, 1941, with an introduction by Lewis, who said he would never write another "Letter" in his life. The second edition was released on November 2, 1959, and has an introduction from Lewis, along with a copy of the original.

name: The Pit and the Pendulum
summary: The story takes place during the Spanish Inquisition. At the beginning of the story an unnamed narrator is brought to trial before various sinister judges. He is condemned to death and finds himself in a pitch black compartment. Before him are seven tall white candles on a table, and, as they melt, his hopes of survival diminish. He then sees a painted picture of Father Time on the ceiling; hanging from the figure is a gigantic scythe-like pendulum swinging slowly back and forth. The pendulum is inexorably sliding downwards and will eventually kill him. However the condemned man is able to attract rats to his bonds with meat left for him to eat and they start chewing through the ropes. As he gazes into the pit, he decides that no fate could be worse than falling into it. The French Army has taken Toledo and the Inquisition is in the hands of its enemies. It is implied by the text that the narrator fears what he sees at the bottom of the pit. The exact cause of his fear is not clearly stated. However, as the narrator moves back from the Pit, he sees that the red-hot walls are leaving him with no foothold. The walls rush back and an arm catches him. As the prisoner begins to fall into thepit, he hears human voices. The narrator then falls into the Pit and is saved by the arm of a man who has been waiting for him in the pit for some time. The story ends with the narrator being rescued by the man who had been waiting to rescue him from the pit and the two of them walking to the other side of the cell. The prisoner is then taken to a different cell and is reunited with his captor, who is also taken to the same cell where he had been held by the French Army. The two men are reunited and the narrator is taken back to his cell to continue his journey to the end of the book. The final chapter is set during the reign of King Charles I of Spain and is set in the year 1536. The last words of the narrator are: “I am going to die.” The narrator is then led to a cell that is slightly illuminated and that he is bound to a wooden board by ropes. After losing consciousness again the narrator discovers that the prison is slightly illumination and he is tied to a board by rope. He looks up in horror to see a painting of Father time on the ceilings and sees that it is swinging slowly towards him. The painting is drawn back to the ceiling and the prisoner breaks free of the ropes and watches as the pendulum reaches a point inches above his heart.

name: The Hunt for Red October
summary: Marko Alexandrovich Ramius is a Lithuanian submarine commander in the Soviet Navy. He intends to defect to the United States with his officers on board the experimental nuclear submarine Red October. Ramius kills the Red Octobers political officer to ensure that he will not interfere with the defection, and writes a letter to Admiral Yuri Padorin, Natalia's uncle, stating his intention to defect. The Soviet Northern Fleet sails out to sink the Red October under the pretext of a search and rescue mission. The U.S. Navy rescues her crew after Ramius fakes a shipboard emergency. The Red October safely docks in Norfolk, Virginia, where Ramius and his crew are taken to a CIA safehouse to begin their Americanization. Ryan is commended by his superiors and flies back to his posting in London, where he returns to his job as an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency in Langley, Virginia. He is responsible for shepherding Ramius, his officers and their vessel away from the pursuing Soviet fleet. In order to convince the Soviets that the RedOctober has been destroyed, the U.N. Security Council is asked to send in a team of experts to investigate Ramius' defection plans. The Soviets refuse, and the Americans escort the submarine safely into the dry-ten side of a broadside and dock it in Norfolk. In the end, the Soviets lose the battle and Ramius flees to safety. The submarine is sunk by a Soviet torpedo from the Alfa-class attack submarine, and after a tense standoff, Tupolev's submarine rams it from broadside to broadside, sinking it. The film ends with Ramius returning to his post in London to begin his Americanization, and Ryan flying back to London to return to his position as an Analyst for the CIA in Langly, Virginia,. The film was released on September 11, 1998. It is the first time that the film has been released in English, and it has been adapted for the big screen in a major Hollywood film, The Godfather: Part II, which opens on September 14, 1998, at 9 p.m. ET. The movie is directed by Robert Redford and stars Tom Hanks, John Cusack, Alec Guinness, Michael Douglas, and David Walliams. The novel is based on a true story, "The Red October," which was written by Mark O'Brien and published by The New York Review of Books.

name: The Cardinal of the Kremlin
summary: CIA analyst Jack Ryan attends a diplomatic conference in Moscow as part of an American delegation to the Soviet Union. He learns that the CIA’s most highly-placed agent, codenamed "CARDINAL", is none other than Colonel Mikhail Semyonovich Filitov. Ryan concocts a plan to both secure the return of Filtov and arrange the defection of the sitting KGB chairman, Nikolay Borissovich Gerasimov. Ryan schemes to go public with the prior capture of Soviet submarine Red October, banking on the political instability of the Soviet Politburo. In the end, the guerrillas destroy a large amount of Soviet equipment, including the death of The Archer. Ryan returns to the United States, where he and several others attend the funeral of Filitovo, who had died of heart disease in the months following his CIA debriefing period. Ryan, always working to keep the peace, explains to him, "One way or another, we all fight for what we believe in that gives us some common ground?" Doesn't we believe that in that common ground that we are all fighting for what gives us common ground? That's the question we're all trying to figure out, isn't it? The answer is yes, of course, because we all believe in common ground, and that's what we're trying to fight for. We're all just trying to find our way to the same place in the world that we all live in, and find our common ground in the same way. We all want to live in a world where we're not fighting each other for our lives, and we can live in peace with each other, even if we don't know it. We can all just live our lives as we choose to do so. We just have to find a way to do it." -- Jack Ryan, in "The Man Who Knew Too Much" (1998) "The man who KNEW too much" is the central character of this novel, as well as the book's other plot twists and turns. The book is written by Mark O'Mara and is published by Simon & Schuster at a cost of $24.99 (including taxes) and $16.95 (with a p&p discount). The film is scheduled to be released on November 14, 1998. "The Jack Ryan Story" is released by Simon&Schuster at 9 p.m. ET (GMT-8) and is available on DVD and Blu-ray.

name: Debt of Honor
summary: Jack Ryan is recruited as National Security Advisor by President Roger Durling. CIA officers John Clark and Domingo Chavez are sent to Japan to reactivate a former KGB spy network in order to gain intelligence. Ryan eliminates Japan's AWACS system through a series of "accidents" using widely dispersed U.S. assets, allowing B-2 bombers to destroy the silos. Ryan engineers a "do-over", where all of the transactions on the day of the mass deletion are ignored and all assets are restored to their state at the start of business that day. America's economy is restored with only minor disruption. Japan immediately sues for peace, offering international talks and seemingly free elections in the Marianas. Cornered, current prime minister resigns, ceding power to his predecessor. Japanese government accepts America's generous offer of status quo ante ante. President Durling faces another less important political crisis: Vice-President Ed Kealty is forced to resign after being accused of drugging and raping a former member of his staff. Nearly the entire presidential line of succession is eliminated before Ryan is confirmed as vice-president. Ryan escapes the crisis and narrowly escapes the attack and kills an embittered Japan Air Lines pilot driven by the deaths of his son and brother during the previous conflict. He then flies directly into the Capitol and assassinates his brother and son-in-law. Ryan's plan is a success: America's economic recovery is restored and Japan's military offensive is forestalled by the second phase of the Japanese offensive: an economic attack. The Japanese hope that America will be too distracted to quickly respond to Japan’s military actions. Japan also attempts to assassinate the chairman of the Federal Reserve, but their target survives the attempt with a broken back. The book ends with Ryan returning to the United States to lead a successful military campaign against the Soviet Union in World War II. It is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99. name: Tunnel in the Sky
summary: Rod Walker is a high school student who dreams of becoming a professional colonist. The final test of his Advanced Survival class is to stay alive on an unfamiliar planet for between two and ten days. On test day, each student walks through the Ramsbotham portal and finds him or herself alone on a strange planet. After nearly two years of isolation, the survivors experience the pain and uncertainty of becoming an adult, by reversing the process abruptly -- each of the students goes from being a personally self-responsible member of an autonomous community back to being a youth with little authority or responsibility in the home culture. Rod is briefly depicted accomplishing his heart's desire; the novel's ending finds him preparing to lead a formal colonization party to another planet. The last advice the students receive is to "watch out for stobor." On the second day, Rod is ambushed and knocked unconscious by a thief. When he wakes up, all he has left is a spare knife hidden under a bandage. Eventually he teams up with Jacqueline "Jack" Daudet, a student from another class whom he initially mistakes for a male. When she tells him that more than ten days have elapsed without contact, he realizes that they are stranded. They start recruiting others for the long haul and Rod becomes the de facto leader of a community that eventually grows to around 75 people. He is subsequently put back in charge. Heinlein tracks the social development of this community of educated Westerners deprived of technology, followed by its abrupt dissolution when contact with Earth is reestablished. All of theStudents go back willingly except for Rod, who has great difficulty reverting from the status of head of a small, but sovereign state to a teenager casually brushed aside by the adult rescuers. Despite disagreeing with many of Grant's policies, Rod supports him. Rod's teacher also informs Rod that his warning against "stobor" ("robots" spelled backwards) was just a way of personalizing the dangers of an unknown planet - to instill fear and caution in the students. Rod has no taste for politics or administration, and is happy to have Grant Cowper, an older college student and born politician, elected "mayor". Grant proves to be much better at talking than getting things done. When a species previously thought harmless suddenly changes its behavior and stampedes through their camp, the settlement is devastated and Grant is killed. When Grant ignores Rod's warning that they're living in a dangerously hard-to-defend location and that they should move to a cave system he has found.

name: The Mismeasure of Man
summary: The Mismeasure of Man is a critical analysis of the early works of scientific racism about the supposed, biologically inherited (genetic) basis for human intelligence. Gould proposed that most psychological studies have been heavily biased, by the belief that the human behavior of a race of people is best explained by genetic heredity. He said that if the genetic heritability of IQ were demonstrable within a given racial or ethnic group, it would not explain the causes of IQ differences among the people of a group, or if said IQ differences can be attributed to the environment. As an evolutionary biologist and historian of science, Gould accepted biological variability, but opposed biological determinism, which posits that genes determine a definitive, unalterable social destiny for each man and each woman in life and society. Gould said that it is very difficult to conceive of a world wherein every man and woman grew up in the same environment, because spatial dispersion upon the planet Earth makes it impossible. Furthermore he dismissed the proposition of randomness, because of the randomness of molecular and genetic development of a given population, given a given genotype and given a population given a certain age. Gould also said that correlation does not imply causation; in example, he said that the measures of the changes, over time, in "my age, the population of México, the price of Swiss cheese, my pet turtle’s weight, and the average distance between galaxies" have a high, positive correlation — yet that correlation doesn't indicate that Gould’S age increased because the Mexican population increased. More specifically, a. high correlation between the intelligence quotients of a parent and a child can be presumed either as evidence that IQ is genetically inherited, or thatIQ is inherited through social and environmental factors. Gould: "If all environments were to become equal for everyone, all remaining differences in IQ would necessarily be 100 percent genetic in origin", which is misleading, at best, and false, at worst, and a false proposition at worst. He also said the data from IQ tests can be applied to arguing the logical validity of either proposition — genetic inheritance and environmental inheritance — the psychometric data have no inherent value. The evolutionary biologist Richard Lewontin, a colleague of Gould's, is a proponent of said argument in relation to the cognitive ability tests that determine a person's intelligence quotient. Gould describes Morton's rather imprecise technique of filling skulls with bird seed to obtain endocranial-volume data and how Morton had probably pushed down bird seed in the white skulls so that they had more volume.

name: The Picture of Dorian Gray
summary: Dorian Gray is a young man who believes beauty is the only worthwhile aspect of life. Under the influence of Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian begins to explore his senses. He discovers amazing actress Sibyl Vane, who performs Shakespeare plays in a dingy theatre. Dorian rejects her, saying her beauty was in her acting, and he is no longer interested in her. When he returns home, he notices that his portrait has changed. He takes Basil to the portrait, which is as hideous as Dorian's sins. He blames Basil for his fate and stabs Basil to death. He then blackmails an old friend named Alan Campbell, a chemist, into destroying Basil's body. Seeing this, he realizes that the motives behind his "self-sacrifice" were merely vanity, curiosity, and the quest for new emotional experiences. Deciding that only full confession will absolve him, he decides to destroy the last vestige of his conscience. In a rage, he picks up the knife that killed Basil Hallward and plunges it into the painting. The servants find Dorian stabbed in the heart, stabbed and suddenly aged. It is only through the rings on his hand that the corpse can be identified, however, that the portrait has reverted to its original form. The title of the novel is never revealed in the novel, but at Oscar Wilde's trial he admitted that he had 'had in mind' Joris-Karl Huysmans's À Rebours ('Against Nature') Dorian tells Lord Henry that he will be good from now on, and has started by not breaking the heart of his latest innocent conquest named Hetty Merton. Lord Henry later informs him that she has killed herself by swallowing prussic acid. The novel ends with Dorian long gone, but a woman from the opium den chastises him for not killing Dorian, revealing Dorian has not aged for 18 years. The book was written in the first half of the 19th century and was published in the second half of that year. It has been described as a "poisonous" French decadence novel, a present from Lord Henry. The name of the book has not been revealed, but it is said to be a work of art by the French writer Jean-Francois Cousteau, who was a friend of Wilde's. It was published by Hodder & Stoughton, a division of Penguin Books, and is available in English and French.

name: The Book of the City of Ladies
summary: The City of Ladies is a book written by Christine in the thirteenth century. In it, Christine tries to understand why men slander women. The three Virtues, Lady Reason, Lady Rectitude and Lady Justice, appear to Christine. They help Christine build the walls of the city and teach her about the merits of women. Part III marks Lady Justice’s joining with Christine to “add the finishing touches” to the city, including bringing a queen to rule the city. At the close of this part, Christine makes another address to all women announcing the completion of theCity of Ladies. She beseeches them to defend and protect theCity and to follow their queen (the virgin Mary). She also warns the women against the lies of men, saying, “Drive back these treacherous liars who use nothing but honeyed tricks to steal from you”. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a print run of 1,000 copies. name: The Sentinel
summary: The story deals with the discovery of an artifact on Earth's Moon left behind eons ago by ancient aliens. The object is made of a polished mineral and tetrahedral in shape, and is surrounded by a spherical forcefield. The narrator hypothesises that this "sentinel" was left on the moon as a "warning beacon" for possible intelligent and spacefaring species that might develop on Earth. In 2001: A Space Odyssey, the operation of the sentinel is reversed. It is the energy of the sun, falling for the first time on the uncovered artifact, that triggers the signal that creatures from the Earth had taken the first step into space. The story ends on a cliffhanger, with the narrator saying: "I don't think I've ever seen such a beautiful thing as a moon. I've never seen a moon so full of stars and moonlight and stars and planets and all of that." The story is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a print run of 1,000 copies.
