name: The Fountains of Paradise
summary: In the 22nd century, Dr Vannevar Morgan is a famous structural engineer. He hopes to develop the'space elevator' from a theoretical concept to reality. The only suitable starting point for the elevator lies at the summit of a mountain in Taprobane occupied by an ancient order of Buddhist monks, who implacably oppose the plan. A short epilogue envisages Earth many centuries later, after the sun has cooled and Earth has been depopulated, with humans now living on the terraformed inner planets. Several space elevators lead to a giant "circumterran" space station that encircles Earth at geostationary altitude. Several years later, the Earth-based tower is well under construction and travel up and down — both for tourists and for transfer to rocket ships &MDash; is being trialled. Despite his rapidly failing health, Morgan asserts his right to travel up the tower in a one-man'spider' to rescue them. He nearly fails, with limited battery power, but ultimately succeeds in reaching the chamber. As Morgan surveys the progress of his brainchild, his heart disease claims his life. The analogy with a wheel is evident: the space station itself is the wheel rim, Earth is the axle, and the six equidistant space elevator the spokes. A theme earlier explored in Clarke's novel The Sands of Mars is also explored in this novel. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, and is available in hardback, paperback and e-book. name: Lord of the Flies
summary: A British plane crashes onto an isolated island in a remote region of the Pacific Ocean. The only survivors are male children below the age of 13. Two boys, the fair-haired Ralph and an overweight, bespectacled boy nicknamed "Piggy" find a conch, which Ralph uses as a horn to bring all the survivors to one area. Ralph emerges as one of the survivors' leaders, as does Jack Merridew, a member of a boys' choir that survived the crash. Jack organises his choir group into a hunting party responsible for discovering a food source. Ralph, Jack, and a boy named Simon soon form a troika of leaders. The tribe, which receives recruits from the main group of boys, grows in strength and begins to adopt customs common to primitive cultures, including face paint and bizarre rituals including sacrifices to the beast. When the tribe grows to a size that rivals Ralph's, they begin to harass those who remain at the shelters and make pronouncements encouraging them to abandon Ralph and the societal order he has imposed. Raiding Ralph's camp, the savages confiscate the glasses and return to their abode near the great rock heap called Castle Rock. Turning against Ralph, the tribe demands that they return the valuable object and return it to Ralph, who is forced to give up his position as "chief" The film ends with Ralph and Piggy, accompanied by Sam and Eric, confronting Jack and his band of "savages" in the island's interior during a dance and telling the boys that they should possess Piggy's glasses, the only means of starting a fire on the island. The film was released on September 14, 2013. The UK release date was September 25, 2013, but the US release date has yet to be announced. The U.S. release date is September 28, 2014, and the UK releasedate is September 30, 2014. The Australian release date for the film is September 29, 2014,. and the U.K. releasedate for the movie is September 26, 2015, and it will be released on October 1, 2015. The US release dates are September 27, 2016, and October 7, 2016,. and it is released in the UK on October 8, 2016 and the US on October 9, 2016. The British release dates have not yet been announced in the US, but they are expected to be released in Australia on October 14, 2017, and Canada on October 10, 2017. The movie is set in the middle of the Second World War, during the Battle of the Bulge.

name: Through the Looking-Glass
summary: Alice is playing with a white kitten and a black kitten when she ponders what the world is like on the other side of a mirror's reflection. Climbing up on the fireplace mantel, she pokes at the wall-hung mirror behind the fireplace and discovers, to her surprise, that she is able to step through it to an alternative world. In this reflected version of her own house, she finds a book with looking-glass poetry, "Jabberwocky", whose reversed printing she can read only by holding it up to the mirror. She also observes that the chess pieces have come to life, though they remain small enough for her to pick up. The Red Queen reveals to Alice that the entire countryside is laid out in squares like a gigantic chessboard, and offers to make Alice a queen if she can move all the way to the eighth rank/row in a chess match. Alice is placed in the second rank as one of the White Queen's pawns, and begins her journey across the chessboard by boarding a train that literally jumps over the third row and directly into the fourth rank, acting on the rule that pawns can advance two spaces on their first move. After crossing yet another brook into the sixth rank, Alice immediately encounters Humpty Dumpty, who, besides celebrating his unbirthday, provides his own translation of the strange terms in "J Jabberwockingy" before his inevitable fall. In the final chapter, the March Hare and Hatter of the first book make a brief re-appearance in the guise of "Anglo-Saxon messengers" called "Haigha" and "Hattai" "Hare" and "Hatter" are only given as other than John Tenniel's illustrations to their identities. Lewis's self-deprecating joke about the "eccentric" movements of chess knights may also be interpreted as a joke about Carroll's own physical stammering and awkwardness in real life. The Knight recites a long poem of his own composition, repeatedly falling off his horse and repeatedly falls off his own horse. The Lion and Unicorn are accompanied by the White King along with the Lion and the Unicorn, who again proceed to act out a nursery rhyme by fighting each other. After leaving the forest to their fight, the Red Knight reaches the seventh rank and takes Alice into the territory of their territory of the forest, where he is intent on capturing the "white pawn"

name: Waiting for Godot
summary: Waiting for Godot follows a pair of men who divert themselves while waiting expectantly, vainly for someone named Godot to arrive. To occupy the time they eat, sleep, converse, argue, sing, play games, exercise, swap hats, and contemplate suicide – anything "to hold the terrible silence at bay" The play opens with Estragon struggling to remove a boot, muttering, "Nothing to be done." His friend Vladimir takes up the thought and muses on it, the implication being that nothing is a thing that has to be do and this pair is going to have to spend the rest of the play doing it. The motif recurs throughout the play, particularly in relation to the two thieves crucified alongside Jesus, and that only one of the Four Evangelists mentions that one of them was saved. It may be linked to its putative central theme of the search for and reconciliation with God, as well as salvation: "We're saved!" they cry on more than one occasion when they feel that Godot may be near. The pair cannot agree on whether or not they are in the right place or that this is the arranged day for their meeting with Godot; they are not even sure what day it is. Their waiting is interrupted by the passing through of Pozzo and his heavily-laden slave Lucky, who has a rope tied around his neck. Pozzo barks orders at his slave and frequently calls him a "pig", but is civil towards the other two. They mistake him at first forGodot and clearly do not recognise him for the self-proclaimed personage he is. This irks him, but, while maintaining that the land that they are on is his, he acknowledges that "the road is free to all". Deciding to ask for a chance to rest, he casts the bones aside and jumps at them, much to the embarrassment of them, but is told that they belong to him. At the original pairing, Vladimir takes to the task regarding his slave, but his protestations are ignored. At least not unless he is prevailing on him to do something else, which he refuses to do. When Lucky hangs his head, Vladimir tries to mollify him, refusing to prevent him from selling him as a "no", but he only refuses to answer. The diversion ends as Estragons announces that they still have nothing to do, and the play ends. The original pairing tries to find out why Lucky does not put down his load (at least unless he does not want to be sold) but he refuses.

name: The Wanderer
summary: The novel is set in a future a few decades ahead of the 1960s, when it was written. A new planet appears out of nothing close to the Moon, shortly after a total lunar eclipse. Over a period of few days the planet appears to consume the Moon. On Earth, the new planet's gravity causes death and destruction as it raises huge ocean tides and causes earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. The novel follows the lives of people around the globe, including a man attempting a solo crossing of the Atlantic ocean, a smuggler operating off the coast of Vietnam, two friends in England, a trio of drug addicts in New York City, and the military controllers of the USA Moon mission, deep in a bunker somewhere near Washington DC. The new planet is referred to by everybody as simply "the Wanderer". The main protagonists are three longtime friends, Paul Hagbolt, Margo Gelhorn (and her cat, Miaow) and Don Merriam, one of the American astronauts at the Moon base. They must avoid tsunamis, more earthquakes, roving mobs and flying saucers to survive. They meet a being calling itself Tigerishka, a large, female telepathic feline creature. They belong to a culture that spans the Universe, has achieved immortality, and can construct planets and traverse hyperspace. However they are fleeing their culture's police. Their culture rejects nonconformists, instead devoting itself to ensuring that intelligent life survives to the end of time. Their flight has brought them to Earth orbit simply to refuel. Huge amounts of matter must be converted to energy to power their hyperspace drive and their weapons. In the final scene, both planets take place, both disappear, and a battle takes place between the Wanderer and the Earth. A second planet, colored a dull gray where the Stranger is bright purple and yellow, appears and threatens the good treatment they have seen along with thousands of other humans by some kind of holographic projection. Paul and Don are evacuated in Don's ship, placed into a position close to Earth, and taken to Vandenberg Spaceport. TigerishKA takes Miaow with her back to her planet, where she is reunited with Paul aboard her ship. Now they must testify in the Wanderers' trial, for the police have arrived and threaten them with good treatment, along with other humans appearing by holographic projections. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book.

name: 2010: Odyssey Two
summary: The story is set nine years after the failure of the Discovery One mission to Jupiter. A joint Soviet-American crew, including Heywood Floyd from 2001, arrives to investigate the monolith in orbit around the planet. A sequence of scenes follows the explorations of David Bowman, who has been transformed into a non-corporeal, energy-based life-form. In the novel, the aliens are using Bowman as a probe to learn about humankind. He then returns to the Jupiter system to explore beneath the ice of Europa, where he finds aquatic life-forms. By this time, the Europans have evolved into a species that has developed into a primitive civilization. They regard Jupiter as their primary Sun, referring to ours as "The Cold Sun" The book ends with a brief epogue, which takes place in AD 20001, which is still facing the Farside hemisphere from which some have begun to explore the Sun, which they refer to as "Lucifer" The novel is published by Simon & Schuster, priced at $24.99 (hardcover) and $26.99 (£16.99) in the U.S., and is available for pre-order on Amazon.com, with a free download of the book for the Kindle version for $12.99. The book is available in hardback and hardback for $16.95 ( paperback) and £14.99 for both hardcover and e-book versions for $19.99 ($24.95). It is published in the UK by Macmillan, which has a print run of 1,000 copies. The UK edition includes a hardback version of the novel with a paperback insert, as well as a hardcover version for £15.95 ($20). The book was released in the US by Simon and Schuster on September 14, 2008. The US edition has a release date of September 21, 2008 (hardback) and a paperback edition of September 23, 2008 for £16.50 ($20) The book has been published in Australia by MacMillan, where it is published as a special edition of $20.00 (£15). The UK version has a paperback version of $15.00 (hardcopy) and the US edition of £12.50 (£13.50). The US version of this article includes a paperback copy of $14.00 ($16.00) and two hardcover copies of $13.95 (£14.50)

name: Brave New World
summary: The novel opens in London in 632 (AD 2540 in the Gregorian Calendar) The vast majority of the population is unified under the World State, an eternally peaceful, stable global society in which goods and resources are plentiful. Natural reproduction has been done away with and children are created, 'decanted' and raised in Hatcheries and Conditioning Centres. All children are educated via the hypnopaedic process, which provides each child with caste-appropriate subconscious messages. The need for transcendence, solitude and spiritual communion is addressed with the ubiquitous availability and universally endorsed consumption of the drug soma. The maxim "everyone belongs to everyone else" is repeated often, and the idea of a "family" is considered pornographic. Sexual competition and emotional, romantic relationships are rendered obsolete because they are no longer needed. Marriage, natural birth, parenthood, pregnancy and pregnancy are considered obscene to be casual conversation. Spending alone is considered an outrageous waste of time and money, and wanting to be an individual is horrifying. The conditioning system eliminates the need for professional competitiveness; people are literally bred to do their jobs within their castes. There is no competition within the castes; there is no desire to do another job, and no one has no family, they have no ties to mourn to mourn. The book is an allusion to a mythical drink of the same name consumed by ancient Indo-Aryans. In the book, soma is a hallucinogen that takes users on enjoyable, hangover-free "holidays". It was developed by the World state to provide these inner-directed personal experiences within a socially managed context of State-run'religious' organizations; social clubs. The few women who can reproduce are conditioned to use birth control, even wearing a "Malthusian belt" (which resembles a cartridge belt and holds "the regulation supply of contraceptives") as a popular fashion accessory. The novel ends on a cliffhanging cliffhanger, with the reader left with no choice but to read the next book in the series, which is due to be published in the spring of 2015. It will be published by Simon & Schuster at a price of £16.99 ($24.99) and will be available in hardback, paperback, e-book, Kindle and audiobook. The author has no plans to self-publish the book and has no immediate plans to release it. It has been described as a "futile" work of fiction.

name: Aeneid
summary: The Aeneid can be divided into two halves based on the disparate subject matter of Books 1–6 (Aeneas' journey to Latium in Italy) and Books 7–12 (the war in Latium) These two halves are commonly regarded as reflecting Virgil's ambition to rival Homer by treating both the Odyssey's wandering theme and the Iliads warfare themes. Virgil begins his poem with a statement of his theme (Arma virumque cano ..., "I sing of arms and of a man≯...") and an invocation to the Muse. He then explains the reason for the principal conflict in the story: the resentment held by the goddess Juno against the Trojan people. This is consistent with her role throughout the Homeric epics. In the manner of Homer, the story proper begins in medias res, with the Trojan fleet in the eastern Mediterranean, heading in the direction of Italy. The fleet, led by Aeneas, is on a voyage to find a second home. It has been foretold that in Italy, he will give rise to a race both noble and courageous, a race which will become known to all nations. He tells of how, rallying the other survivors, he built a fleet of ships and made landfall at various locations in the Mediterranean. After getting outside Troy, he goes back for his wife and appears before him and tells him that his destiny is to found Rome. He also recounts sadly the events which occasioned the Trojans' fortuitous arrival. He begins the tale shortly after the events described in theIliad. The Trojan fleet takes shelter on the coast of Africa. There, Aenees's mother, Venus, in the form of a hunting woman very similar to the goddess Diana, encourages him and telling him the history of the city. Eventually, he seeks and gains the favor of Dido, Queen of Carthage, a city which has only recently been founded by refugees from Tyre and which will later become one of Rome's greatest imperial rivals and enemies. He escapes with his family with his escape with his son Ascanius, who had told him in a dream to flee with his fallen Trojan prince, to fend off tens of thousands of Greeks. The last Trojan general, Polydorus, tells him how he is to be found in Rome, where they encounter the general Harpy, who has been killed in the Battle of St. Helen's.

name: Paradise Lost
summary: The poem follows the epic tradition of starting in medias res (Latin for in the midst of things), the background story being recounted later. It begins after Satan and the other rebel angels have been defeated and banished to Hell, or (as it is also called in the poem), Tartarus. The story of Adam and Eve's temptation and fall is a fundamentally different, new kind of epic: a domestic one. In this manner, Milton portrays Adam as a heroic figure, but also as a greater sinner than Eve, as he is aware that what he is doing is wrong. The poem is separated into twelve "books" or sections, and the lengths of each book varies greatly (the longest being Book IX, with 1,189 lines) and the shortest Book VII, having 640. In 1674 a fully "Revised and Augmented" edition with a new division into twelve books was issued. This is the edition that is generally used today. The Arguments at the head of each books were added in subsequent imprints of the first edition. Adam is shown a vision by the angel Michael, in which Adam witnesses everything that will happen to mankind until the Great Flood. He is very upset by this vision of humankind's future, and so Michael also tells him about humankind's potential redemption from original sin through Jesus Christ (whom Michael calls "King Messiah"). Adam and. Eve are cast out of Eden, and Michael says that Adam may find "a paradise within thee, happier far". Adam and Eden also now have a more distant relationship with God, who is omnipresent but invisible (unlike the tangible Father in the Garden of Eden). Adam is also shown to have lustful sex, and at first, Adam is convinced that Eve was right in thinking that eating the fruit would be beneficial. However, they soon fall asleep and have terrible nightmares, and after they awake, they experience guilt and shame for the first time. Realizing that they have committed a terrible act against God, they engage in mutual recrimination. Adam declares to Eve that since she was made from his flesh, they are bound to one another so that if she dies, he must also die. The final battle involves the Son of God single-handedly defeating the entire legion of angelic rebels and banishing them from Heaven. Following the purging of Heaven, God creates the World, culminating in his creation ofAdam and Eve. God gave them one explicit command: not to eat from the Tree of the knowledge of good and evil on penalty of death.

name: The Merchant of Venice
summary: Bassanio, a young Venetian of noble rank, wishes to woo the beautiful and wealthy heiress Portia of Belmont. Having squandered his estate, Bassanio approaches his friend Antonio, a wealthy merchant of Venice and a kind and generous person, for three thousand ducats needed to subsidise his expenditures as a suitor. Antonio agrees, but since he is cash-poor - his ships and merchandise are busy at sea - he promises to cover a bond if Bassanios can find a lender. Shylock, who hates Antonio because of his Anti-Judaism and Antonio's customary refusal to borrow or lend money with interest, is at first reluctant, citing abuse he has suffered at Antonio's hand. But finally agrees to lend Antonio the sum without interest upon the condition that if Antonio is unable to repay it at the specified date, he may take a pound of Antonio's flesh. At Venice, Antonio's ships are reported lost at sea. This leaves him unable to satisfy the bond and he is brought before court. The climax of the play comes when the court of the Duke of Venice demands his pound of flesh from Antonio, twice the amount of the loan he had agreed to lend him. The Duke, wishing to nullify a contract, refers the case to a visitor who introduces himself as a young male "doctor of the law", bearing a recommendation of recommendation from the learned lawyer Bellario. The doctor is actually Portia in disguise, and the clerk who accompanies her is actually Nerissa, also in disguise. Portia repeatedly asks the doctor to show mercy in a famous speech, advising him that mercy "is blesteth twice". However, the doctor takes that letter and gives him that letter, and that takes him to Venice, where he marries Portia. The play ends with Portia's father leaving a will stipulating each of her suitors must choose correctly from one of three caskets – one each of gold, silver and lead. If he picks the right casket, he gets Portia, and choses the lead casket to win her hand. The first suitor, the luxurious Prince of Morocco, chooses the gold casket because of the baseness of its material and the uninviting nature of its slogan: "Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath" The second suitor,. the conceited Prince of Arragon chooses the silver casket. Both suitors leave empty-handed.

name: The Invisible Man
summary: A mysterious stranger, Griffin, arrives at the local inn of the English village of Iping, West Sussex, during a snowstorm. The stranger wears a long-sleeved, thick coat and gloves, his face hidden entirely by bandages except for a fake pink nose, large goggles and a wide-brimmed hat. He is excessively reclusive, irascible, and unfriendly. He demands to be left alone and spends most of his time in his rooms working with a set of chemicals and laboratory apparatus, only venturing out at night. In the final chapter, it is revealed that Marvel has secretly kept Griffin's notes. Griffin's name is not known by anyone (including the reader) until then, he is referred to as the stranger or Invisible Man. The Invisible Man is Griffin, a former medical student who left medicine to devote himself to optics. He recounts how he invented medicine capable of rendering bodies invisible and, on an impulse, performed the procedure on himself. He tells of how he tries the invisibility on a cat, then himself. Griffin burns down the boarding house he is staying in along with all his equipment he used to turn invisible to cover his tracks, but soon realizes he is ill-equipped to survive in the open. He attempts to steal food and clothes from a large store, but eventually he steals some clothing from a theatrical supply shop and heads to Iping to attempt to reverse the effect. But now that he imagines he can make Kemp his secret confederate, Griffin describes his plan to begin a "Reign of Terror" by using his invisibility to terrorize the nation. Griffin is seized, assaulted, and killed by a mob. He's naked, battered body gradually becomes visible as he dies. A local policeman shouts to covered his face with a sheet, then the book concludes. The novel's most charming aspects is its portrayal of small-town life in southern England, which the author knew from first-hand experience. The book concludes with a mysterious burglary occurs in the village. It is revealed in the last chapter that Griffin has run out of money and is trying to find a way to pay for his board and lodging. He takes shelter in a nearby house that turns out to belong to Dr. Kemp, his former acquaintance from medical school. Griffin shoots and kills a local policeman who comes to Kemp's aid, then breaks into Kemp's house. Kemp bolts for the town, where the local citizenry comes to his aid. Griffin fights his way out and the next day leaves a note announcing that Kemp himself will be the first man to be killed.

name: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea
summary: In 1866, a mysterious sea monster, theorized by some to be a giant narwhal, is sighted by ships of several nations. The United States government assembles an expedition in New York City to track down and destroy the menace. Professor Pierre Aronnax, a noted marine biologist and narrator of the story, is issued a last-minute invitation to join the expedition, and he accepts. Canadian master harpoonist Ned Land and AronNax's faithful assistant Conseil are also brought on board. The expedition sets sail from Brooklyn aboard a naval ship called the Abraham Lincoln, which travels down around the tip of South America and into the Pacific Ocean. After much fruitless searching, the monster is found, and the ship charges into battle. During the fight, the ship's steering is damaged and the three protagonists are thrown overboard. They find themselves stranded on the "hide" of the creature, only to discover to their surprise that it is a large metal construct. They are quickly captured and brought inside the vessel, where they meet its enigmatic creator and commander, Captain Nemo. The rest of the book follows the adventures of the protagonists aboard the submarine, the Nautilus, which was built in secrecy and now roams the seas free of any land-based government. Their travels take them to numerous points in the world's oceans, some of which were known to Jules Verne from real travelers' descriptions and guesses, while others are completely fictional. The travelers witness the real corals of the Red Sea, the wrecks of the battle of Vigo Bay, the Antarctic ice shelves, and a fictional submerged Atlantis. Near the end of the novel, the submarine is tracked and attacked by a mysterious ship from that nation. This gives the three prisoners an opportunity to escape; they make it back to land alive, but the fate of the captain and his crew is not revealed. It is suggested that the captain exiled himself from the world after an encounter with his oppressive country somehow affected his family. The submarine is equipped to carry out cutting-edge marine biology research; he also tells his new passengers that he can never leave because he is afraid they will betray his existence to the world. Nemo attacks the ship under the waterline, sending it to the bottom of the ocean with all crew aboard as Aron nax watches from the salon. The story ends when the submarine enters a whirlpool off the coast of Norway and is attacked by the Moskenstraumen, more commonly known as the "Maelstrom"

name: Keep the Aspidistra Flying
summary: Gordon Comstock has 'declared war' on what he sees as an 'overarching dependence' on money. Comstock lives in a bedsit in London and earns enough to live, without luxuries, in a small bookshop. He is simultaneously content with his meagre existence and also disdainful of it. At the beginning of the novel, he senses that his girlfriend Rosemary Waterlow is dissatisfied with him because of his poverty. He rails at her; "Money again, you see! [-] You say you can't have a baby. You mean you daren't; because you'd lose your job and I've got no money and all of us would starve." Having sent a poem to an American publication, Gordon suddenly receives from them a cheque worth ten pounds — a considerable sum for him at the time. He intends to set aside half for his sister Julia who has always lent him money and support. He treats Rosemary and Philip Ravelston to dinner, but the evening deteriorates as well. Gordon drunk, tries to force himself upon Rosemary, but she angrily rebukes him and leaves him in a cell. The pair of them visit a pair of prostitutes, and ends up broke and in a jail. The ensuing publicity results in Gordon losing his job in the local paper, and losing out on his sister's £5 note. The novel ends in a police case, but after a brief appearance before the magistrate, Gordon hears about it and writes about it in a local paper. The result is one of the tarts or tarts, or stolen or stolen by the police, given to the public by the local newspaper, or given to them by the public. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99, and is available on Kindle, iPad, Kindle and Nook, with a Kindle edition for £12.99. For the full version of the story, visit Amazon.com.

name: Manon Lescaut
summary: Set in France and Louisiana in the early 18th century, the story follows the hero, the Chevalier des Grieux, and his lover, Manon Lescaut. Des Grieix comes from a noble and landed family, but forfeits his hereditary wealth and incurs the disappointment of his father by running away with Manon. The two lovers finally settle down in New Orleans, where the virtual absence of class differences allows them for a while to live in idyllic peace. But the Governor's nephew sets his sights on winning Manon's hand and the couple flee New Orleans and venture into the wilderness of Louisiana, hoping to reach a neighbouring English settlement. Manon dies of exposure and exhaustion the following morning; after burying her, Des Grievux returns to France to become a cleric. In despair, he challenges the Governor’s nephew to a duel and knocks him unconscious. Thinking he had killed the man and fearing retribution, the pair flee into the Wilderness of Louisiana and seek refuge in the neighbouring English settlements. In the end, the couple find refuge in a nearby English settlement, but Manon is killed in the ensuing battle. The story ends on a cliffhanger, with the hero returning to France and becoming a cleric to live out his dream of becoming a priest. The novel is published by Picador, priced £16.99, and is available in hardback. For more information, visit www.picador.com/the-book/The-Book-By-The-Chevalier-Des-Grieux. The book is also available in softback, paperback and e-book versions for £12.99. name: Lions' Commentary on UNIX 6th Edition, with Source Code
summary: The code will run on a PDP-11/40 with RK-05 disk drive, LP-11 line printer interface, PCL-11 paper tape writer and KL-11 terminal interface. All procedures and symbols are listed alphabetically with a cross reference. It is possible to understand the code without the extra commentary, and the reader is advised to do so and only read the notes as needed. The commentary also remarks on how the code might be improved. The book ends with suggested exercises for the student. As Lions explains, this commentary supplements the comments in the source. The source commentary follows, divided into the same sections as the code. The code is lightly edited by Lions to better separate the functionality — system initialization and process management, interrupts and system calls, basic I/O, file systems and pipes and character devices. The text is written in English with an emphasis on punctuation and punctuation, and is written to be easy to understand and understand by students of the Unix operating system. It was written by Lions and published by the University of California, Los Angeles, in the early 1990s. It has been republished several times, most recently in 1998. It can be downloaded for free from the U.S. Library of Congress, with a free download of the book included as part of the hard copy of The Unix Operating System: A Commentary on theUnix Operating System, published by Lions, is available in hard copy for $24.99 (with an optional download fee of $16.99). The book also includes a chapter on how to read C programs, and a section on the architecture of the P DP-11 and how to write C programs. It also includes suggested exercises to help students with reading the code, such as reading C programs and writing C programs on a computer with an MS-DOS operating system, or using a PC with a PC-11 interface, or a suitable emulator, like SIMH. It ends with a list of recommended exercises for students to follow, including how to use the computer with the PC-L, the PCL and the KL-L terminal interface, as well as how to run C programs with the PPD-11 on a PC and a PCL/L interface. It's also available in German, French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, and other languages. For more information on the book, or to order a copy, call the publisher's mail-back copy at: http://www.lions.com/.

name: The Myth of Sisyphus
summary: The essay is dedicated to Pascal Pia and is organized in four chapters and one appendix. Camus undertakes to answer what he considers to be the only question of philosophy that matters: Does the realization of the meaninglessness of life necessarily require suicide? He begins by describing the absurd condition: much of our life is built on the hope for tomorrow yet tomorrow brings us closer to death and is the ultimate enemy. In the last chapter, Camus outlines the legend of Sisyus who defied the gods and put the gods in chains so that no human needed to die. When it came time for Sisyu to die, he concocted a deceit which let him escape from the underworld. But both The Diary and The Karamazovovov find a path to hope and faith and thus fail as absurd creations, he writes. The absurd man gains freedom in a very concrete sense: no longer bound by hope for a better future or eternity, without a need to pursue life's purpose or to create meaning. "What counts is not the best living but the most living," Camus writes in his last novel, The Possessed and The Diary of a Writer, in which he analyzes Dostoyevsky's The Writer, The Writer and the Writer, as absurd creators and works of art. "If the world were clear, art would not exist," he writes, "and art would also refrain from judging and from alluding to even the slightest shadow of the shadow of even the smallest shadow of doubt" He concludes by saying that the absurd man must embrace all that the unreasonable world has to offer: "Everything is permitted' "is not an outburst of relief or of joy, but rather a bitter acknowledgment of a fact" "There is no noble love but that which recognizes itself to be both short-lived and exceptional," says Camus. "In those three hours he travels the whole course of the dead-end path that the man in the audience takes a lifetime to cover," he says of Don Juan, the serial seducer who lives the passionate life to the fullest. "He demonstrates to what degree appearing creates being," says the actor, who depictsEphemeral lives for ephemeral fame, "he enjoys a freedom with regard to common rules" "In the end, no ethical rules apply, as they are all based on higher powers or on justification," writes Camus in the final chapter of the essay. "Integrity has no need of rules."

name: Cymbeline
summary: Imogen (or Innogen), daughter of the British king Cymbeline, is in love with Posthumus Leonatus, a man raised in her father's court. The two have secretly married, exchanging jewellery as tokens: a ring from Imogen, a bracelet from PostHumus. Cymbelines' wife the Queen is conspiring to have Cloten, her cloddish and arrogant son by an earlier marriage, married to Imogen. The Queen also is plotting to murder both Imogen and Cymeline to secure Clotan's kingship. Imogen adopts the name "Fidele," meaning "faithful," and leaves court to find food in a cave. The three men enter their cave and find young men who are captivated by Imogen's beauty, and the men are met outside the cave by the men's father, Belarius, a courtier banished as a traitor for supposedly conspiring with the Romans. The cave is his home to his "sons" Belarius and Polydorewal, whom he raised into great woods, who do not know their origin, but are nevertheless possessed of royal passion and heartiness. After a brief fight, Guiderius kills Clotens, who cuts off his head and cuts off the face of his head, and cuts his head off with a sword. The men are then taken to a cave to eat, and are met by the young men, who are also captivating by "hishishe" beauty, who eat them too. The young men then leave the cave and go home to their fathers, where they are raised in the great woods. The boys are later taken to Italy to live with their father, Caius Lucius, a Roman ambassador, who is on his way to demand the tribute that Cymbline, under the influence of his wife theQueen, has stopped paying. The story ends with Imogen returning to court for marriage to her husband, after which he will rape her on Posthumu's corpse before dragging her back to court to be married to him again. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a UK release date of July 25, 2015. For more information on the book and to order your copy, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk or go to www.samaritans.com/the-book/The-Book-of-the-Book/The Book of the Book of The Book Of The Book.

name: Vanity Fair
summary: Becky Sharp is portrayed as a strong-willed and cunning young woman determined to make her way in society. Amelia Sedley is a good-natured, lovable though simple-minded young girl. The relationship between the two families disintegrates after the Sedleys are financially ruined. George ultimately decides to marry Amelia against his father's will, pressured by his friend Dobbin, and George is consequently disinherited. Captain Crawley survives, but George dies in battle, and Amelia bears the genteel son, also named George, who is George's godfather. Dobbin begins to express his love for the widowed Amelia by small kindnesses toward her and her son. The theme of the book is a theme with which Amelia mistakenly assumes Dobbin's infatuation with Amelia is done by her late husband, which she mistakenly assumes was done by Dobbin. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99. For more information on the book, visit www.chattoandwindus.co.uk or go to the website of Miss Pinkerton's Academy for Young Ladies, which is based on the Duchess of Richmond’s famous ball on the eve of the Battle of Waterloo. The school is now run by the London School of Music, with a new headmistress, Mrs. Curnow, on the same site as the old one, which was founded by the Duke of Richmond in 1805. The novel is also available in hardback and paperback, with prices starting at £7.99 for the hardback version and £10 for the paperback edition. For the paperback version, go to www.thebookshop.org.uk/becky-sharp-and-amelia-says-it-all-over-the-page-for-a-free-book-and the-second-edition-of-this-issue-of the book is £10.99 for the hard-back version, with the price of the second edition being £12.99 (including p&p). For the Kindle version, you can order the book for £9.99 with the p&P option, which includes a free-to-read copy of the novel, and a free download of the eBook, which also includes the book's first chapter and the first two chapters. The paperback version of the story is available on Amazon.com for £8.99, and the eBook version is available for £6.99 (£7.50)

name: Northanger Abbey
summary: Catherine Morland is one of ten children of a country clergyman. By the age of 17 she is "in training for a heroine" She is excessively fond of reading Gothic novels of which Ann Radcliffe's Mysteries of Udolpho is a favourite. Catherine is invited by her wealthier neighbours in Fullerton, the Allens, to accompany them to visit the town of Bath and partake in the winter season of balls, theatre and other social delights. She is soon introduced to a clever young gentleman, Henry Tilney, with whom she dances and converses. Catherine tries to maintain her friendships with both the Thorpes and the Tilneys, though John Thorpe continuously tries to sabotage her relationship with the Tilney. Catherine decides that, since General Tilney does not now seem to be affected by the loss of his wife, he may have murdered her or even imprisoned her in her chamber. She leaves, fearing that she has lost Henry's entire regard in regard to Real Life. Catherine comes to believe that, though their novels may be delightful, their everyday life does not relate to everyday life. The Tilneys are shocked and Catherine is terribly disappointed, realizing what a dishonest person they are. The General goes off to London and becomes less inhibited, becoming less inhibited and less dishonest. Catherine flees, sure that she will be punished. Catherine becomes a country parson's living of a modest sum, 400 pounds annually, which she may have in two and a half years. The couple must wait until that time to marry. Isabella and James become engaged. James departs to purchase a ring, and John accompanies him after coyly suggesting marriage to the oblivious Catherine. Catherine sneaks back to Mrs. Tilney's rooms, to discover that her overactive imagination has once again led her astray, as nothing is strange or distressing in the rooms at all. Unfortunately, Henry joins her in the corridor and questions why she is there. He guesses her surmises and inferences, and informs her that his father loved his wife in his own way and was truly upset by her death. Catherine cannot understand her friend's behavior, but Henry understands all too well, as he knows his brother's character and habits. Catherine learns that the house includes a mysterious suite of rooms that no one ever enters; they were Mrs. tilney's, who died nine years earlier. Catherine realizes that she had been crying, fearing how foolish, she had had beenizing how foolish she was.

name: Amadeus
summary: Shaffer has extensively revised his play, including changes to plot details. At the opening of the tale, Salieri is an old man, convinced he used poison to assassinate Mozart. The action then flashes back to the eighteenth century, at a time when Salieri has not met Mozart in person, but has heard of him and his music. When Salieri first meets him, Mozart is crawling around on his hands and knees, engaging in profane talk with his future bride Constanze Weber. Salieri renounces God and vows to do everything in his power to destroy Mozart as a way of getting back at his Creator. The play ends with Salieri attempting suicide in a last attempt to be remembered, leaving a false confession of having murdered Mozart with arsenic. He survives, however, and his confession is disbelieved by all, leaving him to wallow once again in mediocrity. A major theme in Amadeus is Mozart's repeated attempts to win over the aristocratic "public" with increasingly brilliant compositions, which are always frustrated either by Salieri or by the aristocracy's own inability to appreciate Mozarts genius. On more than one occasion it is only the direct intervention of the Emperor himself that allows Mozart to continue (interventions which Salieri opposes, and then is all too happy to take credit for when Mozart assumes it was he who intervened). Salieri also humiliates Mozart’s wife when she comes to Salieri for aid, and smears his character with the Emperor and the court. On one occasion the Emperor intervenes on Salieri's behalf, allowing him to stop Mozart from killing his wife. On another occasion, the Emperor allows Salieri to kill Mozart, and Salieri then takes credit for it. The following is common to all revisions of Shaffer's play, with the exception of a few minor changes to the plot that have been made since the original run of the play in the 1970s and 1980s. The original version of this article referred to the play as "Amadeus" and referred to it as "The Death and Life of Mozart" This version of the story has been updated to make it clear that the play is in fact called "The death and life of Mozarts" and refers to the composer as "Mozart". The play is also referred to as the "Death and Life Of Mozart", and is referred to by Shaffer as "Salieri"

name: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner
summary: The Mariner's tale begins with his ship departing on its journey. Despite initial good fortune, the ship is driven south off course by a storm and eventually reaches Antarctica. An albatross appears and leads them out of the Antarctic but the Mariner shoots the bird. This arouses the wrath of spirits who then pursue the ship "from the land of mist and snow" The ship encounters a ghostly vessel, on board are Death (a skeleton) and the "Night-mare Life-in-Death" (a deathly-pale woman) Death wins the lives of the crew members and Life-In-Death the life of the Mariners, a prize she considers more valuable. One by one, all of the ship's crew members die, but theMariner lives on, seeing for seven days and nights the curse in the eyes of the corpses. Eventually, the Mar Miner's curse is temporarily lifted when he sees sea creatures swimming in the water. Despite his cursing them as "slimy things" earlier in the poem, he suddenly sees their true beauty and blesses them. After the story, he leaves, and the next morning he wakes up "a sad and wiser man" The Mariner stops a man who is on the way to a wedding ceremony and begins to narrate a story. The Wedding-Guest's reaction turns from bemusement to impatience and fear to fascination as the story progresses. Coleridge uses narrative techniques such as personification and repetition to create either a sense of danger, of the supernatural or of serenity, depending on the mood of each of the different parts of the poem. The poem is written in the language style of the poet Samuel L. M. Coontz, who is known for his use of the vernacular  poem form and  the  synthetic narrative form of the English poet William Butler Yeats, who wrote the first edition of The Rime of the Ancient Mariner in 1815. The Mariners tale is about a sailor who has returned from a long sea voyage and is driven by guilt to wander the earth, tell his story, and teach a lesson to those he meets. After relating the story to the Wedding- guest, the story ends and the man goes home, and wakes up the next day "a wiser and a sad and a wiser man". The poem ends with the words: "For the dear God who made and love us, both great and small, who love all things small; : For the dear and small who love us all, both big and small"

name: The Eye of the World
summary: Rand al'Thor, Matrim (Mat) Cauthon, Perrin Aybara, Egwene al'Vere, and Nynaeve al'Meara. Emond's Field is unexpectedly attacked by Dark forces. The Eye of the World was created by Aes Sedai who sacrificed themselves to create a pool of Saidin untouched by the Dark One's taint, and is hidden in the Blight. The companions are confronted by the Forsaken Aginor and Balthamel. They battle for control of the Eye ofThe World. It is revealed that Rand is the Dragon and that he has channeled the One Power and is therefore condemned to his own fate of madness and death. The book is published by Tor.com on September 14, 2013. The first edition of the book was published on September 13, 2013, by Tor Books. The second edition will be published on November 14, 2014, by The Tor Books Company on behalf of The Tolkien Estate. The third and fourth editions will be released on November 15, 2015 and November 16, 2015, respectively, by the Tolkien Estate and The Tor Publishing Company. The fourth and fifth editions will come out on November 21, 2016, and November 22, 2016. The fifth and sixth editions will arrive on November 23, 2017, and December 22, 2017. The sixth and seventh volumes will come on November 24, 2017 and November 25, 2018, respectively. The seventh and eighth volumes will be available on November 28, 2018 and November 29, 2018. The eighth and final volume will be on November 30, 2019. The last volume is on November 31, 2019, and it will be called "The Book of the Two Rivers" by The Tolkien estate. The final volume is entitled "The Song of the Four Winds" and is published on December 14, 2019 by Theodor Publishing. The books are published in hardback and softback. The price for each volume is $25.99. The series is expected to reach a total of $60 million. The novels are expected to be released in September and October of this year, with a planned release date of September 28, 2020, in the United States and September 29, 2020 in the UK. The trilogy is scheduled to end on September 30, 20th, 21st, and 28th, 2019 in the U.S. and in the Commonwealth of Agrabah, Australia, and the Republic of Rand. The novel is set between the events of The Two Rivers District and The Three Rivers District in the world of Ander.

name: The Great Hunt
summary: The prologue shows how deep Ba'alzamon's influence has gone, even in places the protagonists believe to be safe. The protagonists rest at Fort Fal Dara in Shienar, where the White Tower’s Amyrlin Seat, Siuan Sanche, visits. Siuan tells Rand that he is the Dragon Reborn, which Rand denies. Rand, Loial and Hurin are separated from the Shienaran party and transported to an alternate world via a portal stone. Rand suspects that he activated the portal stone by unconsciously channeling saidin in his sleep, although Egwene dreams that a mysterious woman is responsible. Rand and Loial are attacked by trollocs and, during their escape, destroy the Chapter House of the Illuminator's Guild, a society of people who are extremely protective of their knowledge of fireworks. The Horn and dagger are once again lost. With the aid of Perrin, Ingtar's group is successfully reunited with Rand, and they learn that the Horn has been taken to Toman Head, at the port city of Falme. As these events unfold, action also takes place on the other side of the continent of Falcloak where the invading Seanchan beasts have occupied Falme and their exotic side is preparing to attack the Whitecloak Tower. Nynaeve al'Meara and EgWene al'Vere accompany Moraine to Tar Valon for Aes Sedai training. Later on, Rand finds gleeman Thom Merrilin, whom he thought dead after an encounter with a myrddraal in The Eye of the World. Rand is able to use the Stone to return to their own world, albeit much farther ahead than either Fain's or Ingtars group. Rand's struggle to accept his channeling ability is a recurring element in the novel. When they arrive in Falme, Min is captured by the Seanchan and is collared with a device used by Seanchan to control women who can channel the Light. At Atme, Rand and Elayne escape, but Rand and Min, along with Min, travel with her toToman Head via the Waygate. They arrive with Elayne and escape, and Rand and his friends are in danger, but they arrive with her with her and her children. Rand al'Thor meets Siuan. He is at a loss to explain Rand's disappearance, but Perrin pretends to be another sniffer like Hurin, but secretly uses his wolf senses to smell and track and also ask nearby wolves which way Padan Fain’S group went.

name: A Crown of Swords
summary: Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, prepares to attack the Forsaken Sammael in Illian. Egwene al'Vere and Siuan Sanche attempt to manipulate the Aes Sedai rebels in Salidar. Elayne Trakand, Nynaeve al'Meara, Aviendha, and Mat Cauthon search for a ter'angreal, the Bowl of the Winds, to break the unnatural heat brought on by the Dark One's manipulation of climate. The Seanchan invade Ebou Dar in Altara, where Mat is left behind after searching for Olver, and is caught in the fighting as the Seanchan invaded EbouDar. The book is published by Tor.com on September 14, 2013. It is available in hardback and paperback. The price is $24.99. The novel is published in hardcover by Tor, and in paperback by Tor is $25.99, and the ebook is $16.99 (with a PDF version of $16). The book was published in September 2013. The release date is September 14. It will be published in paperback on September 15, 2013, and it will be released in hardbound on September 16, 2013 (and in e-book form on September 17, 2013). It will also be available in paperback and hardback on September 28, 2013 and paperback on October 1, 2013 ($24.95, £16.98, £18.99). It is published on the same day as A Crown of Swords, the first book in the series. It was published on September 7, 2013 by Tor Books. It has been published in the US by Tor Publishing. It comes in hard-back and soft-back editions of $20, $25, $30, $40, $50, $55, $60, $75, $80, $100, and $100. It also comes in the UK by Harlequin Books, priced £20, £30, £35, £40, £50, £55, and £60. It includes a prologue, a prequel, and a pre-quel, as well as an epilogue, which is available on September 8, 2013 in the U.S. and the UK. It follows the events leading up to the start of the book, including Rand's recovery from injury and his defeat of Sammaal. It ends with Rand taking the crown of Illian, formerly the Laurel Crown, but now called the Crown of swords.

name: Winter's Heart
summary: The events of Winter's Heart take place simultaneously with the events of the next book, Crossroads of Twilight. Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, is bonded as a Warder by Elayne Trakand, Aviendha, and Min Farshaw. Mat Cauthon, making his return to the series after his absence in the previous book, is trapped in the city of Ebou Dar in Altara, which is under Seanchan occupation. In Knife of Dreams, it has been confirmed that saidin is clean, by both Aes Sedai and Asha'man. However, according to Jordan himself, though sane channelers no longer need to fear its destructive effects, it does not restore any already affected by it to their former selves. It has also resulted in the utter destruction of the female Choedan Kal and its access key, which triggered the mass suicide of Amayar along the Sea Folk Islands. The forces of light under Cadsuane split into several groups to be ready for the upcoming attack. The former Damane Alivia fought without being linked, helped by a set of Angreal and Ter'angreal presumably made for battle. Nesune, Beldeine, Daigian linked with Jahar (one of Merise's warders, wielding Callandor) Verin and Kumira linked with a Sea Folk Windfinder Shalon. Osan'garal and Graendal (formerly Aorgin) masquerading as Corlan Dashiva an Asha'rean, killed by Elza (ironically a Black Ajahwil) Eben Hopwil (formerly Lanfear) was killed by Gra endal and Aran'Garal by Gra Endal. It is also believed that the giant statue of Balthien is the signal of the end of the Age of Illusion. The book ends on a cliffhanger, leading to a battle between the forces of the Light and the Shadow. It was written in the same style as the first two books in the series, with many of the major events taking place at the beginning of the book and the middle of it. The final book of the series will be written in a different style, and will be published in the spring of 2015. The last book will be released in the summer of 2015, and is expected to be the last of the books in this series. It will also be the first book in a series of three.

name: Around the World in Eighty Days
summary: Phileas Fogg is a rich English gentleman and bachelor living in solitude at Number 7 Savile Row, Burlington Gardens. He accepts a wager for £20,000 from his fellow club members, which he will receive if he makes it around the world in 80 days. Accompanied by Monsieur Passepartout, he leaves London by train at 8:45 P.M. on October 2, 1872, and this is due back at the Reform Club at the same time 80 days later, on December 21. Fogg buys an elephant, hires a guide, and starts toward Allahabad. During the ride, they come across a procession, in which a young Indian woman, Aouda, is led to a sanctuary to be sacrificed by the process of suttee the next day by Brahmins. They follow the procession to the site, where Passe Partout secretly takes the place of a deceased husband on the funeral pyre. He then rises from the pyre, scaring off the priests, and carries the young woman away. The travellers then hasten on to catch the train at next station, Calcutta, taking them to Hong Kong. However, they jump bail and Fix, who has secretly been following them, is forced to follow them. In Hong Kong, they meet his travelling companion from the earlier voyage, who is delighted to meet them again. They decide to take her with them to Europe without his warrant, so they decide to leave her with a distant relative in Holland, whose care they had been planning to leave to her. The story ends with them going to Holland, where they find her still alive and well, and taking her to Holland with them as they still want to visit her family. The film was released in 1872 and is considered one of the most successful films of the 20th century. It is based on a true story that took place in India between 1871 and 1872. It has been adapted into a film series, which has been released in the UK and the U.S. for the first time in the last few years of the 21st century. The movie is expected to be released in December 2014, with a release date of December 25, 2014. The UK release date has been pushed back to December 21, 2014, to coincide with the 100th anniversary of the opening of the Great Barrier Reef, which will be celebrated in a major museum in New York City, New York and San Francisco.

name: The Grapes of Wrath
summary: Tom Joad is paroled from prison after serving time for homicide. He and former preacher Jim Casy travel to his childhood home in Oklahoma. They find it deserted and are told the family has gone to stay at Uncle John Joad's home. The Joads find little hope of making a decent wage, as there is an oversupply of labor and a lack of rights. Tom Joad witnesses the killing of Casy and kills the attacker, becoming a fugitive. He bids farewell to his mother, promising that no matter where he runs, he will be a tireless advocate for the oppressed. The book is about the Joad family's journey to California after their farm is repossessed in the Dust Bowl and they are told of the high pay to be had in that state. It is also about the family's struggle to cope with the loss of their loved ones, including Grampa, Granma, Noah, Connie and Rose of Sharon, who all die along the way. The novel is about Tom's life as he tries to make a new life for himself and his family in the U.S. and the struggles he faces in the midst of the Great Depression. It was published by Simon & Schuster on September 14, 1974. It has been hailed as one of the best books of the 20th century. The film was directed by Tom Hanks and co-written by Heston Blumenthal and Robert Redford, and it is based on the lives of Tom and Casy Joad and other members of their family, as well as their friends and relatives from the Sallisaw, Oklahoma, area. The movie was released on September 16, 1974, by Simon and Schuster, and was released in paperback on September 25, 1974 (with a limited run of 1,000 copies). The film is available on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray versions of the book for $20, $25, $30, $40, $50, $60, $75, $80, and $100, respectively, in hardback, hardback and softback editions. The paperback version of the novel is also available on Amazon.com for $24, $35, $45, $55, $65, $70, $85, $90, $100 and $110, respectively; the hardback version is available in hardcover, $150, $200, $250, $300, $400, $500, $600, $700, $800, $750, $850, $900, $1000, $1,200, and 2,000, respectively. For more information on the book, visit: www.simonandschuster.com.

name: How Green Was My Valley
summary: The novel is set in South Wales in the reign of Queen Victoria. It tells the story of the Morgans, a respectable mining family of the South Wales Valleys, through the eyes of the youngest son, Huw Morgan. Huw's academic ability sets him apart from his elder brothers and enables him to consider a future away from this troubled industrial environment. He moves in with his sister-in-law, Bronwen, with whom he has always been in love. After everyone Huw has known either dies or moves away, he decides to leave as well, and tells us the stories of his life just before he does. The novel is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99. For more information, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or go to www.hodgerandstroughton.com. name: Lady Audley's Secret
summary: The novel opens with the marriage of Lucy Graham, a beautiful, doll-like blonde, to Sir Michael Audley, an old, rich, and kind widower. Around the time of the marriage, Robert Audley welcomes back to England his old friend, George Talboys, who has returned after three years of gold prospecting in Australia. George is anxious to get news of his wife, Helen, whom he left three years ago when their financial situation became desperate, in the hope of returning to her with Australian gold. He reads in the newspaper that she has died, and, after visiting her home to confirm this, he has a complete breakdown. Robert begins to take notes of the events as they unfold, and he slowly begins to collect evidence against Lady Audley. During the night, Lucy forces Phoebe Marks to let her into the inn and sets the place on fire with the intention of killing Robert. When Lucy tells Robert that Helen Talboys faked her death before creating her new identity, he realizes that he has no proof and leaves to find more evidence, heading to the castle to find out what really happened to George Talboy. The novel ends with Lucy leaving the inn, which is run by Phoe be Marks's husband, Luke Marks, and heading to Castle Castle to find the real culprits behind the death of the Talboys family. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, and is available in hard copy for £12.99. For more information on the novel, visit the publisher's website.
