name: A Streetcar Named Desire
summary: Blanche DuBois is a fading, but still-attractive, Southern belle. Her pretensions to virtue and culture only thinly mask alcoholism and delusions of grandeur. The character of Blanche is thought to be based on Williams' sister Rose Williams who struggled with her mental health and became incapacitated after a lobotomy. In the closing moments, Blanche utters her signature line to the kindly doctor who leads her away: "Whoever you are, I have always depended on the kindness of strangers" The reference to the streetcar named Desire is symbolic. Blanche not only has to travel on a streetcar route named "Desire" to reach Stella's home on "Elysian Fields" but her desire acts as an irrepressible force throughout the play. In their final confrontation, it is implied that Stanley rapes Blanche, resulting in her nervous breakdown. The play ends with Blanche's would-be suitor, Harold "Mitch" Mitchell, getting trampled in their path. It is thought that the play is based on the life of Rose Williams, a woman who struggled to cope with the loss of her husband, Allan Grey, who committed suicide in the early 1960s. The show is directed by David Cromwell and is set in New Orleans in the 1970s and 1980s. For more information on the play, go to: http://www.theplaytimes.com/2013/01/28/27/the-play-and-the-life-of-blanche-duBois-in-new-orleans-by-samuel-cromwell-and.html#storylink=cpy. Theater-review: "Blanche," by Samuel L. Cevallos, is published by Simon & Schuster, priced $24.99, with a limited run of $35.99. Theatre- reviewer: "Blanche" is a "must-see" play for theater-goers and "a must-read" for theatre-goers, as well as a "whole lot of fun" for the rest of the theater-going public. "Theatre-goers" can buy tickets for the play online at: www.theatre-reviews.com and www.bookshop.co.uk.  The play is also available on DVD and Blu-ray, with an audio version of the play to be released later in the year.

name: The Queen of the Damned
summary: Each of the six chapters in Part One tells a different story about a different person or group of people. Several of the characters appear in the two previous books, including Armand, Daniel, Marius, Louis, Gabrielle and Santino. The Queen of the Damned, deals with the origins of vampires themselves. The mother of all vampires, Akasha, begins as a pre-Egyptian queen, in a land called Kemet (which will become Egypt), many thousands of years ago. In Part Five, the vampires leave Maharet's compound and assemble at Armand's resort, the Night Island, (according to Anne Rice, inspired by Fire Island) in Florida to recover. They eventually go their separate ways (as told in The Tale of the Body Thief). Lestat takes Louis to see David Talbot in London. After their brief visit with Talbot they depart into the night, an incensed Louis and his angry words filling Lest at with glee. The vampires eventually return to Armand and the rest of the vampires to their home in Florida, where they are reunited with their friends and family. They then return to New York to continue the story in the second book, Interview with the Vampire, which is due to be published in September. The third and fourth books will be published later this year, and the fifth and sixth will be released in October. The fifth book will be called The Vampire Queen and the Vampire King, and will be available in hardback and e-book. The sixth book, The Vampire King and The Vampire Princess, is expected to be released later in the year. It will be the first of a two-part series, with the first part focusing on the vampire queen Akasha and the twin sisters Maharet and her sister, Mekare. The last part of the series will focus on the vampires' relationship with each other, and on Akasha's plans to rule the world. It is also the first time the vampires have been seen in public since the first book was published. The book will also be the last of Anne Rice's Vampire Chronicles. The series will be made into two films, the second of which will be The Vampire Chronicles, which will air on September 25, 2014. The film will be directed by Stephen King and is based on the book's events. The movie will be based on a series of dreams about red-haired twin sisters, and a fact that a powerful being is killing vampires around the world by means of spontaneous combustion.

name: Gulliver's Travels
summary: Lemuel Gulliver's Travels is a satire on the Court of Lilliput. The book is written in the style of books of the time. It is the last book Swift wrote for the Travels. The author was in Anglican holy orders and was likely to make such comparisons in the book. Swift was attacking reason and the deism movement in this book, the last one he wrote for The Travels. It was published in 1699 and is considered one of the most famous books of all time. The last book of the Travels was written in 1710 and published in 1711. It has been translated into English as "The Travels of Lemuel GULLiver" and "Gulliver and the Travels of the Great Adventure" by William Makepeace Thackeray, with a preamble by Samuel Johnson, is published by Macmillan, priced £12.99. The original version of this article stated that the author had written the book between 1699-1702. We are happy to clarify that this is not the case, and that the book was written between 1698 and 1702, when the author was living in England. We apologise for any confusion this may have caused, and we have been asked to make clear that this was the case. We would like to make it clear that, in fact, the book is about Lemuel's first voyage, and not his second or third. We regret that we have used the term 'travelling box' to refer to the book, and have asked that it be referred to as a 'traveling box' for the sake of clarity. We also apologise for the use of the word 'box' in the title of the book; we would prefer to use the term ‘traveller’s box’. We hope that this has not been perceived as a derogatory term for Lemuel, as it is in fact the name of the travelling box, which is used by the author in the rest of the books. We apologize for the confusion this has caused, as we would like it to be understood that the word ‘box’ means ‘traveler’, not ‘voyage’ or ‘trip.’ We would also like to point out that the title ‘Travelling Box’ is not a reference to a book, but to a series of short stories written by Lemuel in the 17th century about his travels.

name: The Color Purple
summary: Celie, the protagonist and narrator, is a poor, uneducated, fourteen-year-old black girl living in the South. She starts writing letters to God because her father, Alphonso, beats and rapes her. Mr. Johnson has a mistress named Shug Avery, a sultry lounge singer whose photograph fascinates Celie. Celie finds herself infatuated with Shug and attracted to her sexually. Nettie becomes disillusioned with her missionary experience as she finds the Africans self-centered and obstinate. Based on Samuel’s story, Celie asks her adopted children to tell her how he feels about the Africans and how he wants them to feel about the U.S. The story ends with Celie asking her adopted kids how they feel about her and how they want her to react to their parents’ relationship with each other. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Penguin Random House, on November 14, 2013. The novel is published in hardback and e-book versions of the book are available for purchase on Amazon.com and other online retailers for about $20 to $25 (with free shipping and p&p). For more information on the book and to order your copy, visit www.simonandschulder.com or go to www.samuelandcorrine.com. For more on Celie's story, go to http://www.samaritans.org/celie-the-book-and-film-and the-movie-credits-celtic-dance-dancer-caltie-dancing-dancers-caelie-s-dances-drama-culling-the.html. For the full story, see http:// www.sundaytimes.com/2013/11/14/features/ccelie-crowned-best-fictional-girl-of-all-time/story/story.html#storylink=cpy. Also, for the full list of characters, see: http:/www.sndc/2013-11-14/stories/celia-clemente-danced-with-soul-daughters-celia-says-she-wants-to-kill-her-father-but-can't-do-it-because-she's-an-ugly-woman-who-has-a-secret past.

name: A Midsummer Night's Dream
summary: The play features three interlocking plots, connected by a celebration of the wedding of Duke Theseus of Athens and the Amazon queen, Hippolyta. It is set simultaneously in the woodland and in the realm of Fairyland, under the light of the moon. In the opening scene, Hermia refuses to follow her father's, Egeus, instructions to marry Demetrius, whom he has chosen for her. At that same time, Peter Quince and his fellow players gather to produce a stage play, "the most lamentable comedy and most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisbe", for the Duke and the Duchess. Nick Bottom, who is playing the main role ofPyramus, is over-enthusiastic and wants to dominate others by suggesting himself for the characters of Thisbe, the Lion, and PyramUS at the same time. He would also rather be a tyrant and recites some lines of Ercles. Meanwhile, Oberon, king of the fairies, and his queen, Titania, have come to the forest outside Athens. Oberon seeks to punish Titania's disobedience, so he calls for his mischievous court jester Puck or "Robin Goodfellow" to help him apply a magical juice from a flower called "love-in-idleness" He instructs Puck to retrieve the flower so that he can make Titania fall in love with the first thing she sees when waking up, which he is sure will be an animal of the forest. He says, "And ere I take this charm from off her sight, / As I can take it with another herb, / I'll make her render up her page to me." Titania tells Oberon that she plans to stay in the forest until she has attended Theseus and Hippolytta's wedding. When Bottom returns for his next lines, he transforms into a donkey. Determined to wait for his friends for his love, he begins to sing to Titania by singing to himself. Bottom is spotted by his friends and falls in love by Titania. The play ends in terror, much to Nick Bottom's confusion, since he hasn't felt a love for Titania since he was a child, and has to run in the other workmen screaming in terror in order to get to his friends' bower for their rehearsal. The next day, Nick Bottom and his friends venture into the forest to perform their play about Theseus' wedding.

name: The English Patient
summary: The historical backdrop for this novel is the Second World War in Northern Africa and Italy. Hana, a young Canadian Army nurse, lives in the abandoned Villa San Girolamo in Italy, which is filled with hidden, undetonated bombs. All she knows about her English patient is that he was burned beyond recognition in a plane crash before being taken to the hospital by a Bedouin tribe. The only possession that the patient has is a copy of Herodotus' histories that survived the fire. He has annotated these histories and is constantly remembering his explorations in the desert in great detail, but cannot state his own name. One day, while Hana is playing the piano, two British soldiers enter the villa. One of the soldiers is Kip, an Indian Sikh who has been trained as a sapper or combat engineer, specializing in bomb and ordnance disposal. Kip and the English Patient immediately become friends. Over time while Almásy divulges the details of his past, Kip becomes close to Hana. He becomes a part of a community again and begins to feel comfortable as a lover on the U.S. mainland. He also becomes a very skilled sapper at his job at Lord Suffolk's bomb disposal training facility in Westfield, New York. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £12.99 (hardback) and £16 ( paperback). It is available in English, French, Spanish, Italian, German, Italian and Spanish. It is published in hardback on November 14, 2013. It has been published in paperback by Simon and Schuster for the first time in the UK, with a suggested price of £10 (hardcover) of £11 ( paperback) and a hardback of £14.99 for the UK. It was published in the US on November 13, 2013, with an estimated price of $16 (hardcopy) and paperback of £15 (hard copy) £12 ( paperback and hardback) £11.99. It comes in paperback with a hardcover copy of the book’s first chapter, “The English Patient”, in which the patient tells his story to a group of British soldiers. The patient is, in fact, a Hungarian desert explorer who was part of the British cartography group. He chose, however, to erase his identity and nationality. He fell in love with Katharine Clifton, a British woman who accompanied the patient's desert exploration team. When World War II broke out in 1939, the members of the exploration team decided to pack up base camp, and Geoffrey Clifon offered to pick up the patient in his plane, and takes Katharine with him. Geoffrey turned around and crashes his plane in an effort to kill all three of them, revealing he had known about the affair. Geoffrey died immediately; Katharine survived, but was horribly injured.

name: Captains Courageous
summary: Harvey Cheyne is the son of a wealthy railroad magnate and his wife, who are over-indulgent parents in San Diego, California. Washed overboard from a transatlantic steamship and rescued by fishermen off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland, the young Harvey Cheyne cannot persuade them to take him quickly to port, nor convince them of his wealth. Through a series of trials and adventures, the youth learns to adjust to his rough new life and, with the help of his friend, the captain's son Dan Troop, he makes progress. Eventually, the schooner returns to port and Harvey wires his parents. They rush cross-country by their private rail car, given priority over commercial traffic, to Boston, Massachusetts. From there they go to the fishing town of Gloucester to find that their son has matured to become an industrious, serious and considerate young man. Harvey's father rewards Captain Troop by hiring his son Dan to work on his prestigious tea clipper fleet. He is delighted at his son's new maturity and their relationship improves, even as Harvey decides to begin his career with his father's shipping lines. The film was directed by Robert Altman and co-written by Edward Albee and George Curnow. The movie was released on September 14, 1998. It was released in hardback, paperback, and on Blu-ray. It is available in the U.S. and Canada, with a limited edition of 1,000 copies, and a limited run of 2,500 copies, both in hard-back and hard-cover versions of the book. For more information on how to order your copy of this book, visit the publisher's website, The Weinstein Company, or call the National Theatre Bookshop on 08457 90 90 90 or visit their website, www.theinventorbookshop.com. For the full version of this article, go to: http://www.npr.org/news/features/2013/09/08/13/harvey-cheyne-the-book-of-two-films-and-a-novel-about-a young-man-rescued-by-fishermen-in-netherlands-nearly-forgotten-fishing-town-of Gloucester-Massachusetts- and-then-receiving-a compensation-for-his rescue from the fisherman and rewarding him.

name: Ramayana
summary: Dasharatha was the king of Ayodhya. He had three queens and they are Kausalya, Kaikeyi and Sumitra. He was childless for a long time and, anxious to produce an heir, he performs a fire sacrifice known as Putra-Kameshti Yagya. Rama and Lakshmana receive instructions and supernatural weapons from Vishwamitra, and proceed to destroy the demons. The boys are reared as the princes of the realm, receiving instructions from the scriptures and in warfare. When news of these events reaches Ravana, he resolves to destroy Rama by capturing Sita with the aid of the rakshasa Maricha, assuming the form of a golden deer, and killing Rama with the help of his brother Khara. After Rama's departure, king Dasharatha, unable to bear the grief, passes away. Meanwhile, Bharata refuses to profit from his mother's wicked scheming and visits Rama in the forest. He requests Rama to return and rule. But Rama, determined to carry out his father's orders to the letter, refuses to return before the period of exile. But Bharata carries Ramas's sandals, and keeps them on the throne, while he rules as Rama’s regent. After the war, Rama gets married to Sita, Lakshman a to Urmila. Bharata to Mandavi and Shatrughan to Shrutakirti. The weddings are celebrated with great festivity at Mithila, and the marriage party returns to Ayod Pradesh. The king was in possession of an immensely heavy bow, presented to him by the God Shiva: whoever could wield the bow could marry Sita. Only Rama wields the bow and breaks it. When Sita was of marriageable age, the king decided to have a swayamvara which included a contest. The battle was won by Rama. He is then crowned king. The story ends with the marriage of Sita and Bharata, and Rama becomes king of the land of Kshatriya. The book was written by Ravi Agrawal, who is also the author of the epic novel, The God's Scepter, about the life and death of the Hindu god Vishnu. It was first published in 16th century India and has since been republished by the Boudhredi Publication Company.

name: The Forge of God
summary: The novel features scenes and events including the discovery of a near-dead alien in the desert, who clearly says in English, "I'm sorry, but there is bad news" There is another alien faction at work, however, represented on Earth by small spider-like robots that recruit human agents through some form of mind control. They frantically collect all the human data, biological records, tissue samples, seeds, and DNA from the biosphere that they can, and evacuate a handful of people from Earth. In space, this faction's machines combat and eventually destroy the attackers, though not before Earth's fate is sealed. The evacuees eventually settle a newly terraformed Mars. Some form the crew of a Ship of the Law to hunt down the home world of the killers, a quest described in the sequel, Anvil of Stars. One of the point of view characters is Arthur Gordon, a scientist who, with his wife Francine and son Martin is among those rescued from the destruction of Earth. Some other characters are close to an American president who fails to take action against the threat. The two books show at least one solution to the Fermi paradox, with electromagnetically noisy civilisations being snuffed out by the arrival of self-replicating machines designed to destroy any potential threat to their (possibly long-dead) creators. (A similar theme is explored in Fred Saberhagen's Berserkers novels.) The novels are both published by Simon & Schuster and are available in hardback and e-book. For more information on how to order a copy of the book, visit the publisher's website. For the full interview with the author, go to www.simonandschulder.com. for more details on the book and how to buy your copy of The Book Thief, or visit the website of the publisher, Simon & Schulder, for £16.99 (including p&p). For more on the Book Thief and the book Thief, visit the publisher's  website for £12.99. for the book. For a full list of all the books available on the publisher’s website, visit http://www.samaritans.co.uk/book-shaking/ The Book Shaker and The Book Thief and the Second Part of the Anvil of Stars are available in paperback and hardback, respectively.

name: Blood Music
summary: In the novel, renegade biotechnologist Vergil Ulam creates simple biological computers based on his own lymphocytes. Faced with orders from his nervous employer to destroy his work, he injects them into his own body, intending to smuggle the 'noocytes' (as he calls them) out of the company and work on them elsewhere. Inside Ulam's body, the noocytes multiply and evolve rapidly, altering their own genetic material and quickly becoming self-aware. The nanoscale civilization they construct soon begins to transform Ulam, then others. Through infection, conversion and assimilation of humans and other organisms the cells eventually aggregate most of the biosphere of North America into a region seven thousand kilometres wide. This civilization, which incorporates both the evolved noocytes and recently-assimilated conventional humans, is eventually forced to abandon the normal plane of existence in favor of one in which thought does not require a physical substrate. The book's structure is titled "inter-phase", "prophase",'metaphase', "anaphase", "telophase" and "interphase" This mirrors the major phases of cell cycle: interphase and mitosis. The reason for the noocyte's inability to remain in this reality is somewhat related to the strong anthropic principle. The noocytes' inability to stay in thisreality is somewhatrelated to theStrong anthropic Principle. The books structure is called "inter phase", " prophase," "metaphASE", " anaphase," "telophone" and 'interphase." This mirrors a major phase of the cell cycle, mitosis, which is called interphase. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (hardback) and £16 ( paperback). The book is available to pre-order now in hardback, with prices starting at £12.99. name: The World According to Garp
summary: The story deals with the life of T. S. Garp. His mother, Jenny Fields, is a strong-willed nurse who wants a child but not a husband. She encounters a dying ball turret gunner known only as Technical Sergeant Garp who was severely brain damaged in combat. Jenny nurses Garp, observing his infantile state and almost perpetual autonomic sexual arousal. She uses Garp's sexual response to impregnate herself, and names the resultant son after him "T. S." (standing only for "Technical Sergeant"). Jenny raises young Garp alone, taking a position at the all-boys school Steering School in New England. He grows up, becoming interested in sex, wrestling, and writing fiction—three topics in which his mother has little interest. After his graduation in 1961, his mother takes him to Vienna where he writes his first novella. After they return to Steering Garp marries Helen, the wrestling coach's daughter and founds his family, he a struggling writer, she a teacher of English. The publication of A Sexual Suspect makes his mother famous as she becomes a feminist icon as feminists view her book as a manifesto of a woman who does not care to bind herself to a man. She nurtures and supports women traumatized by men among them the Ellen Jamesians, a group of women who cut off their tongues in support of and named after an eleven-year-old girl whose tongue was cut off by her rapists to silence her. The book contains some motifs that appear in almost all John Irving novels: bears, wrestling,. Vienna, New England, people who are uninterested in having sex, and a complex Dickensian plot that spans the protagonist's whole life. Adultery (another common Irving motif) also plays a large part, culminating in one of the novel's most harrowing and memorable scenes. There is also a tincture of another familiar Irving trope, castration anxiety, most obvious in the lamentable fate of Michael Milton. The story is decidedly rich with (in the words of the fictional GARP's teacher, "lunacy and sorrow," and the sometimes ridiculous chains of events the characters experience still resonate with painful truth. The novel contains several framed narratives: Garp’s first novellas, The Pension Grillparzer; Vigilance, a short story; and the first chapter of his novel, The World According to Bensenhaver. GARP learns (often painfully) from the women in his life (including transsexual ex-football player Roberta Muldoon) struggling to become more tolerant in the face of intolerance.

name: Mutiny on the Bounty
summary: The novel tells the story through a fictional first-person narrator by the name of Roger Byam. Byam, although not one of the mutineers, remains with the Bounty after the mutiny. He subsequently returns to Tahiti, and is eventually arrested and taken back to England to face a court-martial. He and several other members of the crew are eventually acquitted. The novel is based on real-life crew member Peter Heywood, who was on the Bounty at the time of the incident in Tahiti in 1842. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschulder.com or www.thevictorybookshop.com. For information on how to buy a copy of the novel, go to www.samaritans.org or call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

name: The Mothman Prophecies
summary: The book combines Keel's account of his investigation into alleged sightings of a large, winged creature called Mothman in the vicinity of Point Pleasant, West Virginia, during 1966 and 1967 with his own theories about UFOs and various supernatural phenomena. It ultimately connects them to the December 15, 1967, collapse of the Silver Bridge across the Ohio River. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Simon&Schuster, which also published the first edition of "Mothman" in 1966. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschulte.com. for more information about the book and its author, visit http://www.samaritans.com/mothman-the-book-and-how-it-alleged-to-occur-in-West-Virginia-during-1966-1967-and the-collapse-of-the Silver Bridge in 1967.

name: The Memory of Earth
summary: Humanity has lived for 40 million years on a planet called Harmony. The Oversoul is a computer left as guardian of this planet. Its main mission was to prevent humans from developing technologies that could make wars a global affair. The first book focuses on the family's eventual betrayal, the taking of the Index, and the downfall of the man Gaballufix, who had been planning to ally the city of Basilica, the home of the main characters and the setting of the first half of the book, with a malignant nation. Nafai, Elemak and Mebbekew, his older half brothers, Issib and his father Volemak are eventually forced to leave the city. They come back to retrieve the Index of the Oversoul, which allows them to communicate with it directly. Through this they learn of the danger that it is in, and begin to try and defy its capability to override thought. Because of Nafa's careless blunders and miraculous successes, Nafia's oldest brother, begins to hate him, a theme that will play out throughout the rest of the saga. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, and is available now in hardback and e-book. For more information on the book or to order a copy, visit www.simonandschulder.com or go to www.bookshop.co.uk. For information on how to buy a copy of this book, visit the bookshop.com/sales/Nafai- and-Elemak- The-Book-Saga-By-Nafia. Movie, The Movie, the Movie, and The. The Film, the Film, The Music, the Music, The Film and the Movie. For the full movie version, visithttp://www.-bookshopping.com /the-film-the movie- The Movie. The movie-goers can also purchase the book on Amazon.com for $24.99. For a limited time only, you can buy the book for $19.99 in the US.

name: Sixth Column
summary: A top secret research facility hidden in the Colorado mountains is the last remaining outpost of the United States Army after its defeat by the PanAsians. The invaders are depicted as ruthless and cruel. The surviving scientists soon learn that they can selectively kill people by releasing the internal pressure of their cell membranes, among other things. Using this discovery they construct a race-selective weapon which will kill only Asians. They devise other uses for the awesome forces they have discovered, but how can a handful of men overthrow an occupation force that controls all communications and when it is a crime to print a word in English? The Americans set up a church of their own and begin acting as "Priests of Mota" (Mota is atom spelled backwards) in order to build a resistance movement. Major Ardmore, the protagonist of the book, refers to as the Sixth Column (as opposed to a traitorous fifth column) The book is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99. For more information on the book and to order a copy, go to www.simonandschuster.com or call the National Book Store at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.nationalbookstore.com/. For more on the film version of this article, visit www.nbc.com/2013/01/29/the-film-of-The-Film-Of-This-City-and-This City-And The Film-of This Land-And-The Movie-Of This-Land of The-City of_The City and TheFilm of The City of the City Of The City  Of The City, The Film Of The City, And The Film Of This City and The Movie of this Land, Also The Music of This Land Of the City,  The film is the City of The City of the City and the Movie Of  The City Of The Mountain, the Film of  The Mountain And the City of The People, as well as the Music and the Film  of this City. The film is based on a true story, and the film was directed by Robert Redford. The movie is scheduled to be released on October 31, 2013. For the full film version, visit the National Book Shop on October 30, 2013, at 9 p.m.

name: The Puppet Masters
summary: "Sam" is an agent in a secret U.S. government intelligence organization. He and another agent, Mary, are called in to investigate a report of a flying saucer landing in Iowa. They discover that the people are being brought under the mental control of repulsive, slug-like creatures that attach to their backs, just below the neck. They are unable to convince the President to stop a meticulously planned military counter-invasion of the heartland. Eventually the politicians realize the danger, and Sam and Mary are given leave. By this time, they have fallen in love and get married. Their idyll is interrupted when a slug takes over first his beloved pet cat, then Mary. Sam manages to push Mary onto a hot fire to kill the slug, leaving them both badly burned, but alive and free. For their part, the slugs drop all pretenses and openly wage war on their human hosts. A network of such interactions could spread rapidly among the invaders, who knew how valuable he is. Some scientists speculate that the slug is really just one organism in many bodies in many different bodies. The slugs are from Titan, the largest moon of Saturn. They can communicate by "direct conference", where they have him sit back and back to back and merge back to their hosts. They use animals such as horses, elephants, and even elephants as marked hosts. The slug is capable of fissioning in two fairly quickly. The number of infected humans must now be so large that any military action would kill tens of millions. The problem has reached a scale beyond their ability to influence it, and the problem has become a problem beyond their abilities to solve. It is revealed that the Old Man is Sam's father. The Old Man tracks Sam down and captures him, but Sam is able to escape. He is at first furious with Mary for entrapping him, and then with his boss, when he learns that his boss tricked Mary into it. He eventually becomes enslaved and escapes the agency. On a solo mission to Kansas City, Sam is shocked to discover the number of slugs is much greater than thought. Instead of taking over key people, they've absorbed the entire human population of the occupied territory. They have infected the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, whose department controls the President's personal security, and are a step away from infecting the President himself. By the time Sam recovers in hospital, anyone fully dressed is suspect. Sam is ready to quit, but when Mary volunteers, he gives in and does it himself.

name: Henry V
summary: The Chorus (a single actor) calls for a "Muse of fire" so that the actor playing King Henry can "[ā]ssume the port [bearing] of Mars" The early scenes deal with the embarkation of Henry's fleet for France, and include a real-life incident in which the Earl of Cambridge and two others plotted to assassinate Henry at Southampton. As with all of Shakespeare's serious plays, there are also a number of minor comic characters whose activities contrast with and sometimes comment on the main plot. The army also includes a Scot, an Irishman, an Englishman and Fluellen, a comically stereotyped Welsh soldier, whose name is an attempt at a phonetic rendition of "Llywelyn". The play also deals briefly with the death of Falstaff, Henry's estranged friend from the Henry IV plays, whom Henry remembers fondly. The action ends with the French king adopting Henry as his heir to the French throne and the prayer of the French queen "that English may as French, French Englishmen, receive each other, God speak this Amen" But before the curtain descends, the Chorus re-appears one more time and ruefully notes that Henry's own heir's "state, so many had the managing, that they lost France and made his England bleed" – a reminder of the tumultuous reign of Henry VI of England, which Shakespeare had previously brought to the stage in a trilogy of plays: Henry VI, Part 1, HenryVI, Part 2 and Henry VI,. Part 3. The Chorus appears again, seeking support for the English navy, and notes that "the ambassador from the French comes back / Tells Harry that the king doth offer him / Katherine his daughter." After the victory at Agincourt, Henry attempts to woo the French princess, Catherine of Valois. This is difficult because neither speaks the other's language well, but the humour of their mistakes actually helps achieve his aim. He agonizes about the moral burden of being king, noting that a king is only a man. Before the battle, Henry rallies his troops with the famous St. Crispin's Day Speech, referring to "we few, we happy few,. we band of brothers" The play ends with Henry's victory over the French and the end of the Hundred Years' War, with Henry as the new king of France. The play was first performed in London in 16th century, when Elizabethan stages did not use scenery.

name: The Wind in the Willows
summary: Mole, Rat and Badger are friends who live in the Wild Wood. Mole wants to meet Badger, but Rat refuses to take him, telling Mole to be patient and wait. Mole gets lost in the woods, sees many "evil faces" among the wood's less-welcoming denizens, succumbs to fright and panic and hides, trying to stay warm, amongst the sheltering roots of a tree. Rat, upon awakening and finding Mole gone, guesses his mission from the direction of Mole's tracks and, equipping himself with a pistol and a stout stick, goes in search, finding him as snow begins to fall in earnest. Badger learns from his visitors that Toad has crashed six cars, has been hospitalised three times, and has spent a fortune on fines. They resolve that once spring arrives they will make a plan to protect Toad from himself; they are, after all, his friends and are worried for his well-being. With the arrival of spring, Badger visits Mole and Rat to do something about Toad's self-destructive obsession. They decide to put Toad under house arrest, with themselves as the guards, until Toad changes his mind. Feozles the Water Rat at under house (who is on guard duty) and escapes. He steals a car, drives it recklessly and is sent to prison on a twenty-year sentence. Though he is sent back to prison, Toad is disguised as a Jailer's Daughter who helps him escape. He is pursued by the gullibility of his clothes and is pursued back upon being back upon his back. Meanwhile, Rat is cross with Rat for gullibility, but draw comfort from the fact that they need no longer waste their summer guarding their home in the hope that Toad may return in the summer. The three animals continue to live in Toad Hall in the hopes that Toad will return in summer. They hope that they will be able to help Toad return to his normal self. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99. It is available in hardback, paperback and e-book, and is available from Amazon.com. It has been published in the UK and the U.S. in paperback, with a run-up price of £12.99, plus a £2.99 p&p option for Kindle and P&P versions of the book, as well as a hardback version of the hardback with a £3.99 UK price.

name: The Hunting of the Snark
summary: The Baker recalls that his uncle once warned him that, though catching Snarks is all well and good, you must be careful. Along the way, the Butcher and Beaver -previously mutually wary for the Butcher's specialty in preparing beavers- become fast friends. The Barrister falls asleep and dreams of a court trial defended by the Snark, and the Banker loses his sanity after being attacked by a frumious Bandersnatch. At the end, the Baker calls out that he has found a Snark; but when the others arrive he has mysteriously disappeared. 'For the Snarks was a Boojum, you see', says the Baker, who had been hunting with his uncle, 'for his Snark was aBoojum' The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99 with a p&p of £12.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or www.hodgerandstroughton.com. For information on how to buy a copy of the book in the U.S., call the National Bookshop at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.nationalbookshop.com/. For more on the UK version of the novel, visit the National Theatre’s website at: www.nortv.org.uk. For the UK edition of this article, go to the National Library of England at:  “The Bookshop in the UK,” priced £14.99, ““”” ‘‘The Book of the World,’ ‘” ’’, ” ”, ’”"’"” and ‘The World of the Book’ – ”The Book Of The World” – “The World Of The Book”.”  “This is the World of The Book, The Book of The World, The World of The Book, the Book of the Book’.

name: Jonathan Livingston Seagull
summary: The book tells the story of Jonathan Livingston Seagull, a seagull who is bored with the daily squabbles over food. Seized by a passion for flight, he pushes himself, learning everything he can about flying, until finally his unwillingness to conform results in his expulsion from his flock. An outcast, he continues to learn, becoming increasingly pleased with his abilities as he leads an idyllic life. One day, Jonathan is met by two gulls who take him to a "higher plane of existence" in that there is no heaven but a better world found through perfection of knowledge. He discovers that his sheer tenacity and desire to learn make him "pretty well a one-in-a-million bird." In this new place, Jonathan befriends the wisest gull, Chiang, who takes him beyond his previous learning, teaching him how to move instantaneously to anywhere else in the Universe. In this other society, real respect emerges as a contrast of the coercive force that was keeping the former "Breakfast Flock" together. The learning process, linking the highly experienced teacher and the diligent student, is raised into almost sacred levels, suggesting that this may be the true relation between human and God. Because of this, each has been described as believing that human andGod, regardless of the all immense difference, are sharing something of great importance that can bind them together. In the third part of the book are the last words of Jonathan's teacher: "Keep working on love." Through his teachings, Jonathan understands that the spirit cannot be really free without the ability to forgive, and that the way to progress leads—for him, at least—through becoming a teacher, not just through working hard as a student. Jonathan returns to the Breakfast Flock to share his newly discovered ideals and the recent tremendous experience, ready for the difficult fight against the current rules of that society. The idea that the stronger can reach more by leaving weaker friends behind seems totally rejected. Hence, love, respect, and all seem to be important to the freedom from the pressure to obey the rules just accepted because they are just accepted. "Do you want to fly so much that you will forgive the Flock, and learn, and go back to them one day and work to help them know?" Jonathan asks his first student, Fletcher Lynd Segull, before getting into any further talks. "You have the freedom to be yourself, your true self, here and now, and nothing can stand in your way"

name: I Am Legend
summary: Main character is Robert Neville, apparently the sole survivor of a pandemic whose symptoms resemble vampirism. The narrative details Neville's daily life in Los Angeles as he attempts to comprehend, research, and possibly cure the disease, to which he is immune. Neville survives by barricading himself by sunset inside his house, further protected by garlic, mirrors, and crosses. After three years, Neville sees an apparently uninfected woman, Ruth, abroad in the daylight, and captures her. Ruth reluctantly allows him a blood sample but knocks him senseless when he realizes she is infected. Neville wakes in a prison where he is visited by Ruth, who informs him that she is a ranking member of the new society but, unlike the others, does not resent him. The infected have slowly overcome their disease until they can spend short periods of time in sunlight and are attempting to rebuild society. They fear and hate Neville who has destroyed some of their people along with the true vampires (dead bodies animated by the germ) during his daytime excursions against the latter. Neville goes to his prison window and sees all the infected waiting for his execution. He remarks to himself as he dies: "[I am] entering the unassailable fortress of superstition forever. I am legend", and then dies as a result of his injuries. "To them, he was an killer who moved by day, even as they hibernated as they were pre-infection times, he is now a remnant of old humanity, now a legend, and the new race of the infection born of the pandemic", he says. "I am a legend", he adds, "and I am entering theUnassailable Fortress of superstitious superstition, forever, to be a legend. To them they view him as to be invisible, in awe of him, and even as he kills their loved ones, he kills them as if they were vampires in pre- Infection times". "I Am A Legend" is out now on Blu-ray and DVD. It is implied that the pand epidemic was caused by a war, and that it was spread by dust storms in the cities and an explosion in the mosquito population. The vampires only come out at night and become comatose by day,. though they also sometimes come out earlier during cloudy weather. Neville discovers that the root of the disease in a strain of bacteria capable of infecting both deceased and living hosts. Neville also discovers more efficient means of killing the infected, other than just driving a stake into their hearts. This included exposing them to direct sunlight (which killed the bacteria) or inflicting deep wounds on their bodies.

name: The Stranger
summary: Meursault is a French man who kills an Arab man and is sentenced to death. He expresses no remorse or personal emotions for any of his actions in life. In the end, Meursault grasps the universe's indifference towards humankind (coming to terms with his execution with his rage) The novel is written in two parts, one for each of the two parts of Meursaults' life. It is set in Paris, France, in the 1970s and 1980s. The author is the son of a French woman who died in a car crash. He was raised by his father, who died of a heart attack, and his brother, who was also killed by a car accident. He is now living with his brother's ex-wife, Marie, and has a sexual relationship with her. He also has a relationship with his neighbour, Raymond Sintès, who he helps to take revenge on a Moorish girlfriend suspected of infidelity. He kills the girlfriend's brother and an Arab friend with a pistol he took from Raymond so that Raymond would not do anything rash. He then shoots the corpse four more times after a brief pause. He does not divulge to the reader any specific reason for his crime or emotions he experiences at the time, if any, aside from the fact that he was bothered by the heat and bright sunlight. In prison, while awaiting the execution of his death sentence by the guillotine, he meets with a chaplain, but rejects his proffered opportunity of turning to God, explaining that God is a waste of his time. He finally explodes in a rage, with a climactic outburst at the absurdity of his personal anguish at the meaning of his existence without respite. At the end of the book, he says: "As if that blind rage had washed me clean, for the first time, I opened myself to the benign indifference of the world. Finding myself in the night with stars and stars, that is so much so much more beautiful than the world." The book is published by Macmillan, priced £16.99, and is available in English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese. The first edition of the novel was published in France in 1973, and was republished in the U.S. in 1974. The second edition was released in the United States in 1978, and the third in the UK in 1979, with the option of an English translation of the first edition being included in the second edition.

name: The Man in the High Castle
summary: The Man in the High Castle contains a loose collection of characters. Some of them know each other, while others are connected in more indirect ways. Three characters guide their lives based on the I Ching. One of the core narrative elements (Operation Dandelion) is centred on a pre-emptive Nazi nuclear strike on the Japanese Home Islands. The initial plot device is used to show the initial difference of opinions in the novel, with the differing opinions being those being a real antique and a real person. The Grasshopper Lies Heavy to the plot and Heavy Lies To the plot is a plot device to show. the initial opinion of the novel is that the opinions of the main characters, Frank Frink and Juliana Frink, are not real. The novel is set in a post-World War II world in which the Third Reich and Imperial Japan became the resultant superpowers of their world and consequently embarked upon a Cold War. The main character, Frank, works for the Wyndham–Matson Corporation, which specializes in reproductions of pre-war Americana artifacts; he is fired for showing his temper. He is a secret Jew (né Fink) who hides to avoid extermination in a Nazi camp. He believes in the essential inferiority of the non-white races of the Asian and African races, but is very conscious of his image, often deliberating how his actions might appear to others. Frank's ex-wife, Juliana, is a judo instructor, who evolves throughout the rest of the book to her becoming a very central plot piece. She is also used throughout the book by a hired assassin. The book is written in the style of Vichy France and is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (including p&p) and £12.99 for the Kindle edition (with p&P). It is available in hardback and hardback versions from £14.99 and £15.99 in paperback. It is published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster and is available for pre-order from £13.99, including p &p, and shipping from £11.99. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, see www.samaritans.org for details. In the UK, call the National Suicide Prevention Line on 0800 555 111 or click here for details on how to get in.

name: Rocket Ship Galileo
summary: After World War II, three teenage boy rocket experimenters are recruited by the uncle of one of them. They refit a conventionally-powered surplus "mail rocket" to run on a thorium nuclear pile which boils zinc as a propellant. Upon completion of the modifications, they stock the rocket, which they name the Galileo, and take off for the Moon, taking approximately 11 days to arrive. After establishing a semi-permanent structure based on a Quonset hut, they claim the moon on behalf of the United Nations. They discover that there is a Nazi base on the Moon. They bomb it from their captured ship and land. One survivor is found, revived, and questioned. The boys also find evidence of an ancient lunar civilization, and postulate that the craters of the moon were formed not by impacts from space, but by nuclear bombs that destroyed the alien race. When the base's Nazi leader shoots the pilot in order to silence him, Cargraves convenes a trial and find him guilty of murder. He capitulates in the airlock and teaches them how to fly the Nazi spaceship back to Earth. They radio the location of the hidden base on Earth to the authorities, leading to its destruction; they return as heroes. They return to Earth as heroes after the base is destroyed by the U.S. government. The film was released on September 11, 2013. It is the 50th anniversary of the start of the Second World War, and the 100th birthday of the first World War. It has been described as one of the most successful science fiction films of the 20th century, with more than 100 million copies sold in the US alone. It was also the first film to be released in the UK, and has been nominated for numerous awards, including the BAFTA and the BAFTAs, as well as being nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture and BAFTA for Best Director. The movie was released in cinemas on September 14, 2013, and is available on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray for the first time on September 21, 2014, and on DVD on September 28, 2014. It will also be released on DVD in Australia on September 29, 2015, and in the United States on September 30, 2015. The UK release date for the film is September 27, 2016, but the US release date is September 31, 2016. For more information on how to order a copy of the film, visit the official website.

name: Space Cadet
summary: Matt Dodson, Oscar Jensen, and William Jarman join the Space Patrol in 2075. Their first real mission is to help search for a missing research vessel, the Pathfinder, in the Asteroid Belt. They find it, but all aboard are dead, the unlucky victims of a fast-moving meteor that punctured the ship when the armored outer airlock door was open. Dodson is initially disappointed when they are not treated as heroes—but then he realizes that what they accomplished was simply what was expected of Patrolmen. They soon find out why. These particular natives had never seen human beings before, until old classmate Burke showed up in a prospecting ship. He had taken the matriarch of the local clan hostage when she refused to give him permission to exploit a rich deposit of radioactive ores. The locals promptly attacked the ship and killed his crew, but Burke managed to send a message for help before being taken prisoner. With the help of the natives, the cadets recommission the ship to fly it back to (human) civilization at Venus's South Pole colony. The crew of the Astarte, the legendary first ship to set out for Venus over a century before and thought to have been lost en route, perished from disease. According to the log, the crew perished from Disease. The captain of the Aes Triplex transfers half the crew to the repaired Pathfinder so that they can take the ship back to Earth quickly. The remainder (including all three cadets) continue their patrol. They are sent to investigate an incident on Venus's surface. The lander touches down on a sinkhole, barely giving the crew enough time to get out before it disappears in the mud. Neither the lander nor Burke's ship is flightworthy. To their amazement, she takes the stranded humans to the carefully preserved Astarte and takes them to the South Pole, where they are reunited with Dodson and the other cadets. The story ends with the crew returning to Earth and returning to their normal lives. The film was directed by Robert Zemeckis and co-written by Mark O'Mara and David Walliams. The movie was released on September 25, 2075, and is available on Blu-ray and DVD. It is the first film in a series of three films. The second film is scheduled to be released on October 1, 2076. The third film will be released in 2077, and the fourth on October 2, 2078.

name: Between Planets
summary: Don Harvey was born in space, with one parent from Venus and the other from Earth. Harvey boards a shuttle to a space station orbiting the Earth. The station doubles as a transshipment terminus and a military base. Harvey gets caught up in the Venusian war of independence when the station is captured by the colonials. The spaceship to Mars has been confiscated, but he remains determined to get there, by way of Venus if necessary. The ring turns out to be carrying the secret of scientific breakthroughs resulting from archeological studies of an extict alien civilization on Mars. With Sir Isaac's assistance, it is used to secretly build an advanced spaceship that is much faster than any other vessel in existence. Harvey is recruited for its maiden voyage, manning a self-destruct mechanism, with strict orders to blow up the ship if it is in danger of being captured. Little David intercepts and defeats a group of warships on their way to Mars to crush the revolt there. Afterwards, Harvey is probably reunited with his parents, although the story ends before then. It is only later that he realizes that all deaths can be described as "heart failure," as he is told that his friend has died of " heart failure" The film was released on September 11, 2012. It was directed by Robert Zemeckis and co-written by Mark O'Mara and John Cusack. It has been rated PG-13 for sci-fi and PG-14 for mature themes. The film is about a young man who leaves his dude ranch high school on Earth to go to his scientist parents on Mars, but is later arrested by security forces. The story ends when Harvey is released and given his ring back, after it has been examined by a doctor. The movie is not available on DVD or Blu-ray, but it is available on Blu-Ray, DVD, and PC, and it is expected to be released on November 14, 2013. It will also be released in the UK on November 15, 2013, and the U.S. on November 16, 2014, and in Australia on November 17, 2015, and Europe on November 18, 2015. The UK release date for the film is November 18th, 2013 and the US release date is November 19th, 2014. The US release dates for the movie are November 19, 2015 and November 20th, 2016, and November 21st, 2016. The U.K. release dates have not yet been released for the UK release.

name: Starman Jones
summary: Max Jones works the family farm in the Ozark Mountains. With his father dead and his stepmother remarrying a man he detests, Max runs away from home, taking his uncle's astrogation manuals. Along the way, he finds a friendly face in hobo Sam Anderson, who later alludes to being a deserter from the Imperial Marines. Max signs on as a steward's mate third class, and then he absorbs the contents of the Stewards' Guild manual using his eidetic memory. The Asgard then departs for Halcyon, a human colony planet orbiting Nu Pegasi. When Max detects an error in his real-time calculations leading up to a "transition", neither the captain nor Assistant Astrogator Simes believe him and the ship winds up lost. They locate a habitable world, and the passengers become colonists. Vastly outnumbered by the hostile natives, the humans are forced to attempt a perilous return to known space by reversing the erroneous transition. However, it turns out the planet is already inhabited by intelligent centaurs. Max and Ellie are captured, but Ellie's pet is able to guide Sam and a rescue party to them. They escape, though Sam is killed covering their retreat. Upon his return, Max is informed that the captain has died, leaving Max as the only remaining astrogator. To add to his burdens, the remaining officers inform Max that he must take charge, as only an astrogators can be the captain. Max accepts this with mixed feelings, but looks forward to a new career. Max pays heavy fines for breaking guild regulations, but he becomes a member of the Astrogators Guild. He loses any chance for a relationship with Eldreth: she returns home to marry her boyfriend. Max is disappointed to find that he had not been named as an heir, but is returned his uncle’s substantial security deposit for his manuals. Max learns that Sam had tried to claim the deposit for himself. In a meeting with Hendrix, Max reluctantly admits to faking his record to get into space. In the end, Max accepts his role as captain and is promoted to the command deck. He also loses his relationship with Ellie, who returns home and marries her boyfriend, but she diplomatically lets him win a game of three-dimensional chess against her pet, an alien, semi-intelligent "spider puppy" that Max has befriended, and she challenges him to a game.

name: Podkayne of Mars
summary: The book is a first-person narrative in the form of Podkayne's diaries. Much of the description of the voyage is based on Heinlein's own experiences as a naval officer and world traveler. Heinlein anticipated, by over forty years, television ads in taxicabs (in the book, holographic), which have since been implemented in major cities worldwide. The story ends with a hint of hope for him, as he admits his responsibility for what happened to PodKayne — that he "mdash &fubbed it, mighty drymdash" & then describes his inability to cry and raise the fairy. In the original ending, Pod Kayne is killed. This did not please his publisher, who demanded and got a rewrite over the author's bitter objections. He also declared that the end "isn't real life, because in real life,. not everything happily ends." In the end they escape from the kidnappers to a safe distance that has been left behind, and he returns to rescue it. When the nuclear bomb that Clark leaves for the kidnapper blows up, PodkayNE is killed, shielding the young fairy with her body. In a letter to Lurton Blassingame, his literary agent, Heinlein complained that it would be like "revising Romeo and Juliet to let the young lovers live happily ever after." He changed the ending to one that would allow them to live happily after the end of the book. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book. It is published in the U.S. for the first time on September 11, 2013. The first edition was published on September 10, 1983. It has a run time of 1,000 pages. It was published in paperback on September 13, 1983, and is now being republished in hard-back for the 20th anniversary of the release of the first edition of "The Lord of the Flies" (with a paperback edition of 2,000 copies). The second edition will be released on September 14, 2013, and will be published in hardcover on September 15, 2013 (with the paperback version of the second edition available for the 30th anniversary. It will also be available in paperback in the UK on September 16, 2013 and the US on September 17, 2013 for the 40th birthday of the author. The novel is written in the style of a diary, written by Pod Kaye Fries, the daughter of Senator Tom Fries.

summary: Parisian fashion photographer, O, is blindfolded, chained, whipped, branded, pierced, made to wear a mask, and taught to be constantly available for oral, vaginal, and anal intercourse. Despite her harsh treatment, O grants permission beforehand for everything that occurs, and her permission is consistently sought. At the climax, O appears as a slave, nude but for an owl-like mask, before a large party of guests who treat her solely as an object. name: The Star Beast
summary: An ancestor of John Thomas Stuart XI brought the alien, long-lived Lummox home from an interstellar voyage. The articulate, sentient pet he inherited has gradually grown from the size of a collie pup to a ridable behemoth. A court orders it destroyed, and John Thomas considers selling it to a zoo. Meanwhile, representatives of an advanced, powerful and previously unknown alien race appear and demand the return of their lost child...or else. A friendly alien diplomat of a third species intimates that the threat is not an empty one. This gives the chief human negotiator the leverage he needs to avert the destruction of Earth. The recently married John and Betty accompany her back to her people as members of the human diplomatic mission. It is discovered that, from her viewpoint, the young Lumm Ox has been pursuing her only hobby and principal interest: the raising of John Thomases. She makes it clear that she intends to continue doing so. It isn't easy to conceal such a large creature. Eventually, the court tries to have Lumm Rox destroyed, but is unable to do so, much to LummOx's amusement. The film was released on September 14, 1998. It was directed by Robert Wise and co-written by John Lydon. It has been rated PG-13, with a rating of 8.5 out of 10. name: Dr. No
summary: After recovering from tetrodotoxin poisoning, James Bond is sent by his superior, M, on a "rest cure" to Jamaica. His task is to investigate the disappearance of Commander John Strangways, the head of MI6 Station J in Kingston, Jamaica, and his secretary. On his arrival in Jamaica, Bond soon realises that he is being watched, as his hotel room is searched, a basket of poisoned fruit is delivered to his room and a deadly centipede is placed in his bed while he is sleeping. With the help of old friend Quarrel, Bond visits Crab Key to establish if there is a connection between Strangway's disappearance and the activities of Dr. Julius No, a reclusive Chinese-German who runs a guano mine. Bond discovers that Dr. No is also working with the Russians and has built an elaborate underground facility from which he can sabotage American missile tests at nearby Cape Canaveral. He is kept under regular observation, suffering electric shocks, burns and an encounter with large poisonous spiders along the way. The ordeal ends in a fight against a captive giant squid, which Bond defeats by using improvised and stolen objects made into weapons. After his escape he encounters Honey from her ordeal where she had been pegged out to be eaten by crabs; the crabs ignored her and she had managed to make good her own escape. Bond kills No by taking over the guano-loading machine at the docks and diverting the Guano flow from it to bury the villain alive. Bond and Honey then escape from No's complex in the dragon buggy. There he meets Honeychile Rider, who visits the island to collect valuable shells. The pair are captured by No's men after Quar Rel is burned to death by the doctor's "dragon"– a flamethrowing armoured swamp buggy to keep away trespassers. After their escape, Bond encounters Honey who had been pinned out by crabs, but she had made good her escape and had been ignored by the crabs, who had ignored her. The film was released in UK cinemas on November 14, 1998. The UK release was delayed by a few days until December 8, 1998, and the UK release date was delayed again until December 14, 1999. name: The Andromeda Strain
summary: A military satellite returns to Earth with a deadly microorganism. The microbe mutates with each growth cycle, changing its biologic properties. A government-sponsored team, Wildfire, is created to combat the organism. Wildfire is hidden in a remote area near the fictional town of Flatrock, Nevada. The novel's epilogue reveals that a spacecraft, Andros V, was incinerated during atmospheric re-entry because Andromeda Strain ate the heat shield of Andros and caused it to burn up in the heat of the atmosphere. It is believed that Andromeda eventually migrated to the upper atmosphere, where the oxygen content is better, suiting its growth form. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, who also published the film version of the novel, "Andromeda", in 1998. The film version was released in Australia in 1998 and in the U.S. in 1999. It was released on Blu-ray and DVD in the United States on September 14, 2009. The movie is based on the novel by Neil Gaiman, who was also the author of "The Godfather" and "The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the Planet of the Apes" (1998). The film was directed by David Lean and co-written by Gaiman and Mark O'Mara. name: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
summary: Harry Dursley is an orphan after his parents are killed by Voldemort. He is placed in the care of his Muggle (non-wizard) uncle and aunt. He meets the Weasley family on the Hogwarts Express. Harry is accepted at Hogwarts and meets the Weasleys. He becomes friends with Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger. He also meets Draco Malfoy, who offers to advise him, but Harry dislikes his arrogance and prejudice. Harry becomes a firm friend of the two boys and sees Snape receiving medical attention for a bite on his leg. He wins the Golden Snitch for Gryffindor in his first Quidditch match. The novel is published in hardback and e-book, with a recommended price of £12.99 (including p&p) The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced at £8.95 (with p&P of £7.99). name: Down and Out in Paris and London
summary: From Chapter III to Chapter X, where the narrator obtains a job at "Hotel X," he describes his descent into poverty. He recounts his two-day experience without any food and tells of meeting Russian "Communists" who, he later concludes, on their disappearance, must be mere swindlers. In Chapter XXII, the narrator considers the life of a plongeur [a youth who had run away from home] He has been trapped by a routine which makes it impossible to have a holiday. He is no freer than if he were bought and sold, but still, he is better off than many manual workers, but he is still servile and servile, he says. The narrative is interspersed with anecdotes recounted by some of the minor characters, such as Valenti, an Italian waiter at an local restaurant. The narrator is not paid for ten days and is compelled to spend a night on a bench rather than face his landlady over the outstanding rent. He falls into a routine again and speaks of quite literally fighting for a place on the Paris Métro in order to reach the "cold, filthy kitchen&#34.; by seven. He has thought that all plongeurs would have thought that they would long ago be free, but that is not the case, he writes. He says he is no longer free, and his only thought is that he is only paid enough to keep him alive; his only holiday is the sack [a holiday is only a holiday]. He is not free, for he has thought he would have been free long ago, but they would not have thought they would be free. He writes: "I am no longer freer, for I am not free. I am trapped by the routine of a routine, which makes a holiday impossible, and I have been trapped for a holiday... I am no free, at all. I have not been free for a long, long time, but I am trying to be free." The book is published by Simon & Schuster, and is available in hardcover, paperback, and e-book. To order a copy of the book, go to http://www.simonandschulder.com/Paris/Paris-Quarter.html. To buy the book in the U.S. call 1-800-273-8255 or go to www.Simon & Schulder’s website, www.shelter.com.

name: The Last Man
summary: Lionel is the first-person narrative of a man living at the end of the 21st century. Mary Shelley states in the introduction that in 1818 she discovered a collection of prophetic writings painted on leaves by the Cumaean Sibyl. She has edited these writings into the current narrative. In 2092, while Lionel and Adrian attempt to return their lives to normality, the plague continues to spread across Europe and the Americas, and reports of a black sun cause panic. At first England is thought to be safe, but soon the plague reaches northland England, and Adrian flees, later dying alone amidst a stockpile of provisions in England. The few survivors decide to abandon England in search of an easier climate in America. Lionel receives a letter from Lucy Martin, who was unable to join the exiles because of her mother's illness, and exiles herself to America to join her mother. Lionel and Idris travel through a snowstorm to find her, but are forced to return to England because of the snow. The plague rages in Ireland and Scotland before invading England. Adrian raises a military force against the few survivors, but ultimately is able to resolve the situation peacefully. In the end, the survivors are able to return home to England, but not before the plague has spread across the world and killed off many of their loved ones. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99 (including p&p) and is available in hardback for £12.95 (with a p&P of £8.99). The novel is set in 2092 and is written in the first person by Lionel, who is the son of a friend of the king. Lionel's father was cast away because of his gambling. When the king leaves the throne, the monarchy come to an end and a republic is created. Lionel becomes close friends with Adrian, and Lionel becomes civilized and philosophical under Adrian's influence. Lord Raymond, who came to renown for his exploits in the war between Greece and Turkey, has returned to England. Raymond intends to marry Idris (with whom Lionel is in love) as a first step towards becoming king, with the help of the Countess. However, he ultimately chooses his love for Perdita over his ambition, and the two marry. Raymond resigns his position and leaves to rejoin the war in Greece, accompanied for a time by Adrian. Raymond's intention to enter Constantinople causes dissension and desertion amongst the army because of reports of the plague.

name: The Transmigration of Timothy Archer
summary: The novel is set in the late 1960s and 1970s. It is one of Dick's most overtly philosophical and intellectual works. The story is told in the first person by a single narrator: Angel Archer, Bishop Archer's daughter-in-law. The character of Bishop Archer is loosely based on the controversial, iconoclastic Episcopal Bishop James Pike, who in 1969 died of exposure while exploring the Judean Desert near the Dead Sea in the West Bank. Tim is already being investigated for his allegedly heretical views about the Zadokite scrolls, which reproduce some of Jesus Christ's statements about the world, but have been dated to the second century before the birth of Christ. Tim travels to Israel to investigate whether or not a psychotropic mushroom was associated with the resurrection, but his car stalls, he becomes disoriented, falls from a cliff, and dies in the desert. Angel agrees to care for Bill, in return for a rare record that Edgar Barefoot, a guru, offers her. On the houseboat, Angel is reunited with Bill, Kirsten's son who has schizophrenia. He claims to have Tim's reincarnated spirit within him, but is soon reinsitutionalised. Angel is sceptical about the efficacy of astrology, and believes that the unfolding existential situation of Tim and Kirsten is akin to Friedrich Schiller's German Romanticism era masterpiece, the Wallenstein trilogy (insofar as their credulity reflects the loss of rational belief in contemporary consensual reality). The three are told that Kirsten and Tim will die, as predicted, and also commits suicide after a barbiturate overdose. Angel may represent Dick's effort to prove he could create a rich and believable feminine voice. Dick's work was often criticized for its flat, stereotypical female characters, so Angel could represent his effort to create a richer, more believable female voice. The novel was published in paperback on November 25, 1980. It has been described as one of the best-selling novels of all time. It was published by Simon & Schuster, with a run-down edition of 2,000 copies. The book is available in hardback and hardback, priced between £16.99 and £24.99. name: Dirk Gently's Holistic Detective Agency
summary: Four billion years in Earth's past, a group of Salaxalans attempts to populate the earth. A mistake caused by their engineer causes their landing craft to explode. The ghost of the Salaxalan engineer roams the earth waiting to undo his mistake, watching human life develop and waiting to find a soul that it can possess. In the early 19th century, the ghost discovers Samuel Taylor Coleridge, and influences the writer to add a second section to "Kubla Khan" and alter parts of "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner" The ghost then begins seeking out someone whose hardship can be influenced by Colersidge's work. It later discovers that Professor Urban "Reg" Chronotis at St Cedd's possesses a time machine disguised as his quarters. In late 20th century the ghost influences Reg to use the time machine to perform a bit of trickery for a young child at the dinner, while the ghost lures another Electric Monk into Reg's quarters. The Monk then goes off to kill Wayforward Technologies II's CEO, Gordon Way, due to a misunderstanding. Theghost later tries to influence Richard MacDuff, a former student of Reg and current employee of Gordon Way. Richard discusses this with his former college friend Dirk Gently, who claims to be a "Holistic Detective" believing in the "fundamental interconnectedness of all things" They travel back, and ghost-possessed Michael, using a makeshift environmental suit, sets up to repair the damage to the landing craft. While they watch, Richard receives a call from Susan from the 20th Century on Reg's phone. Richard learns of Ross's murder, and Dirk quickly surmises the ghost's plan, which if successful will erase the formation of life on Earth. Realising Michael was influenced byColeridge's works, Dirk instructs Reg to take them to the 19th Century, allowing Dirk to interrupt the ghost and prevent the second part of "Kubsh Khan" from ever having been written. Upon arrival back in the 20ths century, Dirk, Richard, and Reg find humanity as they expect it but with very small, subtle changes. The first client was missing in the first place as a result of the first functions of their actions – adding a small amount for the finding of the lost cat, adding "saving the entire human race from extinction – no charge for the loss of the cat" – and the first client is added to the list of clients.

name: Dragonflight
summary: Dragonflight chronicles the story of Lessa, the sole survivor of the noble ruling family of Ruatha Hold on the northern continent of Pern. When the rest of her family is killed by a cruel usurper, Fax, she survives by disguising herself as a drudge. She uses her hereditary telepathic abilities to make others see her as far older and less attractive than she actually is. Lessa travels four hundred turns into the past to bring the five'missing' Weyrs forward to her present. She convinces the dragonriders of the five Weyrs to go with her to their future, and they use the Red Star as a guide to make smaller, less strenuous hops forward in time. This not only provides much needed skilled reinforcements in the battle against Thread, but explains how and why the 5 Weyrs were abandoned centuries before. The White Dragon is a sequel to Dragonflight, set in the same world and with a different cast of characters. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book. For more information on the book, or to order a copy, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk or go to www.santacruz.com/dragonflight/Dragonflight-Book-2-1-The-Black-Dragon-Black Dragon.
