name: The Diamond Age
summary: The protagonist in the story is Nell, a thete (or person without a tribe) living in the Leased Territories, a lowland slum belt on the artificial, diamondoid island of New Chusan. At the age of four, Nell receives a stolen copy of an interactive book, Young Lady's Illustrated Primer: a Propædeutic Enchiridion in which is told the tale of Princess Nell and her various friends, kin, associates. The story follows Nell's development under the tutelage of the Primer, and to a lesser degree, the lives of Elizabeth and Fiona, girls who receive similar books. "Diamond Age" is an extension of labels for archeological time periods that take central technological materials to define an entire era of human history, such as the Stone Age, the Bronze Age or the Iron Age. In the novel, a near future vision of our world, nanotechnology has developed precisely to this point, which enables the cheap production of diamond structures. If nanotechnology develops the ability to manipulate individual atoms at will, it will become possible to simply assemble diamond structures from carbon atoms, materials also known as diamondoids. The title can also be seen as a reference to the Gilded Age, a time of economic expansion roughly coinciding with the late Victorian era, and Queen Victoria's reign, the apex of which is often seen as her Diamond Jubilee. The most important quality to achieving an "interesting life" is deemed to be a subversive attitude towards the status quo. The Primer is intended to intellectually steer its reader toward a more interesting life, as defined by "Equity Lord" Alexander Chung-Sik Finkle-McGraw, and grow up to be an effective member of society. The text also includes fully narrated educational tales from the Primers database. Although The Diamond Age explores the role of technology and personal relationships in child development, its deeper and darker themes also probe the relative values of cultures (which Stephenson explores in his other novels as well) and the shortcomings in communication between them. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback, paperback and e-book. It is priced at £16.99 ($24.99) with a recommended reading age of 8.5 (including free shipping and p&p). For more information on the book and to order your copy, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk. For more details on the novel and its plot, visit the author's website.

name: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
summary: The story begins on Epiphany (6 January), 1482, the day of the Feast of Fools in Paris, France. Esmeralda, a beautiful Gypsy with a kind and generous heart, captures the hearts of many men, including those of Captain Phoebus and Pierre Gringoire. Quasimodo, a deformed hunchback who is the bell-ringer of Notre Dame, is introduced by his crowning as the Pope of Fool. Frollo is torn between his obsessive love and the rules of the church. He orders Qu asimodo to kidnap her, but the hunch back is suddenly captured by Phoibus and his guards who save EsmerALDa. F rollo betrays Esmerlda by handing her to the troops and watches while she is being hanged. When Frolla laughs during Esmerarda's hanging, Quasemodo pushes him from the heights of Notre Notre Dame to his death. Qu asmodo then goes to the vaults under the huge gibbet of Montfaucon, where it had been unceremoniously thrown after the execution, and eventually dies of starvation. About eighteen months later, the tomb is opened, and the skeletons are found. As someone tries to separate them, Qu asmsimodo's bones turn to dust, and his bones are found to have been turned to dust by the skeleton of his love, who had been killed by the king's men. The story ends with the skeletons being found and the bones of the two lovers being removed from the tomb and put in a new tomb, where they are buried together. The book was published in 1482 and has been translated into several languages, including English, German, Italian, and Spanish. It was first published in Paris by the magazine "Le Monde" and has since been republished in a number of editions, as well as in the United States and the UK, including the hardcover edition of the book "The Book of the Fools" (1962). The book is now available in hardback and hardback, with a limited edition of 1,000 copies, priced at $35.00. The first edition of this book sold in the U.S. was published by Simon & Schuster, with the option of a free hardback of the same name. The second edition has been published in the UK by Simon and Schuster and costs £20.00 ($30).

name: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
summary: Alice goes down a rabbit hole to find a curious hall with many locked doors of all sizes. She finds a key to a door too small for her to fit through, but through it she sees an attractive garden. She then discovers a bottle on a table labelled "DRINK ME", the contents of which cause her to shrink too small to reach the key which she has left on the table. A cake with "EAT ME" on it causes her to grow to such a tremendous size her head hits the ceiling. Alice becomes a guest at a "mad" tea party with the March Hare, the Hatter, and a very tired Dormouse. The characters give Alice many riddles and stories, including the famous 'Why is a raven like a raven?'. The Hatter reveals that they have all been punished by Time because they still still at 6 pm (pmtea time). Alice becomes tired of being insulted and she leaves the tea party claiming it was the stupidest tea party she had ever been to. Alice comes upon a mushroom and sits on it is a blue Caterpillar smoking a hookah. The Caterpillar questions Alice and she admits to her current identity crisis, compounded by her inability to remember a poem. She breaks off two pieces from the mushroom and uses the mushroom to reach a more appropriate height. The caterpillar tells Alice that one side of the mushroom will make her taller and the other side will making her shorter. Alice is given the baby by the Duchess and to her surprise, the baby turns into a pig. The Cheshire Cat appears in a tree, directing her to the Marchhare's house. He disappears but his grin remains behind to float on its own in the air prompting Alice to remark that she has often seen a cat without a grin but never a grin without a cat. Alice leaves the garden where she comes upon three roses standing on a white rose tree because she hates the Queen of Hearts because she stands on a red rose tree. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, with a print run of 1,200 copies at £15.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or the publisher's website, which is based on the novel's first publication in 1872, is called "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and is available in paperback and hardback. The novel is published in hardback with a cover price of £12.99 and a Kindle edition of £9.99 (with a Kindle version of £8.99).

name: Now Wait for Last Year
summary: Now Wait for Last Year is the story of Eric Sweetscent, an organ-transplant doctor who gets wrapped up in Earth-Lilistar politics. Set during a war between the 'Starmen (inhabitants of the planet Lilistar) and the Reegs, it is a sci-fi novel set in the mid-20th century. The story follows Sweets cent as he tries to find a cure for his wife's addiction to a new hallucinogenic drug, JJ-180. Each time he slips sideways into an alternate universe, he is sent to the future. Certain details in all universes seem to be moving in the same direction, therefore, information obtained from one world's future will most likely be applicable to another under the Molinari's time. However, no one can effectively change their own past or future and therefore no one is able to effectively change the past or the future of the alternate universe they are in. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, who are also releasing a sequel, Now Wait For Last Year: The Next Generation, in which the author returns to the present day to find out what has happened to his wife. The sequel is expected to be released later this year, with a release date to be announced at the end of the second book in the series. It will be available in hardback and e-book formats, with an expected release date of September 25, 2014. The novel is available for pre-order on Amazon.com, with prices starting at $24.99 (US) and $30 (UK) for the hard-back version and $40 (Australia) with the paperback version, and $50 (Europe) respectively. It is also available on Blu-ray and DVD, and will be released in the UK on September 26, 2014, and the U.S. on September 27, 2014 (both versions will be on the UK release date. The US release date for the UK version will be September 28, 2015 (the UK release dates for the US version are September 29, 2015 and the UK date is September 30, 2015. The UK release versions of the book are not available on the US release dates, but the UK releases will be the same as the US releases. The U.K. release dates are also the same, with the US releasing the UK versions at the same time as the UK. For more information on the book, visit www.samaritans.com.

name: The Magician's Nephew
summary: Two children, Digory Kirke and Polly Plummer, meet while playing in the adjacent gardens of a row of terraced houses. They decide to explore the attic connecting the houses, but take the wrong door and surprise Digory's Uncle Andrew in his study. Uncle Andrew tricks Polly into touching a yellow magic ring, causing her to vanish. Then he explains to Digory that he has been dabbling in magic, and that the rings allow travel between one world and another. He persuades Digory, effectively through blackmail, to take another yellow ring to follow wherever Polly has gone, and two green rings so that both can return. Digory finds himself transported to a sleepy woodland with an almost narcotic effect; he finds Polly nearby. The woodland is filled with pools, and each pool leads to a separate universe. They then find themselves in a desolate abandoned city of the ancient world of Charn. They stumble into a dark void that Jadis recognizes as a world not yet created. They all witness the creation of a new world by the lion Aslan, who brings various entities, stars, plants, and animals, into existence as he sings. Aslan confronts Digory with his responsibility for bringing Jad is into his young world, and tells Digory he must atone by helping to protect Narnia from her evil. As he prepares to leave he is shocked to see the witch has eaten one of the apples, thereby becoming immortal, and is now becoming her face. He has to resist his desire and find despair and find the apples for his mission, but finds himself in despair after he smells the apples and leaves them in a garden high in the mountains. He and Polly fly to a mountainside and plant an apple in the garden, and Digory and Polly leave the garden to fly to the mountains; Polly on him on the mountainside, and he flies to a higher garden. He finds a sign: Come in my gold gates or not at all or forbear for those who steal or those who climb my wall Shall find their heart. He flies to the mountain and finds the apples; he leaves to leave the mountain, but he is now in despair and finds himself becoming her immortal face, but now he is in despair. He leaves the mountain to fly back to the garden and plant the apples in this garden. The children realize the evil nature and attempt to flee, but she follows them back to England by clinging to them as they clutch their rings. She enslaves Uncle Andrew and orders him to fetch her a chariot.

name: The Patchwork Girl of Oz
summary: Ojo the Unlucky is a Munchkin boy who, devoted to life with his uncle Unc Nunkie in the wilderness, goes to see a neighboring "magician" and old friend of Unc’s, Dr. Pipt. While there they see a demonstration of the Pipt-made Powder of Life, which animates any object it touches. The remainder of this book is Ojo's quest through Oz to retrieve the five components of an antidote to the Liquid: a six-leaved clover found only in the Emerald City, three hairs from the tip of a Woozy's tail, a gill (a quarter of a pint) of water from a dark well, a drop of oil from a live man's body, and the left wing of a yellow butterfly. With the help of the patchwork girl Scraps, Bungle the Glass Cat, the Woozy, Dorothy, the Shaggy Man, the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman, Ojo gathers all of these supplies but the left Wing &mdash. The story is also a growth process for Ojo; he learns that luck is not a matter of who you are or what you have, but what you do; he is renamed "Ojo The Lucky," and so he appears in the following Oz books. The Wizard of Oz (one of the few allowed to lawfully practice magic in Oz) restores Unc Nunkerie and Dr.Pipt's wife to their former condition. The party returns to the Emerald city, where the Wizard of Dorothy restores Unc and Pipt's Wife to their original condition. Ojo the Lucky is the first of a series of books about Ojo, who is also known as Ojo "The Lucky" and Ojo" The Lucky" is also the name of a character in the Oz books, "The Wonderful Ojo," and "The Great Ojo", as well as the "Lucky" character in "The Little Red Riding Hood" and "Lonely Red Riding Red" The "Unlucky" series is the second in the "Oz" series, which is the third in the series of "O" series. The series is based on the book "The Lonesome Lion" by Mark O'Mara and is published by Simon & Schuster, with the last book being "The Big Red Lion" published in 2005. The "Lonesome Red Lion," by Marko Kinski, is the fourth in the Ojo series.

name: To Sail Beyond the Sunset
summary: Maureen Johnson Smith Long is a memoir by Robert Heinlein. Maureen is ostensibly recording the events of the book while being held in a future prison, awaiting her uncertain fate. She lives through, and gives her (sometimes contradictory) viewpoints on many events in other Heinlein stories, most notably the 1917 visit from the future by "Ted Bronson" (in actuality Lazarus Long) She is eventually rescued by Lazarus Long and other characters drawn from various novels in the ship "Gay Deceiver" (from The Number of the Beast) and united with her descendants in a massive group marriage in the settlement of Boondock, on the planet Tertius. She ends her memoir and the Lazarus Long saga with the phrase "And we all lived happily ever after". The book is a series of sexual ones, starting with Heinlein describing her as a young girl who, having just had her first sexual intercourse, is examined by her father, a doctor, and finds herself desiring him sexually. Her sexual life story then continues featuring various boys, her husband, ministers, other women's husbands, boyfriends, swinging sessions, and the adult Lazarus Long/Theodore Bronson. All of these are set against a history lesson of an alternate 20th century in which a variety of social and philosophical commentary is delivered. The book was published in 1982. It is the first of a planned two-part series, with the second to be released in October 2013. The series will be called "Maureen: The Book of Maureen" and will be published by Simon & Schuster, with a scheduled release date of October 25, 2013. For more information on the book, visit the book's website or the publisher, Simon &Schuster, or the author's website, The Simon and Schuster Foundation, or visit their website, www.simonandschulte.com/Maureen-The-Book-of-Maureen The Book of Maureen. The book of Maureen is also available in hardback, as well as in softback, paperback, and e-book versions. It was written by Maureen Johnson-Smith, who was born on July 4, 1882, in Kansas City, Missouri. She was married to Brian Smith, another member of the long-lived Howard Families, and her life until her accidental "death" in 1982, when she died in a car accident. She is survived by her daughter, a son, and a daughter-in-law.

name: Double Star
summary: The story centers on down-and-out actor Lawrence Smith (stage name Lorenzo Smythe, a.k.a. "The Great Lorenzo") A brilliant actor and mimic, he is down to his last coin when a spaceman hires him to double for a public figure. It is only when he is on his way to Mars that he finds out how deeply he has been deceived: he will have to impersonate one of the most prominent politicians in the solar system. In a retrospective conclusion set twenty-five years later, Lorenzo has 'become' Bonforte, suppressing his own identity permanently. At the end, Lorenzo looks back on his former life, including the prejudices he used to hold, commenting that they seem to him like they happened to someone else. The central political issue in the election is the granting of the vote to Martians in the human-dominated Solar System. The book is told in the first person, with most of the action taking place in the third-person. It was released in the U.S. on September 11, 2013. The UK release date is September 14, 2013, and the UK release dates are September 15, 2013 and September 16, 2013 respectively. It will be released in Europe on September 21, 2016, and elsewhere on September 22, 2016. The US release date will be September 23, 2017, and it will be in Australia the following day, September 24, 2017. The Australian release date, September 25, 2017 is the UK's release date and the European release date (September 26, 2017) is the European Release Date. The American release date for the book is September 28, 2018. The British release date of the book, September 29, 2018, is the American Release Date (September 28, 2017). The UK Release Date, September 30, 2018 is the Australian Release Date and the US Release Date is September 31, 2017 (the European Release date is also the European Day of Remembrance). name: Time for the Stars
summary: Long Range Foundation has built a dozen exploratory starships to search for habitable planets to colonize. Each starship has a much larger than necessary crew to maintain a more stable, long-term shipboard society. Some of the spacefaring twins, including the protagonist, are able to connect with the descendants of the Earthbound twins. The explorers return to an Earth they no longer recognize, and in most cases, no longer fit in. Tom, however, returns to marry his last telepathic partner, his own great-grandniece, who has been reading his mind since childhood. The ship visits several star systems. The last planet (Elysa) scouted proves to be particularly deadly. Unexpectedly intelligent and hostile natives capture and kill a large portion of the remaining crew. The reserve captain takes charge, but is unable to restore the morale of the devastated survivors. When he insists on continuing the mission rather than returning to Earth, the crew begins to consider mutiny. Shortly after he notifies Earth of the dire situation, they are surprised to hear a spaceship will rendezvous with them in less than a month and surmise it must be a more advanced LRF spaceship. Scientists on Earth have discovered faster-than-light travel, in part due to research into the nature of telepathy, and are collecting the remaining crews of the LRF torchships. Tom works with his niece, then his grandniece and finally his great-Grandniece. He returns to Earth with his wife, his daughter, and his son-in-law, who have been married for more than 30 years and have a son and a daughter- in-law who have also been married. The novel is about a group of teenagers who discover that some twins and triplets can communicate with each other telepathically. The process seems to be instantaneous and unweakened by distance, making it the only practical means of communication for ships traveling many light years away from Earth. However, the twin who remained behind ages faster and eventually the affinity between them is weakened to the point that they are no longer able to communicate easily. The book ends with Tom and Pat Bartlett on a mission to find the last habitable planet on which they have been scouted, the planet of Elysa. It is the first of a series of books about the Long Range Foundation. The second book is about the foundation's attempts to find habitable planets on the other side of the solar system.

name: Citizen of the Galaxy
summary: Thorby is a young slave boy on the planet Jubbul. He is adopted by an old beggar, Baslim the Cripple. Thorby is ultimately identified as Thor Bradley Rudbek, the long-lost heir of a very powerful family. He becomes a substantial shareholder in Rudbek and Associates, a large, sprawling interstellar business including one of the largest starship-manufacturing companies and the entire city of Rudbek (formerly Jackson Hole, Wyoming) Thorby abandons his dream as a member of the elite anti-slaver "X" Corps of the Hegemonic Guard. He resolves to fight the slave trade as the head of Rudek and Associates. He unexpectedly wins a proxy fight and assumes full control of the firm. He fires his stepdaughter Leda and takes over the company. He later becomes the leader of the Terran Hegemony, the dominant military power in the galaxy. He kills a slave-trader who tries to rob him of his inheritance. He also kills a pirate who tried to kill him. He eventually kills the pirate and takes control of his family's empire. He dies of a heart attack on the way back to Jubbul, where he had been taken by Baslim to live with him as a foster-father. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray. It is also available on Kindle and Nook, with a limited edition version of the book available for $25.99. The movie is available in hardback and softback, with the option to buy the book for $10.99 on Amazon and the Kindle version for $15.99 with the additional option of a $20.99 download. The film was released on September 14, 2013. It was directed by George R.R. Martin and co-written by Mark O'Mara. The screenplay was written by Michael R. Wilson and David Wojciechowski. The novel is based on a true story about a slave boy who was adopted by a beggar and later adopted by the captain of a Free Trader society. It has been adapted for the big screen by Simon and Schuster and has been released in a limited series of films, including "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings", "The Descendants", and "Tron: Rise of the Planet of the Apes," and "Jurassic Park"

name: Stranger in a Strange Land
summary: The story focuses on a human raised on Mars and his adaptation to, and understanding of, humans and their culture. It is portrayed as an amplified version of the consumerist and media-driven 20th-century U.S. Protagonist Valentine Michael Smith is the son of astronauts of the first expedition to the planet Mars. Smith was raised in the culture of the Martian natives, who possess full control over their minds and bodies. A second expedition some twenty years later brings Smith to Earth. Because he is heir to the fortunes of the entire exploration party, which includes several valuable inventions, Smith becomes a political pawn in government struggles. Eventually Smith begets a Martian-influenced "Church of All Worlds" combining elements of the Fosterite cult (especially the sexual aspects) with Western esotericism. The church is eventually besieged by Fosterites for practicingblasphemy, but Smith and his followers teleport to safety. With it and their new abilities, they will be able to re-organize human societies and cultures. Smith's methods will die out, leaving Homo superior Incidentally, this may save Earth from eventual destruction by the Martians, who we are told were responsible for the destruction of the Planet V. Smith attempted suicide after the horror of his own death, but was raised by the Fosterites and raised by a mob raised against him by the church. He later returns to his followers, later explaining to Jubal that his gigantic fortune has been bequhed to the Church and that it has been able to save him from an own death from his own suicide. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback, and e-book editions. The first edition of the book was published in May 1998. The second edition was released in May 1999. The third edition will be published in June 1999. It will be released in hardback, paperback and hardback. The fourth edition will come in hardbound, and will be available in paperback in July 1999, and the fifth edition in paperback on August 1, 1999. For more information on the book, visit the publisher's website. For the second edition, see the publisher’s website, which also publishes the book in hard-back and paperback versions of the books, as well as the paperback editions of the second and third editions of each of the novels. The paperback editions are also available in soft-back, hard-cover, and audiobook versions of both the first and third volumes.

name: Glory Road
summary: Evelyn Cyril "E.C." Gordon (also known as "Easy" and "Flash") has been recently discharged from an unnamed war in Southeast Asia. He is presented with a dilemma: follow up on a possible winning entry in the Irish Sweepstakes or respond to a newspaper ad which asks "Are you a coward?". He settles on the latter discovering it has been placed by Star, a stunningly gorgeous woman he had previously met on Île du Levant. Star informs him that he is the one to embark on a perilous quest to retrieve the Egg of the Phoenix. Shortly before the final quest for the Egg itself, Oscar and Star get married. The team then proceeds to enter the tower in which the Egg has been hidden, navigating a maze of illusions and optical tricks. Oscar scouts ahead and finds himself crossing swords with a fearsome foe who resembles Cyrano de Bergerac. He then defeats the final guardian of the Egg, known only as the "Never-Born", in a mental fight, and the party escapes with the Egg. The story ends as he is contacted by Rufo to set up another trip on the Glory Road, which is, by this point, revealed as an allegory for Life's Adventure. The Egg is a cybernetic device that contains the knowledge and experiences of most of her predecessors. Despite her youthful appearance, she is the mother of dozens of children, and has undergone special medical treatments that extend her life much longer than usual. She has Oscar unknowingly receive the same treatments. Initially, Oscar enjoys his new-found prestige and luxurious life as the husband of the empress of worlds across the Twenty Universes. However, as time goes on, he grows bored and feels out of place and useless. He returns to Earth, but has difficulty readjusting to his own world, despite having brought great wealth along with him. He begins to doubt his own sanity and whether the adventure even happened. It will be decades before she can complete the transfer of the knowledge held in the egg, so he must go alone. It is revealed that Star is actually theempress of many worlds—and Rufe's grandmother. She tells him he must leave; her world has no place or need for a hero of his stature. She also tells him that the Egg will be transferred to him, but he will need to wait decades before he can receive it. The film was released on September 14, 2013. It was released in the U.S. on September 15, 2013, and in the UK on September 16, 2013 and in Australia on September 17, 2013 respectively.

name: The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress
summary: In 2075, underground colonies are scattered across the Moon (Luna), of whom most inhabitants (called "Loonies") are criminals, political exiles, or descendants thereof. The total population is about three million, with men outnumbering women 2:1, so that polyandry is the norm. The story is narrated by Manuel Garcia "Mannie" O'Kelly-Davis, a computer technician who discovers that HOLMES IV has achieved self-awareness and has developed a sense of humor. The Loonies overcome military opposition and overthrow the Lunar Authority's Protector, called "the Warden." When Earth tries to reclaim the colony, the revolutionaries plan to use in defense a smaller duplicate of the electromagnetic catapult formerly used to export wheat. When Earth finally learns the truth, Luna declares its independence on July 4, 2076, the 300th anniversary of the United States' Declaration of Independence. (The title is an acronym for There Ain't No Such Thing As A Free Lunch!) The Federated Nations on Earth send armies to destroy the Lunar revolution; but these are vanquished, with great loss of life, by the revolutionaries. As a result, public opinion turns against the fledgling nation. A second attack destroys a secret catapult site in a secret location, with Mannie acting as its commander. When Mannie tries to speak to Mike, the latter replies that the latter's self- awareness has lost its self-consciousness. Mannie takes control of Mike and collapses and dies, but the latter takes control and continues to continue to continue its own self-aware life. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback, and e-book. The first edition of the book was published in May 1998. The second edition has been published in June 1998, and the third has been released in October 1998. It is the first edition to be published in hardback, and it is the second to be released in paperback in the U.S. (the third edition is in softcover). The fourth edition will be released on October 1, 1998. For more information on how to order a copy of this book, visit the publisher’s website, or go to http://www.simonandschuster.com/shop/the-book/The-Book-By-The-Authors-Collection/TheBook-by-The Authors-Collection-By The Authors-Companies-Collection.html.

name: I Will Fear No Evil
summary: The story takes place about 2015 AD, against a background of an overpopulated Earth. The dysfunctional society is clearly an attempt to extrapolate into the future the rapid social changes taking place in the U.S. during the 1960s. Ancient billionaire Johann Sebastian Bach Smith is dying, and wants to have his brain transplanted into a new body. For reasons never made clear, Eunice's personality continues to co-inhabit the body.Near the end of the book, a third personality, that of Joan's new husband, joins them by means that can only be explained via delusion, religion or mysticism, not science. The book was published in 1968. It is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Simon and Schuster Inc., and is available in hardback for $24.99 (with free shipping) and paperback for $28.99. It has been published in paperback and hardcover for $29.99, with free shipping for both paperback and paperback versions of both books. It is available on Amazon.com for $26.99 ($32.99 with no shipping). The book has been released in paperback in paperback, hardcover, and e-book for $23.99 (£19.99). It was published on August 1, 1998. It can be purchased on Amazon for $22.95 ($24.95) and on the Kindle for $19.95 (£16.95). It has not yet been released on CD or Blu-ray. It will be released on September 14, 1998, and it will be available on the Internet on the same day as the Blu-Ray version of this article. The Film Of The Movie, by Simon and Sculpture, is published on September 8, 2008, at 9:30 p.m. ET (GMT-0400GMT). The film is released on DVD on September 9, 2008.

name: The Cat Who Walks Through Walls
summary: Colonel Colin Campbell, living under a number of aliases including his pen name "Richard Ames" is joined by a beautiful and sophisticated lady, Gwendolyn Novak, who helps him flee to Luna with a bonsai maple and a would-be murderer. After escaping to the moon, Gwen refers to the now ancient Lunar Revolt and Mike (Mycroft), the self-aware computer responsible for the uprising's victory. Despite her claim that she was only a girl at the time, Campbell grows suspicious, and learns that she is a rejuvenation of the revolution's most prominent female leader. Still pursued by assassins, Campbell and Novak are rescued by an organization known as the Time Corps under the leadership of Lazarus Long. The Time Corps attempt to recruit Campbell for a special mission. Accepting only on Gwen's account, Campbell agrees to assist a team to retrieve the decommissioned Mike. The story ends with Campbell talking into a recorder (presumably the source of the first-person medium through which the story is told) reflecting on the mission and his relationship with Gwen. During the mission,. Gwen is grievously wounded and Campbell loses his foot again, though the time-travelers succeed in retrieving Mike. Campbell's frequent would- be assassins are revealed to be members of contemporary agencies also engaged in time manipulation who, for unknown reasons, do not want to see Mike rescued by the. Time Corps. Engaged in frequent time- travel, the Time. Corps has been responsible for changing various events in the past, creating an alternate universe with every time-line they disrupt. Mike's assistance is needed in order to accurately predict the conditions and following events in each of the new universes created. The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress is described in the book as being about Campbell's relationship with his girlfriend Gwen, as well as the events that led up to her death. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback, and e-book editions. For more information on how to order a copy of the book, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk/book/moon-is-a-harsh-mistress-in-the-world-of-colonel-colin-campbell-and-gwendolyn-novak-fleeing-lunar-rebellion-to-luna. For a limited time only, you can buy the book in the U.S. via Amazon.com.

name: Methuselah's Children
summary: The Howard Families derive from Ira Howard, who became rich in the California Gold Rush, but died young and childless. Fearing death, he left his money for the prolongation of human life, and the trustees of his will carried out his wishes by financially encouraging those with long-lived grandparents to marry and have children. While the Families have kept their existence secret, with the enlightened human society established under The Covenant, they decide to reveal themselves. Society refuses to believe the Howard Families simply 'chose their ancestors wisely', instead insisting they have developed a method to extend life. The Families are persecuted and interned. In the process of escaping, they are driven too near the Sun by military spacecraft. When they are a few minutes away from overheating, Heinlein invokes a deus ex machina: it turns out that one member of the Families, Andrew Jackson Libby, has managed to invent a device that removes inertia from any mass to which it is attached. Libby applies the device, and instantaneously, New Frontiers is accelerated by light-pressure from the Sun to nearly the speed of light. The families return to the Solar System seventy-five years after their original departure. To their surprise they find that on Earth great longevity is commonplace. Spurred on by the belief that there was a specific "technique" to the Howards' longevity, Earth's scientists developed a series of treatments that extended lifespans to several centuries. They are now free to return, and are even welcomed due to their discovery of faster than light travel. Thanks to humanity's increased lifespan, the Solar system is overcrowded; faster thanlight travel will allow emigrants to ease the population explosion. The first planet they discover has humanoid inhabitants who seem friendly and advanced - but they are merely domesticated animals belonging to the planet's true masters. The second planet is a lush environment with no predators and mild weather. Its inhabitants are part of a group mind with the mental ability to manipulate the environment on the genetic and molecular level. They have no independent personalities; anyone who joins the group mind ceases to exist as a unique individual. This becomes evident when Mary Sperling, second oldest of the families, who has always been fearful of death, joins theGroup mind in an attempt to become truly immortal. The Group mind, in a mistaken effort to be helpful, genetically modifies the first baby born on the planet into a new, alien form. He states that humans are what they are because they are individuals, and that they have no place on this world.

name: Life: A User's Manual
summary: A wealthy Englishman, Bartlebooth, devises a plan that will both occupy the remainder of his life and spend his entire fortune. He spends 10 years learning to paint watercolors under the tutelage of Valène, who also becomes a resident of 11 Rue Simon-Crubellier. Then, he embarks on a 20-year trip around the world with his loyal servant Smautf, painting a watercolor of a different port roughly every two weeks for a total of 500 paintings. Each painting is then sent back to France, where the paper is glued to a support board, and a carefully selected craftsman cuts it into a jigsaw puzzle. Upon his return, Bartlbooth spends his time solving each jigsaw, re-creating the scene. Ultimately, there would be nothing to show for 50 years of work: the project would leave absolutely no mark on the world. By 1975, Bart Lebooth is 16 months behind in his plans, and he dies while he is about to finish his 439th puzzle. Ironically, the last hole in the puzzle is in the shape of the letter X while the piece that he is holding is in a shape of a letter W. The painting is placed in a detergent solution until the colors dissolve, and the paper, blank except for the faint marks where it was cut and re-joined, is returned to Bartle booth. It is the last piece of art that he has left to show the world: the painting is put in a furnace locally instead of couriered back to the sea, for fear of those involved in the task betraying him. Bartle Booth is forced to change his plans and have the watercolor burned in the furnace locally rather than couriering it back to sea. He dies in 1975, and his last piece is the painting of the port where he was painted, exactly 20 years to the day after it was painted. He is buried in the same port as the painting he painted 20 years earlier, in the town of Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France, in front of a group of people who are also residents of 11 rue Simon- Crubelier. The final piece is a picture of the city of St. Germain, which was painted by a man named Georges Morellet, who is also a member of the same street. The picture is shown at the end of the film.

name: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz
summary: Dorothy is a young orphaned girl raised by her Uncle Henry and Aunt Em in the bleak landscape of a Kansas farm. She has a little black dog Toto, who is her sole source of happiness on the dry, gray prairies. One day the farmhouse, with Dorothy and Toto inside, is caught up in a cyclone and deposited in a field in Munchkin Country, the eastern quadrant of the Land of Oz. The falling house kills the evil ruler of the Munchkins, the Wicked Witch of the East. In order to return to Kansas, Dorothy will have to go to the "Emerald City" or "City of Emeralds" and ask the Wizard of Oz to help her. All four of the travelers believe that the Wizard can solve their troubles. The four are the first to ever successfully meet with the Wizard. The Wizard provides the Scarecrow with a head full of pins, the Cowardly Lion with a silk heart stuffed with sawdust, and the Tin Woodman with a lot of bran-new brains. Because of their faith in the Wizard, Dorothy and her friends meet the Wizard again, and he reveals himself to be an ordinary old man who had journeyed to Oz from Omaha long ago in a hot air balloon. The trip ends when Dorothy learns how to use the Golden Cap and summons the Winged Monkeys to carry her and her companions back to the Emerald City. When Dorothy and the Monkeys meet the sorceress Gayelette by the Wizard and the King of Oz again, he tries to put them off by putting them off in a corner of the throne room, but he accidentally tips over a screen and reveals the Wizard to be a man who has been longing to return home and be in a circus again since a circus circus again. The party finds many adventures on their journey together, including overcoming obstacles such as narrow pieces of the yellow brick road, vicious Kalidahs, a river and the Deadly Poppies. When the travelers arrive at the Emerald city, they are asked to wear green spectacles by the Guardian of the Gates as long as they remain in the city. When each traveler meets with theizard, he appears each time as someone or something different. To Dorothy, the Wizard is a giant head; the Scarerow sees a beautiful woman; the Tin woodman sees a ravenous beast; the Cowardsly Lion sees a ball of fire. The Wicked Witch. of the West rules over the western Winkie Country. The Winkies rejoice at being freed of the witch's tyranny, and they help to reassemble the scarecrow and the tin Woodman.

name: King Ottokar's Sceptre
summary: In Syldavia, the reigning King must possess the sceptre to rule or he will be forced to abdicate. Tintin has a hunch that a plot is afoot to steal the. sceptre of King Ottokar IV. In the wallet of one of the thieves he discovers papers that show. that the theft of the sceptr was just part of a major plan for a takeover of Syldavian. by their long-time political rival, Borduria. The plot is foiled when Snowy runs in with the scepte (which had fallen out of TintIn's pocket) and takes it back. The next day is St. Vladimir's Day and Tint in is made a. member of the Order of the Golden Pelican, the first non-Syldavians to receive such an honour. The pair of identical twins: Hector Alembick is one of a pair of twins of identical identical twins. The other is Alfred Alembicks, who left for SyldAvia in his place and was replaced with his brother Alfred, who was kidnapped and replaced by his brother-in-law. The Knight and the Knight is the only book in the series not to feature the Knight and Knight, who suffer a panic attack when flying with Thomson and Thompson. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £12.99. For more information on the book visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk/tintin-the-book-and-the. film-of-the same name. The film is also available on DVD and Blu-ray. The movie is available on Blu-Ray and DVD from £9.99, with the option to buy the book for £8.99 plus a £2.99 transfer fee for the DVD and a £3.99 add-on for the Blu- ray and DVD version of the film. The. film is available in cinemas across Europe and the U.S. and the UK from September 1, 2014, with a UK release date of September 2, 2014. The DVD is available to pre-order on Amazon.com from £7.99 and £10.99 for the UK and £11.99 in the UK. For the rest of the movie, go to http://www.amazon.com/The-Film-Of-The-Sceptre-And-The. Movie-Of The. Book-Of. The-Sovereigns-By-Tintin.

name: Wuthering Heights
summary: In 1801, Mr. Lockwood rents Thrushcross Grange in the north of England for peace and recuperation. He finds the inhabitants of Wuthering Heights to be a rather strange group: Mr. Heathcliff appears a gentleman but his mannerisms suggest otherwise; the reserved mistress of the house is in her mid-teens; and a young man appears to be one of the family, although he dresses and talks like a servant. Thirty years prior, the Earnshaw family lived on the moors. The children of the. family are the teenaged Hindley and his younger sister, Catherine. Hindley finds himself robbed of his. father's affections and becomes bitterly jealous of Heath.cliff. Catherine eventually returns to the Grange as a changed woman, looking and acting as a lady. She falls in love with HeathCliff, seeing him as a romantic hero. He encourages the infatuation, seeing it as a chance for revenge on Edgar, Hindley's gambling habits and Hareton's bad habits. After three years, the pair are married. Six months later, Edgar and Catherine run away, without a trace, and Catherine and Heathcl Cliff return to the farmhouse to live as a couple. They have a son, Hareton, but she dies before the year is out. This leads Hindley to descend into a life of drunkenness and waste. He eventually marries a woman named Frances and returns three years later, after Mr. Earnshaw dies. He becomes master of Wuthring Heights, and forces Heathcliffs to become a servant instead of a member of theFamily. He and Catherine have an argument with Nelly, which then spreads to Edgar who tries to leave. One day in August, while Hindley is absent, Edgar comes to visit Catherine and, before long, they declare themselves lovers. She says that she does not really love Edgar but HeathclIFF. She therefore plans to marry Edgar and use that position to help raise Heathcl Clifford's standing. When Hindley returns, he embraces her and embraces Isabella, who is not so keen on Edgar. He then runs away, leaving Catherine and Edgar behind. He returns six months later as a gentleman, having grown stronger and richer during his absence. Catherine is delighted to see him and is not keen to see Edgar, although Edgar is. She later explains that she had asked her to marry him and she had accepted. He swears vengeance on Hindley. When the Lintons visit the next day, he dresses up to impress her.

name: Jane Eyre
summary: Jane Eyre is an orphan living with her maternal uncle's family, the Reeds. Her aunt Sarah Reed does not like her and treats her worse than a servant. She is finally rescued when she is allowed to attend Lowood School for Girls. After six years as a student and two as a teacher, Jane decides to leave Lowood, like her friend and confidante Miss Temple. She advertises her services as a governess, and receives one reply. She takes the position, teaching Adele Varens, a young French girl. While Jane is walking one night to a nearby town, a horseman passes her. The horse slips on ice and throws the rider. She helps him to the horse. Later, back at the mansion she learns that this man is Edward Rochester, master of the house. He teases her, asking whether she bewitched his horse to make him fall. After returning to Thornfield, Jane broods over Mr Rochester's impending marriage to Blanche Ingram. As she prepares for her wedding, Jane sneaks into her savage-looking woman's room and rips her veil in two. Mr Rochester admits this is true, but that his father tricked him into the marriage for money. Once they were united, he discovered that he is still married to Bertha Mason’s sister. Mr Mason and a lawyer declare that Mr Rochester cannot marry Blanche because he cannot afford it. Mr. Rochester and Jane enjoy each other's company and spend many hours together. Odd things start to happen at the house, such as a strange laugh, a mysterious fire in Mr.hester's room, on which Jane throws water, and an attack on Rochester's house guest, Mr. Mason. Jane begins to communicate to her uncle John Eyre. But on midsummer evening, he proclaims his love for Jane and proclaims a midsummer love for Blanche. Jane leaves Thornfield Hall. She returns to Gateshead and remains there for a month caring for her dying aunt. Jane receives word that her aunt was calling for her, after being in much grief because her son has died. Mrs. Reed admits to telling her uncle that Jane had died of fever at Lowood. Jane's friend Helen Burns dies of consumption in her arms. Jane is comforted by her friend, Helen Burns, a caring teacher, who facilitates Jane's self-defense and writes to Mr Lloyd, whose reply agrees with Jane's. Mr Brocklehurst, the self-righteous clergyman who runs the school, brands her a liar and shames her.

name: Catch-22
summary: The development of the novel can be split into segments. The first (chapters 1–11) broadly follows the story fragmented between characters, but in a single chronological time in 1943. While the first five parts "sections" develop the novel in the present and through use of flash-backs, the novel significantly darkens in chapters 32–41. The horror begins with the attack on the undefended Italian mountain village, with the following chapters involving despair, disappearance in combat (Orr and Clevinger), disappearance caused by the army (Dunbar) or death (Nately, McWatt, Mudd, Kid Sampson, Dobbs, Chief White Halfoat and Hungry Joe) of most of Yossarian's friends. In Chapter 41, the full details of the gruesome death of Snowden are finally revealed, but the novel ends on an upbeat note with Yossarians learning of Orr's miraculous escape to Sweden and Yossary's pledge to follow him there. In the sixth and final part ( chapter 32 on) while remaining in the "present" time the novel takes a much darker turn and spends the remaining chapters focusing on the serious and brutal nature of war and life in general. The final chapter focuses on the rape and murder of Michaela, who represents pure innocence, in which the reader is shown the full effect of the horror of the events that have taken place in the first four and a half thirds of the book. Despite this, the book ends on a positive note with the reader being able to follow Orr to Sweden, where he has made a miraculous escape from the Gestapo and is now living a normal life. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book versions for £16.99 (with a suggested reading price of £12.99). The book is available to pre-order from the publisher's website and is expected to be released in paperback in September 2014. For more information on how to order a copy of this book, visit www.simonandschultz.co.uk or call the publisher on 1-800-273-8255 or visit the publisher’s website at http://www.samaritans.com/book-shop/ The book will be published in paperback on September 14, 2014, with a suggested shipping date of September 15, 2014. The paperback version will be released on September 20, 2014 (the day after the 70th anniversary of the Allied invasion of Normandy.

name: Robinson Crusoe
summary: Crusoe (the family name corrupted from the German name "Kreutznaer") sets sail from the Queen's Dock in Hull on a sea voyage in August 1651, against his parents' wishes. After a tumultuous journey where his ship is wrecked in a storm, his lust for the sea remains so strong that he sets out to sea again. This journey, too, ends in disaster as the ship is taken over by Salé pirates (the Salé Rovers) and Crusoe is enslaved by a Moor. Two years later, he escapes in a boat with a boy named Xury; a Captain of a Portuguese ship off the west coast of Africa rescues him. Years later, Crusoe joins an expedition to bring slaves from Africa but he is shipwrecked on an island (which he calls the Island of Despair) near the mouth of the Orinoco river on September 30, 1659. Only he and three animals, the captain's dog and two cats, survive the shipwreck. Overcoming his despair, he fetches arms, tools, and other supplies from the ship before it breaks apart and sinks. He builds a fenced-in habitat near a cave which he excavates. By making marks in a wooden cross, he creates a calendar. He hunts, grows barley and rice, dries grapes to make raisins, learns to make pottery, and raises goats. He also adopts a small parrot. He reads the Bible and becomes religious, thanking God for his fate in which nothing is missing but human society. He leaves the island 19 December 1686 and arrives in England on 11 June 1687. He learns that his family believed him dead; as a result, he was left nothing in his father's will. Crusoe departs for Lisbon to reclaim the profits of his estate in Brazil, which has granted him much wealth. In conclusion, he transports his wealth overland to England to avoid travelling by sea. On the way, he and Friday endure one last adventure together as they fight off famished wolves while crossing the Pyrenees. They endure one final adventure together, and, en route, they face off against famished Wolves. He dies on December 19, 1686, and leaves England on June 11, 1687; Friday accompanies him and, on the way back to England, they endure one more adventure together. The novel was published in 1687 and has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide.

name: King Lear
summary: King Lear decides to divide his realm among his three daughters. He offers the largest share to the one who loves him best. Goneril and Regan both proclaim in fulsome terms that they love him more than anything in the world. For Cordelia, there is nothing to compare her love to, nor words to properly express it; she speaks honestly but bluntly, which infuriates him. In his anger he disinherits her, and divides the kingdom between Regan and Gomeril. Lear is further enraged by Kent's protests, and banishes him from the country. Lear summons the Duke of Burgundy and the King of France, who have both proposed marriage to Cordelia. But Lear is half-mad and terribly embarrassed by his earlier follies. The two sisters take charge of Lear, whose madness slowly passes. He is now completely mad and rants that the whole world is corrupt and runs off to kill himself and his daughters. Kent leads Lear to the French army, which is accompanied by Cordelia and the two sisters. He insists that they fight the French invaders but not harm the French or Lear. He promises both sisters that he will not harm Cordelia or Lear or Albany. The sisters promise him that they will kill Albany and Cordelia if he does not kill them. Lear dies in a storm, accompanied by the mocking Fool. The Fool mocks Lear's misfortune, and Lear yields completely to his rage. He rushes out into a storm to rant against his ungrateful daughters, and Kent later follows to protect him. Lear meets Edgar, in the guise of a madman named Tom o' Bedlam, and babbles madly while Lear denounces his daughters, while Kent leads them all to shelter. Lear announces he will live alternately with Regan, and their husbands, the Dukes of Albany and Cornwall respectively. He reserves to himself a retinue of one hundred knights, to be supported by his sisters. Lear discovers that now that Gonerill has power, she no longer respects him, and she orders him to behave better and reduces his retinues. Lear then meets Oswald at Gloucester's home, quarrels with him and is put in the stocks by regan and her husband Cornwall. When Lear arrives, he objects, but Regan takes the same line and echoes Regan. Regan kills the servant, and tells Gloucester that Edmund betrayed him; then she turns him out to wander the heath too. Gloucester is completely taken in.

name: Clear and Present Danger
summary: U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Panache intercepts a yacht in the Caribbean Sea. The crew discovers two men cleaning up the vessel after murdering a man and his family. It is later learned that the murdered man was involved in a money laundering scheme. The President of the United States, who is running for re-election, feels compelled to take drastic measures against drug trafficking. The president initiates covert operations within Colombia and a step-up of operations against aircraft believed to be distributing narcotics. The plan consists of four operations: *Operation CAPER is the interception of mobile phone communications between cartel management. *Operation EAGLE EYE uses F-15 Eagles to intercept drug flights. * Operation RECIPROCITY involves using ground-attack aircraft and laser-guided bombs to attack cartel locations discovered by intercepts.  Félix Cortez, a former intelligence officer from Cuba employed by the cartel, feigns romantic interest in the aide of Emil Jacobs, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Cortez plans to engineer a war within the cartel that will leave him in a position to seize power, and blackmails Cutter into ending SHOWBOAT, promising the intra-cartel war will slow drug imports to the States. soldiers are all Hispanic in order to blend in with the local population. Jack Ryan suspects the CIA's involvement in the situation in Colombia. Ryan realizes that the president has more honor and dignity than he originally thought he did. After Ryan briefs the president, the president deliberately loses the election in a bid to hide the covert operations and protect the honor of those involved in the operation. Due to the damage and damage to the helicopter, they land on the Panache Cortez is returned to Cuba, where he is marked as a traitor. Despite his suicide, Ryan confronts the defiant president, informing him that classifying the drug cartel as a "clear and present danger," Ryan must brief Congress over the illegal operations over the cartel. The film ends with Ryan telling the president that he must "clear" the cartel and "clear the U.S." over the drug cartels as a classifying drug cartel and clear him as a 'clear and Present Danger' The film was released on September 11, 2013. The movie is based on a true story that took place in Colombia in the early 1990s. It was directed by Michael O'Neill and written by Michael Douglas Rushkoff. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Random House.

name: Castle Rackrent
summary: The novel is set prior to the Constitution of 1782 and tells the story of four generations of Rackrent heirs through their steward, Thady Quirk. The heirs are: the dissipated spendthrift Sir Patrick O'Shaughlin, the litigious Sir Murtagh Rackrent, the cruel husband and gambling absentee Sir Kit Stopgap, and the generous but improvident Sir Condy Rackrent. Their sequential mismanagement of the estate is resolved through the machinations - and to the benefit - of the narrator's astute son, Jason Quirk, the novel's main character. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99 and is published in hardback at £12.99. For more information on the novel, visit www.simonandschulder.com or go to www.thestar.co.uk/books/the-book-of-the-month. For information on The Book of the Month, go to The Book Of The Month, by Simon and Schulder at £14.99, or for more information about the Book of The month, visit The Book Club, by The Star, at £11.95, or the Book Club at £9.99,.

name: Julius Caesar
summary: Marcus Brutus is Caesar's close friend and a Roman praetor. Brutus allows himself to be cajoled into joining a group of conspiring senators because of a growing suspicion that Caesar intends to turn republican Rome into a monarchy under his own rule. The early scenes deal mainly with Brutus's arguments with Cassius and his struggle with his own conscience. Caesar's assassination is one of the most famous scenes of the play, occurring in Act 3 (the other is Mark Antony's oration "Friends, Romans, countrymen".) After Caesar's death, Brutus delivers an oration defending his actions, and for the moment, the crowd is on his side. The play ends with a tribute to Brutus by Antony, who proclaims that Brutus has remained "the noblest Roman of them all" because he was the only conspirator who acted for the good of Rome. There is then a small hint at the friction between Antony and Octavius which will characterise another of Shakespeare's Roman plays, Antony & Cleopatra, in Act 4. The beginning of Act Four is marked by the quarrel scene, where Brutus attacks Cassius for soiling the noble act of regicide by accepting bribes. During the battle, Cassius commits suicide after hearing of the capture of his best friend, Titinius. After Tit inius, who wasn't really captured, sees Cassius's corpse, he commits suicide. The two are reconciled; they prepare for war with Mark AntONY and Caesar's adopted son, Octavian (Shakespeare's spelling:Octavius). That night, Cassian and Brutus knowing they will probably both die, smile their last smiles to each other and hold hands. With a heavy heart, Brutu battles again the next day. He loses and commits suicide, but his victory is not conclusive. Shakespeare has him add, "Then fall, Caesar," suggesting that Caesar did not want to survive such treachery. The conspirators make clear that they committed this act for Rome, not for their own purposes and do not attempt to flee the scene. The innocent poet, Cinna, is confused with the conspirator Lucius CInna and is murdered by the mob. In Act 4, the innocent poet is mistaken for the conspirators and is killed by the mobs. In the end, the mob rouses the mob to drive the conspirates from Rome. The plot is revealed to have been a ruse.

name: Emma
summary: Emma Woodhouse, aged 20 at the start of the novel, is a young, beautiful, witty, and privileged woman in Regency England. She lives on the fictional estate of Hartfield in Surrey in the village of Highbury with her elderly widowed father, a hypochondriac who is excessively concerned for the health and safety of his loved ones. As the novel opens, Emma has just attended the wedding of Miss Taylor, her best friend and former governess. Having introduced Miss Taylor to her future husband, Mr. Weston, Emma takes credit for their marriage, and decides that she rather likes matchmaking. Emma tries to match her new friend Harriet Smith, a sweet, pretty, but none-too-bright parlour boarder of seventeen, to Mr. Elton, the local vicar. Emma's schemes go awry when Mr Elton fancies Emma is in love with him and proposes to her. After Emma rejects him, he leaves for a while for a sojourn in Bath, and Harriet fancies herself heartbroken. Emma feels dreadful about misleading Harriet and resolves—briefly—to interfere less in people's lives. An interesting development is the arrival in the neighbourhood of the handsome and charming Frank Churchill, Mr Weston's son, who had been given to his deceased wife's wealthy brother and his wife, the Churchills, to raise. The whole neighborhood takes a fancy to him, with the partial exception of Mr. Knightley, who becomes uncharacteristically grumpy whenever his name is mentioned and suggests to Emma that while Frank is clever and engaging, he is also a rather shallow character. Emma begins to feel some sympathy for Jane Fairfax, the orphaned niece of Emma's impoverished neighbour, the talkative Miss Bates, who lives with her deaf, widowed mother. Jane, very gifted musically, is Miss Bates' pride and joy; Emma envies her talent, and although she has known Jane all her life, has never warmed to her personally. Emma imagines Jane's sudden return to Highbury and imagines that she will find her ideal governess under her wing. But Miss Campbell has married, and Jane has returned to her relations, ostensibly to regain her health and earn her penniless. Emma is annoyed to find the entire neighborhood in Highbury's sudden and mysterious return to Miss Campbell's house, including Mrs Weston and Mr Knightley. Mrs Weston, singing Jane's praises, but when Mrs. Weston's singing praises, sings Jane's own praises.

name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
summary: The story revolves around a poor young boy named Charlie Bucket born to a penniless, starving family. Charlie is fascinated by the universally-celebrated candy factory located in his hometown owned by famous chocolatier Willy Wonka. Charlie longs for chocolate to satisfy his hunger and to find a Golden Ticket himself, but his chances are slim. The four eliminated children do receive their lifetime supplies of chocolate but leave the factory as: thin (Augustus), purple (Violet), covered in trash (Veruca), and overstretched to ten feet (Mike). Charlie, the only child who has not been eliminated, has won the contest and the legendary prize mentioned before as a result. The film was released on November 14, 2013. It is the 50th anniversary of the release of The Wizard of Oz, the first film in the Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part II series. The movie was directed by Harry Potter co-creator Tom Hanks and is based on the novel by Roald Dahl. It has been released on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray in the U.S. and on DVD in the UK on November 25, 2013 and November 26, 2013 in the United Kingdom. It will be released in Australia on November 27, 2014 and November 28, 2014 in Australia and the United States on November 29, 2014, and November 30, 2015 in Europe and the UK. The U.K. release date is November 30. The UK release date will be November 30th, 2014. The US release date has been November 29th, 2015, and it will be available in Australia, Canada, and the Netherlands on November 28th, 2016, and October 29, 2016. The Australian release date and the US release dates have not yet been announced, but they are expected to be announced in the near future. The release date for the UK version of the film is November 28 and 29, 2015. The American release date, November 30 and October 30, 2016 will be the 30th and 31st, respectively, for the Australian release and the European release of the movie "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" The film is directed by Heston Blumenthal and is written by David Walliams. It was originally released in 1998 and has been adapted for the big screen in 2010. The story is about a young boy who discovers a Goldenticket in a chocolate bar. The discovery of the Golden Ticket grants the owner a lifetime supply of chocolate and access to the factory's secret recipes.

name: Anne of Green Gables
summary: Anne Shirley is a book about a young orphan from fictional community of Bolingbroke, Nova Scotia. She is sent to Prince Edward Island after a childhood spent in strangers' homes and orphanages. Anne is described as bright and quick, eager to please, talkative, and extremely imaginative. At 16, Anne goes to Queen's Academy to earn a teaching license, along with Gilbert, Ruby, Josie, Jane and several other students. She obtains her license in one year instead of the usual two, and wins the Avery Scholarship for the top student in English. She plans to pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree at the fictional Redmond College (based on the real Dalhousie University) on the mainland in Nova Scotia, and return to Green Gables on weekends. In an act of friendship, Gilbert Blythe gives up his teaching position at the Avonlea School to work at White Sands School instead. After this kind act, Anne and Gilbert's friendship is cemented, and Anne looks forward to the next "bend in the road." Near the end of the book, Matthew dies of a heart attack after learning that all of his and Marilla's money has been lost in a bank failure. Anne realizes she feels sorry about the events and no longer hates Gilbert, but cannot bring herself to admit it; by the end, they finally become friends. The book also follows Anne's adventures in quiet, old-fashioned AvonLEa. Episodes include her play time with friends (Diana, Jane Andrews and Ruby Gillis), her run-ins with the unpleasant Pye sisters (Gertie and Josie), and domestic mishaps such as dyeing her hair green (while intending to dye it black), or accidentally getting Diana drunk (by giving her what she thinks is raspberry cordial but is currant wine). At sixteen, Anne gives up the Avery scholarship to stay at home and help Marilla, whose eyesight is diminishing. Out of devotion to Marilla and Green Gable, Anne plans to teach at the Carmody school, the nearest school available, and returning to GreenGables on weekend. Anne says that they are 'kindred spirits' and that Matthew falls for her immediately. Anne and Matthew are best friends, and Matthew is the love of Anne's life. They live at Green Gabled, their AvonLea farmhouse on PrinceEdward Island. They also have a daughter, Lucy, and a son, Matthew.

name: The Wasp Factory
summary: The Wasp Factory is a huge clock face encased in a glass box and salvaged from the local dump. Behind each of the 12 numerals is a trap which leads to a different ritual death (for example burning, crushing, or drowning in Frank's urine) for the wasp that Frank puts into the hole at the center within tubes. There are also Sacrifice Poles, upon which hang the bodies and heads of larger animals, such as seagulls, that Frank has killed. They define and 'protect' the borders of Frank's territory - the island upon which he lives with his father. Frank is haunted by an accident which resulted in the loss of his genitalia, and resents others for his impotence, particularly women. Frank's older brother Eric is in an insane asylum after being arrested for brutalizing the town's dogs. He escapes at the start of the novel and throughout the book rings Frank from phone boxes to inform Frank of his progress back to the island. Their conversations invariably end badly, with Eric exploding in fits of rage. After confronting his father, Frank finds out that he is in fact female, and that when he thought he was castrated by a dog mauling at an early age, Frank's father had simply pumped her full of male hormones to see if she would transition from female to male. The father said it was simply "an experiment" and there are hints it was in order to distance himself from the women he felt had ruined his life. Frank remembers his older brother as being extremely sensitive before "the incident" that drove him mad: a tragic case of neglect in a hospital where Eric was a volunteer. He checks the usually-alert patient's head dressings to find the child's exposed brain tissue infested with day-old maggots. He is confused as to whether or not he is looking forward to seeing Eric, but it is clear Frank loves his brother dearly. Other than that, Frank has almost no contact with the outside world and admits he is afraid of it due to what it did to his brother, Eric. At the end of the book, Eric's imminent return precipitates a series of events that result in Frank discovering male hormone drugs in his father's study. The book ends with Frank discovering that his father had pumped his daughter with male hormones in an attempt to 'distance himself from women' and that he had been trying to 'turn her into a man' The book is published by Simon & Schuster.

name: Espedair Street
summary: Weir starts out in the Ferguslie Park area of Paisley in a very underprivileged Catholic family. He is impressed by a group named Frozen Gold when he sees them live, and auditions with them. Christine Brice likes his songs, and he joins the band. He ends up writing all their material and playing bass guitar, (after trying unsuccessfully to get them to change their name) as the band rises in the drug- and booze-fuelled rock and roll of the 1970s. He has grown uncomfortable with fame and wealth, and eventually visits his first girlfriend, Jean Webb, now living in Arisaig. In the Three Chimneys tour, singer Davey Balfour takes Dan along on an attempt to break an unofficial (and illegal) speed record for flying around three power station chimneys in Kent in his private plane. He reminisces about this from 1980s Glasgow, where he lives as a recluse in a Victorian folly (St Jutes), ever since the tragic events which led to the demise of the group. After a memorable fight in a nightclub called 'Monty&s&#39%;, his real identity is revealed as Jimmy Hay. He then visits his former girlfriend Jean Webb and finds out that she is now living with her new partner in Scotland. He also visits his ex-wife Jean Webb in Scotland, and learns that she has remarried and has a son. The final chapter of the book is about Weir's decision to stay alive and to try and explain what he has gone through in the last two days. He says: "Two days ago I decided to kill myself. Last night I changed my mind and decided to stay Alive" The book is published by Simon & Schuster. For more information, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk and www.samaritans.org. For the full interview with Weir, visit the official website of Simon and Schuster’s new album, ‘The Book Of Love’, which is out now in paperback and on CD. To order a copy of this edition of The Book of Love, call the Mail Online newsdesk on 08457 90 90 90, or visit their website, www.mailonline.com/book-of-love-the-book-and-shop. To buy the book in the UK, visit a local branch of the British Bookshop, or click here.

name: The Crow Road
summary: This Bildungsroman is set in the fictional Argyll town of Gallanach and the real village of Lochgair. Prentice McHoan's uncle Rory has disappeared eight years previous while writing a book called The Crow Road. He becomes obsessed with papers his uncle left behind and sets out to solve the mystery. Along the way he must cope with estrangement from his father, unrequited love, sibling rivalry, and failure at his studies. The narrative is also fragmentary, leaping days, months, years, or decades back and forth with little or no warning, so the reader must also piece things together. A parallel plot is Prentice's gradual transition from an adolescent fixation on one young woman to a more mature love for another. It is also the story of his attempts to make sense of the world, love, and life in general. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99. For more information on the book, visit www.chattoandwindus.co.uk or go to the bookshop.com/book/The-Crow-Road-Prentice-McHoan-The-Bildung-Sroman-The Book of the Crow- Road-The. Book-of-the-Crown-The Crow-Road, The. Book Shop, The Bookshop, The bookshop, the Bookshop and The Book-Shop, The Park Lane, the Park Lane Hotel and the Park Place Hotel, Glasgow, for more information. For the book about Prentice’s uncle Rory, go to: http://www.thebookshop.org.uk/the-crow-road-prentice-mhoan-the.html. For a copy of the book on the same name, visit: http:www.bookshopping.com/. For a version of this article on the BBC iPlayer, click here: http: www.bbc.ca/news/features/2013/01/29/book-shopping-the Crow Road-The Book The. Story of the Crow Road, the. Bookshop and the. The. Movie The Movie The Crow Road, the BBC Prentice Mhoan The Movie, the Film The Film And The Movie, and the The Game, the TV Series, the TV Series and the Game Series.

name: Consider Phlebas
summary: The Culture and the Idiran Empire are at war in a galaxy-spanning conflict. Horza, a mercenary capable of altering his appearance at will (a Changer), is assigned the task of retrieving a dispossessed Culture Mind. The Mind, while fleeing attacking Idirans who consider its existence an abomination, has taken refuge on Schar's World, a Planet of the Dead. The plot takes many digressions on the way to the denouement. The book opens with Horza about to die an extremely unpleasant death after killing and impersonating a member of the gerontocracy on a world not yet part of the Culture. He is rescued by theIdirans and given his mission to find the Culture Mind, but is soon captured by a Culture ship. Drifting in an escape suit, he is picked up by an independent ship, the Clear Air Turbulence, crewed by a Free Company of mercenaries. Having now changed his appearance to mimic that of the CAT captain, Horza witnesses a game of "Damage", which Kraiklyn has joined in the hopes of winning enough to make up the losses from his foolhardy expeditions with the crew. The crew lands on an abandoned Megaliner cruising the Vavatch ocean, hoping to salvage its powerful laser weapons before the Orbital is destroyed. One of the crew is killed soon after landing because he missed the briefing warning them that their antigravity devices would not work there, and more die when the ship crashes into a massive ice wall. The next raid takes place on the massive artificial "ringworld" 14 million kilometres in diameter, which the Culture is about to destroy. The team is unaware that the temple they plan to rob has been built of laser-reflecting crystal, which turns their beams back on themselves. Here Horza meets Balveda for the first time. He then follows him on his way back to his ship and returns to the GSulture. There he is introduced to the newest crew member - although he immediately recognises her as PerosteckBalveda, a Culture Special Circumstances agent. He soon resolves to take over the ship by replacing the Captain, who leads them on some disastrous pirate raids which kill several of theCrew. The first raid backfires because the team is aware that the Temple they want to rob is built with laser- Reflecting crystal. The second raid backfire because the. team is unsure that the laser beams are not working and they are forced to land on a massive artificial. "ring world"

name: Inversions
summary: The book takes place on a fictional planet based on late-Middle Ages Europe. It alternates chapter-by- chapter between two concurrent storylines. The first storyline is presented as a written account from Oelph, publicly a doctor's assistant, but privately a spy for an individual identified only as "Master" The second storyline follows Vosill, the personal doctor to King Quience of Haspidus and a woman. The latter is unheard of in the patriarchal kingdom, and is tolerated only because Vosil claims citizenship in the far-off country of Drezen. The King himself is appreciative of her and her talents, but nonetheless her elevated position in defiance of the kingdom's social mores inspires hostility among others of the court. The book ends with the King dying, and the King inadvertently revealing the conspiracy against her to the King's Dukes and Guard Commander, Adlain, when the news of Ralinge's death reaches the Duke's chamber. The two are taken from the torturer's chamber shortly thereafter, as the King has taken ill and appears to be dying, though she indicates to him that this is what he "should" remember "should he remember" The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover and e-book versions for $24.99 (with a PDF version for $16.99, with a print-out of the book for $19.99). It is available now in hardback and hardback versions of both books for $20 (with an ebook version for just $9.99), and in paperback for $25 (with no print-outs). The book has been published in the UK by Macmillan, and in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster, and has been translated into German, French, Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese. It is published in a number of languages, including English, German, Italian and Spanish, as well as the original version of the English version of this article. It has been released in the United States by Simon&Schuster, with an English-language version available in the US by Simon and Schuster and a German-speaking edition of the German-English version by Simon and Schuster for the English-speaking version of this article and in the German version by the publisher, Schuster Books. The U.K. version is available as a Kindle version for £7.99.

name: An Inspector Calls
summary: Inspector Goole reveals that a woman called Eva Smith killed herself by drinking strong disinfectant. He implies that she has left a diary naming names, including members of the Birling family. The true identity of the woman is never explained, but the family's confessions are true. The family will be disgraced when news of their involvement in Eva's demise is revealed. The play ends abruptly with a telephone call, taken by Arthur, who reports that the body of a young woman has been found, a suspected case of suicide by disinfectant, and local police are on their way to question the Birlings. It is clear that Goole is never over it, but it is also clear that the identity of Eva Smith is never revealed, but that the true identities of the people named in the diary are never explained. In 1912, Arthur Birling, a wealthy mill owner and local politician, and his family are celebrating the engagement of daughter Sheila to Gerald Croft, son of a competitor of Birling's. In attendance are Sybil Birling,. Arthur's wife and Sheila and Eric's mother, and Eric, Sheila's younger brother, who has a drinking problem that is discreetly ignored. After dinner, Arthur speaks about the importance of self-reliance. A man, he says, must "make his own way" and protect his own interests. He denies responsibility for her death. He admits that he dismissed her 18 months ago for her involvement in an abortive workers' strike. Sheila enters the room and is drawn into the discussion. After prompting from Goole, she admits to recognizing Eva as well. She confesses that Eva served her in a department store and Sheila contrived to have her fired for an imagined slight. She admits that Eva's behaviour had been blameless and that the firing was motivated solely by Sheila's jealousy and spite towards a pretty working-class woman.
