Arthur and Sybil break down, and the family dissolves into screaming recriminations. Gerald is keen to resume his engagement to Sheila, but she is reluctant, since with or without a dead girl he still admitted to having an affair. Arthur makes a call to the Chief Constable, who confirms this. Gerald points out that as Goole was lying about being a policeman, there may be no dead girl. As an ashamed Gerald exits the room, Sheila acknowledges his nature and credits him for speaking truthfully but also signals that their engagement is over. The elder Birling and Gerald celebrate, with Arthur dismissing the evening's events as "moonshine" and "bluffing"

name: Ender's Game
summary: Ender Wiggin is part of an Earth program to produce brilliant officers. He is teased as a "third" under Earth's two-child policy. He has a close bond with his sister Valentine, but fears his brother Peter, a highly intelligent sociopath who delights in manipulating and tormenting him. In the far future, humanity has discovered interstellar travel and faster-than-light communication enabled by ansibles. In exploring the galaxy, they encountered an alien race known as the Formics, derogatorily dubbed "buggers" due to their insect-like appearance. The Formics attacked the humans and the two races enter into a series of wars. Despite political conflict on Earth between three ruling parties, the Hegemon, Polemarch, and Strategos, a tentative agreement was reached to create the International Fleet (IF) to combat the Formic. In addition to a selective breeding program, the IF monitors the children of Earth via implanted devices to find the best and brightest to enter Command School and enlist in the fleet.. Ender is soon promoted to Command School, skipping several years of schooling. In order to ensure Ender develops as a strong leader uninfluenced by his peers, Graff isolates him from the rest of the new cadets by acknowledging his intelligence and ridiculing his peers. Ender adapts by pitting virtual IF fleets under Ender's control against Formic fleets controlled by Mazer Rackham, as the simulations become harder. Though Ender had anticipated that breaking the rules would mean he would be expelled from the school, he discovers he will be celebrating the final test when he discovers his fleet is far-outnumbered by Formic forces. Despite being told that it was against the rules, Ender sacrifices most of his most of the fighters to launch a Molecular Disruption Device at the planet, destroying the entire Formic fleet and launching a Molecular Device to destroy the planet. He then returns to the IF, where he is told by several commanders, watching the simulation, that this is his final test and is told this is the reason he is being expelled from school. Ender returns and is given sub-command of the fleet, working alongside his jeesh, to work alongside the commanders, and to work to the end to save the planet from being destroyed by the Molecular Device. He later becomes friends with several of his cadets, forming "Ender's Jeesh." A fellow squad leader, Bonzo de Madrid, furious at Ender's victories, attacks Ender with the intent to kill him, and fatally wounds him.

name: Titus Andronicus
summary: The play begins shortly after the death of the Roman Emperor, with his two sons, Saturninus and Bassianus, squabbling over who will succeed him. A tribune announces that the people's choice for the new emperor is his brother, Titus, who will shortly return to Rome from a victorious ten-year campaign against the Goths. Distraught, Tamora and her two surviving sons, Demetrius and Chiron, vow revenge on Titus and his family. Meanwhile, Titus refuses the offer of the throne, arguing that he is not fit to rule, and instead supporting Saturninus' claim, who is duly elected. Saturninus tells Titus that for his first act as Emperor, he will marry Titus's daughter Lavinia. Titus agrees, although Lavinianus is already betrothed to BassianUS, who refuses to give her up. Aaron persuades Demetrious and. Chiron to kill Bassanus, so they may rape Lavinie. They do so, throwing Bassianu's body into a pit, and dragging LavinIA deep into the forest before violently raping her. Titus has Aaron cut off his hand and send it to the emperor, but in return, a messenger brings Titus Martius and Quintus' severed heads, along with Titus's severed left hand. Desperate for revenge, Titus orders Lucius to flee Rome and raise an army among their former enemy, the Gothics. Back in Rome, Titus's behaviour suggests he may have gone insane. Tamora, Chiron and Demetrius approach him, dressed as the spirits of Revenge, Murder, and Rape, and offer him revenge on all of his enemies if he can convince Lucius to postpone the imminent attack on Rome. Revenge then offers to invite the Emperor and Tamora as well, when Titus insists that Rape and Murder (Chiron) stay with him. When Tamora is about to leave, Titus cuts their throats and drains their blood into a basin. When the Emperor calls for revenge for the rape for which they have been baked, Titus reveals that they have just been eating pie and kills Tamora. When Titus asks if he should kill his daughter when she has been raped, she answers that he should killing his father when she should kill him. Titus then kills her, telling her that he plans to cook the bones of their heads into powder and bake their heads in the pie. The next day, during the feast at his house, Titus asks Saturninus to marry his daughter. He reluctantly does.

name: Measure for Measure
summary: Vincentio, the Duke of Vienna, makes it known that he intends to leave the city on a diplomatic mission. He leaves the government in the hands of a strict judge, Angelo. Claudio, a young nobleman, is betrothed/unofficially married to Juliet. Angelo, as the personification of the law, decides to enforce the ruling that fornication is punishable by death. Since he does not accept the validity of the marriage, Claudio is sentenced to be executed. The Duke has not in fact left the city, but remains there disguised as a friar (Lodowick) in order to spy on the city's affairs, and especially on the actions of Angelo. In his guise as Friar Lodowick he befriends Isabella and arranges two tricks to thwart Angelo's evil intentions. This main plot concludes with the'return' to Vienna of the Duke as himself, and he hears their claims against Angelo, which Angelo smoothly denies. As a novice nun, Isabella feels that she cannot sacrifice her own immortal soul (and that of Claudio's, if he causes her to lose her virtue) to save his transient earthly life. This is one of the most common "open silences" of the play. A sub-plot concerns the friend, Lucio, who frequently slanders the duke to the friar, who only reveals that Claudio has not, in fact, been executed, relents, and proposes marriage to Isabella. Isabella does not reply, and her reaction is interpreted differently in different productions: her acceptance of his proposal is different in different ways. In some interpretations, this constitutes consummation of their betrothal, and therefore their marriage. In another interpretation, this is the same interpretation that assumes that ClAudio and Juliet are legally married, and that they are not legally married. In other interpretations, it is the other way around: Claudio and Juliet did not observe all the technicalities. This did not make them unique however; at the time most people (including the Church) would have considered them married. It is not known if the play has been performed in the UK or the U.S. since it was first performed in London in the 1970s and 1980s. It has been shown in the Netherlands and the UK in the 1990s and the United States in the 2000s, but not in Australia and the Netherlands in the last few years of the last decade.

name: Flow My Tears, The Policeman Said
summary: The novel is set in a dystopian future United States following a Second Civil War. The National Guard and US police force have reestablished social order through instituting a dictatorship. Resistance to the regime is largely confined to university campuses, where radicalized former university students eke out a desperate existence in subterranean kibbutzim. The novel begins with the protagonist, Jason Taverner, a singer, hosting his weekly TV show which has an audience of 30 million viewers. Both Taverner and his girlfriend Heather Hart are "Sixes", members of an elite class of genetically engineered humans. The book ends with Taverner attempting to escape from the police academy in Los Angeles, where he is being held on suspicion of being part of a larger plot involving the Sixes. It is published by Simon & Schuster on September 11, 2013. The first edition of the book was published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced at £16.99 (including p&p). The second edition has been published by Harlequin Books, priced between £12.99 and £16 (including P&P). The third edition is released on September 14, 2013, and the fourth edition is priced between $16 and £18 (with p&P between £11 and £14). The fourth and fifth editions of the novel will be published on September 15 and September 22, 2013 respectively. The fifth and sixth editions will be released on October 15 and October 22, 2014. The sixth and seventh editions are due on October 23 and October 24, 2014, and will be available on October 25 and October 26, 2014 respectively. It will also be published in paperback on October 27 and October 28, 2015, and on October 29, 2015. The last edition was published on October 28 and October 30, 2015 (see the end of this article for more details). The sixth edition will be issued on October 31, 2016 (and the seventh will be on November 1, 2016). The seventh edition is published on November 14, 2017 ( and the eighth will be the 10th anniversary of the release of the first edition). The eighth and final edition is due on November 21, 2017. The seventh and final volume is entitled "The Sixes: A Novel of a Dystopian Future" by Simon and Schuster, with a foreword by David Walliams, and a prologue by David Frum, and an epilogue by Simon Cowell, with an Introduction by David Perry.

name: Job: A Comedy of Justice
summary: The story examines religion through the eyes of Alex, a Christian political activist who is corrupted by Margrethe, a Danish Norse cruise ship hostess. Alex's journey through timeless space in search of his lost lady takes him to Hell and beyond. Heinlein's vivid depiction of a Heaven ruled by snotty angels and a Hell where everyone has a wonderful, or at least productive, time is a satire on American evangelical Christianity. It owes much to Mark Twain's Captain Stormfield's Visit to Heaven. The novel is linked to Heinlein’s short story, "They", by the term, "the Glaroon", and to his earlier novel The Moon is a Harsh Mistress by referring to the Moon colonies "Luna City" and "Tycho Under". It is also linked to his short story "They" by using the term "the glaroon" to refer to the colony of Tycho Under in his novel "The Moon is A HarshMistress", which is also called "The Glaroons" The novel has been translated into English, as well as German, French, Spanish, Italian, and Japanese. It was published by Simon & Schuster in 1968, and is available in hardback and e-book. It is available for pre-order on Amazon, Kindle, and Kobo, with prices starting at $3.99. It has been published in hardcover by Simon and Schuster, and in paperback by Macmillan, priced between $4.99 and $6.99, with a print run of 1,000 copies. The book was published in paperback in 1968 by MacMillan, and has been republished in hard-to-read editions ever since. The first edition of the book came out in September 1968. The second edition was released in September 1969. The third edition, published in October 1969, came in paperback with a hardcover edition of 2,500 copies, priced at $7.50. The fourth and final edition, released in November 1969, was published with a paperback edition of 1,.000 copies, and included a hardback of the same name. It also came in a hard-back hardback with the title, "The Book of the Lost". The book is available on Amazon and other online retailers for $9.99 or $10.99 in hard copies. It can also be purchased for $12.99 on the Kindle, with the option to buy it for $15.00.

name: Farmer in the Sky
summary: The story is set in a future, overcrowded Earth, where food is carefully rationed. Teenager William (Bill) Lermer lives with his widower father, George. George decides to emigrate to the farming colony on Ganymede, one of Jupiter's moons. Two thirds of the colonists perish, either from the quake or by freezing. The Lermers consider returning to Earth, but then Peggy dies. In true pioneer spirit, they decide to stay and rebuild. The colony gradually recovers, and an expedition is organized to survey more of GanyMede. While exploring, Bill and a friend discover artifacts of an alien civilization, including a working land vehicle that has legs, like a large metal centipede. This proves fortuitous when Bill's appendix bursts and they miss the rendezvous. The shuttle picks up the rest of the group and leaves without the pair. They travel cross country to reach the next landing site. Bill is then taken to the hospital for a life-saving operation. The pair are reunited on their own homestead, they build their house with a pressurized room for Peggy. Bill goes along as the cook, and he and his friend discover a friend's working landvehicle that has feet. The group is then forced to leave the colony and go on a mission to explore more of the planet. They are then taken by the Mayflower to another landing site, where they are reunited with their family and friends. The story ends with the group returning to the colony to rebuild their homestead. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available on Blu-ray and DVD in the US and Europe. For more information, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk or go to the website of the publisher, Simon and Schuster, Inc., in the U.S. or Europe. The UK version of the book is also available on Amazon and the UK version is available in the UK and Australia. The U.K. release date for the book has yet to be announced. The US release date has not yet been announced, but it is expected to be in the next few months. For the UK release, go to www.samaritans.org.uk/book/the-book/The-Book-of-the-Month-of the Month/ The-Book Of The Month/TheBook-Of-The- Month-of The-Month of The Month of the Month February and the Book of the month in the UK is The Book of the Month.

name: Friday
summary: Friday Baldwin is an artificial person both mentally and physically superior in many ways to an ordinary human. She faces great prejudice and will most likely be killed if her "non-human" status is discovered. Employed as a highly self-sufficient combat courier, her various missions take her throughout the globe and also to some of the near-Earth space colonies. The novel is set in a complex, Balkanized world, and Friday is caught up in several civil disturbances during the course of her travels. She reaches her employer's home base safely but is soon displaced. Sent on a space journey as a courier, she realizes that the journey is likely to end with her death, evades the ship's authorities, and settles on a pioneer world with friends made earlier in the narrative. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99. For more information on the book, visit the publisher's website. The author's website is www.simonandschulder.com. For additional information about the book and its characters, visit http://www.samaritans.org/book-of-the-year/2014/01/29/Friday-Baldwin-by-Friday- Baldwin-and-The-Other-Worlds-By-Friday Baldwin-2014-01-29-13-14-15-15. For other book reviews, please visit CNN.com/Book-Reviews/2014-02-29/The-Book-Of-The Year By Friday Baldwin-And-The Otherworlds- By-Friday By Friday Baldwin, by Friday Baldwin and The Otherworld by The Otherworldly-World by Friday Baldwin. For further information about Friday Baldwin and the Otherworldly Worlds, visit the author's website and the Author's Official Page on CNN.com/. For more book reviews on this year's Book of the Year, visit The Book of The Year by Friday Baldwin.

name: Have Space Suit-Will Travel
summary: Clifford "Kip" Russell enters an advertising jingle writing contest, hoping to win an all-expenses-paid trip to the Moon. He instead gets an obsolete, but genuine, used space suit. Using his own ingenuity and determination, Kip puts the suit (which he dubs "Oscar") back into working condition. Kip reluctantly decides to return his space suit for a cash prize to help pay for college, but puts it on for one last walk. As he idly broadcasts on his shortwave radio, someone identifying herself as "Peewee" answers with a Mayday signal. He helps her home in on his location, and is shocked when a flying saucer lands practically on top of him. A young girl and an alien being (the "Mother Thing") debark, but all three are quickly captured and taken to the moon. Their captors are horrible-looking, vaguely anthropomorphic creatures who contemptuously refer to all others as "animals" Kip, Peewee, and the Mother Thing travel to a planet in the Lesser Magellanic Cloud, to face an intergalactic tribunal composed of many species which have banded together, which decides whether new races pose a danger. The Wormfaces are put on trial first. They promise to annihilate all other species, and are judged to be dangerous. Their planet is rotated out of three-dimensional space without their star, most likely to freeze. It is decided to re-evaluate humanity after "a dozen half-lives of radium". (The half–life ofRadium-226 is 1601 years.) Kip makes a stirring speech. The Mother Thing and a representative of another race argue that the short-lived species are essentially children who should be granted more time to learn and grow. Then it is humanity's turn to face the tribunal, as represented by Peewees, Kipper, Iunio (a Roman centurion), and a Neanderthal man. In humanity's defense, Kips' speech is admitted into evidence. The tribunal rejects the Neanderthal as being of another species, but Kip proves belligerent, but brave. The pair are returned to Earth with devices and equations provided by Professor Vegans. After listening to Kip's story, Reisfeld arranges a full scholarship for Kip to study engineering and spacesuit design at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where Kip wants to study design and engineering.

name: Requiem
summary: The story centers around Delos David Harriman, the lead character of "The Man Who Sold The Moon" He had always dreamed of going to the Moon, and had spent much of his career and resources making space flight a practical commercial enterprise. Unfortunately, his business partners prevented him from taking the early flights (as shown in the novella) Now an old man, he has still not been to the moon, a fact that frustrates him, since he lives in a world where space travel is so commonplace that carnivals have their own barnstorming spacecraft. No longer bound by his contractual obligations, he is now too old; he is unable to pass the medical examination needed for space travel. He bribes two spacemen to help him get to theMoon after encountering them at a funfair in Butler, a small town outside Kansas City, Missouri, where they sell rides on their old, somewhat run-down ship. The three of them fight many obstacles, including Harrima's heirs, who want him declared mentally incompetent or senile before he can spend their inheritance. In the end, he finally makes it to Moon, only to die on the surface soon after landing, content at finally having reached his goal. His body is left there, with his epitaph scrawled on the tag from an oxygen bottle. It is Robert Louis Stevenson's "Requiem", which is inscribed on his own headstone in Samoa. :Under the wide and starry sky :Dig the grave and let me lie: :Glad did I live and gladly die, :And I laid me down with a will! :This be the verse you grave for me: :Here he lies where he longed to be; :Home is the sailor, home from the sea, :and the hunter home from a hill.  The town of Butler is Heinlein's birthplace, and it is also where he wrote the novel "The City on the Edge of the Moon", which was published in 1950. It was published by Simon & Schuster, which is now a division of Penguin Books, and is based on the book "The Moon" by Robert A. Heinlein, published by Random House, in which Heinlein wrote about his experiences on the Moon in the 1950s and 1960s. The book is available in hardback and e-book versions for $24.99 each, with the option to buy a hardback version for $25.99. The hardback edition includes a copy of the novel's first chapter, as well as a foreword by Heinlein.

name: Red Planet
summary: Jim Marlowe and Frank Sutton travel to the Lowell Academy boarding school for the start of the academic year. Jim takes along his native, volleyball-sized pet, Willis the Bouncer, who is about as intelligent as a human child and has a photographic memory for sounds. At school, Jim gets into trouble with the authoritarian headmaster, Mr. Howe, who confiscates Willis, claiming that it is against the new rules to have pets. When Jim and Frank sneak into Howe's office and rescue Willis, the bouncer repeats two overheard conversations between Howe and Beecher, the unscrupulous colonial administrator of Mars. The boys run away from school to warn their parents and the colony. After two colonists are killed trying to surrender, and the power to the building is cut, the colonists decide they have no choice but to fight back. The colonists organize a raiding party, with the boys taking part, capture Beechers office and proclaim the colony's independence from the Earth. Dr. MacRae negotiates with the Martians, and is able to persuade them to let the colonists stay, mainly because of Jim's strong friendship with Willis. In the end, Jim resigns himself to giving Willis up so he can undergo the transformation to adulthood. As with Podkayne of Mars, there are two versions of the ending. As originally written (and published much later) it is made clear that Willis will not emerge as an adult for forty years. This was edited and changed by Heinlein's publishers, as was a discussion early in the novel in which Macrae expresses strong support for adults and older children being free to carry handguns, and opposition to any government which would restrict that. The Martians had been content to allow humans to share their planet, but Beecer's threat to Willis has made them reconsider. They present the colonists with an ultimatum: leave the planet or else. The next day, they accept Jim because of his relationship to Willis and water-friendship with Gekko. The Martian treat Frank's illness and send the two boys home by a swift "subway" The next morning, they meet some native Martians who accept Jim. They also share water with a group of its fellows. The three-legged alien takes the boys and Willis to join a ritual called "growing together" with aGroup of its fellow Martians. The two boys set out to skate the thousands of miles to their homes on the frozen Martian canals. On the third night, they are forced to take shelter inside a giant Martian cabbage plant.

name: The Number of the Beast
summary: The book is a series of diary entries by each of the four main characters. The names "Dejah Thoris", "Burroughs", and "Carter" are overt references to the main protagonists of the Barsoom (Mars) novels of Edgar Rice Burroughs. The four travel in Zebadiah's spaceship Gay Deceiver, which is equipped with the professor's "continua" device and armed by the Australian Defence Force. The continua device allows travel into various fictional universes, such as the Land of Oz, as well as through time. In the novel, the Biblical number of the beast turns out to be, not 666, but (6^6)^6, or 10,314,424,798,490,535,546,171,949,056. The geometry of the novel's universe contains six dimensions; the three spatial dimensions known to the real world, and three time dimensions - t (tau), and т (teh). The continUA device can travel on all six axes. An attempt to visit Bar soom takes them to an apparently different version of Mars seemingly under the colonial rule of the British Empire. But near the end of the book, Lazarus Long hints that they had traveled to Barsooom, and that its "colonial" status was an illusion imposed on them by the telepathically adept Bar Soomians. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which also publishes the film version of this novel, which was released in September 2013. The film version is published in hardback and hardback, with a cover price of $24.99. The novel is available in hardcover and paperback versions of $25.99 and $35.99 respectively. The movie version is also available in softcover and hardcover versions of both of the books, with prices ranging from $25 to $50. The DVD version of the film is available for $39.99, and the Blu-Ray version is $49.99 (with the option of a DVD of the movie version for $59.99). The book was released on September 25, 2013, and is available on Blu-ray and DVD in the U.S. and Canada. The UK release date for the book is September 28, 2013. It is also the 30th anniversary of the release of The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King by Robert A. Heinlein. The US release date is September 29, 2013; the UK release dates are September 30, 2013 and September 31, 2014.

name: Foundation's Edge
summary: Five hundred years after the establishment of the Foundation, the Mayor of Terminus, Harla Branno, is basking in a political glow. Golan Trevize, a former officer of the Navy and now a member of Council, believes the Second Foundation (which is almost universally thought to be extinct) still exists and is controlling events. He attempts to question the continued existence of the Seldon Plan during a Council session and is arrested on a charge of treason. As a cover, he is to be accompanied by Janov Pelorat, a professor of Ancient History and mythologist, who is interested in the location of Earth, the fabled homeworld of humanity. They are provided a highly advanced computer controlled 'gravitic' ship with which to carry out their mission. Traveling to Gaia, they discover that it is a'superorganism', where all things, including humans, participate in a larger, group consciousness, while still retaining any individual awareness they might have. As Golan falls in love with a Gaian woman named Blissenobi, who explains that the future of the galaxy will be decided by the Foundation or by Gaia (who envisions an eventual extension of its consciousness to the entire galaxy, thus forming the new entity Galaxia). Once she joins the First Foundation, Gendibal is met by a First Foundation agent, who reveals herself as an agent of Gaia. Once she reveals herself, she reveals her powers as a shield against the Mayor's mental force, and becomes an agent herself as well. The book ends with a battle between the First and Second Foundation, commanded by First Foundation agents, in which both sides are victorious. The film was released on September 25, 2013. It is the 50th anniversary of the foundation's establishment. It has been described as one of the most anticipated sci-fi films of all time, and is expected to be watched by some of the world's most popular sci-fiction series, including The Hobbit, The Lord of the Rings, and The Lord Of The Rings: The Return of the Jedi, as well as the Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: The Dark Knight Rises, among other films. The movie is based on a novel written by Neil Gaiman and published by Simon & Schuster, titled "The Second Foundation" The film is scheduled to be released on November 26, 2013, and will be followed by a sequel, "Second Foundation: The Third Foundation"

name: The Caves of Steel
summary: The book's central crime is a murder, which takes place before the novel opens. Elijah must work with a Spacer partner, a highly advanced robot named R. Daneel Olivaw. One interesting aspect of the book is the contrast between Elijah, the human detective, and Daneel, the humanoid robot. Asimov uses the "mechanical" robot to inquire about human nature. In the concluding scene, Daneel exhibits a sense of morality. He argues that the captured murderer be treated leniently, telling his human companions that he now realizes the destruction of evil is less desirable than the conversion of evil into good. Quoting the Pericope Adulteræ, Daneal tells the murderer, "Go, and sin no more!" The book is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99. For more information on the book, go to www.simonandschulder.com or call the publisher at 1-800-273-8255 or visit the publisher's website at http://www.simonschubert.com/. For more on Asimov's other works, visit the Asimov Museum at the University of California, San Diego. For other information about the author, visit www.asimov- museum.org or go to the website of the Museum of Science and Technology at the San Diego Museum of History at the U.S. and Culture at www.samaritans.org. For additional information about Asimov and his other books, visit his website at: www.Asimov- Museum.com. for more information about his other works and sites, such as www.thesciencemagazine.com and www.vintage.com, visit http:// www.sciencemag.com/magazines/science/science-fiction-and-special-interests/story/article/stories/the-world-of-asimov/story-of the-skeptic-man-who-says-he-can't-be-caught-in-a-robotic-world.html. The story is about Roj Nemmenuh Sarton, an Ambassador for the Spacer planet of Spacetown. He is found dead outside his home, his chest imploded by an energy blaster. The New York police commissioner charges Elijah with finding the murderer. Elijah, like many Earth residents, has a low opinion of robots. Together, they search for the murderer and try to avert an interstellar diplomatic incident.

name: Prelude to Foundation
summary: The story takes place on Trantor during the reign of Emperor Cleon I. It starts with Hari's presentation of a paper at a mathematics convention detailing how practical use of psychohistory might theoretically be possible. The Emperor of the Galactic Empire learns of this and wants to use Hari for political gain. Hari then meets reporter Chetter Hummin, who convinces him that Cleon's first minister Eto Demerzel is attempting to capture him, and that it is therefore imperative for Hari to escape. Thus, Hari goes on his "Flight" and is introduced to Dors Venabili by Hummin. The pair move to Mycogen, where Hari tries to work out his psychohistsory with the knowledge that the MyCogenians supposedly possess. The finale reveals that "Hummin" is in fact the robot R. Daneel Olivaw. By the end of the novel,. Hari suspects that Dors is a robot, too. This theme would later be picked up in Forward the Foundation. Towards the end, Hara, Dors, and Raych are kidnapped by agents from Wye, a powerful sector. While in Dahl they meet a guttersnipe named Raych (whom Hari later adopts as his son), and Yugo Amaryl (who would become Hari’s partner in developing psychohism) Hari asks for the book but Raindrop Forty-three accepts on the condition that Hari allows her to touch his hair. When Hari starts reading the book, he finds it disappointing except for the revealing of what the Mycogenicians call their home planet, Aurora. The book also reveals that the People of Aurora are called "Aurora" Hari and Dors are almost killed when they try to find what they suspect are a robot in the My cogenian "temple" until Hummin arrives in the nick of time to save them. The action then shifts to the Dahl sector, where Dors displays her amazing knife fighting skills, and Hari is later adopted as a son by a Guttersnipes called Raych, who later becomes his partner, Yugo. The novel ends with a cliffhanger, in which Hari learns that Raych is actually the son of the gutterednipe called Yugo, and he is taken hostage by Wye's agents. The story ends in Dahl, where the pair are rescued by the Gutterman, who would later become Hara's partner, Raych.

name: Foundation and Earth
summary: Councilman Golan Trevize, historian Janov Pelorat, and Blissenobiarella of the planet Gaia set out on a journey to find humanity's ancestral planet — Earth. They journey to Comporellon, which claims to be the oldest currently-inhabited planet in the galaxy. While there, they find the coordinates of three Spacer planets. Since the Spacers were the first colonists from Earth back in the ancient days of space travel, it is surmised that their planets would be fairly close to Earth. As well as giving them another 47 Spacer worlds that they could visit, they now have a vital clue to where Earth may be found. They find a remnant of the inhabitants of Earth, who many millennia ago were resettled there. There is a reference back to the events of Asimov's novel Pebble Sky: The restoration of Earth's soil. Later we learn that Earth was indeed attempted but was too uninhabitable, with there being a grand project to 'form a terraforming project' This project was a grand. project to terraform Earth, but it was abandoned too soon, and there was a great deal of damage done to the planet. We learn that the restoration of the soil was attempted, but was indeed abandoned too quickly, with the soil becoming too uninformable, and the terraformed project failing. We also learn that there was an attempt to restore the soil of Earth but that this was also abandoned. This is the reason for the grand project, and why the Earth is still uninhabited today. It is also the reason that the Earth-like planet of Melpomenia is the only one left in the universe that has not been colonised by humans. It has been ruled by a race of hermaphrodite beings, who have remained generally intolerant of human physical presence or contact. The Solarians intentionally avoid ever having to interact with each other, except by holographic apparatus ("viewing"), and reproduce only when necessary to replace someone who has died. They have also given themselves a natural ability to mentally channel ("transduce") great amounts of energy, and utilize this as their sole source of power. They also find that the atmosphere has become depressurized to a few thousandths of normal atmospheric pressure, and find a statue, as well as writings with the coordinates on all of the Spacer world. They set their blasters to minimum power to fry it off, and then set the ship to heavy UV-illumination before stepping on.

name: Time Enough for Love
summary: Lazarus Long is the oldest living human, now more than two thousand years old. The first half of the book takes the form of several novellas connected by Lazarus's retrospective narrative. In the concluding tale, Lazarus attempts to travel backward in time to 1919 in order to experience it as an adult; but an error in calculation places Lazarus in 1916 on the eve of America's involvement in World War I. There are also two "Intermission" sections, each some six or eight pages long. These were later published independently, with illustrations, as The Notebooks of Lazarus Long. The book was written in the style of "The Song of Hiawatha" and has been described as a reverse Arabian Nights scenario. It was published by Simon & Schuster, which has also published other works by the author, such as "The Book of the Dead" and "The Secret of the Moon" (both published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster), and in Europe by Macmillan, which published it in the UK in the 1970s and 1980s. It is the first of a series of books based on the life of Lazarus, which are planned to be published in a number of different languages, including English, French, German, and Spanish. The author has no plans to publish a sequel to the book, although he has said that he would like to do so in the future, if he can find a way to make money from it. He has no children of his own, but has fathered several children with other people, including two clones of himself, who are now living on a new planet with a larger number of children. He also has a daughter, Dora, who he marries, and the two become founders of a new settlement where Lazarus' long life is less likely to be noticed. Because Dora is not a Howard Family member, she eventually dies of old age, leaving Lazarus to mourn her loss. He later falls in love with his own mother, Maureen, and enlists in the army to retain her esteem and that of his grandfather. While in France, he is mortally wounded in the trenches of the Western Front, but rescued by those with whom he appears in Boondock and returned to his own time. At the end of the story, he reveals a belief that they are descendants of him and his grandfather, and later establishes them as the owners and operators of a thriving business. He then moves to another planet and establishes a polyamorous family consisting of three men, three women, and a largernumber of children, two of whom are female clones of Lazarus himself.

name: The Rolling Stones
summary: The Stones, a family of "Loonies" (residents of the Moon, known as "Luna" in Latin), purchase and rebuild a used spaceship. The twin teenage boys, Castor and Pollux, buy used bicycles to sell on Mars. While on Mars, the twins buy their brother Buster a native Martian creature called a flat cat, born pregnant and producing a soothing vibration. In the Asteroid Belt, where the equivalent of a gold rush is in progress prospecting for radioactive ores, the family obtain supplies and luxury goods. En route, the flat cat and its offspring overpopulate the ship, so that the family place them in hibernation, and later sell them to the miners. Subsequently, theFamily set out to see the rings, and are freed by their grandmother Hazel Stone, who is also the book's main character. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which also publishes the novel in hardback, paperback and e-book editions. It is published in the UK by Simon and Schuster at a cost of £12.99, the U.S. by Penguin Books at £9.99 and the UK paperback at £8.99. It was released in Australia by Macmillan Books on September 25, 2013. It has been released in the United States by Random House at a price of £7.95, with a UK release date of September 30, 2013, and a UK publication date of October 25, 2014. The US release date is September 29, 2015. It will be released in Europe on October 1, 2015, and in Australia on October 2, 2015 and in the US on October 3, 2016. For more information on the book, visit: http://www.simonandschmidt.com/the-book/the book and the film of The Stones by Simon & Schuster in the UK and Europe at £7.99 and £10.99 in the U.S., respectively. For the UK release, see: http:www.samuelandschulte.co.uk/thebook/The Book of the Stones of The Stones, by Simon Schulte in the UK and Europe, and the UK at the same time in the United States.

name: The Door into Summer
summary: The novel opens in 1970 with Daniel Boone Davis, an engineer and inventor, well into a long drinking binge. He has lost his company, Hired Girl, Inc., to his partner Miles Gentry and the company bookkeeper, Belle Darkin. She had been Dan's fiancée, deceiving him into giving her enough voting stock to allow her and Miles to seize control. Wishing to stay independent, Dan opposes the takeover, but is outvoted and then fired as Chief Engineer. Left with a large financial settlement, he elects to take "cold sleep" (suspended animation) with his beloved pet cat "Pete", hoping to wake up thirty years later to a brighter future. Dan wakes up in the year 2000, with no money to his name, and no idea how to find the people he once knew. He discovers that Miles died in 1972, while Belle is a shrill and gin-sodden wreck. All she recalls is that Ricky went to live with her grandmother about the time Dan went into cold sleep. Dan tracks her to Yuma, Arizona, where she was apparently married. When Dan looks at the marriage register, he finds that she married "Daniel Boone Davis". He immediately empties his bank account and heads for Colorado. In Boulder, he befriends Dr. Twitchell, a once-brilliant scientist reduced to drinking away his frustrations. Eventually, just as Chuck had told him, he admits to having created a time machine of sorts. With the machine powered up, Dan goes back to 1970, some months before his confrontation with Miles and Belle. Dan is befriended by John and Jenny Sutton and persuades them to help him in his mission. He then creates Dan, which he then uses to design a new version of Eager Beaver, the first version of Flexible Frank, to be called "Aladdin Auto-engineering" Destroying the machine, he heads out to Los Angeles, and sets up a new corporation called Protean Protester. Dan then takes his own car and uses it to remove all his engineering drawings and parts from Miles's garage and all his drawings from the garage. He returns to the summer of 2000 to meet Ricky, who is remarkably mature for her age, and asks her if she would like to go to camp with him. Ricky says she would. Dan returns to LA to meet her and they set up a camp for her, and he asks her to be his Scout.

name: Farnham's Freehold
summary: Hugh Farnham, a middle-aged man, holds a bridge club party for his wife Grace, son Duke, daughter Karen (a college student), and Barbara (Karen's sorority sister) The group, along with Joe (the family's African American servant), retreat to the fallout shelter below the house. After several apparently nuclear explosions rock the shelter, Hugh and Barbara become romantically involved. After their copulation, the largest explosion of all hits the shelter. With only minor injuries, the group decides to ensure that they can leave the shelter when necessary. Upon exiting through an emergency tunnel, they find themselves in a completely undamaged, semi-tropical region apparently uninhabited by humans or other sentient creatures. Several of the group think the final explosion somehow forced them into an alternate dimension. The group strives to stay alive as a pioneer family, with Hugh as the leader (despite friction between Hugh and Duke) They survive the war, then spend the rest of their lives trying to make sure the future they experienced does not come to pass. They return just prior to the original nuclear attack, and flee in Barbara's car. As they drive, they realize that while Barbara had driven a car with an automatic transmission, this car - the same car in every respect but one - has a manual transmission, and Farnham deduces that the time-travel experiment worked, but sent them back to their own time. They are captured by people of clear African ancestry, but is spared execution when Joe intervenes by conversation with their captives' leader in French. They find that it has not been transported to another world, but instead is in the distant future of their own world. A decadent but technologically advanced African culture keeps either uneducated or castrated whites as slaves. Each of the characters adapts to the sudden black/white role reversal in different and sometimes shocking ways. Karen eventually dies during her labor, due to complications, and her infant daughter follows the next day. In the end, Hugh, Barbara fail to adjust to the new situation and attempt to escape, but are captured. Rather than execute them, Ponse (the "Lord Protector" of the house to which they have become slaves) asks them to volunteer (though they speculate that if they didn't volunteer they would have been forced to anyway) for a time- travel experiment to send them back into their ownTime. The film was released on September 14, 1998. It is the first of a two-part series.

name: The Maltese Falcon
summary: Sam Spade and Miles Archer are hired by a Miss Wonderly to follow a man, Floyd Thursby, who has allegedly run off with Wonderly's younger sister. That night, Spade receives a phone call telling him that Archer is dead. Spade is visited by Joel Cairo, who offers Spade $5,000 if he can retrieve a figurine of a black bird that has recently arrived in San Francisco. The figurine was a gift from the Knights of Malta to the King of Spain, but was lost in transit. It was covered with fine jewels, but acquired a layer of black enamel to conceal its value. The latter pair stole the figurine, but kept it, and gave it to Casper Gutman, who traced it to a Russian general Kemidov, who sent Cairo, Thursby and O'Shaughnessy to retrieve it. When Spade returns to his office, Captain Jacobi of the La Paloma arrives, drops a package on the floor, and then dies. After Spade opens the package, and finds the falcon, he receives a call from O' ShaughnessY, asking for his help. He stores the item at a bus station luggage counter and mails himself the collection tag. He finds a drugged girl, her stomach scratched by a pin in order to keep her awake. She gives him information about Brigid, but it is a false lead. When he returns to the address, he finds a man named Wilmer Cook, who tells him that his boss, "G," will have to deal with Spade. He takes the money, but says that they need to take the blame for the murders for the fake figurine. He realizes that the Russian must have discovered its true value and made a copy of his copy of Gutman's copy of the original. He gives it to Gutman to give to Spade's secretary and asks her to pick up the figurines. He then calls his secretary to pick it up and gives her the $10,000 he gave Gutman for the real value of the bird. The next day, Archer's wife Iva asks Spade if he killed Miles. He tells her to leave, and orders his secretary Effie Perine to remove all of Archer's belongings from the office. Later that night, Polhaus and Lieutenant Dundy visit Spade to inquire about his recent whereabouts, and say that Thursby was also killed and that Spade was a suspect. They have no evidence against Spade, but tell him that they will be conducting an investigation into the matter.

name: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
summary: Three down-and-out gringos meet by chance in a Mexican city and set out to discover gold in the remote Sierra Madre mountains. A mine is dug, and much gold is extracted, but greed soon begins and Fred C. Dobbs begins to lose both his trust and his mind, lusting to possess the entire treasure. The drifters, thinking the gold dust is just worthless sand, scatter the paydirt. They are later captured and executed by the Federales. Curtin and Howard hear the story and can do nothing but laugh in the end. The film is out now on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray/DVD. For more information on the film, go to: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/26/gold-discovery-film-tribute-to-the-gold-seekers-of-mythical-sierra-madre-mountain-murders-michael-dobbs-curtin- and-jennifer-crutin-holland-the film is also available on Amazon.com. The movie is out on DVD on January 25, 2014. It will be available in the U.S. and Canada on January 26, 2014, and in the UK on January 27, 2014 and in Australia on January 28, 2014 for $19.99. It is available in English, French, Spanish, and Italian, with a Spanish subtitles option for $16.99, and a German version for $14.99 and a Spanish version for £12.99 (with a German translation option for £11.99). The film was released in the United States on January 24, 2013, and is available on DVD in the US and Europe on January 29, 2014 (and in Canada on February 7, 2014). It is the first of a two-part series about the adventures of three men who seek gold in Mexico's Sierra Madres mountains. The second part of the series focuses on their final confrontation with the bandits who try to rob them of the gold they are seeking. It was released on January 30, 2013 and is being released on DVD, Blu- ray, and other formats on January 31, 2014 in North America and the UK. For the full list of the film's details, visit: www.cinemaexpert.org.uk/2013-01/29/gold.html.

name: Funeral in Berlin
summary: The protagonist travels to Berlin to arrange the defection of a Soviet scientist named Semitsa. Despite his initial scepticism the deal seems to have the support of Russian security-chief Colonel Stok and Hallam in the British government's Home Office. But it soon becomes apparent that behind the facade of an elaborate mock funeral lies a game of deadly manoeuvres and ruthless tactics. A game in which the blood-stained legacy of Nazi Germany is enmeshed in the intricate moves of cold war espionage. In addition to an Israeli intelligence agent named Samantha Steel is involved in the case. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £16.99, with a UK release date of September 25. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk. For details on the film’s European release date, visit the official website of the British Film and TV Company (B&P) or visit the B&P website. For further information about the film, see www.b&t.com/the-film-and-TV-company/The-Film-And-Video-Report-The-Movie-Report The Film-Theatre-The Movie-The Movie-Away-The Film-Awareness-The. Movie-Ahead-Of The Film, the Film Company, the London Film Festival, and the Film Festival of the Arts, the Festival of Literature, the Music and the Science, theatre and the Arts. The Film Festival is the largest film festival of its kind in the world, attracting more than 100,000 visitors each year. The film is also the most successful film of the year, with more than 1.5 million viewers tuning in to watch the film. For the full film, visit bm.com or go to www.thefilmfestival.com.

name: Billion-Dollar Brain
summary: The unnamed protagonist travels to Helsinki to deliver a package after receiving instructions from a mysterious mechanically operated telephone message. On his arrival the protagonist discovers that the message was from 'The Brain', a one billion dollar super-computer owned by eccentric Texan billionaire General Midwinter. Midwinter is using The Brain to organise his own intelligence agency and private army which will soon start an uprising in Soviet-occupied Latvia. After discovering this, and also the fact that the package he delivered contained a deadly virus, the protagonist must stop the virus from falling into the hands of both the Soviets and the madman billionaire - and prevent a nuclear war between the superpowers in the process. The game is expected to be released in the UK on September 25th, 2014, and the US on September 26th, 2015. For more information on the game, visit the official website or watch a trailer for the film on the official YouTube channel, or watch the official video on the website of the game on September 14th, 2013. For further information about the game or the film, see the official site or the official trailer for The Game Room, both of which are available on the Game Room website and on the Official Game Room on September 15, 2013, on theofficial Game Room YouTube channel and the official GameRoom on the YouTube channel on September 16, 2013 on the same day. For additional information on The Gameroom, see http://www.thegameroom.com/ TheGameRoom/TheGameRoom/. For more on TheGameroom, watch a video about The GameRoom, which is available on YouTube on September 17, 2013 at 9pm ET. for the same reason: it is the first time that the Gameroom has ever been used in this way. For the rest of the year, the GameRoom will be using a different version of the story, which will be available at a later date. For all the other games in the series, click here for more information. For a full list of all the games in this series, please visit the Gamebook website and the GameBook Store. For an overview of the other titles in this season’s series, visit http://thegamebook.com/.

name: Kim
summary: Kimball O'Hara is the orphaned son of an Irish soldier and a poor white mother who have both died in poverty. Kim befriends an aged Tibetan Lama who is on a quest to free himself from the Wheel of Things by finding the legendary 'River of the Arrow' Kim becomes his chela, or disciple, and accompanies him on his journey. Kim obtains maps, papers, and other important items from the Russians working to undermine British control of the region. The reader is left to decide whether Kim will henceforth follow the prideful road of the Great Game, the spiritual way of Tibetan Buddhism, or a combination of the two. Kim's Game, also called the Jewel Game, is a pastime still called by Kim himself: "I am not a Sahib. I am thy chela." The novel is set in India under British rule in the late 19th century. Kim is so immersed in the local culture, few realise he is a white child, though he carries a packet of documents from his father entrusted to him by an Indian woman who cared for him. Kim earns his living by begging and running small errands on the streets of Lahore. He occasionally works for Mahbub Ali, a Pashtun horse trader who is one of the native operatives of the British secret service. On the way, Kim incidentally learns about parts of theGreat Game and is recruited to carry a message to the head of British intelligence in Umballa. Kim and the lama are nursed back to health after their arduous journey. The lama finds his river and achieves Enlightenment. Kim delivers the Russian documents to Hurree Chunder Mookherjee, and a concernedMahbub Ali comes to check on Kim. Kim rejoins the lamas and at the behest of Kim's superior, Hurree. Mooksherjee befriends the Russians under cover, acting as a guide and ensures that they do not recover the lost items. Kim, aided by some porters and villagers, helps to rescue the l Lama. Kim returns to the Himalayas. Here the espionage and spiritual threads of the story collide, with thelama unwittingly falling into conflict with Russian intelligence agents. After three years of schooling, Kim is given a government appointment so that he can begin his role in the Great game. Kim also retains contact with his secret service connections and is trained in espionage (to be a surveyor) while on vacation from school by Lurgan Sahib, at his jewellery shop in Simla.

name: Whit
summary: Isis, otherwise The Blessed Very Reverend Gaia-Marie Isis Saraswati Minerva Mirza Whit of Luskentyre, Beloved Elect of God III, is the 19-year-old granddaughter and designated spiritual heir of Salvador Whit, patriarch of the cult. They are a religious cult who live in a commune in Stirlingshire and reject most technology. They run their lives according to a collection of beliefs and rituals "revealed" to Salvador after he washed ashore on Harris in the Western Isles and "married" two young Asian ladies (Aasni and Zhobelia Asis). (Haggis pakora becomes a staple of the Cult's cuisine.) The novel opens shortly before the Luskteenrian Festival of Love, held every four years, about nine months before every leap year day (29 February) The Luskyerrians believe that those born on that day have special power. This includes Isis herself, and expected to take over leadership of thecult. The bulk of the novel tells of Isis' voyages in the world of "the Unsaved" (also known as "the Obtuse", "the Wretched", " the Bland" and "the Asleep") She finds out that her grandfather was Moray Black, a robber on the run, and that the cult he set up is based on lies. Isis also learns the history of her grandfather, and rescues her great-aunt Zhob Amelia from an old people's home. The story now takes a more sinister turn, as we learn that Isis' brother seems to have cooked up her impossible mission in an attempt to discredit her and put her out of the picture in a bid totake over the leadership ofThe cult. Isis' maternal grandmother, Yolanda, a feisty Texan woman, appears and lends her support to Isis' quest. She also meets her whenever she goes to her house to use theLuskentyrian method of free (if laborious) telephone communication, using coded rings. When Isis finds Morag, she learns that though Morag has lapsed somewhat in her LuskTwentyrian practices (her work as a porn actress is not inconsistent with the cult's beliefs) she had every intention of returning for the festival. This normally results in being allowed to get off at the next stop and pointed in the right direction. This consists of getting on buses, and when the conductor comes along, asking for a ticket in the opposite direction while looking confused.

name: Mostly Harmless
summary: After the events in So Long, and Thanks for All the Fish, Arthur Dent and his love interest Fenchurch attempt to sightsee across the Galaxy. Ford Prefect has returned to the offices of the Hitchhikers' Guide, and is annoyed to find out the original publishing company, Megadodo Publications, has been taken over by InfiniDim Enterprises. Meanwhile, an alternative version of Trillian, who never was able to take Zaphod Beeblebrox's offer to travel in space due to wanting to get her handbag, finds herself approached by an extraterrestrial species calling themselves the Grebulons. They reveal that they have set up a base on Rupert (a tenth planet just beyond the orbit of Pluto) after arriving in the Solar System and finding that their computer core and most of their memories had been damaged. They have been following the remaining portions of their mission statement to observe the most interesting things in the system. It is revealed that the Guide Mk. II was created by the Vogons to complete the destruction of the Earth in every possible dimension, using reverse temporal engineering to bring Arthur, Ford, Trillian and Random together for its destruction. After the Earth is destroyed, the Guide collapses in on itself in on Earth, but Arthur is able to save it from the GreBulons' clutches and return it to its rightful owner, the HitchHiker's Guide Mk.-II. The Guide Mk-II is also capable of both time-travel and looking into alternate universes, but Ford realizes that it is manipulating events in accordance with an unknown plan. In the end, Ford and Arthur manage to leave the planet and return to Earth, realizing that Random has also returned there. Trillian leaves Random with Arthur so that she can better pursue her new career as an intergalactic reporter. She is then called to report on a spaceship landing in the middle of London. Tricia finds Random leaving the ship, and the girl believes Tricia to be her mother, and starts yelling at her. However, she manages to take Random to a bar (address number 42) to try to talk to her. She fires a weapon at Arthur; Arthur ducks and the shot kills a man behind him. Ford points out to Arthur that the name of the bar they're in is "Stavro Mueller's Beta", the man just killed being another form of Agrajag, and that Arthur's life is no longer safe, a point at which Arthur takes relief.

name: The Lion in Winter
summary: The Lion in Winter is set during Christmas 1183 at Henry II of England's castle in Chinon, Anjou, Angevin Empire. The play opens with the arrival of Henry's wife Eleanor of Aquitaine, whom he has had imprisoned since 1173. The story concerns the gamesmanship between Henry, Eleanor, their three surviving sons Richard, Geoffrey, and John, and their Christmas Court guest, the King of France, Philip II Augustus. Also involved is Philip's half-sister Alais, who has been at court since she was betrothed to Richard at age eight, but has since become Henry's mistress. The Lion in winter is fictional and none of the dialogue and actions is historical; there was not a Christmas Court at Chinon in 1183. However, the events leading up to the story are generally accurate. The real Henry had many mistresses (and several illegitimate children). There is no definitive evidence that Alais wasHenry's mistress (although Richard later resisted marrying Alais on the basis of this claim). The real King of England had several mistresses and illegitimate children as well as several legitimate children. There was not an English Christmas Court in 11 83. The King of Britain had no Christmas Court until 1183, and there was no English Christmas in 1182 or 1183 until 1187 or 1188. The king of France had a Christmas court in 1181 and 1182, but not 1183 or 1182. The kings of England and France had Christmas courts in 1180 and 1181, and the king of England in 1187 and 1188, but 1183 was the year of the Hundred Years' War (1170-1215). The king's Christmas Court was held in 1184 and 1187. The monarchs of England, France, and Germany had Christmas parties in December and January each year. The Christmas Court of 1183 is the first Christmas since 1181. It is also the last Christmas of the reign of Louis VII of France (by his third wife, Adelaide) and his son Louis VII II Augustus, who was the son of Eleanor's ex-husband, Louis VII, by his third marriage, Adelaide. It was also the first time Henry had been married to a woman other than his wife, and he had no children of his own. Henry was married to Alais from 1173 to 1184, and later to his second wife, Alize, from 1188 to 1189, and to Alise again from 1189 to 1190.

name: Native Son
summary: Bigger Thomas lives with his family in Chicago, Illinois. He gets a job as a chauffeur at a wealthy family's house. The family's daughter, Mary, is a Communist. Bigger drives Mary around and meets her Communist boyfriend, Jan. Mary is so drunk that Bigger has to carry her to her bedroom when they arrive home. He is terrified someone will see him with her in his arms, but he cannot resist the temptation of the forbidden, and he kisses her. Mary dies and Bigger decides to burn her body in the house's furnace. He adds extra coal to the furnace, and after decapitating her with a nearby hatchet, Bigger finally puts the corpse to burn, and goes home to his girlfriend, Bessie. Mr. Britten, a private detective, finds the boy and his girlfriend in the same room and confronts them with their conflicting stories. Mr Britten interrogates Bigger but vouches for Bigger for the events of the previous evening in a calculated way to throw suspicion on Jan, knowing Mr Dalton dislikes Jan because he is a communist. The boy and the Communist boy's story are told in a way that makes it seem like Jan is the one who is to blame for the death of Mary, and not Bigger, who is the only one responsible for it. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a limited edition of 1,000 copies. The film is available on Blu-ray, DVD and Blu-Ray, and for the first time in the U.S. in the US on September 14, 2013. The movie is available for $16.95. The novel is about Bigger Thomas and his friends, G. H. and Jack, who plan a robbery of the white wealth. They are attracted to the world of wealthy whites in the newsreel and feel strangely moved by the tom-toms and the primitive black people in the film, but they also feel that they are equal to those worlds. The fight ends any chance of the robbery occurring; Bigger is obscurely conscious that he has done this intentionally. The story ends on a cliffhanger, with Bigger's friend Gusiffer R. telling Bigger that every time he thinks about whites, he feels something terrible will happen to him. It is published on September 15, 2013, by Simon and Schuster for a limited release of $15.99 (with a limited run of 2,500 copies).

name: East Lynne
summary: Lady Isabel Carlyle leaves her hard-working but neglectful lawyer-husband and her infant children to elope with an aristocratic suitor. After he deserts her, and she bears their illegitimate child, Lady Isabel disguises herself and takes the position of governess in the household of her former husband and his new wife. Lady Isabel is a beautiful and refined young woman. She leaves her husband and their children to become a governess. She disguises her identity and becomes the governess of her ex-husband's new wife, who is also a woman of means. She also leaves her children with their father and takes on the role of mother to the couple's new daughter-in-law. The novel was published in 1765. It was adapted for the screen in 1770 by Henry James. It is considered one of the best-known novels of the 19th century, along with "Hamlet"

name: A Farewell to Arms
summary: The novel is divided into five books. In the first book, Rinaldi introduces Henry to Catherine Barkley; Henry attempts to seduce her. While on the Italian front, Henry is wounded in the knee by a mortar shell and sent to a hospital in Milan. The second book shows the growth of Henry and Catherine's relationship as they spend time together in Milan over the summer. Henry falls in love with Catherine and, by the time he is healed, Catherine is three months pregnant. After a long and painful birth, their son is stillborn. Catherine begins to hemorrhage and soon dies, leaving Henry to return to their hotel in the rain. The final book shows Catherine and Henry living a quiet life in the mountains until she goes into labor and gives birth to a stillborn son. The couple flee to Switzerland in a rowboat and have a son who is also stillborn in the final book. The novel is published in five parts: the first three, the second, the third and the fourth, as well as the fifth and final book, the final one, the sixth and final volume, the seventh and final novel, the eighth and final installment, the ninth and final chapter, the last book, The Seventh and Final Chapter, which is published as a collection of all the books in the series, with the exception of the fourth and the seventh, which are only available as a single copy of the first two books. The book is published by Faber and Faber, priced at £16.99, and is available in English and Italian for £12.99 and £14.99 respectively. It was published in Italy in 1864 and in the U.S. in 1869. It has been translated into several languages, including German, French, Spanish, Italian and Italian. It is also published in the United States and the United Kingdom, with an English-language version available in the US for £11.95 and £15.99. The first edition of the book was published on November 14, 1864. It includes the first four chapters of the novel, aswell as the second and third. The fourth book is the last, and it is published on December 7, 1868. It tells the story of Henry's return to his unit after the Battle of Caporetto. Henry kills an engineering sergeant for insubordination. He is taken to a place by the "battle police", where officers are being interrogated and executed for the "treachery" that supposedly led to the Italian defeat. Henry escapes by jumping into a river.

name: Imitation of Life
summary: Bea Chipley is a quiet, mousey, Atlantic City teenage girl whose mother passes away. Her father suffers an incapacitating stroke, confining him to a wheelchair, and Pullman is killed in a train accident. To care for her infant daughter and disabled father, Bea Pullman hires Delilah, a black mammy figure. The three are mired in a love triangle in the last dozen or so pages, resulting in a tragic ending. The story is a look at early 20th-century American race relations. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster at $24.99, with a hardcover edition of $26.99. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschulder.com. The book is published in hardcover by Simon and Schulder, $24, with an hardcover version of $25, for a paperback of the book by Simon&Schulder at $26, for an eBook of the same price of $28, for two paperback copies of the novel, $28.99 each, for both paperback and e-book editions of $29.99 and $32.99 for two e-books of the paperback version of "B. Pullman" and $35 for the hardcover of "The Waffle House" and the "Waffle House and the Waffle Shop" by Simon and Schupper, respectively, are available at www.Simon & Schupper.com/The-Waffle-House-and-the-Waffles-And-The-Other-Book-By Simon and-Schuper, $35, $40, $50, $60, $75, $80, and $100, respectively. In the U.S., the book is available in hardback, paperback, hardback and $60 for $75.00, $90, $150, $200, $250, $300, $400, $500, $600, $700, $800, $1000, $1,000, $5,000 and $500. For the Kindle version of this article, the price is $99.99; for the Kindle edition, $99, $199, $350, $450, $550, $650, $750, $850, $900, $2,500 and $1000. The paperback version is available at Amazon.com, the Kindle store, and the Amazon Kindle store.

name: The Last Command
summary: The book is set a month after Dark Force Rising. Grand Admiral Thrawn launches his offensive against the New Republic with great success. Han Solo, Chewbacca and Talon Karrde work to form an alliance of smugglers. Mara Jade joins Princess Leia and Han in stopping an Imperial commando force sent to Coruscant to kidnap Leia's newborn twins for Joruus C'baoth. The Jedi Master wants to turn Leia, Luke and the twins to the Dark Side. Mara discovers that Luke Skywalker - the man the Emperor is ordering her to kill - is actually the man she spent time with in the Myrkr forest. Han, Lando, and Chewie rig the base to explode. After a fierce battle, Mara kills C’baoth and fulfills the Emperor's orders - by killing Luuke. When he reads that Noghri were among the attackers, Thrawn’s own bodyguard Rukh stuns him and kills the admiral himself before disappearing. With all hopes of victory now dashed by Thrawn's death, Pellaeon orders all Imperial forces to retreat. When the Republic fleet and the smugglers attack, the Imperial forces severely maul them. Things nearly go the Empire's way - until Capt Gilad Pellaean receives word of the attack on Wayland. When Han Solo and the droids, and Karr de travel to Wayland, they slip past Imperial forces in the area with help from the NoghRI and two local alien races. They slip past the Imperial force and defeat C'BAOTH. Back in Coruscants, Luke gives Mara Jade his father's lightsaber and invites her to train as a Jedi. The book is available now in hardback and e-book formats for the first time in the Empire Strikes Back prequel trilogy, as well as in the prequel films for the original Star Wars trilogy. It is published by Abrams Books and is priced at $24.99 (£16.99) with a recommended retail price of $28.99 (including shipping). It is available in English, Spanish, German, French and Italian. It has been published in the US by Simon & Schuster and in the UK by Macmillan. It was published in Australia by Simon and Schuster, with an estimated run-time of 1.5 hours. It will be released in Australia and New Zealand in the fall of 2013, with a US release date of September 2013. It comes in hardcover and hardback versions of both.

name: The Way of All Flesh
summary: The story is narrated by Overton, godfather to the central character. Ernest Pontifex is the eldest son of Theobald and Christina. The author depicts an antagonistic relationship between Ernest and his hypocritical and domineering parents. Ernest starts out as an Evangelical Christian, and soon becomes a clergyman. He then falls for the lures of the High Church (and is duped out of much of his own money by a fellow clergyman) He decides that the way to regenerate the Church of England is to live among the poor, but the results are, first, that his faith in the integrity of the Bible is severely damaged by a conversation with one of the poor he was hoping to redeem. He attempts a sexual assault on a woman he had incorrectly believed to be of loose morals. This assault leads to a prison term. His parents disown him. As he recovers he learns how to tailor and decides to make this his profession once out of prison. He marries Ellen, a former housemaid of his parents, and they have two children and set up shop together in the second-hand clothing industry. However, in due course he discovers that Ellen is both a bigamist and an alcoholic. Overton at this point intervenes and pays Ellen off. He gives Ernest a job, and takes him on a trip to Continental Europe. In due course Ernest becomes 28, and receives his aunt Alethea's gift. He returns to the family home until his parents die: his father's influence over him wanes. He becomes an author of controversial literature. He is eventually disowned by his father, though to the end he finds small ways purposefully to annoy him. He dies at the end of the novel, and is buried in a secret grave in the grounds of his family's home in Dorset. The novel takes its beginnings in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries in order to trace Ernest's emergence from previous generations of thePontifex family. It ends in the mid-19th century, with Ernest's father having died and his mother having moved to the United States to live with her daughter. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, a division of Penguin Books, which has published a number of other works by the same author, including a biography of William Makepeace Thackeray, the author of "The Godfather" (1905) and "The Man Who Knew Too Much (1907) The novel is available in hardback and paperback.

name: Alice Adams
summary: The novel begins with Virgil Adams confined to bed with an unnamed illness. Virgil's wife pressures him not to return to work for J.A. Lamb once he is well. Alice, their daughter, attempts to keep peace in the family before going to a dance. Alice uses every trick in her book to give the impression that she is not standing by herself, before dancing with Frank Dowling and Arthur Russell. She leaves the dance horribly embarrassed after Arthur discovers Walter's gambling with the servants. Mrs. Adams uses Alice's distress to finally goad Virgil into setting up a glue factory (which she has long insisted would be the family's ticket to success) Virgil arranges to resign from Lamb's employ without speaking to him face-to-face, and puts the glue factory into operation. The glue recipe was developed by Virgil and another man under the direction and in the employ of J. A. Lamb, who over the years declined to take up its production despite repeated proddings from Virgil. It is eventually revealed that Virgil has "stolen" the recipe from Mr. Lamb in setting up the factory with a lower-class clientele. The novel ends with a scene in which Virgil unwittingly acts like his father, acting like his brother, and manages to cap things off by acting like Virgil like his lower- class clientele, and cap it off with a speech about the importance of glue. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide since its publication in 1953. It has been hailed as one of the best novels of the 20th century, along with "Gone with the Wind" and "The Great Gatsby" (both of which have sold over 50 million copies). The novel is also considered to be among the best American novels of all time, with the exception of "The Godfather" (which has sold over 30 million copies) and "A Farewell to the American West" (among other works). It was written in the early 1960s and has been adapted into a film starring Tom Hanks, Woody Allen, and Amy Adams. The film was released in 1998. It was directed by Quentin Tarantino, who also wrote the screenplay for "The Descendants" (with a screenplay co-written by Robert Redford). The film is based on a true story about the Adams family and their daughter Alice, who lives with her parents in New York City.

name: Les Misérables
summary: Jean Valjean was released from imprisonment in the Bagne of Toulon after nineteen years in 1815. He is required to carry a yellow passport that marks him as a prisoner, despite having already paid his debt to society by serving his time in prison. After being rejected by innkeepers, who do not want to take in a convict, he sleeps on the street. The benevolent Bishop Myriel, the bishop of Digne, takes him in and gives him shelter. Six years later, he has become a wealthy factory owner and is appointed mayor of his adopted town of Montreuil-sur-Mer (referred to as "M--- Sur M---" in the unabridged version) The town's police inspector, Inspector Javert, becomes suspicious of the mayor after witnessing his heroics. He knows the ex-prisoner Jean Val jean is also capable of such strength. He intervenes to bring Fantine back to the French authorities after he had accused him of being a thief. He promises Fantine that he will bring her to her daughter, Cosette, and bring her back to a hospital. She begs to be released so that she can provide for her daughter but Javert arrests her and sentences her to six months in prison, but she dies slowly from an unnamed disease. In desperation, Fantine sells her hair, her two front teeth, and is forced to resort to prostitution to pay for Cosette's "care" Fantine is also dying from an unknown disease (probably tuberculosis) while roaming the streets, a dandy named Bamatois harasses her back. She reacts by attacking Javert and puts snow down on him. Javert comes to see Fantine again and admits he had been accused of being Jean Valjane's thief and orders Javert to release her. He does so, feeling responsible because his factory turned her away, and promises to bring Cosette to her mother, who is in a hospital in Montfermeil. In the end, the two are reunited and Fantine dies from an unidentified disease. The story ends with Fantine's daughter being brought back to her parents and her mother dying of an unknown illness. The film was directed by Jean-Claude Van Damme and is based on a novel written by André Malraux, Jean-Baptiste Jules Verne, and Jean-Michel Cousteau. The movie was released in France on September 14, 1815, and was released worldwide on September 15, 1816.

name: Dodsworth
summary: Samual 'Sam' Dodsworth is an ambitious and innovative automobile designer, who builds his fortunes in Zenith, Winnemac. In addition to his success in the business world, he had also succeeded as a young man in winning the hand of Frances 'Fran' Voelker, a beautiful young socialite. On their extensive travels across Europe they are soon caught up in vastly different lifestyles. Fran falls in with a crowd of frivolous socialites, while Sam plays more of an independent tourist. Their marriage comes to an end, when she falls in love with Kurt von Obersdorf in Berlin. Whereas she stays on with her new love, he criss-crosses Europe in an attempt to cope with his new situation. When Sam happens to run into Edith in Venice, she persuades him to accompany her on a visit to a village in the vicinity of Naples. As Fran's fiancé calls off the wedding, Sam joins his former wife on her voyage back to New York. Only three days later he is back on the next ship to meet Edith on a trip to Paris. He eventually meets Edith Cortright, an expatriate American widow in Venice who is everything his wife is not: self-assured, self-confident, and able to take care of herself. Sam ambles along as a stranger in a strange land until the epiphany of getting on with his life hits him in the last act. He is a rare Lewis character: a man of true conviction and purpose. Purpose and conviction can be relied on significantly as the book (and film) concludes with the two main characters going in quite different directions. The novel includes detailed descriptions of Sam and Fran's tours across Europe. In the beginning they leave their mid-Western hometown of Zenith,. board a steam liner in New York and cross the Atlantic Ocean. Their first stop is England. They visit the sights in London and are invited by Major Clyde Lockert to join a weekend trip to the countryside. Later on, when Lockert has made an indecent proposal to Fran, they depart for Paris, where she soon engages in a busy social life and he takes up sightseeing. When he decides to go back to America for his college reunion in New Haven, Fran spends the summer months on the lakes near Montreux and Stresa,. where she has a romance with Arnold Israel. Once Sam has picked her up in Paris, they agree to continue their travels together, touring France, Italy, Spain, Austria, Hungary and Germany.

name: Lost Horizon
summary: In May 1931, during the British Raj in India, the 80 white residents of Baskul are being evacuated to Peshawar, owing to a revolution.
