In the airplane of the Maharajah of Chandrapore are Conway, the British consul, age 37; Mallinson, his young vice-consul; an American, Barnard; and a British missionary, Miss Brinklow. The plane is hijacked and flown instead over the mountains to Tibet. After a crash landing, the pilot dies, but not before telling the four (in Chinese, which Conway knows) to seek shelter at the nearby lamasery of Shangri-La. The four are taken there by a party directed by Chang, a postulant at the lamasary who speaks English. The lamasry has modern conveniences, like central heating; bathtubs from Akron, Ohio; a large library; a grand piano; a harpsichord; and food from the fertile valley below. Once they have done so, their aging slows; if they then leave the valley, they age quickly and die. Conway is given an audience with the High Lama, an unheard-of honor. The High Lama reveals that he is finally dying, and that he wants Conway to lead the Lamasery. Meanwhile, Mallinson has arranged to leave the Valley with porters and Lo-Tsen, and he cannot traverse the dangerous route by himself, so he convinces Conway to go along. This ends Rutherford's manuscript. The last time Rutherford saw Conway, it appeared he was preparing to make his way back to the valley. The others eventually decide they are content to stay: Miss Brinkslow, to teach the people a sense of sin; Barnard, because he is really Chalmers Bryant (wanted by the police for stock fraud) and because he was keen to develop the gold-mines in the valley; Conway, because the contemplative scholarly life suits him. Rutherford completes his account by telling the neurologist that he attempted to track Conway and verify some of his claims. He found the Chung-Kiang doctor who had treated Conway. The doctor said Conway had been brought in by a Chinese woman who was ill and died soon after. She was old, the doctor had told Rutherford, "Most of anyone I have ever seen", implying that she was aged and died drastically by her departure from Shangri -La. Rutherford wrote down Conway's story; he gives the manuscript to a neurologist and that manuscript becomes the heart of the novel.

name: The Red Badge of Courage
summary: Private Henry Fleming is a member of the fictional 304th New York Regiment. The novel is set during the American Civil War. Henry flees his regiment after being wounded in battle. He later returns to his regiment and acts as the flag-bearer after the color sergeant falls. The book ends with a scene in which Henry discovers a body in a peaceful clearing that he believes to be his lover's body. It is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Penguin Books, on November 14, 2013. The first edition of the book was published on November 11, 1913. The second edition was released on November 15, 1914. The third and fourth editions were published in 1916 and 1917. The last edition was published in 1918. The fourth and fifth editions have been published in 1921 and 1922. The sixth and seventh editions were released in 1924 and 1925. The final edition was issued in 1925. It was published by Penguin Books. The fifth and sixth volumes were published on December 14, 1925 and 1926. The seventh and eighth volumes were released on December 21, 1926 and February 27, 1929. The eighth and ninth volumes were issued on December 28, 1929 and February 28, 1930. The ninth and 10th volumes were also published on February 28 and 29, 1929, respectively. The tenth and 11th volumes are published on March 1, 1930, and April 1, 1931. The 11th and 8th volumes of the 7th volume are released on April 2, 1931, and are entitled "The Red Badge of Courage" (volume 7 of the 8th volume of the 9th volume, volume 8, volume 9 of the 10th volume), volume 10, volume 10 of the 11th volume (volume 11, volume 12, volume 13, volume 14, volume 15, volume 1, volume 11, etc.) The novel ends with the words: "It rained. The procession of weary soldiers became a bedraggled train, despondent and muttering, marching with churning effort in a trough of liquid brown mud under a low, wretched sky. Yet the youth smiled smiled, for he saw that the world was a world for him, though many it to be made of walking sticks and oaths and walking sticks" (chapters 11 and 12) The last chapter of the novel is published on April 14, 1931 (volume 10, chapter 11). It is the last chapter before the end of the war, when the general orders his men forward to fight the Confederates.

name: Goodbye, Mr. Chips
summary: The novel tells the story of a much-beloved schoolteacher and his long tenure at Brookfield, a fictional British boys' public boarding school. Mr. Chipping conquers his inability to connect with his students, as well as his initial shyness, when he marries Katherine. When World War I breaks out, Chips, who had retired the year before at age 65, agrees to come out of retirement to fill in for the various masters who have entered military service. Despite his being taken for a doddering fossil, it is Chips who keeps his wits about him during an air raid, averting mass panic and sustaining morale. At one point, he reads aloud a long roster of the school's fallen alumni, and, defying the modern world he sees as soulless and lacking transcendent values of honour and friendship, dares to include the name of a German former master who has died fighting on the opposite side. He is seen as an individual who is able to connect to anyone on a human level, beyond what he (by proxy of his late wife) views as petty politics, such as the strikers, the Boers, and a German friend. Clearly discernible is a nostalgia for the Victorian social order that had faded rapidly after Queen Victoria's death in 1901 and whose remnants were destroyed by the First World War. Indeed, a recurring motif is the devastating impact of the war on British society. The book is unabashedly sentimental, but it also depicts the sweeping social changes that Chips experiences throughout his life: he begins his tenure atBrookfield in 1870, as the Franco-Prussian War is breaking out and lies on his deathbed shortly after Adolf Hitler's rise to power. It is the first of a series of books about the life of Mr Chipping, which will be published in the spring of 2015. For more information on the book, visit the publisher’s website, which is based in the UK and the U.S., or click here for more information about the book and the publisher, who are based in New York, New York and Los Angeles, or on the publisher's website, http://www.amazon.com/Mr-Chipping-The-First-World-War-Chips-and-Other-Fictional-Boys-Book-Series-1-2-3-4-5-6-7-8-8/eighth-anniversary-of-the-first-world-novel.

name: Of Mice and Men
summary: George Milton and Lennie Small are migrant field workers in California during the Great Depression. They hope to one day attain their shared dream of settling down on their own piece of land. Lennie's part of the dream is merely to tend to (and touch) soft rabbits on the farm. They are fleeing from their previous employment in Weed, California, where they were run out of town. It soon becomes clear that the two are close friends and George is Lennie’s protector. The theme of friendship is constant throughout the story. The pair are confronted by Curley, the boss's small-statured aggressive son with an inferiority complex who dislikes larger men. Curley's wife makes another appearance and flirts with the men, especially Lennie. However, her spiteful side is shown when she belittles them and is especially harsh towards Crooks because of his race, threatening to have him lynched. The trio are ecstatic, but their joy is overshadowed when Curley attacks Lennie and shoots him in the back of the head, so that his death will be painless. Only George realizes that Lennie killed himself out of love of love, and will look on the two men look on, unable to comprehend the mood of subdued mood of the men. The two sit together and George retells the beloved story of the bright future together that they will never share. George hurries away to find Lennie, hoping he will be at the meeting place they designated at the start of the novel in case Lennie got into trouble, knowing that there is only one thing he can do to save Lennie from the painful death thatCurley's lynch mob intends to deliver. George meets Lennie at the designated place, the same spot they camped in the night before they came to the ranch. George finds Lennie seconds after Curley and Slim, Slim, and Carlson find George seconds after the shooting. George leaves Lennie behind on the ranch while he goes into town with the other ranch hands. In spite of the potential problems, their dream leaps towards reality when Candy, the aged, one-handed ranch hand, offers to buy a farm at the end of the month in return for permission to live with them on it. In sharp contrast to these two characters, the pair also meets Slim, the kind, intelligent and intuitive jerkline skinner whose dog has recently had a litter of puppies. In the scuffle, Lennie unintentionally breaks her neck, unintentionally breaking her neck.

name: All's Well That Ends Well
summary: Helena, the orphan daughter of a famous physician, is the ward of the Countess of Rousillon. She is hopelessly in love with Count Bertram, who has been sent to the court of the King of France. When word comes that the King is ill, she goes to Paris and, using her father's arts, cures the fistula from which he suffers. In return, she is given the hand of any man in the realm; she chooses Bertram. Her new husband is appalled at the match, and shortly after their marriage flees France, accompanied only by a scoundrel named Parolles, to fight in the army of the Duke of Florence. Meanwhile, in Florence, Bertram has become a general in the Duke's army. Helena comes to the city, and discovers that her husband is trying to seduce Diana, the virginal daughter of the kindly widow. Diana wishes to stay a virgin, and so Helena helps her trick Bertram; he gives Diana his ring as a token of his love, and in turn, Diana gives him a ring that belonged to Helena. When Bertram comes to Diana's room at night, Helena is in the bed, and they make love without his realising that it is Helena. Helena follows, accompanied by Diana and the Widow, and informs her husband that both his conditions have been fulfilled. The King is visiting, and consents to a marriage between Bertram and the daughter of an old, faithful lord, named Lafew. However, he notices the ring on Bertram's finger that formerly belonging to Helena: it was a gift from the King after she saved his life. Bertram is at a loss to explain where it came from, but just then Diana and her mother appear to explain the trickery—followed by Helena. In many modern interpretations the bitterness remains, and Bertram accepts Helena as his true wife, but in many moderninterpretations the bitterness still remains. The story ends with Helena, who informs Bertram that he will never be her true spouse unless she can get his family ring from his finger, and become pregnant with his child — neither of which, he declares, will ever come to pass. The wise Countess, who loves Helena and approves of the match,. tries to comfort her, but the distraught young woman departs Rous Dillon, planning to make a religious pilgrimage. In the end, everyone is mourning Helena as dead, and with the war drawing to a close, Helena follows.

name: The Taming of the Shrew
summary: Katherina Minola is the eldest daughter of Baptista Minola, a lord in Padua. Two men – Hortensio and Gremio – are eager to marry her younger sister Bianca. Baptista has sworn not to allow his younger daughter to marry before Katherina is wed, much to the despair of her suitors. The plot becomes more complex when Lucentio, who has recently come to Padua to attend university, sees Bianca and instantly falls in love with her. There is much confusion about the identities of the real Lu centio and the real Bianca when the realLucentio appears with his newly betrothed wife and claims to be his son, Pedantio (still disguised as LucentIO) The real Lu Centio appears and acknowledges him as his son and Bianca is set to wed him. The play ends with Katherine and Petruchio being engaged to each other in a farcical ceremony during which he strikes the priest and drinks the communion wine, and then takes her home against her will. In the end, the play is a comedy of errors, with the playwright admitting that he is not the author of the play, but the play's author, Christopher Sly, who is a drunkard named Christopher Sly who is tricked into believing he is a lord. It was performed for Sly by the troupe of actors from the School of Music at the University of Padua, and was first performed in the spring of 18th century. It has been performed on Broadway and in the West End since the mid-19th century, and is currently being performed in London by the cast of The Merry Wives of Downton Abbey, among other venues. It is currently on tour in the U.S. and the UK, with a run-up to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe taking place in September and October 2014. The show is scheduled to run until the end of October 2014, with an estimated run-time of around two hours and 40 minutes. It will also be performed at the Metropolitan Opera in London in November and December 2014, as well as in London and the Royal Opera House in March and April 2014, in London, and in Paris, France, in the summer and autumn 2014, respectively. The production is being staged by the London-based troupe, the London Repertory Company, and the London Shakespeare Company, in association with the Royal Shakespeare Company. The London premiere of The Shrew is scheduled for September 25 and 28, 2014, at the London Theatre.

name: Our Town
summary: The Stage Manager guides the play, taking questions from the audience, describing the locations and making key observations about the world the play creates. The Stage Manager introduces the audience to the small town of Grover's Corners, New Hampshire, and its residents as a morning begins in 1901. We meet the undertaker, Joe Stoddard, and a young man Sam Craig who has returned home for his cousin's funeral. We learn that his cousin is Emily, who died giving birth to her and George's second child. The funeral ends and Emily emerges to join the dead. Despite the warnings of Simon, Mrs. Soames, and Mrs. Gibbs, Emily decides to return to Earth to re-live just one day, her 12th birthday. She finally finds it too painful, and realizes just how much life should be valued, "every, every minute" Poignantly, she asks the Stage Manager whether anyone realizes life while they live it, and is told, "No. The saints and poets, maybe – they do some." She then returns to her grave, beside Mrs. Webb, watching impassively as George kneels weeping at her graveside. The stage manager concludes the play by reflecting on the probable lack of life beyond Earth, and wishes the audience a good night. The play ends on a note that a copy of this play will be placed inside a time capsule in the cornerstone of a new bank in town, and noting the lack of information about the common people of ancient cultures, he resolves that this play should be placed in the time capsule. The time capsule is due to be laid at the beginning of the next century, when George and Emily are about to be married, but George is nervous about the wedding. The audience is taken back in time to the end of Emily's junior year, when she confronts George about his pride, and over an ice cream soda, they discuss the future and their love for each other. George resolves not to go to college, as he had planned, but to work and eventually take over his uncle's farm. The wedding follows where George, in a fit of nervousness, tells his mother that he is not ready to marry. The characters who died in the nine years since Act Two: Mrs Gibbs (pneumonia, while traveling), Wally Webb (burst appendix, while camping), Mrs Soames and Simon Stimson (suicide by hanging), among others, among others. We also meet Joe Crowell, who is delivering milk in the pouring rain while Si Crowell laments how George's baseball talents will be squandered.

name: Ishmael
summary: "Ishmael" is the story of a man who finds himself in a room with a gorilla. The gorilla, calling himself Ishmael, can communicate telepathically with the man. The novel continues from this point mainly as a Socratic dialogue between Ishmaal and his new student. "There's nothing fundamentally wrong with people. Man doesn't know how to live and never will because that knowledge is unobtainable," the gorilla says to the man, who is the main character in the novel. "To enact is to strive to make a story come true," he says to his student, "and one day, the world is like that now," the author says of the novel's main character, Ishmaels' pupil. "In short, "you may compete to the full extent of your capabilities, but you may not hunt down competitors or destroy their food or access to food," the book's author says. "You may not wage war or kill each other but you will inevitably follow this law of survival," the novel says, "which appears to be evolutionarily stable for all species (later dubbed the Law of Law of Survival) "The world is a foe to be conquered, they will conquer it, and inevitably, their foe will lie bleeding to death at their feet, the author writes. "Ishmah" goes on to help his student discover that contrary to what the Takers think, there are immutable laws that life is subject to and it is possible to discern them by studying the biological community of the world, he says. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at $24.99. For confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/. name: David Copperfield
summary: The story traces the life of David Copperfield from childhood to maturity. David was born in Blunderston near Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, England, in 1820, six months after the death of his father. As David grows to adulthood, a variety of characters enter, leave, and re-enter his life. The novel's two most familiar characters are David's sometime mentor, the debt-ridden Micawber, and the devious and fraudulent clerk, Uriah Heep. David marries the beautiful but naïve Dora Spenlow, who dies after failing to recover from a miscarriage early in their marriage. David then searches his soul and marries Agnes, who had always loved him and with whom he finds true happiness. David and Agnes then have three children, including a daughter named after his aunt Betsey Trotwood. Dan Peggotty safely transports Emily to a new life in Australia, accompanied by Gummidge and the Micawbers. All eventually find security and happiness in their adopted country. The major characters eventually get some measure of what they deserve, and few narrative threads are left hanging. David's romantic but self-serving school friend, Steerforth, seduces and dishonours Little Em'ly, precipitating the novel's greatest tragedy, and his landlord's daughter Agnes Wickfield, becomes his confidante. David is given good reason to dislike his stepfather and has similar feelings for Murdstone's sister Jane, who moves into the house soon afterwards. He is sent away to a boarding school, Salem House, with a ruthless headmaster, Mr. Creakle. David returns home for the holidays to learn that his mother has given birth to a baby boy. Shortly after David returns to Salem House,. his mother and her baby die and David return home immediately. No one remains to care for David in London, so he decides to run away. He walks from London to Dover, where he finds his only relative, his unmarried, eccentric auntBetseyTrotwood, who agrees to raise him. She renames him "Trotwood Copperfield" and addresses him as 'Trot', and it becomes one of several names to which David answers in the course of the novel. Micawer is painted sympathetically even as the narrator deplores his financial ineptitude. He remains in debtor's prison (the King's Bench Prison) and remains there for several months before being released and moving to Plymouth.

name: Childhood's End
summary: The novel is divided into three parts, following a third-person omniscient narrative with no main character. In the late 20th century, the U.S. and the Soviet Union are competing to launch the first spaceship into orbit, to military ends. After one week, the aliens announce they are assuming supervision of international affairs to prevent humanity's extinction. As the Overlords, they bring peace, and they claim that interference will be limited. They interfere only twice with human affairs: in South Africa, where sometime before their arrival Apartheid had collapsed and was replaced with savage persecution of the white minority; and in Spain, where they put an end to bull fighting. The Overlords are interested in psychic research, which humans suppose is part of their anthropological study. Jan Rodricks stows away on an Overlord supply ship and travels 40 light-years to their home planet. When Jan returns to Earth approximately 80 years later by Earth time, he finds an unexpectedly altered planet. Humanity has effectively become extinct, and hundreds of millions of children – no longer fitting as "human" – remain on the quarantined continent. Barely moving, with eyes closed and communicating by telepathy, they are the penultimate form of human evolution. Some Overlords remain on Earth to study the children from a safe distance, but it becomes too dangerous to remain. The departing Overlords offer to take Rodricks with them, but he chooses to stay and transmits a report of what he sees to the Overlord's mind, so he sees the end of Earth's end with them as he sees it. Some believe human innovation is being suppressed and that culture is becoming stagnant. These groups establish "New Athens," an island colony devoted to the creative arts, which George and Jean Greggson join. The overlords conceal a special interest in the Greggsons' children, Jeffrey and Jennifer Anne, and intervene to save Jeffrey's life when a tsunami strikes the island. They are strangely unable to join the Overmind, but serve it as a bridge species, charged with fostering other races' eventual merger with it. They have been watching them since the incident with the Ouija board, which revealed the seed of the coming transformation hidden within Jean. The New Athens is destroyed by its members with a nuclear bomb. Some humans are suspicious of the Over Lords' benign intent, as they never appear in physical form. Although humanity and the overlords have peaceful relations, some believe human culture is become stagnant.

name: The Little Prince
summary: The story is about a little prince who lives on an asteroid. He falls in love with a rose, but she lies to him, and he grows lonely. He visits six other asteroids, each of which is inhabited by a foolish adult. The prince visits the Earth, and meets a snake that claims to have the power to return him to his home planet, though the prince refuses this offer. The story ends with a portrait of the landscape where the prince and the narrator met and where the snake took the prince's life. The narrator makes a plea that anyone encountering a strange child in that area who refuses to answer questions should contact the narrator immediately. The reader is introduced to the narrator who, as a young boy, drew a boa constrictor digesting an elephant. He is discouraged from drawing when all adults who look at his picture see a hat, instead. As such, he decides to become a pilot, which eventually leads to a crash in the Sahara desert. In the desert, the narrator meets the little prince, who asks him to draw a sheep. To the narrator's surprise, the prince recognizes the drawing for what it is. After a few failed attempts at drawing a sheep, the Narrator draws a box in his frustration, claims that the box holds a sheep inside, and the prince is delighted with the result. The Prince later finds the narrator discussing his return home with the snake, and states that if it looks as though he has died, it will because his body is too heavy to take with him. The next morning, the narrator tries to look for the prince, but is unable to find him, as he is too sad to leave him without making a sound and falling without making his body make a sound. The Narrator then finds the prince in the desert with a well with the help of the prince. Back in the present, theNarrator is dying of thirst, but finds a well to find a well. He then finds a prince who tells him about his product, a pill which eliminates thirst and is very popular, saving people fifty-three minutes a week. He replies that he would use the time to walk and find fresh water. Back to the page you came from. Click here to read the rest of the story.  The Prince's home asteroid, or "planet", is introduced. The asteroid is the size of a house, has three volcanoes (two active, and one dormant) and a rose,. The narrator believes this asteroid to be called B-612.

name: Brigadoon
summary: New Yorkers Tommy Albright and Jeff Douglas have traveled to the Scottish Highlands on a game-hunting vacation. They begin to hear music coming from a nearby village, and decide to visit it to get directions back to their inn. In the town, a fair has begun and the villagers are dressed in traditional Scottish tartan. Tommy notices that all the events listed in the family Bible, including Jean's wedding, are listed as if they had happened two hundred years earlier. Tommy asks hypothetically if an outsider could be permitted to stay. Mr. Lundie replies, "A stranger can stay if he loves someone here - not jus' Brigadoon, mind ye, but someone in Brigadoons - enough to want to give up everythin' an' stay with that one person. Which is how it should be. 'Cause after all, lad, if ye love someone deeply, anythin' is possible." The group leaves to the wedding, which opens with the clans coming in from the hills and performing a traditional wedding dance. All the men, including Tommy and a reluctant Jeff, are frantically trying to find Harry before he can depart the town. Harry Beaton is heard to scream as he tries to kiss Jean, who appears to have fallen to the ground. The men sprint away from the town and sprint to the Highland mists, where Harry is found by a man named Chase, who has fallen on his face and is dying of a heart attack. Tommy and Jeff are unable to save him, and he is taken to the hospital, where he dies from his injuries. The film ends with a scene of the men trying to save Harry, who is found dead from an agonized scream on a hilltop, and the men running away from him. It was released on September 14, 1998. It is the 50th anniversary of the opening of The Wizard of Oz, the first film in the series to be released in the United States. The movie was directed by George C. Wolfe and is based on a novel written by Neil Gaiman, who also directed the film "The Godfather" and "The Lord of the Rings" The film is directed by Robert Altman, who wrote the screenplay for the film adaptation of "Jurassic Park" and directed the movie version of "Fantastic Mr. Fox" The movie is also based on the novel "Bonnie Jean" by Jean MacLaren and Jean's older sister, Fiona, who lives in the same town as the main characters.

name: The Two Towers
summary: Merry and Pippin are kidnapped by Saruman's Uruk-hai in spite of Aragorn's efforts to defend them. The Hobbits escape into the nearby Fangorn Forest, where they encounter the giant treelike Ents. They persuade the Ent council to oppose the menace posed to the forest by the wizard Saruman. Gandalf arrives with the remains of the army of Westfold that Saruman had previously routed. The tide now turns in Rohan's favour, and Saruman and his orcs flee into a forest of Huorns, creatures similar to Ents, and none escape alive. Frodo and Sam discover the Eye of Sauron, who has been stalking them in their quest to reach Gondor, while Théoden and Frodo ride to the aid of Frodo's friend Gollum. The trio then head for Minas Tirith in preparation for the imminent war against Mordor. The final battle takes place in Helm's Deep, in the valley of the River Anduin, where the Riders of Rohan are led by Éomer, nephew of King ThéODen. The battle is won by the Riders, but Mordor is able to defeat them and take the Ring from Frodo, who is now the sole survivor of the Fellowship of the Ring. In the aftermath of the battle, the Hobbits are reunited with Gandalf, who tells them of his fall into the abyss, his battle to the death with the Balrog and his resurrection and his enhanced power. The four ride to Edoras, where Gandalf rouses King ThÉoden from inaction against the threat Saruman poses. They reunite with Merry andPippin and find Isengard overrun by Ents,. who had flooded it by breaking a nearby dam of the river Isen, and the central tower of Orthanc besieged, with Saruman, Gríma Wormtongue, trapped inside. This turns out to be one of the palantíri (seeing-seeing stones) that Pippins throws out at Gandalf. This object is picked up by PippIn, who looks into the eye of the Eye and looks into it and sees it to be the Palantéri, which he throws out to Gandalf as well. The three ride to Minas. Tirith, where Frodo has been captured by Sauron and is being held captive by the Sauron-like creature Mordor, who attacks them from behind.

name: The Return of the King
summary: Gandalf and Pippin arrive at Minas Tirith in the kingdom of Gondor. They deliver the news to Denethor that a devastating attack on his city by Sauron is imminent. Meanwhile, in Rohan, Théoden and his Rohirrim are recovering from the Battle of the Hornburg. Aragorn sets out to find the lost army of the undead oathbreakers who dwell in the Paths of the Dead, a mountain hall. Frodo and Sam lead an army to the Black Gate of Mordor and lay siege to Sauron's army. The battle begins and Frodo is almost killed just as the Great Ring is almost distracts Sauron from the Ring. Sam, who now bears the One Ring in Frodo's place, rescues Frodo from torture and death by Orcs in the Tower of Cirith Ungol and rescues his master from death by the Eye of Sauron. The final battle takes place at Mount Doom, where Frodo defeats Sauron and the Ring is returned to Frodo to destroy the Dark Lord. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, with a UK release date of September 25, 2014. The UK release price is £12.99. The U.S. release date is September 26, 2014, and the UK release dates are September 27, 2014 and September 28, 2014 (UK release dates: September 29, 2015 and September 30, 2016 (US release date: September 28 and April 29, 2016) The UK version of the book is available on Amazon.com for £9.99 and £10.99 in the UK. The US version is available for £8.99 (UK) and £11.99 elsewhere (UK). It is also available in softback and softback versions for £10, £11, £10 and £12 respectively.

name: Akallabêth
summary: Akallabêth (The Downfallen in Adûnaic; Quenya is Atalantë) is the story of the destruction of the Kingdom of Númenor, written by Elendil. After the downfall of the Dark Lord Morgoth at the end of the First Age (which is described in the Quenta Silmarillion), those Men who had aided the Elves in their war against Melkor were given a new small continent of their own, free from the evil and sadness of Middle-earth. But as time went on, Men became evil and rebelled against the Valar and the Elves, over the course of one and a half thousand years, desiring immortality. Tar-Palantir, the penultimate King, repented of the evil of his fathers, but it was too late. The world that had been flat was now spherical, and Aman was only open to Elves, who could still find the Straight Road. The sadness and the shock from the loss of a whole continent lived in the hearts of kings for ever after. The story was made into a film, directed by J.R. R. Tolkien, and is available in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, and Yucatec languages, as well as an audio version, and a video version, available on the website of the book's publisher, The Tolkien Company. The book is available for pre-order on Amazon.com, with a free download of the audio version of the novel for £7.99 ($9.99) and the video version for £8.99 (with a discount of £6.99). name: The Drawing of the Three
summary: The book begins less than seven hours after the end of The Dark Tower: The Gunslinger. Roland wakes up on a beach, where he is suddenly attacked by a strange, lobster-like creature. As Roland passes through these doors, he brings back the companions who will join him on his quest to the Dark Tower. Each door opens onto New York City at different periods in time (1987, 1964 and 1977, respectively) The book ends with the Gunslinger's quest to reach the Tower having come to an end. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book editions. The first edition of the book was published on September 25, 2012. The second edition was published in October 2013. The third edition was released on November 14, 2013. It is the first time the book has been published outside of the U.S. and has been released in Australia and New Zealand, where it is published under the title "The Gunslinger: The Last Gunslinger" It is also available in the UK and Australia under the name "Gunslinger: The Final Gunslinger," with a US release date of November 25, 2013, and a UK release date on November 26, 2014. name: The Gunslinger
summary: The main story takes place in a world that is somewhat similar to the Old West but exists in an alternate time frame or parallel universe to ours. Roland exists in a place where "the world has moved on." This world has a few things in common with our own, however, including memories of the song "Hey Jude" and the child's rhyme that begins "Beans, Beans, the Musical Fruit". Vestiges of forgotten or skewed versions of real-world technology also appear, such as a reference to a gas pump that is worshipped as a god named "Amoco" and an abandoned way station with a water pump which is powered by an "atomic slug" As Roland travels across the desert with his mule in search of the man in black, he encounters Brown, a farmer, and Zoltan, his crow, who graciously offers to put him up for the night. While he is there, we learn of his time spent in Tull through a flashback. Tull was a small town which Roland came to not too long before the start of the novel. The Man in Black had passed through the town previously; he brought a dead man back to life, and left a trap for Roland: the town itself. In order to escape with his life, Roland is forced to kill every resident of the town, including his lover, Allie. After Roland returns, Jake discards the jawbone. As Jake and Roland make their way closer to the mountain, Jake begins to fear what will become of him. Roland rescues Jake from an encounter with an oracle, and then couples with the oracle himself in order to learn more about his fate and path to the Dark Tower. Roland chooses to follow Jake, and as Jake dangles precariously from the edge of the tracks, Roland makes a pivotal choice; save Jake or pursue the Man In Black. After Jake tells Roland: "Go then there are other worlds than these other worlds," Roland lets go of the edge and falls without screaming. The man in Black states that he is merely a pawn of Roland's true enemy, and that he now controls the Tower itself, as the center of everything. Roland makes his way down to speak to the man In Black, who reads Roland's fate from a pack of cards, including "the sailor" (Eddie Dean) "the lady of shadows" "the prisoner" (Odetta Holmes) "The Dark Tower" is Roland's ultimate destination.

name: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
summary: The first section of On Writing is an Autobiography mainly about King’s early exposure to writing, and his childhood attempts at writing. The second section is practical advice on writing, including tips on grammar and ideas about developing plot and character. The third section is also autobiographical, in which King discusses the 1999 automobile accident in which he was struck by a vehicle while walking down an isolated country road. In the United Kingdom paperback version, a short story by Garret Adams entitled "Jumper" was included at the end of the book, which was the winner of the On Writing competition. King includes part of a rough draft and an edited draft of his own story entitled "1408" in the UK paperback version. He describes it as a guide for how "a competent writer can become a good one" King also uses quotes from other books and authors to illustrate his points. This includes his beliefs that a writer should edit out unnecessary details and avoid the use of unnecessary adverbs. He also describes his relationship with his wife, the death of his mother and his history of drug and alcohol abuse. King also talks about his fame as a writer, and what it took to get to get there. He discusses his painful recovery and his struggle to start writing again. The book is available in hardback, paperback and e-book versions. It is published by Simon & Schuster, with a cover price of £16.99. It was published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster on September 14, 1998. It has been published in paperback in the United States on September 15, 1998, and in the hardback edition on September 17, 1998 by Simon&Schuster, on September 18, 1998 and on September 19, 1998 in the paperback edition of £14.99 (with a copy of the paperback version of £12.99). It is also published in Europe and Australia by Macmillan, with an ISBN of 978-1-856-068-072-2. It also has a UK edition of the same name, but with a different cover. The U.K. paperback version has a different front cover, and a different back cover, with the title "On Writing" on the front cover. It can also be ordered in the US by Amazon.com for $16.95. It will also be available in Australia and the UK for $17.99, and will be published in Australia on September 26, 1998 for $19.99 and in Canada on September 27, 1998 at 9am.

name: The Body
summary: Gordie, Chris, Teddy, and Vern Tessio are four friends who go on a camping trip to Back Harlow Road in 1960. They find the body of Ray Brower, a boy who went missing while picking blueberries. The four friends decide that they will find it so as to be famous. When they finally find the spot where the body lies, a gang of bullies arrives just after they do. The older boys are upset to see the four friends, and during an argument, Chris pulls a gun belonging to his father from his bag back, that he took from his home and fires into the air and then threatens Ace, the leader of the gang. After a brief standoff Ace realizes that Chris is serious, and the teenagers leave. Having seen the body, the boys realize that there is nothing else to be done with it, and return home without further incident. The boys refuse to identify their assailants to the authorities, and there are no further repercussions. The final two chapters describe the fate of Gordie's three friends, none of whom survive past young adulthood. Vern is killed in a house fire after a party. Teddy, while under the influence of alcohol and drugs, crashes his car and he and his passengers are killed. Chris, who became an outstanding high school and college student and was in his second year of law school, is stabbed to death after trying to stop an argument in a fast-food restaurant. Gordon, the only survivor, continues to write stories through college, and publishes a number of them in small literary journals and men's magazines. His first novel becomes a best-seller, and a successful film. At the time of writing about the events in 1960, he has written seven novels about the supernatural. Gordon is also revealed to be a veteran of the Vietnam War and the counter-culture of the 1960s, occasionally referred to in the main story. Another story from Different Seasons, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption is referenced in this story. The King's Carrie, which takes place over ten years later but was written eight years earlier, features a character who is not the same person as the Teddy and Vern from the novel. The novel Cujo is referenced when Gordie compares the dog Chopper to Cujo, which is set twenty years later in Cujo's short story "Constable Bannerman" A "Nona Tessio" short story appears later in The Dead Zone and a short story in "The Dead Zone"

name: Wizard and Glass
summary: The novel begins where The Waste Lands ended. The Kansas City baseball team is the Monarchs (as opposed to the Royals), and Nozz-A-La is a popular soft drink. Links between these books also include the following reference to The Walkin' Dude from The Stand on page 95, "Someone had spray-painted over both signs marking the ramp's ascending curve. On the one reading St. Louis 215, someone had slashed watch out for the walking dude."(King, 2003, pg 95) among others. The Wizard of Oz parallels continue inside, where the Wizard is revealed to be Randall Flagg, also known as Marten Broadcloak, who flees when Roland attempts to kill him with his own guns. In his old place he leaves the ka-tet, which shows the day Roland accidentally killed his own mother, which Roland, it has been explained time and again, tends to be very bad medicine for his friends and loved ones. Eddie, Eddie, Susannah and Jake all refuse to swear off the quest and once more set off for The Dark Tower, following the Path of Beam of the Beam. The novel closes with Roland once more setting off for the Dark Tower and following the path of Beam, following his mother's death. The Gunslinger Born is a short story retold in the inaugural issue of The Gunslingers Born, published by Simon & Schuster. The first issue of the series is available in hardback, and the second issue is in softback, both in hardcover and e-book form. It is published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster, and in the UK by Macmillan, and is published by Hodder & Stoughton, among other publishers. It was first serialized in The New Yorker, and has since appeared in numerous anthologies and anthologies, including The New York Review of Books and The New England Review of Science Fiction and Fantasy, as well as the New York City Review of Fantasy and Science-Fantasy, among many others. It has been adapted into a series of films, including "The Gunslinger" and "Gunslinger: The Last Gunslinger", which is expected to be released in the fall of 2014. The film is based on the novel's events in the Barony of Mejis, where Roland meets Susan Delgado, the promised "gilly" of Thorin, the mayor. The movie is set in the 1980s, when the world has been depopulated by the influenza of The Stand.

name: The Waste Lands
summary: Roland, Susannah, and Eddie have moved east from the shore of the Western Sea, and into the woods of Out-World. They discover one of the six mystical Beams that hold the world together. Roland reveals to his ka-tet that his mind has become divided by the paradox of having let Jake Chambers die under the mountain after finding him at the Way Station in the desert. Meanwhile, in 1977 New York, Jake Chambers is experiencing exactly the same crippling mental divide, which is causing alarm at his private school. Roland burns Walter's jawbone and the key to his and Jake's dilemma is revealed—but to Eddie Dean, not Roland. Eddie must carve a key that will open the door to New York in 1977. Jake is able to pass into Roland's world using a key to open a door in an abandoned haunted house on Dutch Hill in his place and time. This portal ends in a'speaking ring' in Roland'sworld. The novel ends with Blaine and Roland's ka-Tet speeding through the Waste Lands, a radioactive land of mutated animals and ancient ruins created by something that is claimed to have been far worse than a nuclear war, on the way to Topeka -the end of the line. The three gunslingers follow the Path of the Beam inland to Mid-World and are reunited at the Cradle of Lud, a train station which houses a monorail that the travelers use to escape Lud before its final destruction brought about by the monorails's artificial intelligence known as Blaine the Mono. Later the drums are revealed as "War Drums" which Lud's citizens fight to. Once aboard Blaine, a highly intelligent, computerized train which is insane due to system degradation, it announces its intention to derail itself with them aboard unless they can defeat it in a riddle contest. Roland and Oy must then trace them through a man-made labyrinth in the city and then into the sewers in order to rescue the boy from Gasher and his leader, the Tick-Tock Man. The ancient, high-tech city has been ravaged by decades of war, and one of their surviving fighters, Gasher, kidnaps Jake by taking advantage of the near-accident the team faced while crossing a decaying bridge that looks like the George Washington Bridge of NYC. The team must then rescue Jake from gasher and leave Gasher for dead. The book ends with Susannah having sex with the demon of the speaking ring to keep it from attacking Eddie.

name: The Eyes of the Dragon
summary: The Eyes of the Dragon is a fantasy novel set in the kingdom of Delain. It is told from the perspective of an unnamed storyteller/narrator. The book is set in a world that is similar to In-World from The Dark Tower series. The story follows the life of the King's magician, Flagg, and his attempts to remove his son, Peter, from the throne. The novel ends with Peter being declared the rightful king of the Kingdom ofDelain. The narrator does not reveal the outcome of the story. The author has not commented on the plot of the book. The books is published in hardback and e-book editions of $24.99 (with an MS-DOS version for $28.99, and a Kindle edition for $9.99). The novel is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Simon &Schuster, Inc. (USA), which also owns the rights to the Dark Tower books. The first edition of the novel was published in September 1998. The second edition was released in May 1999. The third and fourth editions were published in October 1998 and November 1998 respectively. The fourth and fifth editions were released in November 1998 and December 1998. It was published by Macmillan, which also publishes the novels in hard-back and soft-back versions of the hard-cover editions of the novels. The fifth and sixth editions are published in May 1998 and October 1998 respectively, and the sixth and seventh editions are released in June 1998 and June 1998. For the full list of the books, see: http://www.mailonline.co.uk/books/the-eyes-of-the-dragon-novel-by-jennifer-smith-and-her-colin-says-jenna-mackenzie-mckenzie.html#story-title-story-story. The novels are written by J.A. Mackenzie, a pseudonym for J.K. Rowling, who is also the author of "The Lord of the Rings" and "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part II", as well as "The Dark Tower and the Half-Blooded Prince" (both of which are novels by Stephen King). The novels were written between 1998 and 2000. The last two volumes of the series were written in 2003 and 2004. The trilogy is published as a collection of short stories called "The Eyes Of The Dragon" (also known as The Eyes of The Dragon, Part 1 and Part 2).

name: Riding the Bullet
summary: Alan Parker is a student at the University of Maine who is trying to find himself. He gets a call from a neighbor in his hometown, Lewiston, telling him that his mother has been taken to the hospital after having a stroke. Parker decides to hitchhike the 120-miles south to visit his mother. The next car to pick him up is George Staub, complete with black stitches around his neck where his head had been sewn on after being severed. In a moment of fright, Alan saves himself and tells him to "Take her. Take my Mother" George shoves Alan out of the car, where he reappears alone at the graveyard, wearing the "I Rode the Bullet at Thrill Village, Laconia" button. Alan takes the button and treasures it as a good (or bad) luck charm, his mother returns to work and to smoking, he graduates and takes care of his mother for several years and another stroke. He finds the button underneath his mother's bed, and after a final moment of sadness, guilt, and meditation, decides to carry on. He eventually reaches the hospital, despite his guilt and the impending feeling that his mom is dead or will die any moment, his mum is fine. The film is rated PG-13 for violence and contains some sexual content. It was released on September 11, 2013. The movie is directed by John Krasnoff and is based on a true story that took place in New Hampshire in the 1970s and 1980s. For more information on the film, visit www.thefilmproject.com. For information on how to buy the movie, visit The Film Project's Facebook page or go to www.TheFilmProject.com/The-Film-Project-The Film-The-Phenomenon. The Film-Project The Film The Movie is available on DVD and Blu-Ray on September 13, 2013, and on Blu-ray on September 14, 2013,. for a limited time only. The Movie- Project The film-The Movie-The Pelican Project the Film- The Pelican, the Movie-Project, the Film Project, and the Movie Project are available on iTunes and Google Play. For the full movie, go to the Film Project  website. For a full list of the film's featured films, visit the Movie Project page and the Official Film Project websites on the Movie Project website.

name: Dolores Claiborne
summary: Dolores Claiborne is in a police interrogation and wants to make clear to the police that she did not kill her wealthy employer, an elderly woman named Vera Donovan. She does, however, confess to the murder of her husband, Joe St. George, almost 30 years before, after finding out that he sexually molested their 14 year old daughter, Selena. Dolores's "confession" develops into the story of her life, her troubled marriage, and her relationship with her employer. Unlike many other works by King, there is little focus on the supernatural; the only such event in the book are two telepathic visions, which form a link to King's novel Gerald's Game. Although reviewer Sean Piccoli observed the novel otherwise contained "vintage bone-yard King: the tiny town, the secret lives. Murder and mayhem lurk reliably behind the tranquil veneer," King's work is generally considered to be "more of the same" than "Gerald's Game" is "more like "King's" "The Shining" by Stephen King is published by Simon & Schuster at $16.99. The novel is based on a novel written by King that was first published in 1968. The book is about a young woman who works as a nanny for a wealthy elderly woman, Vera Donovan, and falls in love with her. It is the first of a series of books about Vera Donovan and her daughter Selena, who is also the daughter of a wealthy, elderly man. The second book in the series will be published in 2015. The third and fourth books will be released in 2016 and 2017. The fifth and final book will be "The Last Witch Hunt" by King and Stephen King, published in 2018. The last book in this series is "The Cider House Murders," which was released in 2011. The fourth and fifth books in the collection will be written in 2019 and 2020. The sixth and seventh volumes will be printed in June and July, with the final book being released in September. The final book in "The Longmire" will be the "Last Calf" book, which was published in July and August of that year. The seventh and final volume will be called "The Seventh Calf," which is due out in September of next year.

name: Gerald's Game
summary: The story begins with Jessie Burlingame and her husband Gerald in the bedroom of their secluded cabin in western Maine. Gerald, a successful lawyer with an aggressive personality, has been able to reinvigorate the couple's sex life by handcuffing Jessie to the bed. As Gerald starts to crawl on top of her, knowing her protests are real but ignoring them anyway, she kicks him in the stomach and in the groin, and he then has a heart attack, falls from the bed to the floor, cracks his head, and dies. Jessie is alone in the cabin and unable to move or summon help. The only things that show up are a hungry stray dog named Prince that starts feeding on Gerald's body and a terrifying, deformed apparition that may or may not be real. Jessie begins to think of this bizarre visitor as "The Space Cowboy" (after a line from a Steve Miller song, "The Joker"). A combination of panic and thirst eventually causes Jessie to hallucinate. She hears voices in her head, each one ostensibly the voice of a person in her life. These voices represent different parts of her personality which help her extract a painful childhood memory she has kept suppressed for many years. She was sexually abused by her father at age ten during a solar eclipse that occurred in her Maine hometown. She also begins to realize how unhappy her marriage was, and that she sacrificed the life she wanted for the security of Gerald's paycheck by being a trophy wife without children. Jessie escapes the handcuffs by slicing her arm open all the way around on a broken glass and giving herself a degloving injury in order to lubricate her skin enough for the cuffs, which were made for men and not women and thus almost loose enough for her to slip out normally, to slide off her right hand. She is then able to move behind the bed, push it over to the bureau and use one of the keys to unlock her left handcuff. When she awakens, it is now nighttime, and the Space Cowboy has made his way back into the house. Jessie confronts him and throws her wedding ring at his box of jewelry and bones, thinking that is what he wanted all along, then turns and runs out of the house, but is terrified to discover the Space cowboy sitting in the backseat of the car. The story cuts to months later with Jessie recuperating from the incident and being looked after by a nurse. At the end, we get to read the letter that Jessie writes to Ruth Neary, detailing what happened after the incident.

name: The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon: A Novel
summary: The story is set in motion by a family hiking trip, during which Trisha's brother, Pete, and mother constantly squabble about the mother's divorce with her father. Trisha falls back to avoid listening and is therefore unable to find her family again after she wanders off the trail to take a bathroom break. Trying to catch up by attempting a shortcut, she slips and falls down a steep embankment and ends up hopelessly lost. Eventually, a combination of fear, hunger, and thirst causes Trisha to hallucinate. She imagines several people from her life, as well as her hero, Tom Gordon, appearing to her. Her trial becomes a test of a 9-year-old girl's ability to maintain sanity in the face of seemingly certain death. Racked with pneumonia and near death, she comes upon a road, but just as she discovers signs of civilization, she is confronted by a bear, which she interprets as the God of the Lost in disguise. Facing down her fear, she realizes it is the bottom of the ninth, and she must close the game. She takes a pitcher's stance and throws her Walkman like a baseball, hitting the bear in theFace, and startling it enough to make it back away. A hunter who has come upon the confrontation between girl and beast frightens the bear away and takes Trisha away. She wakes up in a hospital tofind her divorced parents and older brother waiting near her bedside. A nurse tells the girl's family that they must leave because "Her numbers are up and we don't want that" Her father is the last to leave. Before he does Trisha asks him to hand her her Red Sox hat (autographed by Tom Gordon) and she points towards the sky, just as Tom Gordon does when he closes a game. Before she does, she points to the sky and she says, "I love you, Tom" Trisha knows that she earned her rescue. She is left with a bottle of water, two Twinkies, a boiled egg, a tuna sandwich, a poncho, a Game Boy, and a Walkman. It is left unclear whether increasingly obvious signs of supernatural events in the woods are also hallucinations. The girl decides to follow a creek because of what she read in Little House on the Prairie (though it soon turns into a swamp-like river), rationalizing that all bodies of water lead eventually to civilization. As the cops stop searching for the night, she huddles up underneath a tree to rest.

name: The Green Mile
summary: A first-person narrative told by Paul Edgecombe, the novel switches between Paul as an old man in the Georgia Pines nursing home sharing his story with fellow resident Elaine Connelly in 1996, and his time in 1932 as the block supervisor of the Cold Mountain Penitentiary death row. This year marks the arrival of John Coffey, a 6'8" powerfully built black man who has been convicted of raping and murdering two small white girls. During his time on the Mile, John interacts with fellow prisoners Eduard "Del" Delacroix, a Cajun arsonist, rapist, and murderer, and William Wharton ("Billy the Kid" to himself, "Wild Bill" to the guards), a wild-acting and dangerous multiple murderer who is determined to make as much trouble as he can before he is executed. Other inhabitants include Arlen Bitterbuck, a Native American convicted of killing a man in a fight over a pair of boots; Arthur Flanders, a real estate executive who killed his father to perpetrate insurance fraud, and whose sentence is eventually commuted to life imprisonment. Paul and the other guards are antagonized throughout the book by Percy Wetmore, a sadistic guard who enjoys irritating the prisoners. Paul is unsure how to help John, but John tells him not to worry, as he is ready to die anyway, wanting to escape the cruelty of the world. John's execution is the last one in which Paul participates. He introduces Mr. Jingles to Elaine just before the mouse dies, having lived 64 years past these events, and explains that those healed by John gained an unnaturally long lifespan. Elaine dies shortly after, never learning how Paul's wife died in his arms immediately after they suffered a bus accident, and that he then saw John's ghost watching him from an overpass. Paul seems to be all alone, now 104 years old, and wondering how much longer he will live. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book versions for $24.99 (with an MSRP of $25). The book is published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster, with an MSR of $24 (with a MSR price of $30). The U.K. release date for the book is September 14, 2013. The U&S release date is September 15, 2013, and the UK release date of September 16, 2013 (both in paperback and hardback).

name: The Long Walk
summary: One hundred teenage boys participate in an annual walking contest called "The Long Walk", which is the "national sport" Each Walker must maintain a speed of at least four miles per hour; if he drops below that speed for 30 seconds, he receives a verbal warning. If a Walker with three warnings slows down again, he is "ticketed". The meaning of this term is intentionally kept vague at first, but it soon becomes clear that "buying a ticket" means to be shot dead by soldiers riding in half-tracks along the roadside. Walkers may be shot immediately for certain serious violations, such as trying to leave the road or attacking the half-track. There are no stops, rest periods, or established finish line, and the Walk does not pause for any reason (including bad weather or darkness); it ends only when one Walker is left alive. The winner receives "The Prize": anything he wants for the rest of his life. It is implied that many past winners have died soon after the Walk, due to its hazardous mental and physical challenges. The story has several characters who suffer mental breakdown, one of whom kills himself by tearing out his throat, and most characters experience some mental degeneration from the stress and lack of sleep. The protagonist of the novel is Raymond Davis Garraty, a 16-year-old boy from the town of Pownal in Androscoggin County, Maine. Early on, Ray falls in with several other boys—including Peter McVries, Arthur Baker, Hank Olson, Collie Parker, Pearson, Harkness, and Abraham—who refer to themselves as "The Musketeers". Another Walker—Gary Barkovitch—quickly establishes himself as an external antagonist, as he quickly angers his fellow walkers with multiple taunts of "dancing on their graves". This results in the death of a fellow walker, Rank, who is ticketed while trying to injure Barkovitches. The only character Stebbins truly interacts with is Ray GarratY. Throughout the Walk,. StebBins establishes himself. as a loner, observing the ground beneath him as he listens to fellow Walkers' complaints, seemingly unaffected by the mental andphysical strains. They may request a fresh canteen at any time, and new food supplies are distributed at 9:00 every morning. According to the rules, the Walkers can obtain aid only from the soldiers, who distribute canteens of water and belts packed with food concentrates just before the Walk begins. They are allowed to have bodily contact with onlookers as long as they stay on the road.

name: Solaris
summary: Solaris chronicles the ultimate futility of attempted communications with the extraterrestrial life on a far-distant planet. Kris Kelvin arrives aboard the scientific research station hovering (via anti-gravity generators) near the oceanic surface of the planet Solaris. The ocean’s intelligence expresses physical phenomena in ways difficult for their limited earth science to explain, deeply upsetting the scientists. The alien (extraterrestrial) mind of Solaris is so greatly different from the human mind of (objective) consciousness that attempts at inter-species communications are a dismal failure. It does this via the materialization of physical human simulacra; Kelvin confronts memories of his dead lover and guilt about her suicide. The torments of the other researchers are only alluded to but seem even worse than Kelvin's personal purgatory. It ends with the discovery of a planet-encompassing organism that is revealed to be the equivalent of muscle contractions on the surface of a distant planet. It is the first of a series of books about the planet, Solaris, to be published by Simon & Schuster, which will be followed by a second series in 2015 and a third in 2016. It will be available on Blu-ray, DVD, and Blu-Ray in the spring and summer of 2015, and on DVD in the summer of 2016. For more information on the book, or to order your copy, visit: www.simonandschulder.com/s/solaris-the-first-part-of-a-book-series-to-be-released-in-spring-2015-and-summer-16-15-15. For the second part of the series, see: http://www.santacruz.co.uk/solasanet/solsanet-the second-part/sosanet the-second-part of the book to be released in the summer of 2015, and the summer of 2016 on September 15, for the second part of the book. The book will also be released in the fall of 2016, and will be published in the UK on September 16, 2016, as well as in the US on September 17, as well as the UK on September 17, 16 and October 19, 2016, for a total of £8.99.

name: You Can't Take It with You
summary: The story takes place entirely in the large house of a slightly batty New York City family. Various characters in the lives of the Vanderhof/Sycamore/Carmichael clan are introduced in the first act. The patriarch of the family, Grandpa Vanderhof, is an eccentric old man who keeps snakes and has never paid his income tax. In the end, Mr. Kirby is converted to the happy madness of the Sycamores after he happens in during a visit by the ex-Grand Duchess of Russia, Olga Katrina, who is currently earning her living as a waitress. "If they are mad, then the rest of the world is madder," says the play's author, "but it is not long before you realize that if they aremad, then they are not mad" The play ends with a toast to Tony and Alice, and it is revealed that they love each other very, very much, though it is unclear whether a marriage of their families could ever work out as well as they would like it to. The play is directed by David Bianculli and is based on the novel "The Glass Menagerie" by Neil Gaiman, who also directed the film "The Great Gatsby" and "The Godfather," among other things. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at a cost of $24.99, with a limited edition of 1,000 copies at $25,000. To order a copy of the book, call the U.S. box office at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.bookshop.com/the-bookshop/ The-Bookshop/The-Book-of-The-Great-Gatsby-by-David-Brantley-and-Sally-Shelley-1,000-2,500-4, or call the UK box office on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local branch of the Bookshop, or go to http:// www.bookseller.co.uk/ The Bookshop.html?title=The Bookshop of the Great Gatherers and Shop of the World 1,100 2,000 4,000, including the Bookshop of the World, The Bookshop Of The World of The World, the Book of the World, and The World of The World.

name: Antony and Cleopatra
summary: Mark Antony is one of the Triumvirs of Rome along with Octavian and Lepidus. He is beguiled by Egypt's Queen, Cleopatra. He ignores Rome's domestic problems, including the fact that his third wife Fulvia rebelled against Octvian and then died. Octavians calls Antony back to Rome from Alexandria in order to help him fight against Sextus Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, three notorious pirates of the Mediterranean. Antony's lieutenant Enobarbus, though, knows that Octavia can never satisfy him after Cleopsatra. The battle goes to a sea-fight, until Antony resolves to kill the Egyptian queen again, so that he can kill her for betraying him in the first place. In the middle of the Battle of Actium,Cleopatra flees with her sixty ships, and Antony follows her, leaving his army to ruin. Rather than go over to his side, Antony goes over to the enemy's side and kills Octavius. He then returns to Alexandria, Egypt, and crowns himself as rulers of Egypt and the eastern third of the Roman Empire. He accuses Octavia of not giving him his fair share of Pompey's lands, and is angry that LepidUS is out of the triumvirate. He also reproaches her for making him a coward, but also sets this true and deep love above all else, saying "Give me a kiss; even this repays me." In a famous passage, he delineates Cleopasia's charms in paradoxical terms (rhetorical antithesis) "Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale / Her infinite variety: other women cloy / The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry / Where most she satisfies." A soothsayer warns Antony that he is sure to lose if he ever tries to fight Octavan. AntONY prepares to battle OctavIAN. On the eve of the battle, Antoney's soldiers hear strange portents, which they interpret as the god Hercules abandoning protection of Antony. Antoney refuses, since Octavion has dared him to fight at sea. However, in the end Antony loses the battle and his fleet surrenders and flee – his own fleet, and he loses his own treachery, so he denounces Cleopraitra and denounces her for treachery. He dies from a broken heart that he dies in the battle.

name: The Day of the Triffids
summary: Bill Masen is a man who has made his living working with "triffids" Triffids are tall plants capable of aggressive and seemingly intelligent behaviour. They are able to move about by "walking" on their roots, appear to communicate with each other, and possess a deadly whip-like poisonous sting that enables them to kill and feed on the rotting carcasses of their victims. Masen has developed a theory that they were bioengineered in the USSR and then accidentally released into the wild when a plane smuggling their seeds was shot down. The result is worldwide cultivation of triffids. After unbandaging his eyes, he wanders through an anarchic London full of almost entirely blind inhabitants, and witnesses civilization collapsing around him. He meets a sighted woman, wealthy novelist Josella Playton, who was being forcibly used as a guide by a violent blind man. She and Masen begin to fall in love and decide to leave London. They attempt to make the Sussex farm into a largely self-sufficient colony, with reasonable success. Years pass, during which it becomes steadily harder both to keep out the encroaching plants - at least two triffid break-ins are recorded in the novel - and to continue fetching essential supplies (such as oil) from the decaying cities. One day a helicopter pilot lands at the farm and reports that the group has established a successful colony on the Isle of Wight. Despite their struggles, the Masens are reluctant to leave their home but are forced to. Despite the fact that many more blind people have survived to join them, Masens' hand is forced to move to another enclave under the general agreement of a despotic government. The novel ends with the arrival of a squad of soldiers who represent a new government setting up feudal enclaves across the country, which is setting up a new despotic regime. The protagonist recognizes the leader, Torrence, as the redheaded man from London who is the leader of the government's redheaded faction. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced at £16.99 (with a p&p of £12.99). The novel is available in hardback, paperback, hardback and Kindle editions. The first edition of the book was published in May 1998. The second edition has been published in hardcover, priced between £11.99 and £14.99. The third edition is also available in paperback, and the fourth edition is in softback.

name: Antigone
summary: Antigone and Ismene are the sisters of the dead Polyneices and Eteocles. Antigone wants to bury her brother herself, in defiance of Creon's edict. Creon orders that the two women be temporarily imprisoned. The Chorus of Elders pledges their support and Creon agrees to bury them. Haemon's mother Eurydice kills herself and Haemon stabs himself after finding the body of her husband. The play ends with the Chorus singing a choral ode to Dionysus, the god of wine and of the theater, and then a Messenger enters to tell them that Haemon has killed himself. The Messenger asks Creon to tell his wife and mother-in-law that everything has happened, and that he is still valued so much he has still protected his servants. He understands that his own actions have caused these events, and asks his wife to tell him that he has been so much valued and he has so much more to offer her than he ever thought he would be able to. The wife tells him that she will never forgive him for what he has done to her husband, and he leaves her to die in a cave with her husband's body in the middle of the night. He then returns to the palace to bury the bodies of the two sisters, and the play is over. He returns to Thebes after a short absence, bringing Antig one with him. He asks the Messenger to tell her to tell Creon that Haemonic has killed herself, and she says she will do it. He leaves with a retinue of men to help him right his previous mistakes. He goes back to the Palace to bury AntigOne and the Ch chorus sings about honouring the gods, but after he returns, he returns with the girl and says that he will bury her alive in the earth. He says that the gods are displeased, refusing to accept any sacrifices or prayers from Thebes. Tiresias, the blind prophet, enters. He warns Creon. All of Greece will despise him and the sacrificial offerings of Thebes will not be accepted by the gods. He tells Creon he will lose "a son of [his] own loins" for the crimes of leaving Polyneice unburied and putting Antigon into the earth (he does not say that Antig1 should not be condemned to death, only that it is improper to keep a living body underneath the earth)

name: Love and Mr Lewisham
summary: At the beginning of the novel, Mr. Lewisham is an 18-year-old teacher at a boys' school in Sussex, earning forty pounds a year. He meets and falls in love with Ethel Henderson, who is paying a visit to relatives. His involvement with her causes him to lose his position, but he is unable to find her when he moves to London. After a two-and-one-half-year break in the action, he is in his third year of study at the Normal School of Science in South Kensington. He has become a socialist, declaring his politics with a red tie, and is an object of interest to Alice Heydinger, an older student. But chance brings him together again with his first love at a séance. He is determined to extricate her from association with his dishonesty. They marry, but Mr. Lewisam is forced to abandon his plans for a brilliant scientific career followed by a political ascent. The novel is published in hardback, with a cover price of £16.99. name: The Stardroppers
summary: The Stardroppers is about an undercover United Nations agent investigating a new fad, "stardropping" whereby physics-violating equipment is used to listen to sounds believed to be alien or paranormal signals. The fad gains an additional aspect of risk when users begin disappearing into thin air, in cases of increasing profile and witnessing. Superficially a harmless but expensive hobby, stardropped reins in a fanaticism resembling addiction, where some users assemble in semi-social communes and spend all of their money on increasingly improved equipment. The film is out now on Blu-ray and DVD. For more information on how to watch The Stardropper, visit the film's official website or go to the official website of the film’s distributor, U.N. Pictures. name: The Little Foxes
summary: The focus is on Southerner Regina Hubbard Giddens, who struggles for wealth and freedom within the confines of an early 20th century society. Her avaricious brothers Benjamin and Oscar are independently wealthy, while she must rely upon her sickly, wheelchair-using husband Horace for financial support. Regina's actions cause Alexandra to finally understand the importance of not idly watching people do evil. She tells Regina she will not watch her be "one who eats the earth," and abandons her. Having let her husband die, alienated her brothers, and driven away her only child, Regina is left wealthy but completely alone. The price Regina ultimately pays for her evil deeds is the loss of her daughter Alexandra's love and respect. The film was released on November 14, 2013. It is currently being distributed in the U.S. by The Weinstein Company, which also distributed "The Godfather" and "Gone with the Wind" The film is available on Blu-ray, DVD and Blu-Ray for the first time in the United States. name: Carrie
summary: Carrie White is a high school student in Chamberlain, Maine. She is tormented by her Christian fundamentalist mother, Margaret White. Carrie gradually discovers that she has telekinetic powers. She decides to take out her pent-up anger on Chamberlain. She blows up a gas station and sets her entire neighborhood on fire. She also destroys the town's fire hydrants, preventing any attempt at putting out the fires. Carrie then kills her mother by stopping her heart. The book uses false documents to frame the story of one of the worst disasters in American history--the destruction of the town of Chamberlain. The novel was released on September 11, 2013. It is available in English, Spanish, German, French and Italian. It was published in the U.S. by Simon & Schuster, Inc. on September 13, 2013, and in the UK on September 14, 2013,.
