For help with suicide matters call the National Suicide Prevention Line on 1 800 273 8255.

name: Dune
summary: Padishah Emperor Shaddam IV of House Corrino has come to fear House Atreides due to the growing popularity of Duke Leto Atreide within the Landsraad. The Emperor instead uses the centuries-old feud between House atreides and House Harkonnen to disguise his assault. Leto's concubine, the Bene Gesserit Lady Jessica, was ordered to give birth to a daughter, but she instead bears a boy, to provide an heir for Leto. The Atreids are able to thwart initial Harksonnen traps and complications while simultaneously building trust with the mysterious desert Fremen, with whom they hope to ally. However, they are ultimately unable to withstand a devastating Hark onnen attack, supported by House CorRino's elite Corps of Sardaukar, disguised as HarkOnnen troops. The House is scattered, with Leto taken captive by Yueh and delivered to the HARKonnens. Paul becomes aware through his prescience that if he is not careful, the Fremen will extend that jihad against all the known universe, which Paul describes as a humanity-spanning effort to avoid genetic stagnation. Paul grows dramatically in influence, and he is regarded as a Fremen messiah in his new name, MuDib'Dib. Paul also becomes aware that the presumed-dead leader of the Hark Onnens, Rautha Feyd, plots to send his nephew and heir to his new fief of Arrakis. Paul and his mother quickly learn Fremen ways while teaching them the weirding way of fighting. Paul's prescience causes his mental powers to be increase dramatically, allowing his future "paths" of possible events to be predicted. As Paul grows as the prophesied messiah, he begins a jihad against HarkONnens under his new rule of the planet, Mu Dib'dib, for this "Dib" is not guessing that this is the leader of this "Mu Dib" He also becomes a Reverend Mother, ingesting the poisonous Water of Life while pregnant with her second child; this unborn daughter Alia is subjected to the same ordeal, acquiring the full abilities of averend Mother before even being born. Paul takes a Fremens lover, Chani, with which he fathers a son. Paul learns the spice diet of the Fremens and his own developing mental powers cause Paul's foresight to be increased dramatically. He also learns the weirded way, a Bene GESSerit method of fighting, to fight.

name: Feersum Endjinn
summary: The book is set on a far future Earth where uploading of mindstates into a world-spanning computer network is commonplace. The solar system is drifting into an interstellar molecular cloud, which will eventually dim the Sun's light sufficiently to end life on Earth. The Diaspora (the long-departed segment of humanity) have left behind a device (the "Fearsome Engine" of the title) to deal with the problem. The book follows four characters who become involved in the attempt to activate it. A quarter of the book is told by Bascule the Teller and is written phonetically in the first person. This is explained by the dyslexia of the main character, who tells the story in first person in a quarter-person format. The fourth chapter of the Book's Part One opens with: "I have been given a gift, and I am going to give it to you." The book's Part Two is titled "The Fearsome engine" and follows the story of the four characters involved in trying to activate the device. It is written in first-person, with the narrative moving between the four (who do not meet until very near the end) in rotation. The final chapter of Part One is titled, "I Have been Given A Gift, I am Going To Give It To You" and is told from the point of view of the character Bascules, who has been given the gift of a device to help him in his quest for immortality. The last chapter of this chapter is entitled, "The Fearless Engine" and tells the tale of the "Fearless Engine", a device that allows the dead to be easily reincarnated. The story of this device is told in the second part of the Part One chapter, which is called the "Fearless Engine". The book is published by Simon & Schuster in paperback on November 14, 2013. The first edition was published on November 13, 2013, and the second edition is released on November 21, 2014, in hardback and hardback. The price for each copy of the first edition is £12.99. The second edition has been priced at £14.99 (£16.99) and the third edition £15.99 ($19.99), and the fourth edition is priced £18.99 (with the option to buy the second copy for £15). The book has been published in two parts, the first of which is the first part of Part Two.

name: Against a Dark Background
summary: The hunt for the eighth and final Lazy Gun is the main plot theme of Against a Dark Background. Much of the novel concerns Sharrow's adventures in searching for and acquiring it. Her motivation is that the Huhsz religious cult regard it as a sacred object, and that if she can find it and give it to them, their vendetta against her will lapse. Sharrow encounters various political systems on her travels across Golter. She also meets the Solipsists, a gang of pirate mercenaries on a hovercraft, who hold very unusual philosophical beliefs. When the last Lazy Guns is eventually discovered, it is guarded by an elaborate defense system incorporating a genetic key which Sharrow has to deactivate. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99. For more information on the book and to order a copy, visit www.simonandschulder.com/against-a-dark-background or go to www.samaritans.org/book/Against-A-Dark- Background-The-Book-by-Simon-Schulder-and-Samaritans-To-Be-Read-On-A Dark- Background. For the full list of events in the book, visit the book's official website or the publisher's website. The novel is available in hardback, paperback and e-book versions for £12.99, and in paperback for £9.99 and £10.99 for both hard-back and hard-cover versions. The cover price for the book is £8.99 with the option to buy the book in the UK for £11.99 plus £1.99 in the U.S. and £3.99 on the UK release date of the book. It is published in paperback by Simon and Schulder, and the UK edition is £14.99 (with the option of £10). The book was published in September 2013. The UK edition was released in October 2013 and the US release date is September 2014. It has been released in paperback in the US on September 14, 2014 and in Australia on September 15, 2014. The U.K. edition was published on September 16, 2014, and it will be released in Australia in October 2014 and the Australian edition on September 17, 2015. It will also be published in Europe on September 18, 2015 and in the United States on September 19, 2015, and elsewhere in the world on September 20, 2016. The original eight Lazy guns were destroyed before the events of the story.

name: Just Like That
summary: Edek Zepler is a Holocaust survivor who was born Edek Zeleznikow in Poland in 1915. He got married in the Łódź ghetto to Rooshka but had to marry her again after the war in a DP camp in Germany. In 1951 the family emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. His life takes a decisive turn when, on a visit to New York, he meets Josl and Henia Borenstein again, a couple he last saw in the German DP camp. Edek packs up all his things, sells his house and moves to the U.S.A. He is married to Henia and they have a son, Zachary, now 21, and a daughter, Zelda, now 16, by him. Esther is the only child of Edek andRooshka Zepler. She was born in a GermanDP camp in 1950. In 1968, aged 18, she became a rock journalist - just like Lily Brett herself - and in this capacity also visited New York. She has always seen herself as "a person with so much to sort out", and this is why she has been in analysis for a number of years. In the novel, she learns the difference between compulsive behaviour and obsessive behaviour. She is a woman with "excessive anxieties and indecisions", likely to face panic and panic when having to face things. She considers herself lucky that you do not really need a car in New York City. She thinks she shows herself as claustrophobia as well as as agoraphobia. She spends a fortune on it and even even even sells her mother's diamond ring in one point. Nobody would guess that Sean, Esther, ZachARY, Zelda and Kate - Sean's 19 year-old daughter by his first wife, who died of cancer - are a patchwork family. For one thing, Sean looks Jewish although he is not; for another, they all understand each other well and there is a certain feeling of belonging amongst them. They all are quite wealthy, they do not suffer from any illnesses - Esther is constantly suffering in some way or other. At one point in the novel she even thinks she is going to drive her father's car in public until they were stopped by the police. They are all quite wealthy and they all are well-behaved - they all have a good job, she is happily married, her children are well behaved and they are all very well-off.

name: Memoirs of a Fox-Hunting Man
summary: The story is a series of episodes in the youth of George Sherston, ranging from his first attempts to learn to ride to his experiences in winning point-to-point races. The book as a whole is a frequently humorous work, in which fox-hunting, one of Sassoon's major interests, comes to represent the young man's innocent frame of mind in the years before war broke out. The story is continued in two sequels: Memoirs of an Infantry Officer and Sherston's Progress. "The Flower-Show Match," an account of an annual village cricket match - an important fixture for those involved - in which young Sherston plays a significant part, was later published separately by Faber as a self-contained story. It was later released as a collection of short stories called The Flower- show Match and The Flower Show Match, with the story of the Flower-show Match being the main focus. The title is somewhat misleading, as the book is mainly concerned with a seriesof landmark events in Sherson/Sassoon's childhood and youth, and his encounters with various comic characters. It ends with his enlistment in a local regiment, and the book ends with the end of the Second World War. It has been described as a "comic masterpiece" by the author's biographer, David Walliams, who has also written a biography of the author. It is published in hardback, with a front cover that reads: "Sherston, George, George. George, the Great War. The Great War... The Story of Sherston." The book also has a back cover that says: "The Great War... The Story Of Sherston" The book is also published in paperback with the title: "George Sherston: The Great Story of George, The Great Race, The Greatest Race." The back cover says: "The Great Race... The Great Game, The Story That Saved My Life. The Story that Saved my Life." It has also been published as a hardback with the name "The Greatest Race" and the title "The Grand Race". The book has also had a number of other titles, including "The First World War" and "The Last World War," as well as two sequels, "Memoirs Of An Infantry Officer" and 'Sherston’s Progress'

name: Uncle Tom's Cabin
summary: Uncle Tom is a middle-aged man with a wife and children, and Harry, the son of Emily Shelby’s maid Eliza. Tom is sold and placed on a riverboat which sets sail down the Mississippi River. While on board, Tom meets and befriends a young white girl named Eva. Eva's father Augustine St. Clare buys Tom from the slave trader and takes him with the family to their home in New Orleans. Tom and Eva begin to relate to one another because of the deep Christian faith they both share. After Tom has lived with the St. Clares for two years, Eva grows very ill. She experiences a vision of heaven, which she shares with the people around her. As a result of her death and vision, the other characters resolve to change their lives, with Ophelia promising to throw off her personal prejudices against blacks, Topsy saying she will better herself, and St.Clare pledging to free Tom. As Tom is dying, he forgives the overseers who savagely beat him by the man they have killed, both men becoming Christians. Very shortly before Tom's death, George Shelby (Arthur Shelby's son) arrives to buy Tom's freedom. On their ride to freedom, Tom finds Cassy and Emmeline, but finds he is too late. He encourages Cassy to escape to Canada where she does, takingEmmeline with her to tell Tom where she has gone. Cassy also discovers that Eliza is her long-lost daughter who was sold as a child. Now that their family is together, they travel to France and eventually to France. They meet George Harris, who had run away previously. They decide to attempt to reach Canada. They are tracked by a slave hunter named Tom Loker. Eventually Loker and his men trap Eliza and her family, causing George to push Loker down a cliff. At this point Loker has changed as the result of being healed by the Quaker settlement for medical treatment. George, Eliza, and Tom have also obtained their freedom after crossing into Canada. The novel ends with Tom and Cassy traveling to France, where they meet Cassy' sister and accompany her to Canada, who discovers that Cassy is their long- lost daughter who is now a child once again. The book is about a Kentucky farmer named Arthur Shelby facing the loss of his farm because of debts. Shelby decides to sell two of his slaves to raise the needed funds by selling two of them.

name: The Beach
summary: Richard, a young English traveller, meets a strange Scotsman going by the pseudonym of Daffy Duck. The Scotsman leaves him a hand-drawn map of a supposed hidden beach located in the Gulf of Thailand that is inaccessible to tourists. Richard, Étienne, and Françoise set out to find what they believe must be paradise on earth. When the three travellers finally reach the beach, they are faced with a tight-knit and largely self-sufficient community which has almost completely shut itself off from civilization. Only a select few are chosen by the original founders to come to the island, and thus newcomers who were not given a personal invitation are not welcome, but are not sent away because to do so would jeopardize the secrecy of the community. It is during the Rice Run that Jed finds out that Richard gave a copy of the map to Sammy and Zeph when Jed overheard the two Americans talking about the beach to some German travellers. Richard later discovers that Jed has been assigned by Sal to keep a lookout on the island's perimeter and scope out arriving travellers who had heard word of the beach. In time, Keaty catches a dead squid which poisons most of the residents, and the healthy members remaining struggle to nurse the sick back to normalcy. Richard returns from his duty to find that Bugs has punched him in the face because of the heated argument due to his stoic nature due to Bugs' dislike of nature. Because of this, Richard moves in to partner with Jed and keep a close eye on the impending invasion of the neighbouring island to reassign him to keep the perimeter reassigned. The film is directed by David Lean and is based on a novel by the same name written by Mark O'Mara and published by Simon & Schuster in 1998. It has been released on Blu-ray, DVD and Blu-Ray in the UK, and on DVD in the US in the U.S. and in Australia in December 2014. For more information on the film, visit the official website of the film’s distributor, The Weinstein Company, or click here for more information about the film and the Weinstein Company. The movie is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, Spanish and Italian, with a few other languages available in other countries as well as in Spanish and Portuguese. It was released in cinemas across the world on November 14, 2014. It will be released in Australia on December 14, 2015, and in the United States on December 15, 2015 and in Germany on December 16, 2015.

name: Murder Must Advertise
summary: "Death Bredon" is the story of a young English copywriter. He is hired to investigate a cocaine-selling ring at a publicity firm. By day he is a distant, impoverished Wimsey cousin who works for a living. But on some evenings, he dresses up as a masked harlequin. He draws the attention and company of dissolute socialite Dian de Momerie - annoying Major Milligan. Wimsey wins the match for Pym's, which is about to expose his cover when the police, led by Chief Inspector Parker, arrest him for the murder of De Momerie. But the ring is still operating, and the police want to nab the whole gang at their next distribution - which they need to nab "Bredon's" boss. While "Lord Peter" sits in jail, "Lord Bred on" is seen about town for the next few days, and is supposedly seen about the town for much of the next year. The book was written by S. H. Bensons, where Sayers worked, and was published by Hodder & Stoughton. It was first published in 1936, and has since been republished in numerous editions, including a new edition of the first edition of this book, as well as a number of hard-to-read editions. For more information on the book, visit the publisher's website, www.hodder-stoughton-co.co.uk. For the second edition, see the Hodder/Stoughton website, and for the third edition, the publisher, Hodder and Stoughts, Inc., at the request of the author, go to www.hodderandstoughts.com, or call the publisher on 08457 90 90 90 or visit their website, http://www. HodderandStought.com/Hodges-and-Stoughts-Volume-II-of-The-Second-Involves-A-New-Invitation-To-Astery-by-S.H.B.-Sayers-in-A.W.S. (2nd Edition). For the third and final edition, visit www. Hodges&stought-company.org.uk, or go to the website, "Pym's Publicity, Ltd. (3rd Edition"). For the fourth and final issue of the series, see www.Hodder&Stoughtt-Company- Ltd.

name: The Man Who Would Be King
summary: Kipling is a British journalist in India. He meets two scruffy adventurers, Daniel Dravot and Peachey Carnehan. They plan to find a king or chief, help him defeat his enemies, then take over for themselves. They succeed in becoming kings, mustering an army, taking over villages, and dreaming of building a unified nation. Their schemes were dashed when DravOT decided to marry a Kafir girl, the girl bit him when he tried to kiss her, and the priests cried that he was "Neither God nor Devil but a man!" Most of the Kafirs turned against them, but the army defected and the two kings were captured. The story ends with the narrator sending Carnehans to the local asylum, where he later dies of sunstroke, no belongings were found with him. The book was first published in India in 1857, and has since been republished in several editions, including the first edition of "The Jungle Book" (1957) and the second edition (1961). The book is published by Chatto & Windus, a division of Penguin Books, and is published in the UK by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £12.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodgesandstoughton.co.uk. For the full story, see "Killing in the Name of God" by Rudyard Kipling, published in 1858, and "The Killing in the name of God," published in 1862, by Hodges & Stroughton, £11.99, and published by Hodgett & Stearn, £12,99. for the UK, £14.99 (including p&p). For the U.S. edition, go to http://www.hudleysandstearn.com/killing-in-the-name-of-god/Killing-In-The-Name-Of-God-by-Rudy-Kiplings-Volume-1-2-2/ (1958-1961-1962-2). For more on Kipling and his other works, visit http:// www.kipling.com and the-kidding-in the book of Killing in The First Invisible World (1958, 1961 & 1962 2,2,3).

name: A Vicious Circle
summary: The novel chronicles the life of Amelia, the only daughter of newspaper tycoon Max de Monde. Amelia decides to marry Mark Crawley, the father of her child, an ambitious young critic intent on shaking off his humble background. Mary Quinn, an Irish girl lacking a university education, rises to become a prominent reviewer of new fiction. Mary makes friends with Adam Sands, a yet unpublished author who keeps his homosexuality a secret from almost everyone including his own mother. When he is dying of an AIDS-related disease, Mary is the only person who remembers and eventually takes care of him. When the recession of the 1990s hits the country everyone seems to be affected by it. A Vicious Circle is published by Simon & Schuster, priced $28.99 (hardcover) and $24.95 (softcover) The book is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian and Portuguese. For more information on the book, go to www.simonandschulder.com and www.thebookshop.com/book/a-vicious-circle-by-jennifer-shelter-in-the-middle-of-the 1990s-and-towards-the end of the first year-of this year. For information on how to order a copy of the book in the U.S., call the National Book Store at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.bookseller.com/. For more about the book and its author, visit the bookshop.co.uk/shop/A-Vicious-Circle-In-The-Middle-Of The-1990s and the-Bookshop in the United States and/or the Bookshop Bookshop in the United Shelter in the United  States and Europe and the Bookshop in Europe and the Shop in the UK and Canada and  the Store in the Middle East and the Shop in the Europe in The Middle East and elsewhere in the world and on the World in Europe and the continent and in the Asia and Africa and North Africa and South East of the Countries and Asia at the same time and place as the book is being published. The book is published in English by Simon and Schulder, in English and French.

name: To Kill a Mockingbird
summary: The main story takes place during three years of the Great Depression in the fictional "tired old town" of Maycomb, Alabama. It focuses on six-year-old Scout Finch, who lives with her older brother Jem and their widowed father Atticus, a middle-aged lawyer. Atticus is appointed by the court to defend Tom Robinson, a black man who has been accused of raping a young white woman, Mayella Ewell. Despite significant evidence of Tom's innocence, the jury convicts him. Jem's faith in justice is badly shaken, as is Atticus', when a hopeless Tom is shot and killed while trying to escape from prison. Humiliated by the trial Bob Ewell vows revenge. He spits in Atticus' face on the street, tries to break into the presiding judge's house and menaces Tom Robinson's widow. Finally, he attacks the defenseless Jem and Scout as they walk home on a dark night from the school Halloween pageant, but amid the confusion, someone comes to the children's rescue. The mysterious man carries Jem home, where Scout realizes that he is Boo Radley. While standing on the Radley porch, Scout imagines life from Boo's perspective and regrets that they never repaid him for the gifts he had given them. The book opens with the Finch family's ancestor, Simon Finch, a Cornish Methodist fleeing religious intolerance in England, settling in Alabama, becoming wealthy and, contrary to his religious beliefs, buying several slaves. The children feed each other's imagination with rumors about his appearance and reasons for remaining hidden, and they fantasize about how to get him out of his house. After two summers of friendship with Dill, Scout and Jem find that someone is leaving them small gifts in a tree outside theRadley place. Several times, the mysterious Boo makes gestures of affection to the kids, but, to their disappointment, never appears in person. For many years few have seen him and for many years many people in Maycomb are hesitant to talk about Boo. For his part, Atticus faces a group of men intent on lynching Tom. This danger is averted when Scout, Jem, and Dill shame the mob into dispersing by forcing them to view the situation from Atticus's and Tom's points of view. It also becomes clear that the friendless Mayella was making sexual advances towards Tom and her father caught her and beat her. The sheriff argues with Atticus about the prudence and ethics of holding Jem or Boo responsible, but eventually accepts the sheriff's story that Ewell fell on his own knife.

name: The Emperor Jones
summary: The play is divided into eight scenes. Scenes 2 to 7 are from the point of view of Jones, and no other character speaks. The first and last scenes feature a character named Smithers, a white trader who appears to be part of illegal activities. During this scene, Jones is killed by a silver bullet, which was the only way that the rebels believed Jones could be killed, and the way in which Jones planned to kill himself if he was captured. In the last scene, Smitherings converses with Lem, the leader of the rebellion. SmitherS has mixed feelings about Jones, though he generally has more respect for Jones than for the rebels. The play was first performed in New York City in 1858. It has been performed in the U.S. and Europe since 1881. It was first staged in New Jersey in 1878, and in London in 1881 and 1883. It is the only play of its kind to be staged in the United States in the 19th century, and has been staged in more than 30 cities since then. The last scene of the play is the one in which Lem kills Jones by shooting him in the head with the silver bullet. The final scene is the last one in the play, when Lem kills himself by shooting himself in the face. The show was first produced in 1879. It had its world premiere at the New York Theater Center in New Jersey and was staged at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1883 and 1884. It also had a world premiere in Paris in 1884, and at the Grand Théâtre-Drouot in 1885, and was staged in Paris again in 1891 and 1894. It was the first play in the world to be performed at the Royal Court Theatre in Paris, which is now the home of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

name: The Go-Between
summary: Leo Colston is an elderly man looking back on his childhood with nostalgia. The greater portion of the text concerns itself with Leo's past, particularly the summer of 1900. Leo becomes a secret "go-between" for Marian Maudsley, the daughter of the host family, and nearby tenant farmer Ted Burgess. Leo's involvement as messenger between the lovers has disastrous consequences. The trauma which results when Marian's family discover what is going on leads directly to Ted's shotgun suicide. In a final twist to the story, 52 years later, Leo returns to Brandham. There he meets Marian's grandson and finds Marian herself in a cottage she had always told people she was going when she was really having clandestine meetings with Ted. Lord Trimingham married Marian, but died in 1910, and Marcus and his brother Denys were killed in the First World War. In the epilogue the older Leo tells the reader the consequences of this summer. The experience profoundly affects Leo, leaving him with permanent psychological scars. He subsequently grows up to be an emotionally detached adult who is never able to establish intimate relationships. He succeeds in repressing the memories until the diary unlocks them. Now looking back at the events through the eyes of a mature adult, he is fully aware of how the incident has left its mark on him. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, with a print run of 1,000 copies. The novel is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, and Spanish. It is published in the US by Simon & Schuster, and in the UK by Macmillan, £12.95, and £14.99. It has been published in Australia by Simon and Schuster and has been released in the U.S. by HarperCollins, £9.99 and £15, respectively. It was published in France by Penguin Books, with an edition of 2,000copies priced £10.95 and £12,99, in the United States by MacMillan and £13,99. The paperback version of the book is also available in Germany and the Netherlands. The U.K. edition has a copy of the paperback version for £10, with the price of £11.99 including the p&p, and the UK paperback version is £13.95. The US edition of the novel is also published in Germany, France, Switzerland, Italy and Spain. The UK edition has the US edition in paperback.

name: Mildred Pierce
summary: The book is the story of middle-class housewife Mildred Pierce's attempts to maintain her family's social position during the Great Depression. Mildred encounters both success and failure as she opens three successful restaurants, operates a pie-selling business and copes with the death of her younger daughter, Ray. Veda enjoys her mother's newfound financial success but increasingly turns ungrateful, demanding more and more from her hard-working mother while openly condemning her and anyone who must work for a living. When Mildred discovers her daughter's plot to blackmail a wealthy family with a fake pregnancy, she kicks her out of their house. After she finds Veda in bed with her stepfather, Mildred snaps, brutally attacking and apparently strangling her daughter, who now appears incapable of singing and loses her singing contract. Mild Red ultimately is forced to resign from her business empire, leaving it to Ida, a former company assistant. The book is set in Glendale, California, in the 1930s. It is about a middle- class housewife who tries to support herself and her children during the Depression. The novel is about the life of Mildred and her daughter Veda, who is an ambitious and pretentious elder daughter. The film is based on a true story that took place in Los Angeles, California in the 1940s and 1950s. The movie is directed by Robert Redford and features a cast of actors, including Robert Redfearn, Robert De Niro, Tom Hanks, David Carradine, David O'Brien, Michael Douglas, Richard Donohue and Robert Downey, Jr. It was released on September 14, 2008. It has been released on Blu-ray, DVD and Blu-Ray in the U.S. and in the UK on September 15, 2008, and on September 17, 2009, the UK release of the film will be released. It will be available on DVD in the United States on September 16, 2009 and on October 1, 2009 in Europe and the UK. The U.K. release date is September 28, 2009. For more information on the film, visit www.amazon.com/The-Great-Daughter-of-Mildred-Pierce-and-The-Movie-The Great-Daughters-Of-1930s-And-1940s/e/978-1-738-739-715-4. For the full movie version of this article, go to www.mailonline.com.

name: A Christmas Carol
summary: Dickens divides the book into five chapters, which he labels "staves", that is, song stanzas or verses, in keeping with the title of the book. Scrooge is established within the first stave as "a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous, old sinner!" He hates Christmas, calling it "humbug", refuses his nephew Fred's dinner invitation, and rudely turns away two gentlemen who seek a donation from him to provide a Christmas dinner for the Poor. His only "Christmas gift" is allowing his overworked, underpaid clerk Bob Cratchit Christmas Day off with pay - which he does only to keep with social custom. In the fifth and final stave, Scrooges awakens on Christmas morning with joy and love in his heart, then spends the day with his nephew's family after anonymously sending a prize turkey to the Cratchesit home for Christmas dinner. The story closes with the narrator confirming the validity, completeness and permanence of ScrooGE's transformation of the spirit of Christmas. It is the first of a series of Christmas books by Dickens, which include The Chimes, The Cricket on the Hearth, and The Christmas Carol. The book was published in 1843, exactly seven years after the death of Ebenezer Scrooges business partner, Jacob Marley. The tale begins on a "cold, bleak, biting" Christmas Eve in 18 43 exactly 7 years after Marley's death. It ends on Christmas Day in 1844, with Scroodge's son Tiny Tim dying from an illness that had been caused by his neglectful and untended grave. It was the last of Dickens' Christmas books, and he wrote the next two books in the series in 1855 and 1856. The last of the Christmas books was The Winter's Tale, released in 1856, and the last one in 1857, The Snowman, released the following year in 1858. The final Christmas book was The Christmas Card, published in 1861, and released the same year as the first two Christmas books. It tells the story of a man who dies and is visited by three ghosts, each in its turn, who accompany him to various scenes with the hope of achieving his transformation. The third spirit, the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, harrows Scrooie with dire visions of the future if he does not learn and act upon what he has witnessed including Tiny Tim's death, and it is shown that Scroo ge has passed away where businessmen planned to attend if lunch is provided.

name: About a Boy
summary: The novel is about Will Freeman, a 36-year-old bachelor, and Marcus, an introverted, bullied 12-year old who lives alone with his suicidal mother, Fiona. The action is set in 1993 and 1994 in London. The title is a reference to the song "About a Girl" by Nirvana, a band that is featured in the book, and Patti Smith's tribute to Kurt Cobain, 'About a Boy' Will and Marcus have started to live appropriately for their age groups. Therefore, Will, meanwhile, finally grows up and ends up wanting to marry Rachel. He also spends some time with his dad Clive, who visits Marcus and Fiona for Christmas together with his new girlfriend Lindsey and her mother. Will starts going out with a single mother named Rachel, whose son Alistair is about the same age as Marcus. In the end, Marcus comes out of his shell and learns to stand up for himself. He is adopted by Ellie McRae, a tough, moody girl, who is constantly in trouble at school because she insists on wearing a Kurt Cobains jumper. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99 (hardback) and £14.99 paperback ( paperback). name: The Hustler
summary: "The Color of Money" is a novel about a man who loses to a man he doesn't want to lose. The book is a treatise on how someone, with all of the skills, can lose if he "wants" to lose; how a loser is beaten by himself, not by his opponent; and how he can learn to win, if he can look deeply enough into himself. The novel was followed by the sequel The Color of money, which was also published in paperback and was published in the UK as "The color of money" in paperback, and in the U.S. as "Eddie and Fats" in hardback, and "Fats and Eddie" in softback, which is published in hardcover, and both are published by Simon & Schuster, Inc. in the United States as "FATS and Eddie," and "Eggs and Eddie", which is released in paperback in hardbound, paperback and hardback. For more information on the book, or to order your copy, go to: http://www.simonandschuster.com/.

name: Letter from an Unknown Woman
summary: As a teenager she had fallen totally in love with both the opulent cultured lifestyle of her neighbour and the handsome charming man himself. At age 18 she returned to Vienna, took a job and tried to meet the writer. He did not recognise her and, without revealing her name, she succeeded in spending three nights with him before he disappeared on a holiday. Pregnant, she lost her job and had to give birth in a refuge for the indigent. Resolved that their child should have a good life, she spent nights with or became mistress of various rich men but would never marry. In the 1918 flu pandemic, the child died and she, ill herself, wrote this letter to be posted after her death. [Condensed and translated from  The Letter from an unknown Woman by Barbara Ehrenreich, is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99. To order a copy of the letter, call the Mail Online newsdesk on 0203 615 4157 or visit http://www.mailonline.co.uk/newsdesk/article/article-18054/The-Letter-from-an-unknown-Woman-by-Barbara-Ehlenreich-is-posted-after-her-death.html#storylink=cpy. The letter is from a rich and well-known writer, returning from one of many holidays to Vienna. He finds a long letter from a woman who had lived with her poor widowed mother in the same building and had fallen completely in love. She had never met him before and he did not know who she was. She was an agreeable companion for that night, as he again did not recognise her. To him, she was just an agreeable companions for that day. To her, he was the writer and she was the woman he had fallen for. She never married because her heart belonged always to the writer because she was always with him. She wrote the letter to him after he had returned from a holiday and he sent it to her in a letter. She then wrote it to him to be sent after she had died in the 1918 influenza pandemic. It is published as a book by Simon and Schuster and costs £15.99 (£12.99). To order the book, go to www.samaritans.org/s/the-letter-from an unknown-woman-by Barbara Ehhenreich and £11.99 (or £10.99 in paperback).

name: Miss Lulu Bett
summary: The story concerns a woman, Lulu, who lives with her sister's family, essentially acting as a servant. She does not complain about her position, but is not happy. When her brother-in-law's brother, Ninian, comes to visit, there is a certain attraction between them. While joking around one evening they find themselves accidentally married, due to the laws of the state requiring little more than wedding vows to be recited while a magistrate is in the room for a marriage to count as legal. On learning they actually like the idea of being married, and choose to stick with it. However, within a month Lulu is back home, having discovered that Ninian was already legally married: 18 years prior he had wed a girl who left him after 2 years, and he had actually forgotten about the whole thing. She also notices that her teenage niece, Di, is unhappy, and also seems to be trying to use marriage as a way to escape her circumstance. Lulu eventually has to prevent Di from eloping, and is finally inspired to move out of her sister’s home and live on her own. Two endings were written for the play, the original as seen in December 1920 (and the ending that won Gale the Pulitzer Prize from Drama; the first woman ever to do so) The revised ending is a much less satisfying one, but more typical and would have been a bit more commercially acceptable and far less challenging to the audiences of the day. In this ending Ninian shows up in the nick of time just as Lulu decides to go off on her Own life to work and live elsewhere. He asks her forgiveness and she agrees saying "I forgave you in Savannah, Georgia." Lulu says in her final lines, "Good-by. Good-by, all of you. I'm going I don't know where-to work at I don’t know what. But I’m going from choice!" The original ending has Lulu starting a life on my own and undertaking adventures of her own as we hear in her last lines. In the revised ending, she says, "I don'tknow where to work at. IDon't know what, but I'mgoing from choice" Lulu's final lines: "I forgive you, my love. I forgive you. You've been a good friend to me. I love you, and I miss you, I love your family, I want to see you again."

name: Flatland: A Romance of Many Dimensions
summary: The story is about a two-dimensional world referred to as Flatland which is occupied by geometric figures. The narrator is a humble square, a member of the social caste of gentlemen and professionals. He is visited by a three-dimensional sphere, which he cannot comprehend until he sees Spaceland for himself. After the Square's mind is opened to new dimensions, he tries to convince the Sphere of the theoretical possibility of the existence of a fourth (and fifth, and sixth...) spatial dimension. Eventually the Square himself is imprisoned for just this reason, where he spends the rest of his days attempting to explain the third dimension to his brother. The Square recognizes the connection between the ignorance of the monarchs of Pointland and Lineland with his own (and the Sphere's) previous ignorance of other, higher dimensions. The point perceives any attempt at communicating with him as simply being a thought originating in his own mind (cf. Solipsism): The point (sole inhabitant, monarch, and universe in one) perceives all attempts at communication with him to be a thought originated from him. The Sphere visits Flatland at the turn of each millennium to introduce a new apostle to the idea of a third dimension. After this proclamation is made, many witnesses are massacred or imprisoned (according to caste) The Square finds it difficult to convince anyone of Spaceland's existence, especially after official decrees are announcedanyone preaching the lies of three dimensions will be imprisoned (or executed, depending on caste) Depending on caste, this novella can be read as either a novel or a short story. It is published in hardback, with a cover price of $16.99 (£9.99) and a Kindle edition of $12.99 (with a Kindle version of the same price available for $10.99). It is available in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Spanish and Portuguese. It has been translated into several languages, including Spanish, Italian and Portuguese, and has been published in a number of editions, including a special edition of the hardback version with a paperback version of $14.99 ($15.99), as well as a hardback of the book's hardcover version of £12.95 ($16.95). The book has been released in the U.S. and the UK, with the option to buy the book in the UK for £11.95 (with the option of paying £10.95 plus a free shipping fee).

name: Sick Puppy
summary: Florida's corrupt governor, Dick Artemus, pursues schemes to line his pockets and those of his rich entrepreneur backers at the expense of the environment. He has high hopes of a plan involving Toad Island, virtually uninhabited except for innumerable tiny toads. A former drug smuggler-turned-developer, Robert Clapley, plans to bulldoze the island and turn it into Shearwater Island, with high rise condominiums, a golf course and a massive new bridge to the mainland. He hires Palmer Stoat, a lobbyist, to expedite the project. By random happenstance, Stoat incurs the wrath of Twilly Spree, an ecoterrorist. Spree obsessively pursues a path of retribution after seeing Stoat litter, and tracks him back to his Fort Lauderdale residence where he and his wife Desirata live. Meanwhile, Twilly and Clinton Tyree are driving along the highway towards Tyree's wilderness when they see another group of litterbugs throwing lighted cigarette butts, empty bottles and other rubbish out of their speeding car. They immediately agree the they have to teach them a lesson. The film ends with the death of Stoat and only a few people show up at Stoat's funeral. It is the first of a two-part series on the corrupt Florida governor and his scheme to turn Toad Island into a high-rise condominium island. The second part of the series will be released on September 14. It will be followed by a look at the corrupt governor's schemes to turn the Everglades into a theme park. The third part will focus on the governor's attempts to locate an ex-governor who vanished about 20 years ago after a short and unsuccessful (but honest) term of office and is said to be hiding out somewhere in the remaining wilderness of Florida. The fourth and final episode will be about the governor trying to locate the ex-Governor's brother, who is still on his payroll as the keeper of a lighthouse that has not been in use for years. The fifth and final chapter will be a look into the corrupt Governor's scheme to make a deal with an environmentalist to stop the development of Toad Island. The last episode will feature a confrontation between the governor and the environmentalist who is trying to stop him from making the project a reality. The series will end with the governor seeking out and locates ex- governor ClintonTyree, who vanished 20 years.

name: The Prisoner of Zenda
summary: King Rudolf of Ruritania is drugged on the eve of his coronation. His brother, Prince Michael, has him imprisoned in a castle in the small town of Zenda. Rassendyll falls in love with Princess Flavia, the King's betrothed, but cannot tell her the truth. He determines to rescue the king and leads an attempt to enter the castle. The King is rescued and is restored to his throne, but the lovers, in duty bound, must part forever. The film was directed by Fritz von Tarlenheim, and is based on the novel by Rudolf Rass endyll, who was born in Germany in 1838. The movie was released in Germany on September 14, 1951, and in the U.S. on September 17, 1951. It was the first film in the series to be released in the UK, and the first in the German-language version, which was released on September 18, 1951 and the German version, September 19, 1951,. The film is about the coronation of King Rudolf, and also the death of his brother Prince Michael. It is the first of a two-part series about the King and his brother, with the second to follow on September 25, 1952, and September 26, 1953. The book is about Rudolf's cousin Rudolf and his attempt to rescue his brother from captivity. It also tells of the plots of Prince Michael's mistress, Antoinette de Mauban, and Count Rupert of Hentzau, the henchman of the King, and his dashing but villainous brother, Colonel Sapt. The story ends on September 27, 1952. The second part of the series, on September 28, 1953, is about Prince Michael and his attempts to reclaim the throne. The third and final part is about Michael and the King on September 29, 1953 and September 30, 1954, respectively. The novel is about these last two episodes, and how the King is finally restored to the throne and restored to power. The final chapter is about how the two brothers come to terms with the loss of their loved ones, and their love for each other, and what they must do to make up for their lost loved ones. For more information on the film, visit the film's website.

name: The Great Gatsby
summary: The novel opens early in the summer of 1922 in West Egg, Long Island, where Nick has rented a house next to the mansion of Gatsby, the mysterious host of regular, extravagant parties. Tom and Daisy Buchanan live across the bay in the more fashionable East Egg, where those coming from 'old money' live. Tom is muscular, brusque and considers himself an intellectual. The story begins with the narrator, Nick Carraway, a Midwesterner who has graduated from Yale and fought in World War I. He is restless and has decided to move to New York to learn the bond business. They invite Nick to dinner at their mansion where he meets a young woman named Jordan Baker, whom Daisy wants Nick to date. Daisy is Nick's second cousin, and Tom and Nick had been in the same senior society at Yale College. During dinner the phone rings, and when Nick and Daisy leave the room, Jordan informs Nick that the caller is Tom's mistress from New York. He then takes Myrtle and Nick to a party in a flat he is renting for her. The party breaks up when Myrtle insolently starts shouting Daisy's name, andTom breaks her nose with a blow of his open hand. The group decides to go to the city to escape the heat. Tom, Jordan and Nick take Gats by's car, a yellow Rolls-Royce. On the way home by the way by Myrtle's husband, George Wilson, runs out into the street after an explosive argument with her husband and hits the car with her yellow Rolls Royce. The book ends with the rest of the party in Tom's car followed by the end of the car, followed by an argument with the husband of Myrtle Wilson's husband and Tom's wife. The novel feels like it is watching them from the Plaza Plaza Hotel, where Tom confronts Gatsbys about his relationship with Daisy and demands that she tell him that she never loved him once, which shocks Gatby. The pair finally meet for the first time in five years, and he tries to impress her with his mansion and his wealth. She is overcome with emotion and their relationship begins anew, and they drive back together in the car together in GatsBy's car. After the War, Gats By decided to win Daisy back by buying a house in West egg and throwing lavish parties in the hopes that she would attend. His house is directly across theBay from hers and he can see a green light at theend of Daisy's dock.

name: For Whom the Bell Tolls
summary: This novel is told primarily through the thoughts and experiences of the protagonist, Robert Jordan. The character was inspired by Hemingway's own experiences in the Spanish Civil War as a reporter for the North American Newspaper Alliance. Robert Jordan is an American in the International Brigades who travels to Spain to oppose the fascist forces of Francisco Franco. In their camp, he encounters María, a young Spanish woman whose life had been shattered by the execution of her parents and her rape at the hands of the Falangists (part of the fascist coalition) at the outbreak of the war. He refuses an offer from another fighter to be shot and lies in agony, hoping to kill an enemy officer and a few soldiers before being captured and executed. The novel graphically describes the brutality of civil war. The narration ends right before Jordan launches his ambush. Though the bridge is successfully destroyed, it may be too late for the purposes of delaying enemy troop movements rendering the mission pointless, and Jordan is maimed when his horse is shot out from under him by a tank. Knowing that he would only slow his comrades down, he bids goodbye to María and ensures that she escapes to safety with the surviving members of the guerillas. In the end Jordan improvises a way to detonate his dynamite, and María is able to escape with the other members of her band of antifascist guerrillas. It is the only novel by a U.S. author to tell the story of the Spanish civil war from the point of view of a man who fought for the Republican side in the conflict. It was published in 1939 and is considered one of the best-selling novels of the 20th century, along with "The Godfather" and "The Great Gatsby" The novel was published by Simon & Schuster, and is available in hardback, paperback, and e-book. It has been translated into several languages, including Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese, and Portuguese. The book is available for pre-order on Amazon.com for $24.99, with a suggested retail price of $28.99. name: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?
summary: Jane Hudson was a child star of early vaudeville known as "Baby Jane" Her older sister, Blanche, became a star while Jane languished in her shadow. Blanche had a clause in her contract stipulating that her studio create a film starring Jane for every Blanche Hudson picture. Jane resents having to live in the shadow of her sister, who is now being remembered because of a revival of her films on television. In a drunken daze, Jane decides to revive her childhood singing and dancing act of Baby Jane, reasoning that Fanny Brice had success with Baby Snooks. She then hires a musical accompanist, Edwin Flagg, through a want ad. Jane abuses her sister with monstrous cruelty while embezzling her money to buy liquor and revive her Childhood act as " Baby Jane Hudson" Jane kills Elvira with a hammer from behind before she can help, and dumps the body. Jane goes to buy an ice cream and is recognized by the crowd of people who gather around to stare at her. She realizes what they want, so she begins to dance so she can get what she wants. Jane and Blanche continue to live together in the same mansion in a declining neighborhood. Jane is a slatternly alcoholic who still dresses as if she were 10 years old, and Blanches, disabled after a mysterious car accident involving Jane, continues to live with her in a decaying Hollywood mansion. Jane kills her sister and heads for the location of some of her happiest childhood memories, the beach, where crowds used to gather around and watch Baby Jane practice her songs and dances while Daddy played the banjo. Jane plays in the sand while Blanche lies there wrapped in a blanket. Jane eventually kills Blanche and dumps her body on the beach. Jane then goes to the police and is questioned by the police about her sister's disappearance. Jane believes that Blanche wants to sell the house and have her committed to a mental hospital, but Blanche reveals to Jane that it was actually she, and not Jane, who had driven the car on the fateful night. Jane had spent the evening teasing and mimicking Blanche at a party. As Jane unlocked the gates,. Blanche tried to run her down with the car, but Jane moved out of the way. The car then slammed into the metal gate, snapping Blanche's spine, crippling her. Jane was too drunk to know what had happened and could refute the accusations and could not refute the truth had almost come to her.

name: From Russia with Love
summary: British secret service agent James Bond is targeted by the Soviet counterintelligence agency SMERSH. His death is planned to precipitate a major sex scandal, which will run through the world press for months and leave his and his service's reputation in tatters. Bond's killer is to beSMERSH executioner Red Grant, a psychopath whose homicidal urges coincide with the full moon. The story ends with Bond fighting for breath and falling to the floor after being kicked in the foot by a woman who had poisoned him with a poisoned blade in her shoe. The film was released in UK cinemas on November 14, 1979. The UK release was delayed by a month. The US release was postponed by a year. The U.S. release was pushed back to December 8, 1979, and the U.K. release date was December 16, 1979; the UK release date is December 21, 1979 and the US release date of December 28, 1979 is December 30, 1978. The movie was released by Universal Pictures in the UK and Universal Pictures Europe in the USA. It was released on home release in the United States on December 31, 1978, and on European release on December 26, 1978; the US Release date is November 28, 1978 and the UK Release Date is November 29, 1978 (the UK release dates are November 28 and November 30, 1979 respectively). The film is directed by George Lucas and co-written by Ian Fleming. The screenplay was written by Michael Caine and Peter Morgan. It is based on a novel by Caine, based on the experiences of James Bond during his time as an MI6 agent in the 1950s and 1960s. The novel was adapted by Peter Morgan for the screen adaptation of The Godfather: Part II, starring Ian Fleming and Daniel Craig. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, who also wrote the screenplay for the film version of the Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part III, Part IV, and Part V, both of which are available on Blu-ray and DVD. The films were released on November 26 and December 7, 1978 respectively. The British release of the film was on December 14, 2008; the American release is on December 17, 2008 (the day after the release of The Lord of the Rings: The Dark Knight Rises). The movie is also available on DVD and Blu-Ray, with an audio version released on December 18, 2008, and a DVD of the movie on December 19, 2008.

name: The Tombs of Atuan
summary: The story centers on a Kargish child who is taken from her family and dedicated as the high priestess in the service of the "Nameless Ones" on the island of Atuan. Her true name is Tenar, but she is renamed Arha, "the eaten one", when she is formally consecrated to the gods' service at age six. Gradually she comes to accept her lonely, anonymous role, and to feel at home in the unlit underground labyrinth, the eponymous Tombs, where the malevolent, powerful Nameless Ones dwell. When she is fifteen years old, the arrival of Ged, the protagonist of A Wizard of Earthsea, dramatically disrupts the routine of her world. She finds him wandering, lost in the magic-laced labyrinth, and traps him underground to die in order to punish what she sees as sacrilege. Arha spares Ged's life and keeps him prisoner in the tombs, bringing him food and water. By now Arha's relations with Kossil have deteriorated to the point of no return and they have a public falling out in front of the subordinate priestesses. In the meantime while prisoner there Ged has discovered what he came to find - the other half of Erreth-Akbe's ring, which had been broken centuries before. He begs Arha to abandon her role as priestess and escape with him from the Tombs. She renounces her role and reverts to her original name, calling herself by her name Tenar. She helps Ged escape from the ring, as he frees her from the priesthood. Ged brings her with him back to Havnor where they are received in a new era of peace to Earthsea. The Tombs fall in upon themselves as Tenar and Ged free themselves and escape. They are reunited in Havnor and in a triumph and a new age of peace is ushered in. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (with a p&p of £12.99). It is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, Spanish and Portuguese, with a Spanish edition of £14.99, and a German edition of the same price (£12.95). The UK release date for the book is September 14, 2014. The US release date is September 15, 2014, and the UK release dates for the UK (September 14, 2015, and September 16, 2016, respectively).

name: Good Omens
summary: It is the coming of the End Times: the Apocalypse is near, and Final Judgment will soon descend upon the human race. The real Anti-Christ is Adam Young, a charismatic and slightly otherworldly eleven-year-old who has lived a perfectly normal life as the son of typical English parents. The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse assemble and the incredibly accurate (yet so highly specific as to be useless) prophecies of Agnes Nutter, seventeenth-century prophetess, are rapidly coming true. Agnes was burned at the stake by a mob because she had foreseen her fiery end and had packed 80 pounds of gunpowder and 40 pounds of roofing nails into her petticoats. She, in fact, decided to publish it only so that she could receive a free author's copy. There is only one copy of the book left, which belongs to her descendant Anathema Device. She teams up with Newton Pulsifer, the descendant of the man who initiated the burning of Agnees, to use the prophesies and find the Antichrist. As Adam blissfully and naively uses his powers, creating around him the world of Just William (because he thinks that is what an English child's life should be like), the race is on to find him—time is running out. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is scheduled to be released on September 14.
