The Book-Shop is the only store that has the bookshop's bookshop version of the The Book of The Show, which is also available on iTunes and Google Play.

name: Coraline
summary: The book is about a girl named Coraline Jones. She and her parents move into an old house that has been subdivided into flats. She discovers a locked door in the drawing room, which has been bricked up. In its place is a long passageway, which leads to a flat identical to her own, inhabited by her Other Mother and Other Father, who are replicas of her real parents. The Other Mother offers Coraline a chance to stay in the Other World forever, if Coraline will allow buttons to be sewn into her eyes. If Coraline wins, she, her parents and the ghost children may go free. If she loses, the Other Mother will not let them go. Coraline overcomes all the other Mother’s obstacles, using her wits and Miss Spink's stone. Back in the real world, Coraline finds her parents safe and with no memory of the afterlife. She returns home, victorious, and prepares to go about the ordinary life she has come to love and accept. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book. It is published in the U.S. on September 14, 2013. The UK release date is September 25, 2013, and the UK release dates are September 26, 2013 and September 27, 2013 respectively. The US release date for the UK version is September 28, 2014, and September 29, 2013 in the UK and September 30, 2014 in the Europe. The U.K. release dates for the European version are September 28 and October 7, 2013; the UK publish dates are October 8 and October 9, 2013 (the UK releasedate is October 9 and October 10, 2013). The UK publication date is October 8, 2013,. and the US publish date is November 8, 2014. The English release date of the book is November 14, 2014 (the U.N. release date was November 13, 2014). It is also the 30th anniversary of the publication of the first edition of "The Cuckoo's Calling" by Paddy J. Curnow and P.J. O'Brien. The paperback edition is also published by P.C. Wilson and is published as a special edition of $20 (with a suggested retail price of £12.99). The book was published by HarperCollins in the US on November 11, 2012, and in the United Kingdom on November 17, 2013 for £11.99 (and £14.99 elsewhere).

name: The Sandman: Dream Country
summary: Dream Country is the shortest of the eleven Sandman collections, featuring just four issues. Like the sixth collection, Fables and Reflections, and the eighth, Worlds' End, Dream Country consists of short stories that do not have a common storyline running through them. This is the story of a frustrated author, Richard Madoc, whose first book has been released to critical acclaim but who simply cannot write a page of the promised follow-up. He strikes a deal with an elder writer, Erasmus Fry, for Calliope, one of the Muses of Greek mythology, whom Fry had captured earlier in his life, in exchange for a bezoar. Fry kept her imprisoned and regularly raped her, and her presence provided the inspiration for his successful novels. Madoc also takes her captive and has great success in writing, but Calliopes calls upon the triad of witches known by many names, such as the Furies, the Kindly Ones or the Gracious Ladies, for help. They direct her to Morpheus, who we are told was once her lover (this relationship is elaborated on later in the series) Madoc's Book "Her Wings" appears in a few other stories by Neil Gaiman including The Last Temptation as a sort of inside joke. Rose Walker is later seen reading Fry's book "Here Comes a Candle" in Season of Mists. In the library of Dream, an unfinished book by Erasmos Fry, "The Hand of Glory" is seen in season of Mist. One of Madoc’s works, “The Spirit Who Had Half Of Everything", takes its name from an unused chapter title in an early draft of James Branch Cabell's Figures of Earth. This tale begins with a small, white cat being called by another cat to sneak away from her house one night. They speak of an event in a graveyard that they don’t want to miss. When they arrive, they see that many cats are already there. A Siamese cat comes to tell her story. She becomes disillusioned in human beings and ultimately rejects the life of a pampered pet. Her cause is strengthened when she has a dream that she has entered a boneyard in the Dreaming. A raven with no skin on its head informs her where she can find out exactly why the humans killed her offspring: a cave inhabited by the Dream Lord. She responds by saying that she will only state her business to Dream.

name: The Sandman: Season of Mists
summary: Morpheus travels to the Dreaming to free his former lover Nada from Hell. He finds that there are many entities who want to control Hell or prevent their enemies from controlling it. This episode sets up the basis for the spin-off comic series Lucifer written by Mike Carey. Susano-o-no-Mikoto, Duma and Remiel later become important characters in thespin-off series Lucifer. Between these deliberations is the story "In Which The Dead Choose To Stay", which takes place at a traditional English-school boarding school. His Return and Charles Rowland, #25, takes place in a school which borrows its name from the book. The story ends with Morpheus telling Nada that she will always be welcome in any form that she chooses to take in the Dreamer's world, even if she is reincarnated as a baby. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book versions for $3.99 each. The first two volumes of the series were published in the United States, with the third and fourth being released in the UK in the spring of 2013. The fourth and fifth volumes will be released in Europe in the summer of 2014. The final volume will be published in Australia in the fall of 2014, and the final volume of the first collection of the second collection will come in the Spring of 2015. The last two volumes are available in the U.S. and the UK for $4.95 each, with a suggested retail price of $6.99. The series is published in hardcover in the US and UK by Simon and Schuster, and in Europe by Macmillan Publishing, with an estimated retail value of $9.99 for the two volumes combined of $12.99 and £7.50 for the second and third volumes. The third volume is expected to be released later in the year, and will be the last of the Endless series to feature Morpheus in the Endless universe. It will also be the first to feature the character of Death, who angers Morpheus by taunting him about his intolerant treatment of a former lover, whose story formed the prologue to the second collections, The Doll's House. It is also the last collection to feature an Endless family meeting descending almost immediately into a Endless family argument. It also features a pair of angels sent by God, after Remiel relays a message that as Hell is a reflection of Heaven, its true creator should claim it.

name: Interview with the Vampire
summary: A vampire named Louis tells his 200-year-long life story to reporter Daniel Molloy. In 1791, Louis was a young indigo plantation owner living south of New Orleans, Louisiana. Distraught with the death of his pious brother, he seeks death in any way possible. Louis is approached by a vampire named Lestat, who turns Louis into a vampire. Louis begins to come to terms with his vampire nature but also becomes increasingly repulsed by what he perceives as Lestsat's total lack of compassion for the humans he preys upon. Louis feeds off a plague-ridden young girl one night, who is six years old, whom he finds next to the corpse of her mother. Fearing this, Lestats then turns the girl into a "daughter" for them, to give Louis a reason to stay. She is then given the name "Claudia". Louis and Claudia seek out more of their kind. They travel throughout eastern Europe first and do indeed encounter vampires, but these vampires appear to be nothing more than animated corpses, mindless and unintelligible. It is only when they reach Paris that they encounter vampires like themselves - specifically, the 400- year-old vampire Armand and his coven, the Théâtre des Vampires. Louis, Madeleine and Claudia live together for a brief time, but all three are abducted by the vampires. Louis eventually returns to the Theatre, killing all the vampires inside and killing the sun as it rises and killing all of them. Louis never recovers from Claudia's death and never fully recovers from the emotional connection between himself and Armand. Louis finds the remains of Thenhen as the sun rises and kills the vampire inside the Theatre. Louis and Madeleines are locked in an open coffin, but are burned to death by the rising sun. Louis then returns to America and leaves the Old World to live as a vampire in the New World. He later returns to Europe and eventually dies as a human vampire in a vampire-infested hotel room. He is eventually reunited with Claudia and the two travel across Europe for several years, but never fully recover from Claudia’s death and the connection between herself and Louis. Louis dies in a battle with the vampires of Paris, where he is eventually killed by the vampire Santiago, a prominent figure among the vampire coven. He then dies in the same hotel room where he first met Claudia and Claudia in 1791. The novel was written by Jean-Claude Van Damme.

name: Seven Against Thebes
summary: Oedipus, the king of Thebes, realized he had married his own mother and had two sons and two daughters with her. He blinded himself and cursed his sons to divide their inheritance (the kingdom by the sword) Eteocles and Polynices, in order to avoid bloodshed, agreed to rule Thebes in alternate years. After the first year, ETeocles refused to step down and as a result,Polynices raised an army (captained by the eponymous Seven) of Argives to take Thebes by force. This is where Aeschylus' tragedy starts. There is little plot as such; instead, the bulk of the play consists of rich dialogues that show how the citizens of the Thebes feel about the threat of the hostile army before their gates. Due to the popularity of Sophocles's Antigone, the ending of Seven against Thebes was rewritten about fifty years after Aes chylus's death. Where the play was meant to end with somber mourning for the dead brothers, it instead contains an ending that serves as a lead-in of sorts to SophocLES' play. The seven attackers and defenders in the play are: Tydeus, Melanippus, Capaneus, Hippomedon, Hyperbius, Parthenopeus, Amphiaraus, Lasthenes, Megareus, and Eteoclus. The play ends with a messenger announcing that the attackers have been repelled but that EteOCles and polynices have killed each other in battle. Their bodies are brought on stage, and the chorus mourns them. Then, a messenger appears, announcing a prohibition against burying Polynice; Antig one, however, announces her intention to defy this edict. The chorus then sings a choral ode to mark the end of the battle and the bodies of the attackers are brought to the stage to be laid to rest. Then the chorus sings another ode, this time to honor the seven defenders of the seven gates of the city. The final chorus ends with the chorus singing a song of praise for the seven captains of the Argive army and their respective shields. The last chorus is then sung by the chorus of the Seven, who then sing a song in honor of the king and queen, who are then laid to their final resting place at the seventh gate. Then they sing a final chorus to celebrate the victory over the attackers.

name: Tartarin de Tarascon
summary: The book was followed by two sequels: Tartarin sur les Alpes (1885) and Port-Tarascon (1890) It tells the burlesque adventures of Tartarin, a local hero of Tarascon, a small town in southern France. Tartarin's invented adventures and reputation as a swashbuckler finally force him to travel to a very prosaic Algiers in search of lions. Instead of finding a romantic, mysterious Oriental fantasy land, he finds a sordid world suspended between Europe and the Middle East. And worst of all, there are no lions left. By a coincidence, Tartarin encounters a lion and kills him. Unfortunately, the lion was a mascot of the local military garrison and Tartarin is dragged in front of a judge. But by a stroke of luck, he is released on a technicality and returns to Taras Con with the lion's skin to a hero's welcome. The book was published in 1885 and followed by a sequel in 1890. It was published by J.C. Penney and is available in English, French and Spanish. For more information, visit www.jcpenney.co.uk or www.amazon.com/Tartarin-Sur-Les-Alpes-Port-Tar ascon-Port. For information on the sequels to the book, visit Tartarin- sur- les- Alpes-Tartarascon. For a list of all the sequels, visit the JK Rowling website. For details on the sequel to Tartarin Sur- les Alpes, visit J.K. Rowling’s website or Amazon.com. For the sequel to Tartarin Sur Les Alpes, see J. K. Rowling's website or the Amazon Kindle store. for more information on Tartarin. for. the book or the Kindle store, visit Amazon.uk. for the Kindle version of the book. For an overview of the sequel, see the J.J. Rowling website and the Kindle Store.

name: The Sandman: The Kindly Ones
summary: The Kindly Ones is a single storyline written as a Greek tragedy, with Morpheus as its doomed hero and an aspect of the triad of witches, the Erinyes, as the Greek chorus. It pulls together various threads left dangling throughout the series, notably the grudges against Morpheus of several characters. It also continues several other stories, including that of Cluracan of Faerie and his sister Nuala, that of the Corinthian, and that of Rose Walker and her former landlord Hal. Parts from other collections are also important to its story, however, notably elements from Season of Mists and the story of Orpheus, told mostly in Fables and Reflections. In many places, Lyta is depicted as Medusa, even meeting Medusa's two sisters, Stheno and Euryale, at one point in the story. In an affecting sequence, the main story ends withMorpheus and Death on a desolate peak, echoing a sequence from one of the series' early high points, "The Sound of her Wings" (issue #8). Death asks for Morpheus' hand, and he simply disappears, in a flash of light. Having existed for all but an eternity, Dream of the Endless dies. Immediately upon the death of Morpheus, Daniel metamorphoses into a new aspect of Dream, with white clothes and hair, and an emerald instead of a ruby. It is never exactly clear to what extent he is aware of the course on which he has, to some extent, set himself, and how serious are his attempts to save himself. In a telling sequence, he finally lays himself open to the Furies by leaving his kingdom to fulfill a boon he had granted to Nuala even though he knows that his own end will likely be the consequence. Once more his refusal to shirk what he perceives as his responsibility for any reason is a turning point of the story, and once more he is unable to stop the Fury from taking their revenge. In the end, Daniel is eventually recovered alive and well by Morpheus's servants, the raven Matthew and a restored Corinthian. But Lyta learns that Daniel is still alive and safe, and is subsequently unable to stopping the F Fury from taking revenge on the witches who agree to help her in her goal. Unbeknownst to Lyta, the witches are empowered to destroy Morpheus by the fact that he has shed the blood of one of his family (that of his son, Orpheus) when he granted him the boon of death.

name: SS-GB
summary: Douglas Archer is a British homicide detective assigned to Scotland Yard. He is called in to investigate a murder of a well-dressed man in an apartment in Shepherd Market. Archer soon discovers that the dead man was a British physicist named William Spode. Spode was part of a German military team working on developing an atomic bomb. As his investigation proceeds, Archer finds the dangers increasing, as a subordinate is killed and Archer himself is nearly murdered by a member of the Resistance. Archer also develops a romantic relationship with Barbara Barga, an American reporter whom he first met at the Spode murder scene and who appears involved in the mystery. In a final meeting before his execution, Oskar Huth lwhom Archer has deduced was Spode's murderer, has also got what he wanted most: an honourable death for the King, and an incident that will bring about war between Germany and the United States. In the end, Archer is freed by Fritz Kellerman, who has what he wants – evidence which he can use to convict Huth of aiding the resistance and use that evidence to develop the atomic bomb that Archer will use to use against Huth. The film was released in November 1941, nine months after a German invasion led to the British surrender. It is one of the best-known films of the Second World War, along with "The Godfather" and "The Descendants" (both of which were released the same year). It was directed by David Lean and co-written by Tom Hanks. It was released on the 50th anniversary of the end of the First World War and the 100th birthday of the Battle of the Bulge. It has been hailed as one of Britain's best-ever films, and has been described as "a classic" by many critics. The movie is based on a true story, with many of the main characters based on real-life people and events in the 1930s and 1940s. The screenplay was written by Mark O'Mara, who also served as the editor of The New York Review of Books, and was co-authored by Peter Travers, who served as an assistant editor for The New Yorker and The Paris Review. The book was published by Simon & Schuster, which also published the novel as a hardback, with a foreword written by Simon and Schuster. The novel was also published by Harper Collins, which published it as a paperback, with an abridged version in paperback.

name: Finnegans Wake
summary: Finnegans Wake comprises 17 chapters, divided into four Books. Book I contains 8 chapters, Books II and III contain 4, and Book IV consists of only one short chapter. The chapters appear without titles, and while Joyce never provided possible chapter titles as he had done for Ulysses, he did title various sections published separately (see Publication history below). The standard critical practice, however, is to indicate book number in Roman numerals, and chapter title in Arabic, so that III.2, for example, indicates the second chapter of the third book. The entire work is cyclical in nature: the last sentence—a fragment—recirculates to the beginning sentence: "a way a lone a last a loved a long the / riverrun, past Eve and Adam's, from swerve of shore to bend of bay, brings us by a commodius vicus of recirculation back to Howth Castle and Environs." Joyce himself revealed that the book "ends in the middle of a sentence and begins in themiddle of the same sentence." I.2 opens with an account of "Harold or Humphrey" Chimpden receiving the nickname "Earwicker" from the Sailor King. He is then brought low by a rumor that begins to spread across Dublin, apparently concerning a sexual trespass involving two girls in the Phoenix Park, although details of HCE's transgression change with each retelling of events. HCE is finally brought to trial, under the name Festy King, and is eventually freed, and goes once more into hiding. An important piece of evidence – a letter about HCE written by his wife ALP – is called for so that it can be examined in closer detail in I.5. This letter was dictated by ALP to her son Shem, and entrusted to her other son Shaun, a postman, for delivery to a midden heap where it is unearthed by a hen named Biddy. In the two chapters of Book I we learn more about the letter's writer the Penman (I7) and its original author, his mother ALP. The final chapter consists of "Shaun's assassination of his brother Shem", describing the death of his mother [PAL], who appears at the end of the book. I.6 digresses from the narrative in order to present the main and minor characters in more detail in the form of twelve riddles and answers. The book reaches its ending up in a letter never before seen in a writer.

name: The Virgin Suicides
summary: The Lisbons are a Catholic family living in Grosse Pointe, Michigan in the 1970s. Their lives change dramatically within one summer when Cecilia, a stoic and astute girl described as an "outsider", attempts suicide by cutting her wrists. Lux begins a romance with local heartthrob Trip Fontaine. Trip negotiates with the overprotective Mr. and Mrs. Lisbon to take Lux to a homecoming dance, on the condition that he finds dates for the other three girls. After having sex with Trip on the high school football field after the dance, Lux misses her curfew. Consequently, the Lisbons become recluses and their house falls into a deeper state of disrepair. The girls send a message to the boys to come to the house. Shortly after the boys arrive, three of the sisters kill themselves: Bonnie hangs herself, Therese overdoses on sleeping pills, and Lux dies of carbon monoxide poisoning. Mary attempts to put her head in the oven, but fails. Mary continues to live for another month before successfully ending her life by taking sleeping pills. Mr. Lisbon officially takes a leave of absence. The house is sold to a young couple from the Boston area and most of the Lisbon's personal effects are either thrown out or sold in a garage sale. The narrators scavenge through the trash to collect much of the "evidence" they mention. The boys call the Lisbon girls and communicate by playing records over the telephone for the girls. From a safe distance, all the people in the neighborhood watch the Lisons' lives deteriorate, but no one can summon up the courage to intervene. After the suicide "free-for-all," Mr.  Lisbon leave the neighborhood. The narrator boys in particular. The Lisbon girls become increasingly fascinating to the neighborhood in general and the narrator boys, the narrators of the novel. The mystique of the LisbonGirls operates also for the neighborhood boys. The Lisbons' lives are popular subjects of neighborhood gossip. The cause of Cecilia's suicide and its after-effects on the family are popular Subjects of gossip. After Cecilia dies, the girls throw a chaperoned party, during which Cecilia jumps from their second story window and dies, impaled by a fence post. Cecilia is remembered as an astute and stoic girl who is described as a "outider" and a "stoic" and "stylist" The girls are also known as the "Lisbon Girls"

name: What Makes Sammy Run?
summary: Told in first person narrative by Al Manheim, drama critic of The New York Record, this is the tale of Sammy Glick, a young uneducated boy who rises from copy boy to the top of the screenwriting profession in 1930s Hollywood. Manheim recalls how he first met the 16-year-old Glick when Sammy was working as a copy boy at Manheim's newspaper. In the film industry, Manheim remarks at one point in the novel, it is the rule rather than the exception that "convictions are for sale," with people double-crossing each other whenever the slightest chance presents itself to them. The bosses prefer to have carte blanche when dealing with their writers, ranging from having them work on a week-to-week basis to giving them a seven-year contract. The one connection between Sammy's childhood days and his present position seems to be Sheik, someone who went to school with him and regularly beat him up. Now Sheik is working as Glick's personal servant (or almost slave)—possibly some kind of belated act of revenge on Sammy's part, or the "victim's triumph". Manheim becomes an eyewitness to the birth of what was to become the Writers Guild, an organization created to protect the interests of the Screenplay Writers Guild. He comes to understand, at least to some degree, "the machinery that turns out Sammy Glicks" and "the anarchy of the poor" Manheim realizes that Sammy grew up in the "dog-eat-dog world" of New York's Lower East Side (Rivington Street), much like the more sophisticated dog- eat- dog world of Hollywood. He feels that he is about to kill two birds with one stone with his girlfriend, Laurette Harrington, the daughter of a Wall Street banker, when he meets Glick at a reception, and genuinely falls in love with this "golden girl" At the reception, Glick meets Laurete's daughter, Laurete Atte, and immediately falls inLove with this girl, who is unceremoniously thrown out of the reception by the film company's financiers. When Glick sees his chance to get rid of Fineman altogether and take his place with his new girlfriend, he feels about two stone with one bird with two stone, and feels about one birds with two birds. When the film of Girl Steals Boy opens, Sammy is credited for "original screenplay" and Blumberg is not acknowledged.

name: The Razor's Edge
summary: Maugham characterises his story as not really a novel but a thinly veiled true account. He includes himself as a minor character, a writer who drifts in and out of the lives of the major players. Larry Darrell's lifestyle is contrasted throughout the book with that of his fiancée’s uncle, Elliott Templeton, an American expatriate living in Paris. Larry's proclivities tend towards the 13th century Flemish mystic and saint John of Ruysbroeck. Maugham dedicates the tale after Sophie has been murdered with an inscribed book by Baudelaire and Rimbaud in her room in Antibes, France. He is drawn back into the tale when police interrogate him in Toulon, where she has returned to smoking opium and promiscuity. But his outlook on death is somewhat positive: "I have always moved in the best society in Europe, and I have no doubt that I shall move in heaven in the next life" He also reveals how, through deep meditation, Larry goes on to realize God and thus become a saint—in the process gaining liberation from the cycle of human suffering, birth and death that the rest of the earthly mortals are subject to. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, and is available in hardback for £12.99 and paperback for £14.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk and www.amazon.com/The-Book-By-Larry-Darrell-and-Sophie-Bridgette-Antibes-Rimbaud-Budapest-1929-1930. name: Born Yesterday
summary: Harry Brock, a rich junk dealer, brings his showgirl mistress Billie Dawn with him to Washington, D.C. When Billie's ignorance becomes a liability to Brock's business dealings, he hires a journalist, Paul Verrall, to educate his girlfriend. In the process of learning, Billie realizes how corrupt Harry is and begins interfering with his plans to bribe a Congressman into passing legislation that would allow his business to make more money. The film was directed by Robert Redford, who also directed "The Godfather" and "Gone with the Wind" The film is available on Blu-ray and DVD in the U.S. and in the UK. For more information on the film, go to the film's official website or watch a trailer for the film on CNN.com/soulmatestories. The movie is based on a true story that took place in Washington, DC in the 1970s and 1980s. It was written by John Sutter and directed by Bobcat Goldthwait. It is the first of two films in the series about the corrupt junk dealer Harry Brock. The second film will be released in the spring of 2015.

name: King Solomon's Mines
summary: Allan Quatermain is an adventurer and white hunter based in Durban, in what is now South Africa. He is approached by aristocrat Sir Henry Curtis and his friend Captain Good, seeking his help finding Sir Henry's brother. They take along a mysterious native, Umbopa, who seems more regal, handsome and well-spoken than most porters of his class. They cross the mountains into a raised valley, lush and green, known as Kukuanaland. The inhabitants have a well-organised army and society and speak an ancient dialect of IsiZulu. They soon meet a party of Kukuana warriors who are about to kill them when Captain Good nervously fidgets with his false teeth. They are brought before King Twala, who rules over his people with ruthless violence. She shows them a treasure room inside a mountain, carved deep within the living rock and full of gold, diamonds and ivory. She then treacherously sneaks out while they are admiring the hoard and triggers a secret mechanism that closes the mine's vast stone door. After a few despairing days sealed in the dark, they find an escape route, bringing with them a few pocketfuls of diamonds from the immense trove. The Englishmen bid farewell to a sorrowful Ignosi and return to desert, assuring him that they must return to their own people. They eventually return to Durban and eventually to wealthy England, promising them that they will be venerated among his people and honoured among his. They find a different route, unable to go forward or back to an oasis by a broken leg, by which time they find themselves stranded in a different part of the desert. They then join Ignosi's army in a furious battle. Although outnumbered, the rebels overthrow Twala and Sir Henry lops off his head in a duel. They also capture Gagool, who reluctantly leads them to King Solomon's Mines. After the men prepare to be crushed under the stone door, they prepare to die also – but not before fatally stabbing Foulata, who had become attached to Good after nursing him through his injuries sustained in the battle. It takes all Quater main's skill to save his life. He has little hope they will return alive, but reasons that he has already outlived most people in his profession, so dying in this manner at least ensures that his son will be provided for. He comes to power years before when he murdered his brother, the previous king, and drove his brother's wife and infant son, Ignosi, out into the desert to die.

name: Babel-17
summary: During an interstellar war one side develops a language, Babel-17, that can be used as a weapon. Learning it turns one into an unwilling traitor as it alters perception and thought. This is discovered by the beautiful starship captain, linguist, poet, and telepath Rydra Wong. She is recruited by her government to discover how the enemy are infiltrating and sabotaging strategic sites. The novel deals with several issues related to the peculiarities of language, how conditions of life shape the formation of words and meaning, and how the words themselves can shape the actions of people. It is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (hardback) and £14.95 ( paperback) in the U.S. and is available to pre-order now. name: The Languages of Pao
summary: Beran Panasper is the son of the Panarch of the planet Pao. The Panarch is assassinated by his brother, who uses mind-control to do so. Lord Palafox, an offworld scientist, tries to reform Pao by creating three new castes. Beran attempts to return the planet to its previous state by re-integrating the castes into the general populace. The warrior caste stages a coup and takes command of Pao, but Beran returns to Pao under the name Ercolo Paraio and works for a few years as a translator at several locations. In the end, Beran looks ahead twenty years, to a future when all inhabitants of P Chao will be Pastiche-speakers — i.e., will speak a language which mixes some attributes and mindsets appropriate to peasant cultivators, proud warriors, skilled technicians, smart merchants and multi-skilled individuals. He will presumably shape a highly fluid and socially mobile society, composed of versatile and versatile andMulti-skilled people. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 (hardcover) and £12.95 (softcover). It is available in English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Spanish and Portuguese, with a Spanish-language abridged version available in the U.S. and Canada. name: The Count of Monte Cristo
summary: In 1815 Edmond Dantès, a young and successful merchant sailor, returns to Marseille to marry his fiancée Mercédès. His erstwhile captain Leclère, a supporter of the exiled Napoléon I, found himself dying at sea. On the eve of his wedding, Fernand, Danglars, and Villefort send an anonymous note accusing him of being a Bonapartist traitor. In order to silence him, he condemns him without trial to life imprisonment. After years of friendship, and knowing himself to be close to death, Faria tells him the location of the treasure, on Monte Cristo. He fakes an injury and convinces the smugglers to temporarily leave him on the island, then makes his way to the hiding place. He recovers the treasure and buys both the island and the title of Count from the Tuscan government. Disguised as the rich Count, he takes revenge on the three men responsible for his unjust imprisonment: Fernand, now Count de Morcerf and MercéDès' husband. He also becomes with the Baron Franz d'Épinay, the son of the young Viscount Albert d' Épinay. The Count appears first in Rome, where he becomes acquainted with the young MorcerF. He then moves to Paris, and becomes the sensation of the city. Due to his knowledge and rhetorical power, even his enemies, who do not recognize him, find him charming and desire his friendship. He is eventually rescued by the bandit Luigi Vampa before rescuing him from the same bandit before he is captured by the same group of men. He eventually persuades the Count to extend him a credit of six million francs and withdraws him from his enemies' clutches. He dies in Paris in 1820, but not before he has made his fortune and become the richest man in the city, even though his enemies do not recognise him. He later dies in a car crash in Paris, having lost all of his wealth and power. He leaves behind a wife and three children. He has a son with the Count of Montpellier, and a daughter with a wealthy banker, who is now living in Paris. He learns that his other enemies have all become wealthy, and gives Caderousse a diamond that can be either a chance to redeem himself, or a trap that will lead to his ruin. He returns to his old employer Morrel, in the guise of a senior clerk from a banking firm, buys all of Morrel's outstanding debts and gives Morrel an extension of three months to fulfill his obligations.

name: Cat's Cradle
summary: The novel is set in the fictional Caribbean island of San Lorenzo. It is ruled by the dictator, "Papa" Monzano, who threatens all opposition with impalement on a giant hook. The dictator later uses ice-nine to commit suicide rather than succumb to his inoperable cancer. Those caught practising Bokononism are punished with death by the giant "hook" The book ends with the dictator contemplating the last words of Bokon on the top of Mt. McCabe, where he states that if he were younger, he would have climbed to the top and placed a book on top of the mountain. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Penguin Books, on September 11, 2013. The first edition of the book is available in hardback and e-book, priced at $24.99. The second edition is expected to be released on September 14, 2013, and will be priced between $26.99 and $39.99 respectively. It will also include a free copy of the novel's first chapter, as well as a foreword and an extract from the book's second chapter, which is published on September 21, 2013,. The book will also feature a short story by the author, which will be called "The Book of the Dead" by David Perry. The novel is published in English and Spanish. The publisher has not confirmed whether or not the book will be translated into English or Spanish. It has been published in the UK and the U.S. since 2008. The U.K. has not published the book in the U.,S. and the UK have not published it in Europe.

name: Excellent Women
summary: The book details the everyday life of Mildred Lathbury, a spinster in her thirties in 1950s England. Perpetually self-deprecating, but with the sharpest wit, Mildred keeps busy with near-romances, church jumble sales, and of course the ubiquitous cup of tea. Mildred's life grows more exciting with the arrival of new neighbours, anthropologist Helena Napier and her handsome, dashing husband, Rocky. Through the Napiers, she meets another anthropologist, Everard Bone, and it is with him that Mildred will eventually form a relationship. A sub-plot revolves around the activities of the local vicar, Julian Malory, who becomes engaged to a glamorous widow, Allegra Gray. Eventually matters come to a head and Allegra leaves the vicarage after a quarrel. In the meantime, Helena, who has been on the verge of leaving Rocky for Everard, accepts that Everard does not care for her and leaves the neighbourhood, along with Rocky. As with most of Pym's books, the plot is less important than the precise drawing of the comic characters (such as Everard's elderly mother who is obsessed with birds) and situations. The book is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99, and is published in the UK on September 14. name: The Scarlet Pimpernel
summary: Marguerite St. Just is the wife of wealthy English fop Sir Percy Blakeney, a baronet. Before their marriage, Marguerite took revenge upon the Marquis de St. Cyr, who had ordered her brother to be beaten for his romantic interest. When Percy found out, he became estranged from his wife. Meanwhile, the "League of the Scarlet Pimpernel", a secret society of twenty English aristocrats, is engaged in rescuing their French counterparts from the daily executions (see Reign of Terror). Their leader, the mysterious Scarlet PIMpernel, takes his nickname from the drawing of a small red flower with which he signs his messages. Despite being the talk of London society, only his followers and possibly the Prince of Wales know the Pim pernel's true identity. The film is set in 1792, during the early stages of the French Revolution. It is the first of a two-part series, with the second due to be released in October. The second will be released on October 25, 2018. The third will be on October 26, 2018, and the fourth will come on October 27, 2019. name: Becket
summary: The play is a re-enactment of the conflicts between King Henry II and Thomas Becket as the latter (Henry's best friend) ascends to power. Becket begins as a clever, but hedonistic, companion; as a result of being created Archbishop of Canterbury, he is transformed into an ascetic. Ultimately, Becket is slaughtered by several of the king's nobles; and lastly we find the king thrust into penance for the episcopicide. The play is set in the reign of Henry II, who was crowned King of England in 1215. The production is directed by David Hockney and is based on the life of Henry III of England and his son, Henry IV of England. It was first performed in London in 1216 and has since been staged in London and elsewhere in the UK. It is currently on tour in the U.S. and is set to open in New York City in September 2014. It has been described as one of the best plays in the history of the theatre, with a cast of around 30. It also has been called the "greatest play of all time" by the New York Review of Books. For more information on the play, visit the website of the London School of Music and the Dramatic Arts.

name: The Robe
summary: The book explores the aftermath of the crucifixion of Jesus through the experiences of the Roman tribune Marcellus Gallio and his Greek slave Demetrius. In Jerusalem during Passover, Mar cellus ends up carrying out the crucifixions of Jesus, but is troubled since he believes Jesus to be innocent of any crime. Prince Gaius, in an effort to rid Rome of Marcelles, banishes MarcellUS to the command of theRoman garrison at Minoa, a port city in southern Palestine. Based upon their experiences first Demetrius and then Mar Cellus become followers of Jesus. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Simon and Schuster Publishers, on November 14, 2013. name: The Closing of the American Mind
summary: Allan Bloom's The Closing of the American Mind is a critique of the contemporary university and how Bloom sees it as failing its students. Bloom's critique extends beyond the university to speak to the general crisis in American society. Bloom argues that commercial pursuits had become more highly valued than love, the philosophic quest for truth, or the civilized pursuits of honor and glory. He cites the pop-star Mick Jagger as a cardinal representative of the hypocrisy and erotic-sterility of pop-music. Pop music employs sexual images and language to enthrall the young. Bloom claims that Jagger is a hero to many university students who envy his fame and wealth. Along with the absence of literature in the lives of young people, the first part of Closing tries to explain the current state of education in a fashion beyond the purview of an economist or psychiatrist——to explain the leading umpires of contemporary culture's leading uppires and their sexual but often unerotic relationships, the author says. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, with a print run of 2,500 copies. name: Murder in the Cathedral
summary: The play chronicles the days leading up to the martyrdom of Thomas Becket following his absence of seven years in France. Becket's internal struggle is the main focus of the play. The book is divided into two parts. Part one takes place on December 2, 1170. Part II takes place in the Archbishop's Hall and in the Cathedral. Four knights arrive with "Urgent business" from the king. They had heard the king speak of his frustration with Becket, and had interpreted this as an order to kill Becket. They accuse him of betrayal, and he claims to be loyal. He tells them to accuse him in public, and they make to attack him, but priests intervene. The chorus sings that they knew this conflict was coming, that it had long been in the fabric of their lives, both temporal and spiritual. Thomas is taken to the Cathedral, where the knights break in and kill him. The Interlude is a sermon given by Becket on Christmas morning 1170, about the strange contradiction that Christmas is a day both of mourning and rejoicing. He announces at the end of his sermon, "it is possible that in a short time you may have yet another martyr". We see in the sermon something of Becket’s ultimate peace of mind, as he elects not to seek sainthood, but to accept his death as inevitable and part of a better whole. The Chorus is a key part of the drama, with its voice changing and developing during the play, offering comments about the action and providing a link between the audience and the characters and action, as in Greek drama. The play begins with a Chorus singing, foreshadowing the coming violence. It ends with the knights step up, address the audience, and defend their actions. The murder was all right and for the best: it was in the right spirit, sober, and justified that the church would not undermine stability and state power. In the end, Becket again says he is ready to die, and the chorus again reflects on the coming devastation. The last temptation is the greatest treason: :To do the right deed for the wrong reason. You, my Lord, :In being with us, would fight a good stroke. You hold the keys of heaven and hell. :Power to bind and loose : bind, Thomas, bind, :King and bishop under your heel. :King, emperor, bishop, baron, king: Becket responds to all of the tempters and specifically addresses the immoral suggestions of the fourth tempter.

name: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
summary: The story is set in 1790 in the countryside around the Dutch settlement of Tarry Town (historical Tarrytown, New York) Sleepy Hollow is renowned for its ghosts and the haunting atmosphere that pervades the imaginations of its inhabitants and visitors. The most infamous spectre in the Hollow is the Headless Horseman, said to be the ghost of a Hessian trooper who had his head shot away by a stray cannonball during "some nameless battle" The "Legend" relates the tale of Ichabod Crane, a lean, lanky and extremely superstitious schoolmaster from Connecticut, who competes with Abraham "Brom Bones" Van Brunt, the town rowdy, for the hand of 18-year-old Katrina Van Tassel. The tension between the three is soon brought to a head when the ghoul clambers over the bridge, rears his horse, and hurls his decapitated head into IchabOD's terrified face. The next morning, Ichabid has mysteriously disappeared from town, leaving Katrina to marry Brom Bones, who was said "to look exceedingly knowing whenever the story of Ichbod was related" The story implies that the ghost was really Brom (an agile stunt rider) in disguise. Irving's narrator concludes, however, by stating that the old Dutch wives continue to promote the belief that Ichabods was "spirited away by supernatural means" and a legend develops around his disappearance and sightings of his melancholy spirit. The only relics of the schoolmaster's flight are his wandering horse, trampled saddle, discarded hat, and a mysterious shattered pumpkin. The story is left open to interpretation, but the nature of the headless horseman is said to "vanish, according to rule, in a flash of fire and brimstone" upon crossing the Old Dutch Burying Ground, where the Hessian is saidto have been killed in a battle of the American Revolutionary War. It is also possible that the story is a fabrication by the author to make money from the book. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Random House, on November 14, 2013. The first edition of the book was published by Random House for £12.99 (with a suggested retail price of £8.99). The second edition is expected to be published on November 25, 2013, and will be published by Penguin Books for £13.99. The third edition will be released on November 26, 2013 (with an estimated retail price for the book of £10.95 (including the p&p).

name: The Thirty-nine Steps
summary: Richard Hannay, an expatriate Scot, returns from a long stay in southern Africa to his new home, a flat in London. One night he is buttonholed by a stranger, a well-travelled American, who claims to be in fear for his life. The man appears to know of an anarchist plot to destabilise Europe, beginning with a plan to assassinate the Greek Premier, Karolides, during his forthcoming visit to London. Four days later Hannay returns home to find Scudder dead with a knife through his heart. Hannay fears that the murderers will come for him next, but cannot ask the police for help because he is the most likely suspect for the murders. Not only does he want to avoid imprisonment, but he also feels a duty to take up Scudder's cause and save Karolide from the assassination, planned in three weeks' time. He decides to go into hiding in Scotland and then to contact the authorities at the last minute. In order to escape from his flat unseen, he bribes the milkman to lend him his uniform and exits wearing it. He catches an Anglo-Scottish express train leaving from London St Pancras station. The next morning he reads in a newspaper that the police are looking for him in Scotland. Miraculously, he meets a road mender out on the moor, and swaps places with him, sending the workman home. His disguise fools his pursuers, who pass him by. By this time, Hannay is being pursued by an aeroplane, and a policeman in a remote village has tried to stop him. He manages to stay ahead of pursuers in a cottage in Beattock, south-west Scotland. Unfortunately, the man turns out to be one of the enemy and with his accomplices he is locked out of the room in which he is full of bomb-making materials, which he uses to make a bomb. A day later, he retrieves his possessions from the helpful roadmender and stays for a few days to recover from the explosion. He dines at a Public House in Moffat before walking to the Foreign Office to meet Sir Harry's relative at the Reading Public House. Sir Harry invites him to address an election meeting that afternoon, and Hannay feels able to trust him with his story. He leaves Sir Harry and tries to hide in the countryside, but is spotted by a group of men on the ground searching for him. The following day, he escapes, finding an inn where he stays the night. He tells the innkeeper a modified version of his story, and is persuaded to shelter him.

name: The Winter's Tale
summary: King Leontes of Sicilia begs his childhood friend, King Polixenes of Bohemia, to extend his visit to Sicilia. Furious at their escape, Leonte accuses his wife of infidelity, and declares that the child she is bearing must be illegitimate. The answer comes from Delphi--Hermione and Polixene are innocent, and Leontis will have no heir until his lost daughter is found. Sixteen years pass, and the son of Polixes, Prince Florizel, falls in love with Perdita. The sight of his wife's form makes Leonten distraught, but then, to everyone's amazement, the statue comes to life--it is Hermione.. The whole company celebrates the miracle. As the play ends, Paulina and Camillo are engaged, and they are married. The play ends with a scene in which the king is asked to name his daughter, and he says, "Perdita" The play is set in the time of the Roman Emperor Augustus, who ruled from 4th century BC to 5th century AD. name: Dead Air
summary: The first person narrative begins on 11 September 2001. Ken Nott is at a loft party in London at the crucial moment. The reader hears many of Nott's shock-jock lines. He is described as a drug and booze fuelled, sexually promiscuous party animal. His politics are left-wing and libertarian, and he rants at every chance. An indiscretion with a mobile phone and an answering machine leads him into some difficult and frightening situations. Apart from the expected difficulties associated with being a politically controversial radio DJ, everything is going smoothly for Ken until he meets Celia (or "Ceel"), a gangster's wife. He falls in love with Celia, who is also his long-suffering radio show colleague Phil, and his black DJ friend Ed. Nott also meets Jo, who does public relations for an indie band called Addicta. He also meets Ed, who works for a public relations company called the Public Relations Company. Notte's various girlfriends (including Jo) and Phil's long- Suffering Radio Show colleague Phil are described. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99. name: Nibelungenlied
summary: The Nibelungenlied was written in Middle High German. The poem is divided into two parts, the first dealing with the story of Siegfried and Kriemhild, the wooing of Brünhild and Siegfried's death at the hands of Hagen. The first chapter introduces the court of Burgundy, the virgin sister of King Gunther, and his brothers Gernot and Giselher. The second part deals with the marriage to Etzel, her plans for revenge, the journey of the Burgundians to the court, and their last stand in Etzel's hall. The original version of the poem began with the introduction of the protagonist of the work, which is believed to have been a late addition to the text, composed after the body of the poems had been completed. The opening verses are believed to be from the poem's preface, which promises both joyous and dark tales ahead. The preface ends with the words: "Full many a wonder is told us in stories old, of heroes worthy of praise, of hardships dire, of joy and feasting, of weeping and of wailing; of the fighting of bold warriors, now ye may hear wonders told" The poem has been translated into English, French, Italian, Spanish, Czech, Danish, Swedish, Finnish, Finnish and Swedish. It was written by the German playwright Hans Holbein, who was also the author of the Aesop's fable of the same name, and was published in 1283. The epic is set in the fictional city of Isenstein in Iceland, where Gunther requests Siegfried to sail with him to win the hand of Iceland's Queen, BrüNhild. Siegfried agrees, though only if Gunther allows him to marry Gunther's sister, whom Siegfried pines for. Gunther becomes afraid that Siegfried may yet be planning to kill them, so Siegfried goes invisibly to Nibelenland to kill Nibelun, the dragon who killed his brother Schilbung. After seeing Siegfried kill the dragon, it becomes apparent to the group that Brühild is immensely strong and they fear for their lives. After Siegfried wins the trial of strength with her hand in marriage as a reward, they will be sentenced to death. If they lose, Siegfried is sentenced to three athletic contests, throwing a javelin, tossing a boulder and a leap and becoming a single man. The group of 12 men then set sail for Iceland.

name: The Exorcist
summary: An elderly Jesuit priest named Father Lankester Merrin is leading an archaeological dig in northern Iraq. A young girl named Regan MacNeil living with her famous mother, actress Chris MacNeil, becomes inexplicably ill. After a series of poltergeist-like disturbances, she undergoes disturbing psychological and physical changes. Father Damien Karras, who is currently going through a crisis of faith coupled with the loss of his mother, agrees to see Regan as a psychiatrist, but initially resists the notion that it is an actual demonic possession. When he demands that the demonic spirit inhabit him instead of the innocent Regan, the demon seizes the opportunity to possess the priest. When Merrin, who had previously suffered cardiac arrhythmia, dies during the process, completion of the exorcism ultimately falls upon Father Karr as. The lengthy exorcism tests the priests both physically and spiritually. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99. name: The Sweet Hereafter
summary: The Sweet Hereafter is a multiple first person narrative novel. It is set in a small town in Upstate New York in the wake of a terrible school bus accident in which numerous local children are killed. The book was chosen in 1998 by Nancy Pearl, the then Director of the Washington Center for the Book at the Seattle Public Library, to be the first selection for "If All Seattle Read the Same Book", a program that has continued in the Seattle community and at many other public libraries around the country. The novel captures the atmosphere in aSmall town suddenly shaken by catastrophe. Fathers take to drinking, secret affairs are abruptly ended, whole families move away. Only the reader/viewer knows that Mitchell Stephens, the lawyer, has himself effectively lost his own child—his estranged, drug-addicted daughter informs him over the phone that she has just tested HIV positive. Only her father knows why, but he is unable to publicly reveal his daughter's motives. All the people involved know that Nichole Burnell is lying but cannot do anything about it. When she unexpectedly accuses Dolores Driscoll, the driver, of speeding and thus causing the accident, all hopes of ever receiving money are thwarted. The case now depends on the few surviving witnesses to say the right things in court. Only Nichole knows that she is lying and can't do anything to stop her. The story ends with Nichole telling her father she is HIV positive and that he must leave her alone to deal with it. She is now unable to move from the waist down (but isn't paralysed), but is still able to look after her younger brother, who is also in the same school as her and is a good friend of the family. The parents are reluctant to do so, but eventually they are persuaded by the lawyer that filing a class action lawsuit would ease their minds and also be the right thing to do. When Nichole accuses the driver of speeding, she does so, and the case is settled out of court and all hopes are put in the hands of the parents. The family is left devastated and Nichole is left unable to go back to school. The children are left orphaned and their father is forced to leave his job as a carpenter. The town is left without a father and a mother and the children are forced to grow up without their mother and father, who has to leave the town and move to a new town. It ends with the death of a 14-year-old girl who was sitting at the front of the bus and is now is unable.

name: A Severed Head
summary: Martin Lynch-Gibbon is a 41-year-old well-to-do wine merchant. His childless marriage to an older woman called Antonia has been one of convenience rather than love. It never occurs to him that his ongoing affair with a young academic called Georgie could be immoral. He falls for Honor Klein, Anderson's half-sister, who is a lecturer in anthropology at Cambridge. In the end, however, he realizes that life must—and somehow will—go on. The book is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99. For more information, visit www.simonandschulder.com and www.thestar.co.uk/book-of-the-week. For confidential support call the Samaritans in the UK on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details. For support in the U.S., call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/. For confidential support on suicide matters call the Salvation Army in the United States on 1-877-457-9255 or  visit www.samaritans.org.  For confidential help in the Middle East, call the Samaritans on 8457 90 90 90, or visit the Worldwide Suicide Prevention Line on 8457 90- 90 or click here for England. For help in Europe, visit The Samaritans in the UK and Europe on 8 457 90, or UK + Ireland + Italy + France + Germany + Spain + Greece. Italy and the Middle East are countries where relationships can become morally ruined by incompetence and abuse. Germany is one of the countries in which the book is set, along with the United States, France, Italy and the UK. The book is written by British author Martin Lynch-gibbon, who lives in London with his wife Antonia and her psychoanalyst, Palmer Anderson, a friend of the couple's. It is set in the 1970s and 1980s in London. The author has a son, a daughter, a son-in-law and a daughter-in law.

name: Coming Up for Air
summary: The themes of the book are nostalgia, the folly of trying to go back and recapture past glories and the easy way the dreams and aspirations of one's youth can be smothered by the humdrum routine of work, marriage and getting old. It is written in the first person, with George Bowling, the forty-five-year-old protagonist, who reveals his life and experiences while undertaking a trip back to his boyhood home as an adult. Bowling relates his life history, dwelling on how a lucky break during the First World War landed him in a comfortable job away from any action and provided contacts that helped him become a successful salesman. The concept of "you can't go home again" hangs heavily over Bowling's journey, as he realizes that many of his old haunts are gone or considerably changed from his younger years. Throughout the adventure he receives reminders of impending war, and the threat of bombs becomes real when one lands accidentally on the town. The final disappointment is to find that the estate where he used to fish has been built over and the secluded and once hidden pond that contained the huge Carp he always intended to take on with his fishing rod, but never got around to, has become a rubbish dump. In his eyes she has been so ravaged by time that she is almost unrecognizable and is utterly devoid of the qualities he once adored. She fails to recognize him at all. The social and material changes experienced by Bowling since childhood make his past seem distant. This painful memory seems to have sensitized him to - and given him a repugnance for - what he sees as the marching ravages of "Progress". He usually finds Old Porteous entertaining, but on this occasion his dry dead classics make Bowling even more depressed. He decides to use the money on a 'trip down memory lane', to revisit the places of his childhood. He recalls a particular pond with huge fish in it which he had missed the chance to try and catch thirty years previously. Eventually he locates the old pub where he is to stay, finding it much changed. Only the church and vicar appear to be the same but he has a shock when he discovers an old girlfriend, for in his eyes they have been almost unrecognisable and are utterly unrecognizable. He finds the place unrecognisable. His home has been transformed into a tea shop. His old girlfriend fails torecognize him atAll. The last time he saw her was at a Left Book Club meeting where he was horrified by the hate shown by the anti-fascist speaker, and bemused by the Marxist ramblings.

name: Shadow Puppets
summary: Peter, Ender's brother, is now Hegemon of Earth. Peter had planned for Bean to operate the mission, but at the last minute assigns Suriyawong, a battle school student from Thailand, to rescue Achilles in transport. Bean believes Peter has seriously underestimated Achilles, and that he (Bean) is not safe unless he is hidden. During their travels, Petra convinces Bean to marry her and have children with her by taking him to Anton, the person who Anton's Key was named after. Bean is reluctant to have children, as he does not want his Anton'skey gene to be passed on. The novel ends with Peter restored as Hegemonic, Petra reunited with Bean, and the world's Muslims reunited with a Caliph in command of the world’s Muslims, a China severely reduced in territory and forced to accept humiliating surrender terms. The original doctor who activated the key in Bean's genes, Volescu, has him prepare nine embryos through artificial insemination. One of the remaining six is implanted into Petra, while the rest of them are placed under guard. In the previous novel, China had conquered India and Indochina. Alai plans to liberate them by invading first China (in a feint), and then India (once China has withdrawn its armies to defend the homeland). His invasion is successful, and in the midst of realizing their danger, the Chinese government disavows Achilles, providing evidence that he stole the missile launcher that destroyed the decoy space shuttle. Left with nowhere to turn, Achilles contacts Bean and offers the embryos in exchange for safe passage. Achilles expects Bean to be so besotted with the idea of retrieving his children that he can be killed with a bomb in the transport container for them. When Bean sees through that trap, Achilles offers up fake embryos in petri dishes, expecting to lure Bean into a vulnerable position. However, Bean has already decided that Achilles was faking and refuses to fall for any of his traps. Finally, Bean pulls out a pistol and shoots him in the eye. Thus, Achilles is killed in a similar fashion to his first victim Poke, who he killed witha knife to the eye earlier in the series. Peter and his parents escape to the colonization platform in space that used to be the battle school, relying on the protection of Colonel Graff, the former commander of that school, now Minister of Colonization. Shortly after they arrive, however, a message is sent betraying their presence. The unmanned shuttle sent as a decoy is shot down over Brazil (the location of the former compound of the Hegomon, now occupied by Achilles.

name: The Road to Mars
summary: Told from the point of view of Professor Bill Reynolds, a scholar in the fictitious discipline of'micropaloentology' The novel is set in the 24th and 25th Centuries, when the solar system has been colonised. Reynolds is writing a thesis on fame and in his research discovers a dissertation on comedy submitted by Carlton, a robotic secretary for two stand-up comedians. Carlton seeks to understand the nature of comedy and human laughter, and attempts to describe humor as a mathematical formula. Most of the action in the novel follows this trio's adventures during the time when Reynolds believes Carlton was developing his theories. During this time, Carlton and his owners, Alex Muscroft and Lewis Ashby get caught up in a series of disasters including loss of work, parental responsibility and close scrapes with terrorists, the law, other entertainers, and a refugee crisis. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton at a cost of £16.99. For more information on the book and to order a copy, visit the publisher's website or call 0203 615 4157. name: Regeneration
summary: Siegfried Sassoon is a British soldier and poet. He is sent to Craiglockhart War Hospital after declaring against the continuation of the war. The opening chapters of the novel describe the suffering of other soldiers in the hospital. Sassoon struggles with the idea that he is safe in CraigLockhart while others are dying. The last chapters introduce the concept of class in the British Army, even during war. In the end, Sassoon and Owen work on their poetry on their return to France. The novel is published by Chatto & Windus, priced £16.99. The first edition of the book was published in April 1913. name: House of Leaves
summary: House of Leaves begins with a first-person narrative by Johnny Truant, a Los Angeles tattoo parlor employee and professed unreliable narrator. The rest of the novel incorporates several narratives, including Zampanò's report on the fictional film; Truant's autobiographical interjections; a small transcript of part of the film from Navidson's brother, Tom; and occasional brief notes by unidentified editors, all woven together by a mass of footnotes. Each narrator's text is printed in a distinct font, making it easier for the reader to follow the occasionally challenging format. The novel is about a family who move into a new home in Virginia. The house seems to be expanding, while maintaining the same exterior proportions. It is quoted by different characters at different times to have been located in each of the cardinal directions. The book ends with a series of passages along which various characters drive various characters to insanity, eventually driving them to death, murder, and Ultimately, Will releases what has been recorded as The Navidon Record, which has been edited and edited by Will and Karen because the house was becoming strained with Will's work-related absences. The sound of a passing truck causes Karen to look out the window every couple of minutes to look for her husband, who has been missing for a few days. "And yet even though Karen keeps overfilling the mold from the mold or cutting herself with scissors, she still cannot resist looking out the windows and looking away" The book is published in Times New Roman in the American version and Courier New in the British version. The U.S. version of the book is available in hardback and e-book versions, with prices starting at $24.99. It was published by Simon & Schuster in the U.K. in the summer of 1998. It has been hailed as one of the best books of the 20th century, and has been described as "a masterpiece of American literature" and "a towering achievement of American culture" The novel has been translated into several languages, including German, French, Spanish, and Italian. The American version has been published in the fall of 1998, and the German version in the spring of 1999, with the English version coming out in September of that year. The US version of House of Leaves was published in paperback in the Spring of 1998 and the paperback edition in the Summer of 1999. The UK version has not been released in the US yet, but it will be released in October of this year.

name: The Whalestoe Letters
summary: Pelafina writes these letters to Johnny from The Three Attic Whalestoe Institute, a mental institution. While a number of these letters appear in House of Leaves, The Whaleestoe Letters introduces a new set of letters. These letters serve to more fully develop Pelafina's character as well as her relationship with Johnny. The letters are published in a hardback edition of 10,000 copies. name: Restoree
summary: Restoree is the story of Sara, an introverted, beak-nosed, 24-year-old virgin librarian from New York who is abducted by the Mil. She is kept alive, with her skin removed and in a catatonic state from the physical and mental shock, on a meat hook as a Mil meal until the alien ship she is on is captured by human inhabitants of the planet Lothar. Without her skin, some Lotharians mistake her for one of their own and perform controversial "restoration" procedures on her, including a nose job. Sara comes to her senses in a mental institution with no memory of what happened, little knowledge of the local language, and a beautiful, golden-skinned body. At the institution, she is treated as if she were retarded and given menial tasks to do, as are other "restorees" who have been clandestinely salvaged from Mil ships. It is apparently some factor of Sara's Terran origins that allows her to fully recover from the shock of the Mil ordeal, while Lotharian restorees are of limited intellect at best. One of her jobs is to care for Harlan, the deposed planetary regent, who is being drugged into a moronic state. Recognizing what is being done, Sara helps Harlan to regain his senses and escape the mental institution. Sara and Harlan then gain the advantage over Harlan's political enemies, defeat the Mil, solve some of Lothor's emerging domestic problems and, of course, fall in love. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback and e-book. For more information on the book, or to order a copy, visit www.simonandschuster.com. For details on the movie, go to www.santacruz.com/restoree or www.the-film-of-restorere.com/. For more about the film, visit the film's official website or watch the film trailer for the film on CNN.com or watch a clip from the film "Star Trek: The Next Generation" at the beginning of the film. The film is also available on Blu-ray and DVD, as well as on the Blu-Ray and DVD versions of the movie "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the Planet of the Apes" The film was directed by David Lean and co-written by Robert Rodriguez.

name: Mister Roberts
summary: The title character, a Lieutenant Junior Grade naval officer, defends his crew against the petty tyranny of the ship's commanding officer during World War II. Nearly all action takes place on a backwater cargo ship, the USS Reluctant that sails, as written in the play, "from apathy to tedium with occasional side trips to monotony and ennui" The play is set in World War Two and is directed by David Cromwell, who also directed "The Godfather" and "The Great Gatsby," among other works. For more information, go to the theatre company's website or go to www.theatrecompany.org. For tickets, call the theater company at 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.theatercompany.com/theatre-company/the-godfather-theater-theatre.

name: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof
summary: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is the story of a Southern family in crisis, especially the husband and wife Brick and Margaret (usually called Maggie or "Maggie the Cat") The family is aware that Brick has not slept with Maggie for a long time, which has strained their marriage. Brick's indifference and his drinking escalated with the recent suicide of his friend Skipper. Maggie fears that Brick's malaise will ensure that Gooper and his wife Mae end up with Big Daddy's inheritance. Big Daddy reappears and makes known his plans to die peacefully. Attempting to secure Brick's inheritance, Maggie tells him she is pregnant, but Big Mama and Big Daddy believe that Maggie "has life". When they are alone again, Maggie locks away the liquor and promises Brick that she will "make the lie true" Big Daddy storms out of the room, leading the party gathered out on the gallery to drift inside. Both Big Daddy and Maggie separately confront Brick about the true nature of his relationship with his pro football buddy Skipper, which appears to be the source of Brick's sorrow and the cause of his alcoholism. Brick explains to Big Daddy that Maggie was jealous of the close friendship between Brick and Skipper because she believed it had a romantic undercurrent. He believes that when Skipper couldn't complete the act, his self-questioning about his sexuality and his friendship with Brick made him "snap". Brick also reveals that, shortly before he committed suicide, Skipper confessed his feelings to Brick, but Brick rejected him. Big Mama defends her husband from Gooper's proposals to gain control of the family fortune. Gooper, Mae and Big Mama start to discuss the division of the Pollitt estate. The party is to celebrate the birthday of patriarch Big Daddy Pollitt, "the Delta's biggest cotton-planter", and his return from the Ochsner Clinic with what he has been told is a clean bill of health. All family members are aware of BigDaddy's true diagnosis: he is dying of cancer. Maggie, Brick, Mae, Gooper,. and Doc Baugh (the family's physician) decide to tell Big Mama the truth about his illness and she is devastated by the news. BigDaddy reappears to make known his Plans to Die peacefully. Goopers and Mae know this is a lie, but big Mama andbig Mama believe that Big Daddy believes that Maggie 'has life' Big Mama tells him that Maggie is pregnant but BigDaddy believes that she is not.

name: Elmer Gantry
summary: The novel tells the story of a young, narcissistic, womanizing college athlete who abandons his early ambition to become a lawyer. The legal profession does not suit the unethical Gantry, who then becomes a notorious and cynical alcoholic. Gantry is mistakenly ordained as a Baptist minister, briefly acts as a "New Thought" evangelist, and eventually becomes a Methodist minister. He becomes her lover but loses both her and his position when she is killed in a fire at her new tabernacle. During his career, Gantry contributes to the downfall, physical injury, and even death of key people around him, including a genuine minister, Frank Shallard. Ultimately Gantry marries well and obtains a large congregation in Lewis's fictional Midwestern city of Zenith. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster at a price of $24.99.
