name: Sons and Lovers
summary: Gertrude Coppard meets a rough-hewn miner at a Christmas dance and falls into a whirlwind romance characterized by physical passion. The couple fight and drift apart and Walter retreats to the pub after work each day. Gradually, Mrs. Morel's affections shift to her sons beginning with the oldest, William. William gives his sex to a fribble, and his mother holds his soul. But the split kills him, because he doesn't know where he is. The next son gets a woman who fights for his soul — fights his mother. All the sons hate and are jealous of the father. The battle goes on between the mother and the girl, with the son as object. The son decides to leave his soul in his mother's hands, and, like his elder brother go for passion. He gets passion. Then the split begins to tell again. But, almost unconsciously, the mother realizes what is the matter, and begins to die. TheSon casts off his mistress, attends to his mother dying. He is left in the end naked of everything,. with the drift towards death. Lawrence summarized the plot in a letter to Edward Garnett on 12 November 1912: It follows this idea: a woman of character and refinement goes into the lower class, and has no satisfaction in her own life. She has had a passion for her husband, so her children are born of passion, and have heaps of vitality. But as her sons grow up she selects them as lovers, first the eldest, then the second. But when they come to manhood, they can't love, because their mother is the strongest power in their lives, and holds them. As soon as the young men come into contact with women, there's a split. Lawrence: "It's rather like Goethe and his mum and Frau von Stein and Christiana &MDash;... The son loves his mother andmdash"; all the sons love his mother &mdAsh; the son loves and is jealous of his father; he is jealous and resentful of his mother; he wants to be with his father, but he can't be with him. He wants to leave her but wants to go out on his own, and needs to experience love. He leaves Miriam behind as he grows more intimate with Clara, but even she cannot hold him. When his mother dies soon after, he is alone. When he meets Miriam's family's farm, Paul meets Clara Dawes, a young woman with feminist sympathies who has separated from her husband.

name: Survivor
summary: Tender Branson is a member of the fanatical Creedish cult, which engaged in a mass suicide ten years previously. He is one of the Creedish members who was sent out into the world to work as a servant, and send his income back to the community. Tender is not really a name, but a title, which is given to all male children except the firstborn, who is called "Adam". Likewise, all female children are called "Biddy", including the eldest. "Tender" is meant to denote one who tends; "Biddable" is one who is biddable. All but the first born sons and their wives are discouraged from having sex of any kind and are forbidden to marry, and the latter are expected to have sex only for procreation. The FBI move in to arrest the cult leaders only to find the entire community dead in an act of mass suicide upon hearing the news. The survivors are expected. to be prepared for such an event (called the "Deliverance" by the Church) as soon as they hear the news and kill themselves as soonas they hear it. Because it is revealed that Fertility is psychic, it is understood that she knows at this point that she is speaking to Tender about her brother's suicide and how she met him at the mausoleum. Eventually asks the man who hijacked the plane to be her lover, and he says "everything" He then hijacks the plane and takes it to New York City, where he plans to commit suicide in the middle of the day. He has released all of the plane's passengers and crew prior to this point. He explains the events leading up to the hijacking. At the start of his story, Tender works as the housekeeper for a rich couple he never sees in Oregon. At his dingy apartment, he gets phone calls from people who want to kill themselves - the result of a newspaper misprint which printed his phone number as the number for a suicide prevention hotline. He enjoys the thrill of passing divine judgment on these people, and tells them to kill himself as often as not, and sees this as an acts of mercy. After their meeting, Fertility calls Tender thinking she's a fake crisis hotline, so he begins to talk to her in a fake voice. Later that night, he has his weekly meeting with his caseworker from the Federal Survivor Retention Program, a government agency that keeps tabs on the survivors of suicide cults.

name: The Jungle
summary: Main character in the book is a Lithuanian man called Jurgis Rudkus, an immigrant to the United States trying to make ends meet. The book ends with another socialist rally, which comes on the heels of several recent political victories, which the speaker encourages his comrades to keep fighting for fighting for. The family's tragedies cumulate when Ona confesses that her boss, Phil Connor, had raped her, and made her job dependent on her giving him sexual favors. After his stint in jail, JurgIs returns home, only to find out that his family has been evicted. He finds his family at a relative's house, where he also discovers Ona in labor with her second child. Ona dies in childbirth from blood loss at the age of eighteen; so Ona has to rely on the greedy and incompetent Madame Haupt, whose carelessness leads to Ona's death. Soon after their first child drowns in the muddy street, causingJurgis to flee the city in utter despair and turn to drinking. At first the mere presence of fresh air is balm to his soul, but his brief sojourn as a hobo in rural United States shows him that there is really no escape—even farmers turn their workers away when the harvest is finished. One night, while looking for a warm and dry refuge, he drifts into a lecture by a charismatic Socialist orator, being given a sense of community and purpose. A fellow socialist employs him, and he resumes his support of his wife's family's family, although some of them are damaged beyond repair. He returns to Chicago and holds down a succession of jobs outside the meat packing industry and digging tunnels, as a political hack, and as a con-man. One injury results in him being fired, but injuries on the job, his past and his innate sense of personal integrity continue to haunt him. He drifts back into being a Socialist and finds a community and a strong labor unions, the answer to the evils that he and his fellow sufferers are forced to endure. A series of unfortunate events at work, along with a number of deaths in the family that under normal circumstances could have been prevented, lead the family further toward catastrophe. The most devastating decision comes when, in hopes of owning their own home, the family falls victim to a predatory lending scheme that exhausts all their remaining savings on the down-payment for a sub-standard slum house that (by design) they cannot possibly afford.

name: The Music Man
summary: "Professor" Harold Hill is a con man who tries to convince parents he can teach their musically disinclined children to play musical instruments. On the premise that he will form a band, he takes orders for instruments and uniforms. But once the instruments arrive and are paid for, he skips town without forming the band, moving on before he is exposed. Harold stumbles across his old friend Marcellus Washburn, who has "gone legit" and now lives in River City, Iowa. He declares his love for Marian Paroo, the librarian who gives piano lessons, but she ignores him. He kisses her and she slap him, and she forgets him. With Tommy's help, Harold signs up all the boys in the town to be in his band, including Winthrop, who is shy and self-conscious because of his lisping. He also sets up Zaneeta, the mayor's eldest daughter, with Tommy, and persuades Tommy to work as his assistant. The school board arrives to collect Harold's credentials, but he leads them in song and slips away ("Goodnight, Ladies"). The next day, Harold walks into the library, but Marian ignores him yet again, leading the teenagers in the library in dance. For a moment, her decorum and Harold's love for her are revealed. He forgets her again and kisses her again, andShe kisses him and she hits him instead. The town ladies are very excited about the band and the ladies' dance committee that Harold plans to form. He mentions Marian, and they intimate to him (falsely, as it turns out) that she had an inappropriate relationship with deceased old miser Madison, who gave the town the library to her. They also warn Harold that she advocates the "dirty books" by "Chaucer, Rabelais, and Balzac" ("Pick-a-Little, Talk-A-Little"). Harold tries to find out why Marian is not interested in him. She describes her ideal man as "My White Knight" She tries to give evidence against Harold against Mayor Shinn that she found in the Indiana State Educational Journal, but they are interrupted by the arrival of the Wells Fargo Wagon, which delivers the instruments for the band. Harold follows Marian home, attempting to flirt with her. Marian tells her to just say goodnight to her "someone" since she doesn't have a sweetheart. He follows her home and she tells him that she doesn’t have asweetheart. The next morning is Independence Day, and Harold takes the stage and announces to the townspeople he will prevent "sin and corruption" from the pool table by forming a boys' band.

name: Level 7
summary: World War III lasts a total of 2 hours and 58 minutes. All civilian life moves from the surface of the earth to a collection of underground shelter complexes. It later emerges that the orders given have been wholly automatic, and the war has taken place as a series of electronic responses to an initial accident. Toward the end of the novel, the inhabitants of the surviving shelters gradually find their deaths, as the surface contamination makes its way down past air filters and into ground water sources. At last, the occupants of "Level≯7" are exterminated through a malfunction in their nuclear power pile. The novel was published in paperback on September 14, 1998. It is the first of a two-part series. The second part will be published on September 21, 1999 and September 22, 1999. It will be available in hardback and e-book versions. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, Inc. and is available for pre-order on Amazon.com for $24.99 (with free shipping) and $26.99 with free shipping on September 28, 1999, and September 29, 1999 respectively. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschuster.com. For the second part of the series, see www.samaritans.com/world-war-III. The third and final installment will be released on September 30, 2000, and is expected to be released in hardcover on September 31, 2000. name: The Prince
summary: Machiavelli's work has a recognizable structure, for the most part indicated by the author himself, which can be summarized as follows. The Prince starts by describing the subject matter it will handle. New states are either totally new, or they are “mixed” meaning that they are new parts of an older state, already belonging to that prince. Machiaveelli generalizes that there were several virtuous Roman ways to hold a newly acquired province, using a republic as an example of how new princes can act. In some cases the old king of the conquered kingdom depended on his lords. 16th century France, or in other words France as it was at the time of writing of the Prince, is given by Machavelli as an examples of such a kingdom. The solution is to eliminate the old bloodline of the prince, to illustrate this point. The Medici, if they think about it, will find this historical example similar to the "Ottoman Empire" in their time - making this potentially easier to hold than France would be. Gilbert Gilbert notes that this chapter is quite atypical of any previous books for princes for the need to discuss conquering free republics. He also notes that holding a state is highly difficult for a prince, making it clear that holding such a state in any case makes it even more difficult for such a prince to hold it in the first place. He thinks MachiaVElli may have been influenced by Tacitus as well his own experience, but finds no clear predecessor for this. This categorization of regime types is also "un-Aristotelian" and apparently simpler than the traditional one found for example in Aristotle's Politics, which divides regimes into those ruled by a single monarch, an oligarchy, or by the people, in a democracy. In the opening of his Education of Cyrus he says that, concerning the knowledge of how to rule human beings, Cyrus the Great, his exemplary prince, was very different "from all other kings, both those who have inherited their thrones from their fathers andThose who have gained their crowns by their own efforts". Xenophon, on the other hand, made exactly the same distinction between types of rulers in the opening. of his education of Cyrus where he said that Cyrus the great was different from all other king, both in terms of his personal character and his methods of rule. In Chapter 2, he deals with hereditary princedoms quickly in order to show how easy it is to rule them.

name: Sounder
summary: A black sharecropper's family is poor and hungry. The father and his dog, Sounder, go hunting each night, but the hunting is poor. The family subsists on fried corn mush, biscuits, and milk gravy until one morning they wake up to the smell of boiling ham. They feast for three days, but finally the sheriff and two of his deputies burst into the cabin and arrest the father. Sounder runs after them, and one of the deputies shoots him. The arrested man's son goes looking for Sounder but cannot find him anywhere. Despite their deaths, there is a sense of peace and resolution over the family—especially over the boy, who has achieved the single thing he most wanted in the world, which is achieving his literacy. The boy leaves and finds a school where he tries to wash the blood off of his hands. He eventually meets an old teacher who takes him in, dresses his wounds, and asks what has happened to him. He tells the teacher about Sounder and his father, and the teacher extends an offer for the boy to live with him and learn to read. In the summer, the boy stays with the teacher during winter, working in the fields during the summer. The man and the dog are reunited and leave one night to go hunting, and, when the boy finds him and thinks he is asleep. When he gets home he tells his mother and she breaks to him that his father is dead. Soon after, Sounding climbs under the porch and dies as well. Soon they receive word that his dad was convicted and sentenced to hard labor, traveling county to county. TheBoy resolves to search for his father. During the late fall and winter months over a period of several years, he journeys within and among counties, looking for convicts working. One day the boy spots a group of convictsworking, and he leans up against a fence to watch them,Looking for his dad, he looks for him, and finds him. One fall the boy is at home helping with chores when they see his father walking back toward them. Half of his father's body is damaged from a dynamite blast, but he has made it home. The dog can only use three of its legs and only has one ear and one eye. The child finds an old book in a trashcan and carries it with him. Along the way he finds a teacher who offers to teach him how to read in the winter. He learns to read and goes back to school.

name: Nemesis
summary: The novel is set in an era in which interstellar travel is in the process of being discovered and perfected. Before the novel's opening, "hyper-assistance" is used to move a reclusive space station colony called Rotor from the vicinity of Earth to the newly discovered red dwarf, Nemesis. There, it takes up orbit around the semi-habitable moon, Erythro, named for the red light that falls on it. It is eventually discovered that the bacterial life on Ery Thro forms a collective organism that possesses a form of consciousness and telepathy. Back on Earth superluminal flight is perfected, ending Rotor Colony's isolation and opening the galaxy to human exploration. The story also relates the breakup and reunion of a family (the mother, the discoverer of Nemesis, and the daughter were separated from the Earthbound father when the colony departed; the father becomes part of the hyperjump research project as a result) and the discovery and resolution of a massive crisis: Nemesis' trajectory threatens to gravitationally destabilize the Solar System. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99 (hardback) and £20 ( paperback) and is available in hardback and e-book. name: Island of the Sequined Love Nun
summary: Main character, Tucker Case (Tuck), is a pilot for a cosmetics company, who crashes the company plane while having sex. This event causes Tuck to be blacklisted from flying in the United States, so he accepts a lucrative offer from a doctor-missionary on a remote Micronesian island. Tuck moves to the island, along with a male Filipino transvestite navigator and a talking fruit bat. There Tuck eventually uncovers a horrible secret harbored by the doctor and his wife, who have taken advantage of fact that the natives of the island have fallen under the influence of a cargo cult that developed as a result of establishment by Allies of an air runway there during World War II. The film's shock at the gruesome immorality of the situation leads to an adventurous and suspenseful climax. The movie was released on September 14, 2013. It is directed by Michael O'Neill and co-written by David Wojciechowski. It has been rated PG-13 by the U.S. censors, and PG-14 by the UK censors. It was released in theaters on September 13, 2013, and is available on DVD and Blu-ray. It will be released in Australia on September 15, 2014, and in the UK on September 16, 2014. name: The Lust Lizard of Melancholy Cove
summary: Pine Cove suffers a major crisis when the town psychiatrist, Val Riordan &mdash, substitutes all of her patients' anti-depressants with placebos. By coincidence, human-generated environmental activity stirs a prehistoric sea-beast from its underwater keep to come ashore. The beast exudes a pheromone that inspires uncontrollable lust among the residents of Pine Cove and also lures some of them as prey. When the beast starts eating residents and interfering with Theo's boss's meth business, Molly (who has become romantically involved with the beast) and Theo band together to make possible the beast's safe escape and to take down the boss at the same time. Meanwhile, Theophilus Crowe, the town constable, investigates a strange suicide, the activities of his corrupt boss, and his adversely affected marijuana habit. The film was released on September 14, 2013. It was directed by Mark O'Mara and co-written by John Cusack. It is based on the novel "The Secret Life of the Sea-beasts" by John L. Sutter and Mark O’Mara, and was published by Simon & Schuster at a cost of $16.99. name: Lost Girls
summary: Alice from Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, Dorothy from The Wizard of Oz and Wendy from Peter Pan are visiting the expensive mountain resort "Hotel Himmelgarten" in Austria on the eve of World War I (1913–1914) The women meet by chance and begin to exchange erotic stories from their pasts. The stories are based on the childhood fantasy worlds of the three women: *Wendy Durling. Wendy's sexual escapades begin when she meets a homeless teenage boy named Peter and his sister Annabel in Kensington Gardens. She marries the much older Harold Potter because she is not attracted to him, and would not have to think about enjoying sex ever again. *Dorothy Gale. While trapped in her house during a cyclone, she begins masturbating and experiences her first orgasm at the age of 16. She has sexual encounters with three farm hands whom she refers to as The Straw Man, The Cowardly Lion and The Tin Man. The erotic adventures are set against the backdrop of unsettling cultural and historic events of the period, such as the debut of Igor Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring and the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand. The graphic novel ends with Alice's mirror being destroyed by German soldiers who burn down the Hotel. In addition to the women's erotic flashbacks, the graphic novel depicts sexual encounters between the women and other guests and staff of the hotel. In the book, Alice becomes addicted to opium, and watches a young girl named Lily, among many others, abused just as she was. When Lily is instructed by Mrs. Redman to secretly perform cunnilingus on Alice under the table during a dinner party, Alice exposes her employer's secrets to the guests. Upon release Alice resumes her lesbian activity and drug use. Disowned by her family, she moves to Africa to run a family-owned diamond mine. Throughout most of her stories, Alice refers to her "aunt" and "uncle", whom she later admits were her step-mother and father, who discover her affairs. Her father takes her to New York City, under the pretense of seeking psychological help, but has sex with her repeatedly while they are in the city. Dorothy feels guilty of destroying her father's marriage, and leaves to travel the world. Alice's employer marries a Mr.Redman, but begins hosting extravagant, drug-fueled lesbian sex parties. She endures by staring into a mirror and imagines she is having sex with herself.

name: Quartet in Autumn
summary: Marcia, Letty, Norman and Edwin all work together in the same office, are all unmarried (Edwin being a widower) and have all reached retirement age. All four find retirement difficult to cope with, but the effects are most noticeable for the eccentric Marcia. She gradually withdraws from the outside world, gives up eating, and eventually dies in pathetic circumstances. Letty has the opportunity to take the country cottage after all. By now she has come to terms with retirement and does not move. At the end of the book, she is considering whether to introduce Edwin and Norman to Marjorie in the hope of matchmaking. She has unexpectedly left her estate to Norman, in whom she had indulged a brief and secret romantic interest. The book is published in hardback, with a cover price of £16.99. name: Some Tame Gazelle
summary: The two heroines, Belinda and Harriet Bede, are Barbara herself and her sister, Hilary. Archdeacon Hoccleve, a married clergyman for whom Belinda has long nurtured a passion, is believed to be based on Pym's first love, Henry Harvey. In the course of the book, both sisters receive proposals of marriage which they feel obliged to reject, partly because they are not attracted to the men in question, but mainly because they have become devoted to one another. In fact, Pym and her sisters did end up living together in a quiet village in Oxfordshire. Another character, Count Riccardo Bianco, is based on the real-life count and academic, Roberto Weiss. The British writer Robert Liddell, appears in the novel in the guise of Dr Nicholas Parnell. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £16.99. name: Satyricon
summary: The Satyricon is regarded by classicists such as Conte and Rankin as emblematic of Menippean satire. The work is narrated by its central figure, Encolpius, a former gladiator. In his insightful depiction of everyday Roman life, Petronius delights in exposing the vulgarity and pretentiousness of the illiterate and ostentatious millionaires of his age. The surviving sections of the novel begin with EncolPius traveling with a companion and former lover named Ascyltos, who has joined him on numerous escapades. An orgy ensues and the sequence ends with EnColpius and Quartilla exchanging kisses while they spy through a keyhole at Giton having sex with a virgin girl; and finally sleeping together (26). This section of the Satyricson takes place a day or two after the beginning of the extant story, and takes place at the estate of Trimalchio, a freedman of enormous wealth, who entertains his guests with ostENTatious and grotesque extravagance. The next day, En Colpius wakes to find that a fire has broken out in his inn, and uses this sudden alarm as an excuse to get rid of the sophist Agamemnon, whose company he had been with. The story ends with the end of the story, in which the characters are reunited with their former lover, Giton, who is now a boy of about 12 years old. The novel was written between 4th and 5th century BC. It is thought to have been written in the reign of Claudius VII, who was assassinated in 4th century BC. It was first published in Rome in 472, and has since been republished by the Library of Congress in a number of editions, including a new edition in 18th century editions. It has been described as one of the most important works of classical literature, along with the works of Sophocles and Diderot. The author is also known for his use of the term "frivolous" to refer to the excesses of the rich and powerful, and for his satire of the Roman elite, such as his depiction of the aristocrats of the time. He also used the word "sadness" to describe the suffering of the poor, which he called the "sufferers" in the novel. The ending of the book is said to have made him cry out for help, and he was eventually rescued by a porter.

name: Guns, Germs, and Steel
summary: Eurasia was the beneficiary of favorable geographic, climatic and environmental characteristics, particularly after the last Ice Age about 13,000–15,000 years ago. Diamond argues that Eurasian civilization is not so much a product of ingenuity, but of opportunity and necessity. Agricultural production leads to food surpluses, which supports sedentary societies, specialization of craft, rapid population growth, and specialization of labor. Large societies tend to develop ruling classes and supporting bureaucracies, which may lead in turn to the organization of nation states and empires. Although agriculture arose in several parts of the world, Eurasia gained an early advantage due to the greater availability of suitable plant and animal species for domestication. The book uses geography to show how Europeans developed such superior military technology, and how Europeans and Asians developed some immunity to diseases which spread among them, while epidemics of them devastated the indigenous populations in the Americas after European contact. In contrast, Native American farmers had to struggle to develop maize as a useful food from its probable wild ancestor, teosinte; moreover, it provides few nutrients and must be planted one by one – an extremely cumbersome task. The first step towards civilization is the move from hunter-gatherer to agriculture, with the domestication and farming of wild crops and animals. Grains such as bananas can also be stored for longer periods of time unlike tropical species, unlike tropical Grains can also can be stored of greater time. Sub-Saharan Africans had mostly wild mammals, whereas Eurasians are mostly chanced to have the most large animals on the planet: camels and camels. Diamond describes the principle of Anna Karenina as an instance of the promising breeds of domesticated species: Karenina horses, llama and alpaca as well as the llama, camels, llamas and alpacas within the same species; the rest of world none at all. He proposes explanations to account for such disproportionate distributions of power and achievements. He believes this is due to Eurasian societies' military and political advantages, stemming from the early rise of agriculture after thelast Ice Age. He also argues that Europeans have just one of the few promising species of docile animals that are just one small number of "candidates" (14 out of 148) as an example of the type of species that can be domesticated in Eurasia. He says Europeans have the potential to be the world's greatest innovators and inventors, but they have to work hard to achieve their goals.

name: On Golden Pond
summary: Norman and Ethel arrive at the summer house, finding it in need of repairs. There are hints that Norman is having problems with his memory. Chelsea returns, and reveals that she and Billy are now married. Ethel shows her impatience with Chelsea's habit of bitterly harping on the past. Chelsea confronts her father about their troubled relationship, and the two have a reconciliation. Norman seems to suffer a heart attack, (whilst picking up a box of his mother-in-law's heavy china) but recovers. The pair leave their home along Golden Pond for the winter. They agree to go visit her in California. Norman and Billy Jr. have become friends, and spend much of their time fishing. Norman (a bit reluctantly) agrees to keep Billy Jr.'s father, Billy Ray, at the house while he and Chelsea go to Europe. In the end, the Thayer's go to California to celebrate Norman's 80th birthday with Chelsea and her boyfriend Bill. They return to Golden Pond in the fall, where they will spend the rest of the year fishing and living in the summer home with Ethel and Norman's brother, Billy, and his wife, Ethel's sister, Mary, and her husband, Bill. The final episode of the series is set in New York City in the spring of 2013. It is the first time that the Thayers have been seen together since the end of the third season of The Partridge Family. The Thayer family have never been seen in the same place at the same time in one of the three films. The last time they were together was in the second season of the show, when they went to New York to visit Mary and Bill's family. The film is based on a novel written by Ethel Thayer, who is the daughter of Norman Thayer and the wife of Billy Ray. The novel is called "The Summer House" and is published by Simon & Schuster at a cost of $16.99. The book is available in hardback and hardback, and is available on Amazon.com for $12.99 and $14.99 in paperback. The movie is released on September 14, 2013. For more information on The Partridges, visit www.simonandschuster.com. For information on how to buy a copy of the book, or to order a copy, visit the publisher's website at www.samaritans.com/sales/The-Partridges-New-Series-The-Summer-House.

name: A Passage to India
summary: British schoolmistress Adela Quested and her elderly friend, Mrs. Moore, visit fictional city of Chandrapore, British India. Dr. Aziz, a young Indian Muslim physician, is dining with two of his Indian friends and conversing about whether it is possible to be friends with an Englishman. Adela meets Cyril Fielding, headmaster of the government-run college for Indians, at a tea party. Fielding invites Adela to see the Marabar Caves, a distant cave complex that everyone talks about but no one seems to actually visit. In the first cave, Adela is overcome with claustrophobia, for the cave is dark and Aziz's retinue has followed her in. She reports the alleged incident to the British authorities for attempted sexual assault. The British authorities release the British-up to Aziz for attempted assault for sexual assault, and the tensions between the British and the Indians are eased. Then the blow falls on Adela when she is arrested and charged with sexually assaulting Aziz in a cave in a bid to extort money from him. She is released and Adela and Mrs.Moore return to the train station on the train to return to Chandrapores. The book ends with Adela's marriage to Ronny Heaslop, the city magistrate. It is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Random House, on November 14, 2013. The first edition of the book was published by Random House at a cost of £12.99. The second edition has a price of £14.99 and the third edition is £16.99, both prices include a free copy of the unabridged version of the novel, which includes the author's personal essay and an extract from the first edition. The third edition includes a foreword and an excerpt from the second edition, as well as a selection of the first two chapters of the second book. The fourth and final chapter is published on November 15, 2013, and includes the novel's opening and closing scenes. The last chapter is the first of a two-part series on the history of the Indian subcontinent, titled "The Story of India" (Part I: The Story Of India, Part II: The story of India, Parts III and 4). The third and fourth chapters are the first and second of a series on India, entitled "India, The Story of the World" (part I: the Story Of The World, part II: the story of the world, part III: the drama).

name: A Room with a View
summary: The first part of the novel is set in Florence, Italy, and describes a young English woman's confusion at the Pensione Bertolini over her feelings for an Englishman staying at the same hotel. Lucy Honeychurch is touring Italy with her overbearing older cousin and chaperone, Charlotte Bartlett. In Rome, Lucy spends time with Cecil Vyse, whom she knew in England. Cecil proposes to Lucy twice in Italy; she rejects him both times. As Part Two begins, Lucy has returned to Surrey, England to her family home, Windy Corner, and this time she accepts. Cecil is a sophisticated and "superior" Londoner who is desirable in terms of rank and class, even though he despises country society. Lucy's brother, Freddy, invites George to play tennis with him at Windy corner, and they enjoy themselves so much they end up running around the bushes and running through the woods. Cecil thinks Lucy's mother is a snob as she thinks a comeuppance to the young man brought them to the village's landlord, whom Cecil thinks to be the new cottage's landlord. Lucy is initially mortified, but Freddy later invites him to bathe in a nearby pond, in the woods, and take off their clothes and swim in the water. Lucy and Freddy later meet the Emersons in Santa Croce, where Lucy meets them again. Lucy observes how boyish George is. As they stop to look over the River Arno before making their way back to the hotel, they have an intimate conversation. Lucy asks George to retrieve some photographs of hers that happen to be near the murder site. George, out of confusion, throws her photographs into the river because they were spotted with blood. After this, Lucy decides to avoid George, partly because she is confused by her feelings and partly to keep her cousin happy—Miss Bartlett is wary of the eccentric Emerson, particularly after a comment made by another clergyman, Mr. Eager, that Mr. Emerson "murdered his wife in the sight of God" Mr. Beebe persuades the pair to accept the offer, assuring Miss Bartlett that Mr Emerson only meant to be kind. The next day, Lucy embarks on a tour of Florence with another guest, Miss Eleanor Lavish, a novelist who shows Lucy the back streets of Florence, takes her Baedeker guidebook and subsequently loses her in Florence. The driver is permitted to invite a woman he claims is his sister onto the box of the carriage, and when he kisses her, he promptly forces the lady to get off the carriage box.

name: Alas, Babylon
summary: Randy (Randolph) Bragg, the protagonist, is a man who dabbles at law and lives a life with little purpose. He lives in the small Central Florida town of Fort Repose, which was founded by an ancestor during the 19th century. Bragg's life appears to be drifting down a somewhat aimless path when he receives a telegram from his older brother, Colonel Mark Bragg. The telegram ends the message with an ominous code: "Alas Babylon", a Biblical reference that the Bragg brothers employed throughout their lives as a euphemism for disaster. Mark believes the Soviet plan is flawed and that the West would ultimately prevail, but danger lies in Moscow's belief that they can succeed. This event becomes the apparent casus belli for the Soviet Union to launch a preemptive nuclear strike against the United States and her allies. The brothers soon say their goodbyes, and Randy realizes that he may never see Mark again. He also privately gives warning of the impending war to those people of Fortrepose whom he believes to be his friends, including Dr. Daniel Gunn and Elizabeth "Lib" McGovern, a young woman for whom Randy has come to care deeply. The book was released on September 11, 1998. It is the first novel by the author to be published in English. The novel is based on a true story; it was written by Randy Bragg and his brother Mark. It was published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Penguin Random House, on September 14, 1998, in a run-up to the 50th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the U.S. President's assassination. The film was directed by Robert Redford and co-starred by Tom Hanks. The screenplay was co-written by Robert Downey, Jr. and directed by Michael O'Brien. The movie was based on the memoirs of Michael O’Brien, who served in the Army during the Korean War and served as a member of the Florida State Legislature during the 1950s and 1960s. It has been described as one of the most anticipated films of the 20th century, along with "The Godfather" and "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part II" The film has been praised by many critics and is expected to be a cult classic. It will be released on DVD and Blu-ray on September 25, 2008. It also will be available on Blu-Ray and DVD on September 26, 2008, and on Blu/Ray on September 27, 2009, respectively.

name: Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures
summary: Christian Scientists often call Science and Health their "textbook" At Sunday services, passages from the book are read along with Bible passages. Eddy called the two books Christian Science's "dual and impersonal pastor" The two books encapsulate the teachings of Christian Science, Eddy says. name: Sister Carrie
summary: Caroline "Sister Carrie" Meeber takes the train to Chicago, where her older sister Minnie, and her husband Sven Hanson, have agreed to take her in. On the train, Carrie meets Charles Drouet, a traveling salesman, who is attracted to her because of her simple beauty and unspoiled manner. Carrie soon embarks on a quest for work to pay rent to her sister, and takes a job running a machine in a shoe factory. Before long, she is shocked by the coarse manners of both the male and female factory workers, and the physical demands of the job, as well as the squalid factory conditions. She also senses Minnie and Sven's disapproval of her interest in Chicago's recreational opportunities, particularly the theatre. Carrie’s dissatisfaction increases when she meets Robert Ames, a bright scholar and neighbor from her neighbor's Indiana. The couple grow distant, as Hurstwood abandons any pretense of fine manners toward Carrie, and she realizes that she no longer is the powerful manager of his Chicago bar. Carrie and Robert eventually move to New York City, where they live in a flat where they rent a saloon, and Carrie and Hurstwoods have an affair. The next day, the affair is uncovered and Carrie learns that HurStwood is married, and that his wife, Julia, has been out driving with another woman and deliberately excluded her from the Elks theatre night. After a night of drinking, and despairing at his wife’S financial demands and Carrie's rejection,Hurstwood stumbles upon a large amount of cash in the unlocked safe in Fitzgerald and Moy's offices. In a moment of poor judgment, he succumbs to the temptation to embezzle a large sum of money. Once they arrive in Montreal, HurstWoods’ guilty conscience – and a private eye – induce him to return most of the stolen funds, but he realizes that he cannot to mollify his wife to marry her, and so they return to Chicago and return to the U.S. The relationship intensifies as Minnie dreams about her sister's fall from innocence. That night, she writes a good-bye note to Minnie. and moves in to a much larger apartment, and their relationship intensified. The following day, Carrie learns she has been cuckolded, and Drouen discovers he has beenCuckolded. The pair eventually marry and move to Chicago. The novel ends with Carrie and Carrie returning to the United States.

name: The Accidental Tourist
summary: The plot revolves around Macon Leary, a writer of travel guides whose son has been killed in a shooting at a fast-food restaurant. Macon hires Muriel Pritchett, a quirky young woman with a sickly son, to train his unruly dog, and soon finds himself drifting into a relationship with the two of them. When his wife Sarah becomes aware of the situation, she decides they should reconcile, forcing him to make a difficult decision about his future. The book is set in Baltimore, Maryland, and is published by Simon & Schuster, which also published the film version of "The Reader" in 2004. name: Lamb: The Gospel According to Biff, Christ's Childhood Pal
summary: Biff has been resurrected in the present day to complete missing parts of the Bible, supposedly under the watchful eye of the angel Raziel. Biff is made to write down his account of the decades missing from Jesus' life. During these years he and Joshua travel to the East to seek the Three Wise Men (a magician, a Buddhist, and a Hindu Yogi) who attended Joshua's birth so that he may learn how to become the Messiah. Over a span of roughly twenty years, Joshua learns a great deal about human nature, world religions, and how he is able to translate those into his teachings. The recounting of Jesus' human and godlike qualities, combined with Biff's earthy debauchery, leads to its all-too-familiar tragic ending. At the conclusion of the novel, Biff completes "The Gospel According to Biff", giving it to Razial, who allows Biff to finally leave the hotel room. As Biff exits into the hallway he is surprised to find a resurrected Maggie exiting the room opposite, having finished her own Gospel weeks ago. The two embrace, informed by an angel that it is "the will of the Son" that they be together. In Moore's version, Mary Magdalene is depicted as harboring love for Joshua, though in this version Joshua remains chaste, as per Razile's instructions. This in itself leads to some of Biffs's debauchers, as he is literally attempting to go through enough harlots for both of them. The story takes a fantastical twist on Joshua's miracles as well: he learns to multiply food from one of the Wise Men and learns to become invisible from another; however, his ability to resurrect the dead figures strongly into his first meeting with Biffs when both boys are six years old. The novel also humorously explains many things: the origins of judo (a pun that is definitely intended), why Jews eat Chinese food on Christmas, and why rabbits became associated with Easter. In the final chapter, it is revealed that Biff was essentially "cut out" of the story. This leads to a revolving love triangle, leading to the two leaving together, Biffs content to be with Maggie even though he is her second choice. In this version Biff plans to marry if anything happens to Joseph, and Mary (Joshua's mother) all have their part in the life and times of Joshua. The three Wise Men, Mary, Joseph and Mary's mother are all shown in the novel.

At the end of the novel, Stevens instead focuses on the "remains of [his] day", referring to his future service with Mr Farraday. name: Crime and Punishment
summary: Raskolnikov, a conflicted former student, lives in a tiny, rented room in Saint Petersburg. He refuses all help, even from his friend Razumikhin, and devises a plan to murder and to rob an unpleasant elderly pawn-broker and money-lender. His motivation comes from the overwhelming sense that he is predetermined to kill the old woman by some power outside of himself. He also receives a letter from his sister and mother, speaking of their coming visit to Saint Petersburg, and his sister's sudden marriage plans which they plan on discussing upon their arrival. As the novel progresses, Raskolnkov is introduced to the detective Porfiry, who begins to suspect him for the murder purely on psychological grounds. At the same time, a chaste relationship develops between Sonya, though a prostitute, is full of Christian virtue and only driven into the family's poverty by her profession by her true character. Meanwhile, Razum and Raskolnikov manage to keep Avdotya from continuing her relationship with Pyotr Petrovich Luzhin, whose true character is exposed to be conniving and conniving. She, upon hearing the news, refuses to pay him any money in exchange for his treachery. She reveals that his wife is dead, and that she is willing to pay a vast sum of money for a vast exchange for nothing. She also reveals that he has killed her half-sister, Lizaveta, who happens to stumble upon the scene of the crime. He then flees and, due to a series of coincidences, manages to leave unseen and undetected. After the bungled murder, he falls into a feverish state and begins to worry obsessively over the murder. He hides the stolen items and purse under a rock, and tries desperately to clean his clothing of any blood or evidence. He shows strange reactions to whoever mentions the murder of the pawn- Broker, which is now known about and talked of in the city. In his delirium, he wanders Saint. Petersburg, drawing more and more attention to himself and his relation to the crime, and starts to draw more attention. In one of his walks through the city, he sees Marmeladov, who has been struck mortally by a carriage in the streets, and gives the remainder of his money to the man's family, which includes his teenage daughter, Sonya. In the meantime, his mother and sister, Pulkheria Alexandrovna, have arrived in the. city, both to meetLuzhin there and to attain RaskOlnkov's approval. It is for these very reasons that the two of them come to meet Luzkin.

name: The Long Dark Tea-Time of the Soul
summary: The central premise of the book is that gods are created by humans' necessity and desire for them. Because nobody worships them, many become destitute, like the tramps whom Dirk witnesses entering Valhalla. Odin makes Thor accidentally transmogrify objects when he gets angry, in a bid to delay him getting to Norway and finding the Draycotts' contract. The gods' world exists in parallel with our own – where St Pancras railway station is Valhalla. At the end of the novel, Dirk's fridge generates a new god of Guilt; it is implied this stops Toe Rag and the green monster from preventing Thor from retrieving the contract in Norway. The eagle that pursues Dirk and Thor is the transformed jet fighter that tries to stop him fromgetting to Norway. One of Dirk's chief characteristics in the novel is guilt—about the fridge and about the death of Anstey, whom he should have protected. This is why he needs to visit the airport at the opening of the novels. It is also why he is unable to fly to Norway using his hammer, and needs to go to the airport to find out how to get to Norway in the first place. He is naive and quite literally unworldly; this is how the Drayscotts are able to take advantage of him. He sees one of Cynthia Draycott's adverts for a soft drink, which seemingly involve various gods promoting the drink; one of these adverts is seen when Dirk confronts AnStey's son early in the book. He makes contact with the DrAYCOTts after seeing one of the adverts, which seems to involve gods promoting a drink. It's implied that this is what leads to his meeting with them. name: Damage
summary: The first person narrator of the novel is an unnamed medical doctor turned politician. The MP is casually introduced to his grown-up son's enigmatic girlfriend Anna. For as long as it lasts, Martyn, his son, has no idea that his father is having an extramarital affair with his girlfriend (and later fiancée) The MP enjoys a brief period of sexual bliss, meeting Anna in various European cities and having sex with her in unlikely places. Eventually, she buys them a small flat in central London where they meet on a regular basis. One day Martyn happens to get hold of that address and, curious, goes there to investigate. He climbs up a flight of stairs to the top floor, opens the unlocked door to the apartment, and is shocked to see his father making love to his fiancnee. Dazed and utterly confused, he tumbles backwards, hits the low banister and falls down the stairwell. He runs down the stairs completely naked, finding Martyn dead, sprawled out on the ground floor. He kneels on the floor and clutches Martyn's body to him until the police arrive. In the final scene, the MP, stripped of his political office and living abroad as a recluse, sits in his solitary room staring at oversized photographs of Anna and Martyn on the wall. name: The Railway Children
summary: The story concerns a family who move to "Three Chimneys", a house near the railway. The father, who works at the Foreign office, is imprisoned as a result of being falsely accused of selling state secrets to the Russians. The theme of an innocent man being falsely imprisoned for espionage and finally vindicated might have been influenced by the Dreyfus Affair. The Russian exile, persecuted by the Tsars for writing "a beautiful book about poor people and how to help them" was most likely an amalgam of the real-life dissidents Sergius Stepniak and Peter Kropotkin who were both friends of the author. The family take care of Mr Szczepansky, who came to England looking for his family (later located) and Jim, the grandson of the Old Gentleman, who suffers a broken leg in a tunnel. They become friendly with Albert Perks, the station porter, and with the Old gentleman who regularly takes the 9:15 down train. He is eventually able to help prove their father's innocence, and the family is reunited. The book was written a few years before the Dryfus affair was a prominent worldwide news item. It was published in 1936 and is available in hardback, paperback and e-book. A number of other sub-plots suggest some sort of greater mystery, but remain unexplored. The book ends with him returning home with his new "child" Malcolm (who is a clone of his dead friend Karl), leaving the other plot threads dangling. name: The Masque of the Red Death
summary: The story takes place at the castellated abbey of the "happy and dauntless and sagacious" Prince Prospero. Prospero and one thousand other nobles have taken refuge in this walled abbey to escape the Red Death. One night, Prospero holds a masquerade ball to entertain his guests in seven colored rooms of the abbey. At the chiming of midnight, the revelers and Prospero notice one figure in a dark, blood-splattered robe resembling a funeral shroud, with an extremely realistic mask resembling a stiffened cadaver. The revelers forcibly remove the mask and robe, only to find to their horror that there is no solid form underneath either. All of the guests contract and succumb to the disease. The final line of the story sums up: "And Darkness and Decay and the Red death held illimitable dominion over all" and "Darkness and Decay" is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99. name: Chocolat
summary: Two strangers, Vianne Rocher, and her small daughter Anouk, move into the small French village of Lansquenet-sous-Tannes. They are brought by 'the wind' during the last days of carnival, and they settle and open a chocolaterie, La Céleste Praline. The village priest, Francis Reynaud, is initially mystified, because Lent has just begun, but his confusion turns rapidly to anger when he understands that Vanne holds dangerous beliefs, does not obey the church, and "flouts" the unspoken rules that he feels should govern his "flock" VianNE is a witch though she does not use the word. Her mother and she were wanderers, going from one city to another. They were born with gifts, and used a kind of "domestic magic" to earn their living. When her mother is killed by a cab, she continues on her own, trying to evade the Black Man and the mysetrious force of the wind and settle down to a normal life. She has an innate talent for cooking and a charming personality. She tries to fit in and help her customers. She starts to build a group of regular customers, and, to Reynaud's dismay, she doesn't go out of business. Some people initially stay away, but not for long. His conflict with her becomes his personal crusade. He attempts to have her run out of town, and he talks about her every Sunday at church. But she announces a "Grand Festival of Chocolate", to be held on Easter Sunday. Vianene, however, is an old dream of hers, and it is her dream to run a ch chocolateaterie. She also has a daughter, who is more social and passive than her daughter. She is born with a gift for cooking, and uses it to earn her living. Throughout her life, she has been running from the "Black Man", a recurring motif in her mother's folklore. When she is killed, she tries to evade it and settles down to the normal life she has always dreamed of. But her daughter is killed and she is left with a daughter who is also a wanderer, who uses her gifts to earn a living. She begins to run away from the town, but some people stay away. Reynaud attempts to get her out of the village, but she refuses to leave. He becomes obsessed with her, and his battle with her is a personal crusade, and becomes his own.

name: The Ghost Road
summary: Prior has been cured of shell-shock and is preparing to return to France. Rivers, concerned for Prior's safety, finally recognises that his relationship with Prior, and his other patients for that matter, is deeply paternal. This episode is a symbolic capitulation to the inevitability of his death at the Western Front, a fate he shares with the poet, Wilfred Owen to which in a futile battle that takes place a few days before the Armistice, Billy and his friendWilfred Owen are killed. In contrast with upper-class officers like Sassoon, with whom Rivers has been able to form warm friendships, he has always found Prior to be a thorn in his side. As Prior returns to the front, Rivers continues to take care of his patients and his invalid sister. Amid this he reminisces uncomfortably about his childhood and memories of his experience ten years earlier on an anthropological expedition to Melanesia (now Eddystone Island). There, he befriended Nijiru, the local priest-healer who took Rivers on his rounds to see sick villagers and also to the island's sacred Place of the Skulls. In this episode, he takes Rivers on a tour of the island and visits the sacred place of the skulls, which he later visits again with his sister. In the end, Rivers is forced to leave the island to return home to his wife and children. This is a symbol of how he has come to terms with the fact that he will never be able to see his children again, and how he will have to live with the loss of his mother and sister. It is also the last episode of the film, which is set during the Second World War. The film is directed by David Lean and is based on a novel by the same name, written by David Walliams. It was released on 25th November 2013 and is available on Blu-ray and DVD. For more information on the film and to order a copy of the book, visit the publisher's website. Rosemary and Guy are quickly welcomed by Minnie and Roman Castevet, an eccentric elderly couple. After receiving a warning from a friend, who also becomes mysteriously ill, Rosemary investigates and confirms that her neighbors are the leaders of a Satanic coven. They plan to use Rosemary as a vessel to carry a child spawned from Satan himself. In the end, Rose Mary discovers she is wrong about the coven's reason for wanting the baby, but the truth is even more horrific than she could ever imagine. name: This Perfect Day
summary: Li RM35M4419, nicknamed "Chip" (as in "chip off the old block") by his nonconformist grandfather Jan, is a typical child Member who, through a mistake in genetic programming, has one green eye. Chip is told by his adviser that "picking" and "choice" are manifestations of selfishness, and he tries to forget his dreams. Chip and Lilac begin to search through old museum maps and soon discover islands around the world that have disappeared from their modern map. They begin to wonder if perhaps other "incurable" members like themselves have escaped to these islands. Chip conceives of a plan to destroy the computer, UniComp, by blowing up its refrigeration system. He recruits other incurables to join him, and they make their way to the mainland. But when a new group of incurables arrive, Chip steals their explosives and completes his mission to blow up UniComp. Before he returns to Majorca, signs of a new life have already begun: rain begins to fall in the daytime, and members who were scheduled to die do not. He locates Lilac again and kidnaps her. At first she fights him, but as she too becomes more "awake," she remembers the islands and comes willingly. Finding a convenient abandoned boat on the beach, they head for the nearest island of Majorca. There they learn that UniComp has planted failsafes that eventually lead all incurables. toThese islands, where they will be trapped forever away from the treated population. They are met by Wei, one of the original planners of the Unification. Wei and the other "programmers" who live in UniComp have arranged this test so that the most daring and resourceful incurables will make their own way to UniComp where they, too, will live in luxury as programmers. Chip begins an affair with Snowflake, but is really attracted to Lilac. Chip soon learns that King has already interacted with some "incurables" and that they are indeed real. He is able to shield his arm from the treatment nozzle and becomes fully awake for the first time. He and all the other members of the group are captured and treated back into docility. He eventually learns that the incurables are real and that he must kill Wei to save them. He kills Wei in the process, but before he can tell Lilac, Chip's ruse is discovered by his Adviser and he is captured and captured.

name: The Boys from Brazil
summary: Yakov Liebermann is a Nazi hunter who documents crimes against humanity. In 1974 he receives a phone call from a young man who claims to have eavesdropped on the so-called "Angel of Death" Dr. Josef Mengele. According to the young man, Mengesle is sending out six Nazis to kill 94 men, who share a few common traits. All men are civil servants, and all of them have to be killed on or about particular dates, spread over several years. It eventually transpires each of the 94 targets has a son aged 13, a genetic clone of Adolf Hitler planted by Mengelle. The book ends with one of the Hitler clones developing delusions of grandeur and being killed by the targeted man's collection of dangerous dogs. The plan is halted, but 18 Hitler clones have already lost their fathers, and 18 more are in the process of losing their fathers as a result of Liebermanns' work. name: A Descent into the Maelstrom
summary: The story is told by an old man who reveals that he only appears old. The narrator is convinced by the power of the whirlpools he sees in the ocean beyond. The "old" man tells of a fishing trip with his two brothers a few years ago. Driven by "the most terrible hurricane that ever came out of the heavens", their ship was caught in the vortex. One brother was pulled into the waves; the other was driven mad by the horror of the spectacle, and drowned as the ship was pulled under. At first the narrator only saw hideous terror in the spectacle. In a moment of revelation, he saw that the Maelström is a beautiful and awesome creation. Observing how objects around him were pulled into it, he deduced that "the larger the bodies, the more rapid their descent" and that spherical-shaped objects were pulled in the fastest. Unlike his brother, he abandoned ship and held on to a cylindrical barrel until he was saved several hours later. The old man tells the story to the narrator without any hope that the narrator will believe it. The story is couched as a story within a story, a tale told at the summit of a mountain climb in Lofoten, Norway. It is inspired by the Moskstraumen, a story told by a man on a mountain summit in Norway. The book was published in 2005 and is available in hardback and e-book formats. It has been translated into several languages, including German, French, Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese, and has been published in a number of editions, including a hardback version of the first edition of the book, as well as a paperback version. The second edition was released in 2006. It was published by the publisher, Penguin Books. The third edition, published in 2007, was released by Penguin Books in hardcover and hardback, with a print run of 1,000 copies. It also includes an extract from the second book of the story, which was written by the author and published in the same year as the first book, in the form of a short story called "The Story of the Sea". The book has been released in paperback in the US and in the UK, with an estimated run-time of about two hours and 40 minutes. The first edition was published on November 14, 2005. The last edition was printed on November 23, 2005, and the second edition on November 24, 2005 in the U.S.

name: The Murders in the Rue Morgue
summary: The story surrounds the baffling double murder of Madame L'Espanaye and her daughter in the Rue Morgue, a fictional street in Paris. Neighbors who hear the murder give contradictory accounts, each claiming that he heard the murderer speaking a different language. Because none of the witnesses can agree on the language the murderer spoke, Dupin concludes they were not hearing a human voice at all. Dupin puts an advertisement in the newspaper asking if anyone has lost an "Ourang-Outang". The ad is answered by a sailor who comes to Dupin at his home. The sailor reveals that he had been keeping a captive orangutan obtained while ashore in Borneo. The animal escaped with the sailor's shaving straight razor. When he pursued the orangutans, it escaped by scaling a wall and climbing up a lightning rod, entering the apartment through a window. The bloody deed incited it to fury and it squeezed the daughter's throat until she died. It then attempted to hide the body by stuffing it into the chimney. The prefect of police, upon hearing this story, mentions that people should mind their own business. Dup in responds that G– is "too cunning to be profound" Dupin offers his services to "G–" as a private investigator. The two live in seclusion and allow no visitors. They have cut off contact with "former associates" and venture outside only at night. "We existed within ourselves alone", the narrator explains. The story is about a man named Adolphe Le Bon who has been imprisoned though no evidence exists pointing to his guilt, but Dupin is so intrigued that he offers his service to the prefect. The pair have no children of their own and live together in a secluded house in the middle of the street. The end of the story sees Dupin and his friend, the unnamed narrator, living in secluded and allowing no visitors to visit them. The narrator explains that the two live within themselves alone and have no one else to talk to but each other about their lives. The author has no children himself and has no one to talk about. The book is about the life of Dupin, the narrator, and their experiences in Paris in the 1930s and 1940s. It was written by Jean-Michel Basquiat and published in 1950. It is the first of a two-part series, with the second to be published in 2012. The third part will be released in 2013.

name: The Purloined Letter

He has been blackmailing his victim. A month later, the Prefect returns, still bewildered in his search for the missing letter. He is motivated to continue his fruitless search by the promise of a large reward, recently doubled, upon the letter's safe return. The Prefect determines that it is genuine and races off to deliver it to the victim. As a political supporter and old enemy of the Minister, Dupin hopes that D— will try to use the letter to his political downfall, and be presented with an insulting note at the end of the story. name: The Tale of Genji
summary: The work recounts the life of a son of the Japanese emperor, known to readers as Hikaru Genji, or "Shining Genji" For political reasons, Genji is relegated to commoner status (by being given the surname Minamoto) and begins a career as an imperial officer. The tale concentrates on Genji's romantic life and describes the customs of the aristocratic society of the time. Genji was the second son of a certain ancient emperor and a low-ranking but beloved concubine (known to the readers as Lady Kiritsubo). Genji and his wife, Lady Aoi, reconcile and she gives birth to a son but dies soon after. He marries another wife, Murasaki, whom he marries. His son, Reizei, becomes the real father, and Genji raises his rank to the highest possible. His nephew, Kashiwagi, later forces himself on the "Third Princess" and she bears Kaoru Kaoru (who is legally known as the son of Genji) Waley's version of the story is known as "Onna san no miya in the Seidener" (known as Onna San no Seiden in Waley’s version, or Onna san miyasen in Nyōsan in Nyohsan in the Nyohs version), and it is published in English as "The Emperor's Son, or The Emperor's Daughter, by Waley, and in Japanese as "Hikaru Genjisu" (Onna San San no Miyasu, or the Emperor's daughter, in Japanese). It was written in the 16th century and published in 17th century. It has been translated into English and French as "Emperor's Daughter" and "The Empress' Daughter, or, The Empress' Son, by Kaley, in the 19th century, and into Chinese as "Empress' Daughter" (Empresses' Daughter) and "Empire's Daughter", in the 21st century, respectively. It is written in Japanese and English, and has been published in Japan and the United States as well as in France and Germany. It was first published in 1872. It also has been republished in the UK in 1883 and in the US in the 20th century as "Genji and the Empress, or "The Empress and the Prince of Japan", and in Australia and the U.S. as well.

name: Master and Commander
summary: The story starts out on April 18, 1800, in Port Mahon, Minorca, a base of the Royal Navy at that time. A shipless lieutenant wasting away in port, Jack Aubrey, meets Stephen Maturin, a poor half-Irish and half-Catalan physician and natural philosopher. The two of them do not quite get along during this first encounter. A duel almost occurs when Aubrey gets elbowed by Maturein to stop beating the time while the string quartet is playing. Later that evening, on his way back to his living quarters, Aubrey finds out that he has been promoted to the rank of Commander and has been given command of the brig Sophie. On her following escort duty, Sophie is captured by a squadron of four large French warships after a pursuit and a brave but hopeless resistance. The Battle of Algeciras begins, and after a short period as prisoners of war, they are exchanged, missing the fighting. Aubrey must undergo a court-martial over the loss of his ship, but he is cleared of the charges. Also introduced into the story are Master's Mates Thomas Pullings, William Mowett, midshipman William Babbington, and James Dillon, the Sophies first lieutenant. Dillon and Stephen both have secret backgrounds as members of the United Irishmen. After the convoy duties, Lord Keith allows Aubrey to cruise independently, looking for French merchants. After a number of prizes are taken, they meet and defeat the Cacafuego, a Spanish frigate, losing a many crew, including Dillon, in the bloody action and gaining the respect of other naval officers. However, Captain Harte's malevolence ensures that the victory brings Aubrey and his crew no official recognition, promotion, or significant prize money, although Aubrey gains a reputation among members of British Navy as one of its great, young fighting captains. As he does this, he and the crew explain many naval matters to MaturIn (and to the reader) since the doctor has never served aboard a man-of-war. The ship's surgeon having left with the previous captain, Matur in is asked by Aubrey in that post. Since he is currently unemployed, he agrees, since he was currently unemployed. He and Aubrey quickly become good friends in part due to their shared love of music. The story ends with Aubrey having been having an affair with his wife, who has been having a relationship with Lord Keith.

name: The Devil and Daniel Webster
summary: A local farmer, Jabez Stone, is plagued with unending bad luck, causing him to finally swear that "it's enough to make a man want to sell his soul to the devil!" Stone is visited the next day by a stranger, who later identifies himself as "Mr. Scratch" and makes such an offer (in exchange for seven years of prosperity), to which Stone agrees. Wanting out of the deal, Stone convinces famous lawyer and orator Daniel Webster to accept his case. A trial is then demanded by Daniel as the right of every American. A jury of the damned then enters, "with the fires of hell still upon them" They had all done evil, and had all played a part in the USA. They admit that, "Perhaps 'tis not strictly in accordance with the evidence, but even the damned may salute the eloquence of Mr Webster." The judge and jury disappear with the break of dawn. Mr Scratch congratulates the stranger and twists his arm behind his back, "for he knew that you once knew that once you like anybody like you, you can fight anybody like anybody in the fight in this country." Mr. Sc scratch congratulates Webster and the contract is torn up and the stranger is arrested. Mr. and Mrs. Benet (1960), in a letter to the New York Times Book Review, claimed that the good reverend was entirely imaginary. Stephen Vincent Benet even quoted from a made-up person named John Cleveland Cotton. He went so far as to write an apocryphal biographical note about Cotton that ended up in Marion King's Books and People (King, 1954). In this Benet anticipated authors Tim Powers and James Blaylock, who created a poet named William Ashbless. In "The Exchange" - Trick Reference Questions, p. 122: "In 'The Devil and Daniel Webster' there is a character named the Reverend John Smeet. Was this a real person? :Mrs. Benét explained that her husband occasionally used to insert imaginary people into his writings. She explained that she had no idea if the character was real or not. She said that she was just making it all up for her husband's enjoyment of the story, and that she didn't know if he had ever heard of the character, or if he was even alive at the time of the book's publication. "The exchange" is published by Simon & Schuster, a division of Simon and Schuster.

name: The Luck of Barry Lyndon
summary: Redmond Barry of Bally Barry, born to a genteel but ruined Irish family, fancies himself a gentleman. He flees to Dublin, where he quickly falls in with bad company in the way of con artists, and soon loses all his money. Pursued by creditors, he enlists as a common private in an infantry regiment headed for service in Germany. Despite a promotion to corporal, he hates the army and seeks to desert. When his Lieutenant is wounded, Redmond helps take him to a German village for treatment. The German soon realizes that Redmond is a deserter, but rather than turn him over to the British to be hanged, impresses him into the Prussian army (for a bounty) Then his stepson, Lord Bulldon, goes off to the American war—and is killed in battle. He spends the last nineteen years of his life in prison, dying in a horse-riding accident. As the American War of Independence breaks out, Barry Lyndon (as he now calls himself) raises a company of soldiers to be sent to America. He also defeats his wife's cousins to win a seat in Parliament. He is separated from his wife (Redmond Lyndon) and lodged in Fleet Prison. A small stipend allows him to live in moderate luxury, and his mother lodges close by to tend to him. Combined with his own profligate spending practices, he is ruined on many levels on the "memoirs" of "Redmond" Barry (Barry Lyndon) Barry ends up in Fleet Fleet Prison, dying of a dying alcoholism-related illness, lodged in a small prison, and lodging close to his elderly mother. He dies in a tragic horse-Riding accident, and spends the final 19 years of life in a dying prison, Dying in a Horse- Riding Accident. The last chapter of the novel is about the death of Barry Lyndon, and how he tries to rebuild his life and his family's fortunes. It is also about the end of the war and the birth of a new generation of Irishmen in the United States. The novel ends on a happy note, with Barry Lyndon's son and daughter-in-law living happily together in New York City. It ends with a tragic end, as Barry Lyndon dies of a horse riding accident in front of a crowd of thousands of people, and he is forced to flee for his life to the U.S. to be with his wife.

name: The End of Eternity
summary: The Eternity of the title is an organization and a place which exists outside time. It is staffed by male humans called Eternals who are recruited from different eras of human history. The protagonist is a Technician named Andrew Harlan, who finds himself involved in an ontological paradox orchestrated by his superiors. He is to secure the creation of Eternity by sending a young Eternal back in time with the mathematical knowledge to make it possible. Harlan is trapped in the wrong time, so Eternity cannot be created. Unless something is done to change the past, Harlan’s reality, and Eternity, will be erased from existence. The novel comes upon an ad for stock in Talk Of the Market, concealing the A-T-O-M drawing of a mushroom cloud on the masthead. Since the publication of this year's edition, a copy of the novel has been preserved in the Library of Congress. This is where Asimov's mistaken “mushroom cloud” appears in the novel. The book is also available in hardback and e-book, with a selection of the best lines from the novel, as well as an extract from the first chapter of the second chapter, and an excerpt from the third chapter. The fourth and final chapter is published in a special edition of the book, which includes a foreword by Asimov himself. The first chapter is also published in the book's second volume, which is entitled “The Eternity Of The Future”. The third and fourth chapters are published in paperback, with an extract of the fourth and fifth chapters also included. The fifth and sixth chapters are released in a hardback, and the last is the third and the fourth, in which the author describes how he came to the idea of time travel in the first place. The last, the fifth and the sixth, are the last two chapters, which are published as a book of short stories, with the last being the final chapter of The Eternity Of the Future, which has been published in hard-back as a hard-to-read book. The final, the seventh and the eighth, is the first and last, in the collection of short chapters, “A Man Walks On To a precipice”, which was written by Harlan in the early 1930s and published by Simon & Schuster in the 1950s. It was the first time that the author has written about time travel, and it is the last time he has written on the subject.

name: Little Dorrit
summary: The novel begins in Marseilles "thirty years ago" (i.e. ca. 1826) with the notorious murderer Rigaud informing his cell mate that he has murdered his wife. There is also the character Arthur Clennam, who is returning to London to see his mother following the death of his father with whom he had lived for twenty years in China. In London, William Dorrit, imprisoned as a debtor, has been a resident of Marshalsea debtor's prison for so long that his three children — snobbish Fanny, idle Edward, and Amy (known as Little Dorrit) — have all grown up there, though they are free to pass in and out of the prison as they please. Amy is devoted to her father and through her sewing,. has been financially supporting the two of them. Arthur meets the struggling inventor Daniel Doyce, whom he decides to help by becoming his business partner. Arthur, however, fails to recognize Amy's interest in him. Eventually after a spell of delirium, Mr Dorrit dies in Rome, and his distraught brother Frederick, a kind-hearted musician, who has always stood by him, also passes away. Amy's father has been suppressing her knowledge that he is the youngest daughter of Amy's paternal uncle, Frederick Dorrit. Over the course of the novel, Amy rises from a chairress to a chairiress and rises from her passion to an enormous fortune and becomes the richest woman in the world. Arthur's biological mother was a beautiful young singer with whom his father had gone through a ceremony of sorts before being pressured by a wealthy uncle to present Mrs ClennAm as his child. Mrs ClENNam had agreed to bring up Arthur never see his real mother, but the wealthy uncle, stung by Arthur's grief at being separated from Arthur and left to Arthur's mother, had left the estate to Arthur. As he died, Arthur's father had given Arthur a mysterious watch, murmuring, "Your mother." Arthur had assumed that it was intended for his mother, and the world supposed to be his mother. It was a message, but when Arthur shows it to harsh and implacable Mrs Clennyam, she refuses to reveal what it means. The French villain Rigaud, now in London, discovers that Mrs Clenam has been hiding the fact that Arthur is not her real son, and Rigaud attempts to blackmail her. While there, he is taken ill and is nursed back to health by Amy.

name: A Man Called Horse
summary: The protagonist is a Boston aristocrat who is captured by a Native American tribe. Initially enslaved, he comes to respect his captors' culture and gains their respect. He joins the tribe by showing his bravery and, later, gets back his dignity by marrying his owner's daughter, killing rival Indians and taking their horses. Taking the native name "Horse" (he was treated as a horse), he becomes a respected member of the tribe. es:Un hombre llamado Caballo nl:A Man Called Horse. name: Where Angels Fear to Tread
summary: E.M. Forster's "Where Angels Fear to Tread" is one of his best-known novels. In it, the widowed Lilia Herriton falls in love with both Italy and Gino, a handsome Italian. Gino's physical outburst toward Philip in response to the news makes Philip realize what it is like to truly be alive.
