name: Shame
summary: This story takes place in a town called, "Q" which is actually a fictitious version of Pakistan. In "Q," the 3 sisters (Chunni, Munnee, and Bunny Shakil) simultaneously pretend to give birth to Omar Khayyám Shakil. While growing up, Omar becomes mischievous and learns hypnosis. He enrolls in a school and is convinced by his tutor (Eduardo Rodriguez) to become a doctor. Over time, he comes in contact with both Iskander Harappa and General Raza Hyder. As a birthday present, Omar's "mothers" allow him to leave "Q." He joins the army and becomes an officer. He is also the son of a doctor and a lawyer. He also has a daughter and a son-in-law, both of whom are in the army. He has a son and a daughter who are both in the police force. His daughter is in the military and his wife is in a nursing home. His son and his daughter have a son who is a lawyer and a doctor, respectively. The son and the daughter are in love and have a child together. They are also in love with each other, but they are unsure of who the father is as the three sisters got pregnant at a house party. It is impossible to know who Omar's true mother is. In addition, they are not sure who Omar’s father is. The three sisters don't know who the real father is, as they don’t know who they got pregnant with Omar at the same time. They don't even know if Omar is their son or their son's father. The story ends with Omar leaving the hospital and becoming an officer in Pakistan.

name: Trent's Last Case
summary: Trent's Last Case is actually the first novel in which gentleman sleuth Philip Trent appears. The novel is a whodunit with a place in detective fiction history because it is the first major sendup of that genre. Not only does Trent fall in love with one of the primary suspects, he also, after painstakingly collecting all the evidence, draws all the wrong conclusions. He is told by the real perpetrator over dinner what mistakes in logical deduction he has made in trying to solve the case. On hearing what really happened, Trent vows that he will never again attempt to dabble in crime detection. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which also publishes the novel in hardback and e-book form. name: Play
summary: Samuel Beckett’s Play Skull is one of his most ‘musical’ pieces with ‘a chorus for three voices, orchestration, stage directions concerning tempo, volume and tone, a da capo repeat of the entire action’ Beckett writes that this spotlight "provokes" the character's speech, and insists that whenever possible, a single, swivelling light should be used, rather than separate lights switching on and off. In an almost fugal style the three obsess over the affair. Each presents his or her own version of the truth told in the past tense. Clichés and puns abound. The play appears as if it is about to start again for a third time (as in Act Without Words II), but does not get more than a few seconds into it before it suddenly stops. “The affair was unexceptional. From the moment when the man tried to escape his tired marriage and odious professional commitments by taking a mistress, [events took a predictable enough course:] the wife soon began to ‘smell her off him’” Beckett has used similar imagery before, Mahood's jar in The Unnameable, for example, or the dustbins occupied by Nell and Nagg in Endgame. According to John Pillingson and Frescoes, the three figures in Skull are not three-dimensional characters in any way. The stereotype of melodrama and romance in romanticized fiction predominates [They belong to the artificial world ofmelodrama]. The Play Skull: The Three Figures in Play Skull would be absurd to analyse them as if they were absurd, they would predominately be absurd.” – John Knowlson, John Fresco, Fresco and John Pillson, The Play skull: The three figures of Samuel Beckett, abcoes and drama, in later prose and later drama, abes later prose, and in later drama and prose, the later abes and abes of the play Skull.“[I]n the London production, variations were introduced: a weakening of light and voices in the first repeat, and more so in the second; an abridged second opening; increasing breathlessness; changes in the order of the opening words” - Beckett in the notes of the London version of Act Without words, Act without words, Part II, Part III, Part IV, Part V, Part VI, Part VII and Part VII.

name: Waverley
summary: Edward Waverley is brought up in the family home by his uncle. His uncle maintains the family Tory and Jacobite sympathies. Edward's Whig father works for the Hanoverian government in nearby London. He is posted to Dundee, then promptly takes leave to visit Baron Bradwardine, a Jacobite friend of his uncle, and meets the Baron's lovely daughter Rose. He has overstayed his leave and is accused of desertion and treason, then arrested. Highlanders rescue him from his escort and take him to the Jacobite stronghold at Doune castle then on to Holyrood Palace where he meets Bonnie Prince Charlie himself. Encouraged by the beautiful Flora Mac-Ivor, he goes over to theJacobites and takes part in the Battle of Prestonpans, where he saves the life of a colonel who turns out to be a close friend of the Baron. Thus he escapes retribution and marries the Baron’s daughter, Rose Bradwardsine. The novel is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, and is available in hardback. name: The Vampire Lestat
summary: The story follows the 200-year-long life of the vampire Lestat de Lioncourt, and his rise from humble beginnings as an impoverished aristocrat in the countryside of France to the city of Paris. The book ends on a cliffhanger after Lest at's debut concert in San Francisco, and leads directly into the third volume, the Queen of the Damned. The author has also written a number of spin-off books, including a children's book series, as well as a TV series and a movie series. The books are available in English, French, Spanish, and Italian, and are set in the late 18th century to the late 1980s in Paris and the late 1990s in the U.S. They are published by Simon & Schuster, which also publishes a hardback version of the book, which is available in hardback for $25.99. The first volume of the series was published in 1998, and the second volume was released in 1999. The third volume is due to be published in 2002. The fourth and final volume will be released in 2003, and will cover the early 1980s and the early 1990s, in addition to the second and third volumes. The last volume is expected to come out in 2004, and it will be the first of a two-part series, with the second being released in 2005 and the third in 2006. The novels are published in English and French, with a Spanish version available in 2006 and 2007. The English version is published in paperback in 2008, and in the Spanish version in 2009, the fourth volume is released in paperback. The fifth and sixth volumes will be published later in 2008 and 2009, respectively, and then in 2010 and 2011. The final volume, published in 2010, will be called "The Queen of The Damned" by Simon and Schuster and published in the UK in the same year as the first volume, and also in the US in the following year, the sixth and seventh volumes. It is the first time that the author has written about a vampire in the modern era. The novel is set in Paris in the 1980s, and follows the life of a vampire. The vampire, LestAt, is orphaned by the rogue elder vampire Magnus, who orphans him on the night he is made. Later, his dying mother, Gabrielle, arrives to say goodbye to him. In order to save her, he bites her, transforming her into his first companion. He abandons Nicki for fear of causing him harm and shuns contact with his loved ones.

name: The Tale of the Body Thief
summary: At the beginning of the story, Lestat grows depressed and becomes remorseful because of his vampiric nature. The "coven" of vampires formed at the end of The Queen of the Damned has long since broken up. Among his only remaining friends is the mortal head of the Talamasca Caste, David Talbot. A mysterious figure, Raglan James - the eponymous "Body Thief" of the book - offers to trade bodies with Lest at the suggestion of other vampires. However, James has no intention of ever switching back, and Lestsat is forced to scheme to regain his body. LestAt nearly dies after becoming human again - his new body is wracked by pneumonia, which he ignores during a tour of Washington D.C. in the middle of winter. He is saved by the care of a nun named Gretchen. He enjoys a short love affair with Gretchen before she returns to South America, where she works in a convent. He returns to New Orleans, reunites with Louis and begins to renovate his old house in the French Quarter. Above all, he claims that he has finally come to accept his vampsic nature, before dying in his current body. At this point, Tale of the Body Thief reaches a false ending - James is beginning to enjoy life in his new, young body. He now wants to become a vampire, despite his earlier protestations, while taking his friend's blood, while forced to take out his own body instead of returning to his own. The blow proves fatal - the death of James' current body prevents him from leaving the dying body or leaving the current one or leaving his current one. The story ends on a cliffhanging cliffhanger, with the reader left with no choice but to continue reading the book. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardcover, paperback and e-book editions. It is published in the U.S. and Canada by Simon and Schuster, and in the UK by Macmillan, with an estimated run-up to the release date of November 14, 2013. The U.K. release date for the book is November 15, 2013, and the UK release date is November 16, 2013 by Simon&Schuster, with a release date to be announced at a later date. For more information on how to buy the book, visit www.simonandschuster.co.uk.

name: Memnoch the Devil
summary: The novel follows up on claims made by David Talbot in The Tale of the Body Thief that God and the Devil are on better terms than most Christians believe. It also reinterprets biblical stories to create a complete history of Earth, Heaven and Hell that fit neatly with the history of vampires given in The Queen of the Damned. Although the novel fits into the storyline of The Vampire Chronicles, the vast majority of it consists of Memnoch's account of cosmology and theology. Lestat loses control of himself and Maharet is forced to chain him in the basement of the St. Elizabeth's convent, which is owned by the vampires, so that he will not hurt himself or others. At the end of the novel, Lest at and David go to New Orleans. There, Maharet returns LestAt's eye to him, along with a note from MemnoCh that reveals Memno ch may have been manipulating Lestet to serve his own agenda. Lestsat is left in confusion, unable to decide whether or not to cast his lot with the Devil. He believes that he has seen Christ's crucifixion. He has also lost an eye in Hell. Dora and Armand are deeply moved upon seeing the veil. Armand goes into the sunlight and immolates himself in order to convince people that a miracle has occurred. He tells his story to Armand, David and Dora, who have joined him in New York. D Nora takes it and reveals it to the world, triggering a religious movement. Lets Armand immolate himself in the sunlight in order for people to believe in the miracle that has occurred, and then Dora takes the veil and shows it to people in the daylight. LESTat believes himself to have had a major revelation. He also believes he has received Saint Veronica's Veil. He is also left in a state of confusion and is unable to make a decision about whether to join him as God's adversary or God's servant. He eventually decides to join the Devil, who claims he is not evil, but merely working for God by ushering lost souls into Heaven. The novel was released on September 14, 2013. It is the second novel in the Vampire Chronicles series, following The Queen Of The Damned on September 7, 2013, and The Tale Of The Body Thief on September 13, 2014, respectively. It was written by L.A. Hellyer and is published by Simon & Schuster.

name: The Further Adventures of Robinson Crusoe
summary: Crusoe was married in England and had three children. After losing his wife, he decided to go to "his island" Crusoe and Friday left England in January 1694. They arrived at Crusoe's Island via Ireland. They discovered that the English mutineers left on the island by Crusoe a decade earlier had been making trouble, but that when the island fell under attack by cannibals the various parties on the Island were forced to work together under truce to meet the threat. Crusoe takes various steps to consolidate leadership on. the island and assure the civility of the inhabitants, including leaving a quantity of needed supplies. He also sets up a sort of rule of law under an honour system and ensuring cohabitating couples are married. On the way to the mainland once again from Crusoe’s island, the ship is attacked by the cannibal. Friday dies from three arrow shots during an attempt to negotiate, but the crew eventually wins the encounter without further serious casualty. After having buried Friday in the ocean, the same evening they set sail for Brazil. They stayed for a long period there, then went directly over to the Cape of Good Hope. They landed on Madagascar where their nine men were pursued by three hundred natives, because one of his mariners had carried off a young native girl among the trees. They went to the river of Cambodia and Cochin-China or the bay of Tonquin, until they came to the latitude of 22 degrees and 30 minutes, and anchored at the island of Formosa (Taiwan). Then they arrived to the coast of China. Then they travelled through the following places: Changu, Naum (or Naun, a fortified city), Argun(a) on the Chinese-Russian border (April 13, 1703). They passed a little river called Kirtza, near Ozomoys (or Gzomoys), came to Veuslima (?) on the river Witzogda (Vychegda), running into the Dwina, then they stayed in Lawrenskoy (July 3–7, 1704; Yerenskoy Gorodok at that time). Finally Crusoe arrived at Hamburg, sailed into Hamburg and sailed into the White Sea on August 18, 1705. He arrived at London on 10 January 1705, having been gone from England and ten years and ten months from England. He had been there for nine years and nine months.

name: The 120 Days of Sodom, or the School of Libertinism
summary: The 120 Days Of Sodom is not a complete novel. Only the first section is written in detail. After that, the remaining three parts are written as a draft, in note form, with Sade's footnotes to himself still present in most translations. Four wealthy libertines lock themselves in a castle, the Château de Silling, along with a number of victims and accomplices. They intend to listen to various tales of depravity from four veteran prostitutes, which will inspire them to engage in similar activities with their victims. Sade glorifies as well as vilifies the four main protagonists, alternately declaring them freethinking heroes and debased villains, often in the same passage. The story does portray some black humor, and Sade seems almost lighthearted in his introduction, referring to the reader as "friend reader". In this introduction he contradicts himself, at one point insisting that one should not be horrified by the 600 passions outlined in the story because everybody has their own tastes. But at the same time he goes out of his way to warn the reader of the horrors that lay ahead, suggesting that the reader should have doubts about continuing. It is not set at any specific point in time, although it is implied at the start that the events in the book take place either during or shortly after the Thirty Years' War, which lasted from 1618 to 1648. The novel takes place over five months, November to March, and is set in a remote medieval castle, high in the mountains and surrounded by forests, detached from the rest of the world. The description of Silling matches de Sade’s own castle,. the Ch teau de Lacoste. It was written by Sade in 1648, but he decided he would not be able to complete it in full and elected to write out the remaining three-quarters in brief and finish it later. The book is now considered one of the most important works of French literature. It has been translated into more than 20 languages, including English, German, French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian and Spanish, and has been called a masterpiece. The 120 Days of Sodom was published in 1649. It was written by de Sades, who died in Paris in 1650. The author was known as "Sade" until the end of his life, when he was forced to retire due to ill-health. He died in 1701.

name: War and Peace
summary: War and Peace has a large cast of characters, the majority of whom are introduced in the first book. Some are actual historical figures, such as Napoleon and Alexander I. While the scope of the novel is vast, it is centered around five aristocratic families. The plot and the interactions of the characters take place in the era surrounding the 1812 French invasion of Russia during the Napoleonic wars. The novel begins in July 1805 in Saint Petersburg, at a soirée given by Anna Pavlovna Scherer — the maid of honour and confidante to the queen mother Maria Feodorovna. Many of the main characters in the novel are introduced as they enter Anna Pav Lovna's salon. The second part opens with descriptions of the impending Russian-French war preparations. Book Two begins with Nikolai Rostov briefly returning on home leave to Moscow. He spends an eventful winter at home, accompanied by his friend Denisov, his officer from the Pavlograd Regiment in which he serves. Natasha has blossomed into a beautiful young girl. Denis falls in love with her and proposes marriage, but Nikolai refuses to accede to his mother's request. He promises to marry his childhood sweetheart, Sonya Bezukhov, despite knowing it is wrong. He is rationally attracted to the richest and most eligible bachelor in the Russian Empire, Hélène Kuragin, whom he is rams into marriage with. Despite rationally knowing that he is wrong, he is convinced it is the right thing to do. He meets Prince Andrei Nikolayevich Bolkonsky, husband of Lise, the charming society favourite. He makes the fateful choice to be an aide-de-camp to Prince Mikhail Ilarionovich Kutuzov in the coming war against Napoleon. Nikolai gambles and socializes with his officer, Vasily Dmitrich Denisov. He befriends the ruthless, and perhaps, psychopathic Fyodor Ivanovich Dolokhov. The Rostov family are introduced. Count Ilya Andreyevich Rostov has four adolescent children. The eldest child, Vera Ilyinichna, is cold and somewhat haughty but has a good prospective marriage in a Russian-German officer, Adolf Karlovich Berg. Petya (Pyotr Ilyich) is nine and the youngest of the Rostov families; like his brother, is impetuous and eager to join the army when of age.

name: On the Beach
summary: The story is set primarily in and around Melbourne, Australia, in 1963. The only parts of the planet still habitable are Australia and New Zealand, South Africa, and the southern parts of South America. People in Australia detect a mysterious and incomprehensible Morse code radio signal originating from Seattle, Washington, in the United States. With hope that someone has survived in the contaminated regions, one of the last American nuclear submarines, USS Scorpion, is ordered to sail north from its port of refuge in Melbourne. The novel's poignant dilemmas is that of Peter Holmes, who has a baby daughter and a naive and childish wife, Mary, who is in denial about the impending disaster. The remaining submariners return to Australia to live out what little time they have left to enjoy what they've left, speaking of their small pleasures and continuing their customary activities that they will never see again. name: Son Excellence Eugène Rougon
summary: The novel opens in 1857 with Rougon's career at a low ebb. His greatest ally and his greatest adversary is Clorinde Balbi, an Italian woman of dubious background and devious intent. Rougon refuses to marry her because he believes two such dominant personalities would inevitably destroy each other. Instead, he encourages her to marry M. Delestang, a man of great wealth who can easily be wheedled, while he himself takes a respectable nonentity of a wife who will not hinder his ambition. The novel ends in 1862. The Emperor has returned Rougon to service as Minister without Portfolio, giving him unprecedented powers in the wake of Italian unification. Ostensibly, the appointment is meant to reconfigure the country on less imperialistic, more liberal lines, but in reality Rougon has a free hand to crush resistance, curtail opposition, and control the press. It is the story of the life of the French Prime Minister, Jean-Baptiste de Rougon, from 1857 to 1858. The book is published by Macmillan, priced at £16.99, and is available in English, French, Spanish, German, and Italian. It was published in France in 1858, and in the U.S. in 1859, and it is published in the UK in 1861, and the US in 1871. It has been translated into Italian as "Rougon: A Novel of a Prime Minister" and in English as "The Prime Minister of France, 1858-1862" It was first published in Paris in 1856, and has since been republished in France and the UK, with a US edition published in 1881. The French edition of the novel was published as part of a series of four volumes, with the US edition appearing in the second volume in 1883. The UK edition has been published as a special edition, entitled "The Emperor’s Daughter, 1857-1860". The US edition has also been published in a special collection of the same name, entitled “The Emperor and His Daughter,” with a different title, “A Novel of the Emperor, 1859-1861.” It is also available in the US as a hardback, priced between $24.99 and $49.99. The US version of the book is available on Amazon.com and the French edition is priced at $39.99 (with an MSRP of $50).

name: La Curée
summary: The book opens with scenes of astonishing opulence, beginning with Renée and Maxime lazing in a luxurious horse-drawn carriage. Zola then rewinds time to pick up the story practically minutes after La Fortune des Rougon ended. The rest of the novel takes place after Saccard has made his fortune, against the backdrop of his luxurious mansion and his profligacy. The novel continues in this vein with the tensions continuing to mount and culminates in a series of bitter observations by Zola on the hypocrisy and immorality of the nouveau riche. The film adaptation by Jean Cau, starring Jane Fonda, Michel Piccoli and Peter McEnery, was released in English-speaking markets as The Game is Over in 1966. Roger Vadim updated the novel for its modern setting to modern-day Paris in a movie adaptation by Roger Vimim, which is still hugely popular today. name: L'Argent
summary: The novel takes place in 1864-1869, beginning a few months after the death of Saccard's second wife Renée. The novel follows the fortunes of about 20 characters, cutting across all social strata, showing the effects of stock market speculation on rich and poor. The financial events of the novel are played against S Accard's personal life. The effects on the characters of L'argent are disastrous, including complete ruin, suicide, and exile, though some of the characters escape and Gundermann experiences a windfall. The fall of the Banque Universelle is felt across the entire financial world, and all of France feels the force of its collapse. It ends with the novel ends with Caroline preparing to follow her brother to Rome, and they are forced to leave France. They are sentenced to five years in prison. Through the intervention of Eugène Rougon, who doesn't want a brother in jail, their sentences are commuted. The pair leave France and go to Belgium, where they live with Caroline's sister. They have a son, Victor, but Victor is completely unredeemable, given over to greed, laziness, and thievery. After he attacks one of the women at the institution, he disappears into the streets, never to be seen again. He dies in 1869, leaving behind a wife, a son and a daughter. He also leaves behind a widow, a daughter and a son-in-law, who he leaves behind to live with his sister. He later dies in a car accident. He leaves a fortune to his wife, but she dies a few years later, and he dies in her arms. He is also left with a daughter, who dies in childbirth in 1872. He then dies in an accident in 1874, leaving a widow and son. The book ends with him and his wife in a hotel room in Paris, where he leaves a note for his daughter, saying, "I love you, my darling, I love you very much, and I will always love you." He dies the next year, in 1875, at the age of 80. He was the father of a young boy, Victor. He died in 1879, and his son is buried in a Paris cemetery. He left a note to his daughter saying, “I will never forget you.” He also wrote a letter to his son saying that he loved him very much and that he would always love him.

name: The Crying of Lot 49
summary: The novel follows Oedipa Maas, a Californian housewife who becomes entangled in a convoluted historical mystery when her ex-lover dies and designates her the co-executor of his estate. The catalyst of her adventure is a set of stamps that may have been used by a secret underground postal delivery service, the Trystero (or Tristero) The existence and plans of this shadowy organization are revealed bit by bit; or, then again, it is possible that the Tristerso does not exist at all. The novel's main character is buffeted back and forth between believing and not believing in them, without ever finding firm proof either way. She finds herself torn between believing in the trystero and believing that it is all a hoax established by the real estate mogul Pierce Inverarity himself. She leaves her comfortable home in Kinneret-Among-The-Pines, a northern California village, and travels south to the fictional town of San Narciso (Spanish for "Saint Narcissus"), near Los Angeles. The book ends with Oedsipa attending an auction, waiting for a lot to begin on a rare set of postage stamps, which she believes are called The Tristeros. She believes they are trying to acquire a lot of items called "#lots;cots;&#34#;A lot is a lot, and a lot is up for auction (A lot of it is called John John, which is John the Tristeroso). name: Jack of Shadows
summary: The novel is set in a world that is tidally locked. One side of the planet is always in light, and the other in darkness. Science rules on the dayside, while magic holds sway in the night. Jack of Shadows (a.k.a. Shadowjack) is unique among the magical beings in that he draws his power not from a physical location but from shadow itself. The novel ends with Jack falling, perhaps to his death, but Morningstar has been freed by the world's turning and rushes to rescue him. The fate of this ambiguous hero is left untold, with Jack wondering, as he falls, if Morningstar will reach him in time. The Key itself and the consequences of its use parallel Jack's progress in his own endeavors. Ultimately, the Key will be responsible for Jack's salvation and his doom. This makes him unbeatable, but not all-powerful. He seeks the advice of Morningstar, who advises him to destroy The Machine at the Heart of the World, which maintains the world’s stability, and set it rotating. He gets access to a computer and uses it to recover Kolwynia. This gives him new powers, but he is unable to rule the world as he once did. He is nearly incapacitated in complete light or complete darkness, but given access to even a small area of shadow, his potency is unmatched. Fleeing the dark side, Jack gets access into the light side. He uses this access to get back to the night side, where he is able to rule as he pleases. He makes a mess of ruling with his new powers and is eventually overthrown by Morningstar. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, and is available in hardback and e-book. The first edition of the book was published in May 1998, with a hardback cover priced at $24.99. The second edition was released in May 1999, with prices starting at $16.99 and the second edition at $19.99 each. The third and fourth editions will be released in June 1998 and July 1998, respectively. The fourth and fifth volumes will be published in September 1998 and October 1998. The fifth and sixth volumes are expected to be released later in the year. The sixth and seventh volumes are scheduled for release in October 1998 and September 1999. The seventh and eighth volumes are due in November 1998, and October 1999, respectively, and will be entitled "The Key That Was Lost" by Simon and Schuster.

name: Whose Body?
summary: Wimsey's mother, the Dowager Duchess of Denver, telephones to say that Thipps, an architect hired to do some work on her local church, has just found a dead body. Sir Reuben Levy, a famous financier, has disappeared from his own bedroom, and there has been a flurry of trading in some Peruvian oil shares. Wimsey becomes convinced that the two are linked. The trail leads to the teaching hospital near the architect's flat, and to surgeon and neurologist Sir Julian Freke, who is based there. He attempts to murder both Parker and Wimsey, and finally tries suicide when his actions are discovered, but is arrested in time. The book establishes many of Wimsey's character traits - for example, his interest in rare books, and his nervous problems associated with his wartime shell-shock. It also introduces many characters who recur in later novels, such as Parker, Bunter, Sugg, and the Dowage Duchess. Whose Body? is now in the public domain in the United States, but may still be copyrighted elsewhere. There is a passing reference in the book to Freddy Arbuthnot, Wimsey’s friend and contact for the stock market, being in love with Sir Reuben Levy's daughter Rachel and wanting to marry her. This theme is picked up in Strong Poison, taking place seven years later, when Freddy at last manages to convince Rachel's family to consent to the match despite his being a gentile - after Freddy compared his long wait with that of the Biblical Jacob for his Rachel. The pauper's body, washed, shaved and manicured, was then carried over the roofs and dumped in Thipp's' bath as a joke. He also tried to murder Wimsey and his friend, Inspector Parker, but was stopped by the police. This is the story of how Freddy finally managed to convince the family of Rachel's father to allow him to marry his daughter, despite being a Gentile. The story is told in the novel's final chapter, in which Freddy finally persuades the family to agree to the marriage. The novel is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, and is available in hardback, paperback and e-book. To order a copy of the book, go to www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk/whose-body? or call 0203 615 4157.

name: Clouds of Witness
summary: Lord Peter Wimsey goes on an extended holiday in Corsica. He receives the news that his sister Mary's fiancé, Captain Denis Cathcart, has been found shot dead outside the Wimseys' shooting lodge at Riddlesdale in Yorkshire. His brother, Gerald, Duke of Denver, is arrested for the murder. Cathcart was killed by a bullet from Denver's revolver, and Denver's only alibi is that he was out for a walk at the time Cathcart died. Peter and his close friend, Inspector Charles Parker, investigate the grounds, and find several tantalizing clues: footprints belonging to a strange man, motorcycle tracks outside the grounds and a piece of jewellery, a lucky charm in the shape of a cat. They also agree that both Gerald and Mary are hiding something; Gerald stubbornly refuses to budge from his story, and Mary is faking a severe illness to avoid talking to anyone. Eventually, the jewelled cat leads Wimsey to Cathcart's mistress of many years, who had left him for an American millionaire. Wimsey travels to New York to find her, and makes a trans-Atlantic flight to return to London before Gerald's trial in the House of Lords ends. From her, Wimsey brings a letter that Cathcart wrote on the night of his death, after receiving her farewell letter. In it, Cathcart announces his intention to commit suicide. He took Gerald's revolver from the study, went out into the garden and shot himself, though he lived long enough to crawl back to the house. While investigating the surrounding countryside Peter meets a violent, homicidal farmer, Mr. Grimethorpe, with a stunningly beautiful wife. He seems a likely killer, but while investigating his alibi (and nearly being killed by stumbling into a bog pit), Peter confirms that GrimethOrpe was elsewhere on the fatal night. He discovers Gerald's letter from his friend in Egypt wedged in the window of the Grimeth orpe's bedroom, proving that Gerald was visiting Grimeth Orpe's wife. Gerald is acquitted. As he is leaving the house to meet his wife, Grimetholpe appears and shoots at him, then panics and flees, and dies. In the final scene, Inspector Sugg, last seen in Whose Body?, is startled to find all the lords celebrating the end of the case on the street after midnight, all drunk as all cabs cabs have been celebrating the start of the investigation.

name: Unnatural Death
summary: Wimsey discovers that the patient's great-niece - popular locally - had nursed her through her illness and was the intended heiress. The patient had a horror of contemplating death, however, and refused to listen to entreaties that she must make a will. When Wimsey begins investigating, using the recurring character Miss Climpson as his intelligence agent, the great-Niece is provoked into covering her trail. She kills a former servant, fakes a kidnap-murder and tries to frame a distant relative with an interest in the Dawson estate, and almost kills Miss Clim Simpson. She is eventually arrested and imprisoned on remand, where she commits suicide. The doctor from whom Lord Peter originally heard the anecdote has moved on and is not grateful to be vindicated. The film is based on a true story by the same name, and is directed by David Lean. It is available on DVD and Blu-ray. For more information on the film, visit the official website of the Royal Shakespeare Company. The movie is also available on Blu-Ray and DVD, as well as on the DVD version of the book, and on the Blu- ray version of The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, by William Cuthbert, is out on DVD on September 14. For the full film, click here. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99, with a run-time of £25.99. The DVD is available in the UK from September 14, and the UK release date is September 15, and it is on sale in the U.S. and Europe from September 16, 2014. The UK release is on the 17th and 17th, with the US release date of September 17, 2014, and a UK release of the DVD is September 18, 2014 (UK release dates are September 19, 2014 and September 20, 2014). The UK release date of this book is September 17, 2013 (UK released in the UK and the US on September 21, 2013.

name: The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club
summary: General Fentiman has been estranged from his sister, Lady Dormer, for years. On her deathbed, he learns the terms of her will. If she dies first he will inherit a fortune, which his grandsons sorely need. But if he dies first, nearly all of the money will go to Ann Dorland, a distant relative of her late husband. That afternoon the General is found dead in his armchair at the club. The General was poisoned with an overdose of heart medication. Suspicion falls on the last person to see the General, who was among the last persons to see his sister and has an obvious motive to compromise with the General. The only person who agrees to compromise is the General's younger grandson, George FENTiman, a veteran of World War I still suffering from the effects of poison gas and shell shock. In the meantime, Wimsey has had the General exhumed and properly examined and discovered that the General had died on Remembrance Day at 10:37 AM. The next day, Robert found his grandfather dead in the club's library, apparently of natural causes. Piqued at losing the inheritance, he concealed the body overnight in theClub's telephone booth. Wimsey is asked to help solve the puzzle by his friend Mr Murbles, the solicitor for theFentiman family. He agrees, though he insists that he will pursue the exact truth, regardless of who benefits. He also turns up a few clues - there was a fresh tear in the General’s trouser cuff and a scraping of paint on the side of his shoe. There is another sighting of Oliver, and this time Robert and the detectives follow him to Italy. Robert returns from Italy, and admits that Oliver does not exist. He has figured out what happened. There was no memorial poppy on the general's suitcoat - impossible if he had been on the streets on Remem remembrance Day. He had just told Robert the Terms of LadyDormer's will. He was found later that day at the Bellona Club, shortly after seeing his sister. It would seem obvious that he must have died sometime after arriving at theClub on the morning of 11 November. But nobody saw him arrive. But the General went to the club at some point after visiting his sister the previous afternoon, but his whereabouts are unknown between those two events. He went to see Dr Penberthy in between, and then, en route, he had the taxi pick up George Fentimans.

name: Strong Poison
summary: Mystery author Harriet Vane has been accused of the murder of her former lover, Phillip Boyes. Boyes was a novelist and essayist who wrote in support of atheism, anarchy, and free love. He persuaded a reluctant Harriet to live with him against her principles and they led a Bohemian life in the London art community. A year later he proposed, and Harriet, outraged at being deceived into giving up her public honour, broke off the relationship. Harriet is tried, but the result is a "hung" jury, thanks in no small part to the presence of Wimsey's aide, Miss Climpson, on the jury. With fewer than ten of the jury agreeing on a verdict, the judge must order a fresh trial to be held. Wimsey visits Harriet in prison, declares his conviction of her innocence, and promises to catch the real murderer. At her retrial the prosecution presents no case and Harriet is set free. Exhausted by her ordeal, she again rejects Wimsey’s proposal of marriage. It is also in this novel that Peter finally persuades Parker to propose to Peter's sister, Mary. Also the Honourable Freddy Aruthnot, the daughter of Sir Reuben Levy who was murdered in Whose Body? finds a long-delayed domestic bliss with Rachel, the wife of Sir Sir Re-bayed Levy, who was also murdered in. Whose body? is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99. For more information, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or call 0203 615 4157. name: Five Red Herrings
summary: The story is set in Galloway, a part of Scotland popular with artists because of its landscapes. Sandy Campbell is a talented painter, but also a notoriously quarrelsome drunkard. When he is found dead in a stream, with a half-finished painting on the bank above, it is assumed at first that he fell in accidentally, fracturing his skull. Lord Peter Wimsey, who is in the region on a fishing holiday, points out the inconsistency which makes it impossible for Campbell himself to have worked on the painting. Campbell's death is now a murder case. Whoever killed Campbell also executed the painting in Campbell's distinctive style, to contrive the appearance of an accident. Six other artists in the area are talented enough to have achieved this, and had also had public brawls with Campbell in the recent past. Wimsey has to figure out "who done it" and who the five red herrings are. The killer finally realises that the case against him is unbreakable and confesses, but pleads that he killed Campbell in self-defence. When the case is tried, the jury decide that he is guilty of manslaughter (which carries a lighter sentence) rather than premeditated murder. The plot is told through the viewpoint of Wimsey and of the various police investigating the case (including Wimsey's brother-in-law Charles Parker, involved because a suspect is in hiding in London). Large parts of the book follow the various Scottish police officers, who are shown as highly intelligent and competent, and for time seem to overshadow Wimsey. In contrast, Bunter (Wimsey's valet) plays a smaller role in this than in other Wimsey novels. There is only a closed circle of suspects to deal with, and Wimsey have no emotional involvement, although, having alerted the Police to Campbell's murder, he subsequently reflects that Campbell was a man anyone might feel justified in killing. He nevertheless resolves to uncover the truth, so that the five innocent artists should not live under lifelong suspicion. In one episode a character angrily accuses him of "entering people's homes as a police spy". The six suspects are all eventually traced and give statements in which they deny killing Campbell. Some have convincing alibis, but others have none which can be verified. Finally, Wimsey offers to reconstruct the crime and over the course of twenty-four hours' strenuous activity, he demonstrates how the killer contrived the scene above the stream and established an alibi. The police put forward several theories implicating all of the suspects either as the killer or as accessories.

name: Have His Carcase
summary: Harriet Vane and Wimsey are on a hiking holiday after her acquittal on murder charges in Strong Poison. They find the body of a man, with his throat cut and the blood still liquid, on an isolated rock on the shore. The dead man, Paul Alexis, was of Russian extraction and engaged to a rich older widow. The romantic Alexis believed himself a descendant of Russian royalty, and the widow's rather stupid son, appalled at the prospect of his mother's remarriage to a gigolo, conspired with a friend and his wife to play on Alexis's fantasies. Alexis was lured to the rock and murdered by the son, who rode a horse along the beach through the incoming tide to avoid leaving tracks, whilst his friends supplied his alibi. The death was intended to look like suicide. However, Alexis suffers from haemophilia, and his unclotted blood leads to confusion over the time of death, which eventually assists with the unmasking of the conspirators. The film was directed by David Walliams and is based on a novel by the same name, written by Julian Fellowes and published by Simon & Schuster. name: The Nine Tailors
summary: Wimsey helps ring a nine-hour peal of bells overnight after Will Thoday, one of the ringers, is stricken by influenza. The Thorpe family has been blighted for 20 years by the unsolved theft of jewels from a house-guest by the butler, Deacon, and an accomplice, Cranton. Both men were imprisoned, but the jewels were never recovered. At Easter, Sir Henry himself dies and his wife's grave is opened for his burial. A body is found hidden in the grave, mutilated beyond recognition. It is first thought to be the body of a tramp labourer calling himself "Driver" who arrived and then vanished just after the New Year. An odd document found in the bell chamber by Hilary Thorpe, SirHenry's daughter, proves to be a cipher. Wimsey assumes the two men did recover the emeralds and Cranton then killed Cobbleigh for them, but cannot prove it. When he decodes the cipher (which requires knowledge of change-ringing) it leads him to theEmeralds, still untouched in their hiding place in the church. He also discovers the Thodays' whereabouts through the Archbishop of Canterbury. In 1918 Deacon murdered a warder and escaped from prison. He married bigamously in France and waited several years to return for the emerALDs, which he had hidden before his arrest. In fact Deacon had murdered a soldier and swapped identities with him, making his marriage bigamous and their daughters illegitimate. Will tied Deacon to the bell-chamber, planning to bribe him to leave, but became helpless with Spanish influenza next day. Neither can explain how Deacon died and Will marries Mary again under Archbishop Blomsbury's licence. Both are released and Will returns to Fenchurch St. Paul, under Archbishop's licence, under the alias of "Paul Taylor", the tenor (largest) bell in the ring. He goes on to marry Mary after the war, believing her a widow. When Jim's body was discovered, Will assumed Jim had killed Deacon and hid it in the new grave, then left for the sea. When the body was found, he made the body unrecognisable andhid it in a new grave. He assumed that Will had murdered him and waited until the night after Lady Thorpe's funeral on 4 January, made it unrecognisable. He then left the newgrave for the new year. When Will's brother Jim led him to find Deacon's body on 2 January, he left for sea.

name: Busman's Honeymoon
summary: Lord Peter Wimsey and Harriet Vane plan to spend their honeymoon at Talboys, an old farmhouse in Harriet's native Hertfordshire. Arriving late at night, they are surprised to find the house locked up and not prepared for them. They gain access and spend their wedding night there, but next morning they discover the former owner, Noakes, dead in the cellar with head injuries. The quiet honeymoon is ruined as a murder investigation begins and the house fills with policemen, reporters, and brokers' men. The suspects include Noakes's niece, Mrs. Ruddle (his neighbour and cleaning lady), Frank Crutchley, a local garage mechanic and the local police constable, who was his blackmail victim. In a final scene, in which almost the entire cast of characters is gathered in the front room of Talboys - reflecting the novel's origin as a work for the stage, the killer turns out to be Crutchly. He planned to marry Noakes' somewhat elderly niece and get his hands on the money he had left her in his will. He set a booby trap with a weighted plant pot on a chain, which was triggered by the victim opening the radio cabinet after locking up for the night. The house had been locked and bolted when the newly-weds arrived, and medical evidence seems to rule out an accident, so it seems he was attacked in the house and died later, having somehow locked up after his attacker. Wimsey's reaction to the case - his arrangement for the defendant to be represented by top defence counsel; his guilt at condemning a man to be hanged; the return of his shell-shock – dominate the final chapters of the book. It is mentioned that Wimsey had previously also suffered similar pangs of conscience when other murderers had been sent to the gallows. In fact Sayers wrote no further Wimsey novels after this one. The 1942 short story "Talboys", the very last Wimsey fiction produced by Sayers, is both a sequel to the present book, in having the same location and some of the same village characters, and an antithesis in being lighthearted and having no crime worse the theft of some peaches from a neighbour's garden. The book ends with Peter's and Harriet's relationship, always complex and painfully negotiated, is resolved during the process of catching the murderer and bringing him to justice. His deep remorse and guilt at having causedCrutchley to be executed leave doubt as to whether he would undertake further murder investigations.

name: Thrones, Dominations
summary: Lord and Lady Peter Wimsey have just returned from a European honeymoon. They are settling into their new home in London, where daily life is affected by the illness and then death of the king. The couple become slightly acquainted with Laurence Harwell, a wealthy theatrical "angel" and his beautiful wife, whom he has rescued from poverty. After two years' marriage the Harwells are famously still devoted to one another. When she is found dead at their weekend cottage in the country Wimsey is asked to help interview the distraught husband. After some plot twists, a second murder and a scene involving the hidden rivers and Victorian sewers that run under London, it is revealed that Harwell unintentionally killed his wife in a jealous rage. He later committed the premeditated murder of an actress who was in a position to disprove his alibi and tried to blackmail him. Harriet visits Harwell in prison to comfort him with the knowledge that his wife had not, after all, been unfaithful. In doing so, she finally banishes the lingering ghosts of her own imprisonment and murder trial, and the effect they have had on her relationship with her own husband. She also discovers she is expecting a baby, and finds a practical solution to allow Wimsey's devoted manservant Bunter to marry without having to leave the household. Harriet's unorthodox approach infuriates her sister-in-law (who believes Harriet has an obligation to abandon her career, do her duty to the family and produce an heir) but it allows her to solve most of the practical difficulties that might have stood in the way of a successful and happy marriage. She is also asked to undertake sensitive diplomatic duties connected with the problematic behaviour of the new king, and as the 1936 abdication crisis looms, he gloomily predicts the coming war with Hitler's Germany. Two men who knew Mrs Harwell's father in prison, and who have been blackmailing him with threats to harm her, are also suspected. Harriet straightens out her domestic situation, learning how to fulfill her new role whilst keeping her own identity. She finds a solution to let Bunter marry without leaving the household, and also finds a way to allow her to have a child with her husband's childhood sweetheart, who is also her best friend. Harriet also discovers that she is pregnant with her first child, who she names after her late father, who was also a playwright. The book ends on a cliffhanger, with Harriet's husband telling her that he will never be able to see her again.

name: Light in August
summary: The narrative structure consists of three connected plot-strands. Lena Grove is trying to find Lucas Burch, the father of her unborn child. Joe Christmas came to Jefferson three years before the novel's beginning, and got a job at the planing mill. Joanna Burden continues her ancestors' struggle for Black emancipation, which makes her an outsider in Jefferson, much like Christmas. Reverend Gail Hightower is obsessed by the past adventures of his Confederate grandfather, who was killed while stealing chickens from a farmer's shed. The novel leaves readers uncertain whether Joe Christmas or Joe Brown is the murderer. The only character who does not turn his back on the Reverend Hightowers is Byron Bunch, who tries to convince him to give the imprisoned Joe Christmas alibi, but he accepts it too late. In the end, Christmas is seen musing over his past past alone in his house as he prepares for his own death' Before Christmas' escape, he is seen moving into a train and getting into a fight which he loses and gets into a moving train and is moving into his own train. He is leaving Joanna's burning house when a passing farmer stops to investigate and pull her body from the fire. The sheriff at first suspects Joe Brown, but initiates a man-hunt for Christmas after Brown claims that Christmas is black. A zealous national guardsman, Percy Grimm, follows him there and shoots and castrates Joe Christmas. In Mottstown, Christmas arrives undisguised in a neighboring town; he is arrested and jailed, then moved to Jefferson, no longer running. His grandmother visits him in the Jefferson jail and advises him to seek help from GailHightower. In Jefferson, Christmas escapes from police's house and runs to Hightsower's house, but then accepts Byron's suggestion to hide, too late as Percy Grimm is close behind him. When Joe Christmas gets there, Byron arranges for Brown/Burch to come and see her, but when he gets there he runs again, instigating a fight, which he gets into and loses his train and gets moving into the moving train. The narrative of Lena's story builds a framework around the two other plot-Strands. One of these is the story of the enigmatic Joe Christmas, who as a child ran away from his abusive adoptive parents who were conservatively religious. As a result of sexual frustration and the beginning of menopause, Joanna turns to religion. She is murdered soon after: her throat is slit and she is nearly decapitated.

name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
summary: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 1 is the first novel in the Harry Potter series. The book is set during the summer of 2003. Harry is temporarily expelled from Hogwarts for using magic outside of the school. He joins the Order of the Phoenix, a group of witches and wizards dedicated to fighting Lord Voldemort and his followers. The Order is forced to operate in secrecy, outside the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Magic, which is headed by Cornelius Fudge, who refuses to believe that Lord Voldemort has returned. Harry and his best friends form their own Defense Against the Dark Arts group, also known as the D.A., or Dumbledore's Army, to learn from Harry and practice spells. The film ends with Harry and the Order moving to London, where they plan to open a joke shop in Diagon Alley using the money they won in the previous year's Triwizard Tournament. The last chapter of the book is dedicated to Harry's godfather, Sirius Black, who has died in a car accident. The movie is released on November 14, 2004. The first book in the series is available on DVD and Blu-Ray. The second and third books are available on Blu-ray and DVD on November 15, 2004, and November 16, 2005, respectively, and the fourth and fifth books are released on December 16, 2004 and December 17, 2005. The fourth and sixth books of the series are expected to be released on January 14, 2006 and January 18, 2006. The seventh and final book is expected to come out on January 19, 2006, and will be released in the UK on the same day as the UK release of the US version of the film. The sixth and seventh books will be published in the US on January 20, 2006; the UK releases on January 21, 2006,. and the US release on January 22, 2007. The UK release date is January 28, 2007; the U.S. release dates are January 29, 2007, and January 30, 2008. name: Consciousness Explained
summary: Dennett's view of consciousness is that it is the apparently serial account for the brain's underlying parallelism. One of the book's more controversial claims is that qualia do not (and cannot) exist. Dennett claims that our brains hold only a few salient details about the world, and that this is the only reason we are able to function at all. Research subsequent to Dennett's book indicates that some of his postulations were more conservative than expected. A year after Consciousness Explained was published, Dennett noted "I wish in retrospect that I'd been more daring, since the effects are stronger than I claimed". And since then examples continue to accumulate of the illusory nature of our visual world. Also Dennett says that only a theory that explained conscious events in terms of unconscious events could explain consciousness at all: «To explain is to explain away». The book puts forward a "multiple drafts" model of consciousness, suggesting that there is no single central place (a "Cartesian Theater") where conscious experience occurs. The brain consists of a "bundle of semi-independent agencies"; when "content-fixation" takes place in one of these, its effects may propagate so that it leads to the utterance of one of the sentences that make up the story in which the central character is one's "self" Dennett wryly notes that he is committed to the belief that we are all zombies. He also says that "philosophical zombies", which are supposed to act like a human in every way while somehow lacking qualia, cannot exist. This approach allows the reports of the subject to be a datum in psychological research, thus circumventing the limits of classical behaviorism. A key philosophical method is heterophenomenology, in which verbal or written reports of subjects are treated as akin to a theorist's fiction. The subject's report is not questioned, but it is not assumed to be an incorrigible report about that subject's inner state. This is not necessary and would consume valuable computing power. Rather, we log what has changed and assume the rest has stayed the same, with the result that we miss some details, as demonstrated in various experiments and illusions, some of which Dennett outlines. In the book Dennett argues that the only way to explain consciousness is to look at unconscious events, which he calls "theory of unconsciousness" The book also argues that we need a theory of consciousness that explains unconscious events as well as conscious events.

name: The Clouds
summary: Faced with legal action for non-payment of debts, Strepsiades enrolls his son in the "thinkeria" (the "Phrontisterion") so that he might learn the rhetorical skills necessary to defeat their creditors in court. The son thereby learns cynical disrespect for social mores and contempt for authority and he subsequently beats his father up during a domestic argument. In the end, the audience reveals that the school of Inferior Argument is a bugged school of people - people who know how to talk their way out of trouble. At the end of the debate, a quick survey of the audience by the buggers reveals that people with the best education can offer the best of both worlds. The play is set in Athens in the 4th century BC and is set against the backdrop of the Battle of Thermopylae. It is one of the most famous plays of all time and is thought to have been written by Sophocles. It was first performed at the Festival of the Four Seasons in Athens, Greece, in 476 BC. It has been described as the "greatest play ever written by a Greek author" and has been called "one of the best plays ever written in the history of the theatre" by the University of California, San Diego. The author has also been called the "father of the playwright" and "the father of the drama" by The New York Review of Books. He has also written a play about the life of Socrates, which was first published in 4th Century BC, called "Socrates and The Thinkery" (The Thinkery and The Clouds). He has written a second play about Socrates called "The Great Debate" which has been published in 2nd century BC, also by The NY Review. He is also the author of the book about Socrates' life, The Great Debate (The Great Argument, The Clouds, and The Great Debates). The play has been translated into German, French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian and Spanish. The composer has said that he was inspired by Socrates to write the play. He also says that the play was written in response to the events of the First World War. The writer has also said that the work was written as a response to events in the aftermath of the Second World War, when the Allies were at war with the Germans, and that he wanted to make a point about the role of the U.S. military in the conflict.

name: The Knights
summary: The Knights is a satire on political and social life in 5th-century Athens. The characters are drawn from real life and Cleon is clearly intended to be the villain. However it is also an allegory, the characters are figures of fantasy and the villain in this context is Paphlagonian, a comic monstrosity responsible for almost everything that's wrong with the world. This summary features the real-world names Cleon, Nicias and Demosthenes (though these names are never mentioned in the play). See Discussion for an overview of the ambiguous use of characterization in The Knights. The Knights by Aristophanes is published by Oxford University Press, priced £16.99, with a limited run of 1,000 copies. name: Romance of the Three Kingdoms
summary: In the final years of the Han Dynasty, incompetent eunuchs deceive the emperor and persecute good officials. The government becomes extremely corrupt on all levels, leading to widespread deterioration of the empire. During the reign of the penultimate Han sovereign, Emperor Ling, the Yellow Turban Rebellion breaks out under the leadership of Zhang Jue (a.k.a. Zhang Jiao). The rebellion is barely suppressed by troops under the command of He Jin, General-in-Chief of the imperial armies. In the ensuing chaos, the child Emperor Shao and the Prince of Chenliu disappear from the palace. The missing emperor and prince are found later by soldiers of the warlord Dong Zhuo, who proceeds to seize control of the Imperial capital Luoyang under the pretext of protecting the emperor. Dong later deposes EmperorShao and replaces him with the Prince. Sun Jian finds the Imperial Seal and keeps it secretly for himself, further weakening royal authority. Without a strong central government, warlords begin to rise and fight each other for land, plunging China into a state of anarchy. Many others, even those without title or land, such as Cao Cao and Liu Bei, are also starting to build up power. Cao Cao unites the Central Plains and northern China under his rule, and the lands he controlled would serve as the foundation for the state of Cao Wei in the future. Sun Ce dies at the pinnacle of his career from illness under stress of his terrifying encounter with the ghost of Yu Ji, a venerable magician whom he had falsely accused and executed in jealousy. However, his younger brother Sun Quan, who succeeds him, proves to be a capable and charismatic ruler. Sun, assisted by skilled advisors Zhou Yu and Zhang Zhao, inspires hidden talents such as Lu Su to join his service, and builds up a strong military force. Liu Bei becomes the governor of Xu Province after Tao Qian passes on the post to him. While Cao Cao subtly reveals his intention to usurp power, Liu Bei is officially recognised by the Emperor Xian as a saviour and seen as a defector. However Liu Bei's ambitions are not realized until the later part of the novel, when he joins in defeating Lü Bu at the Battle of Xiapi. They join the campaign against Dong Zuo and participate in a campaign against Gongsun Zan and join the battle against Dong. They are not recognized for his efforts in quelling the YellowTurban Rebellion and appointed as junior magistrate.

name: The Dragon in the Sea
summary: Set in a near-future earth, the West and the East have been at war for more than a decade. The West is stealing oil from the East with specialized nuclear submarines. The suspicion is that sleepers are sabotaging the subs or revealing their positions once at sea. John Ramsey, a young psychologist, is trained as an electronics operator and sent on the next mission, replacing the previous officer who went insane. His secret mission is to find the sleeper, or figure out why the crews are going insane. The last twenty submarines have simply disappeared, with the suspicion that they have been sabotaged or reveal their positions. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, which also publishes the novel in hardback and e-book form. For more information on the book, visit www.simonandschulder.com and www.thebookshop.com/. name: Destination: Void
summary: In the future, humankind has tried to develop artificial intelligence, succeeding only once, and then disastrously. The current project is being run on the moon, and the book tells the story of the seventh attempt in a series of experiments to create an artificial consciousness. For each attempt the scientists raise a group of clones. These clones are kept isolated and raised to believe that they will be the crew of a spaceship that will colonize a planet in the Tau Ceti solar system. The crew are just caretakers: the ship is controlled by a disembodied human brain, called "Organic Mental Core" or "OMC" that runs the complex operations of the vessel and keeps it moving in space. But the first two OMC's (Myrtle and Little Joe) become catatonic, while the third OMC goes insane and kills two of the umbilicus crew members. The ship carries thousands of other clones in hibernation, intended to populate the new colony and, if necessary, provide replacements for any crew members who die along the way. Space Ship Earthling number Seven ultimately succeeds. The consequences of their success form the basis of the plot for the novels which follow. fr: Destination vide he:Destination: Void. He understands the nature of the test: create a high pressure environment in which brilliance may break through out of necessity, and create in the safety of the void what humans couldn't safely create on Earth. He is aware that six other ships have gone out before theirs, each one failing. He's aware that the breakdown of the "OMM"s was planned. He knows that if they attempt to turn back they would be ordered to abort (self destruct) The crew knows that the ship will take hundreds of years to reach the system and the crew will spend most of their time in hibernating. The clones have been bred and carefully selected for psychological purposes to reinforce each other, as well as to provide various specialized skills that will give them the best chance of success. They know that the crew includes a chaplain-psychiatrist, Raja Flattery, who knows their real purpose, and that the break-down of the OMCs is planned. The captain of the ship knows that he will be killed if he tries to abort the mission. He can't turn back, so he decides to go through with the mission, even though he knows it will be a waste of his life and his life will be destroyed.

name: Whipping Star
summary: In Whipping Star, Jorj X. McKie is a saboteur extraordinary, a born troublemaker who has naturally become one of BuSab's best agents. As the novel opens, it is revealed that Calebans, who are beings visible to other sentient species as stars, have been disappearing one by one. Each disappearance is accompanied by millions of sentient deaths and instances of incurable insanity. When the Caleban dies, everyone who has ever used a jumpdoor (which is almost every adult in the sentient world and many of the young) will die as well. The Calebans begin to disappear one at a time, leaving our plane of existence (or exiting "our wave") to save themselves. As all Calebans are connected, if all were to remain in our existence, when Fannie Mae died, all Caleans would die. As each Calean exits, millions of the ConSentiency are killed or rendered insane. The Bureau of Sabotage (BuSab) is created to slow the wheels of government, thereby preventing it from legislating recklessly. Mliss Abnethe, a psychotic human female with immense power and wealth, has bound a Calesan in a contract that allows the Calesans to be whipped to death. McKIE has to find MlISS and stop her before Fannie Rae reaches, in her words, "ultimate discontinuity" But he is constrained by the law protecting private individuals by restricting the ministrations of Bu Sab to public entities. McKies succeeds in saving Fannie. Mae by opening a. jumpdoor into space which shunts a large interstellar cloud of (presumably) hydrogen into her stellar body, rejuvenating her from her torture at the hands of the Palenki henchmen hired by M liss Ab nethe. The novel is set in the far future, when humankind has made contact with numerous other species: Gowachin, Laclac, Wreaves, Pan Spechi, Taprisiots, and Calesban (among others) and has helped to form the Con Sentiency to govern among the species. Ninety years prior to the setting of Whipping. Star, the Calebans appeared and offered jumpdoors to the collective species, allowing sentients to travel instantly to any point in the universe. Gratefully accepting, the sentiency didn't question the consequences. The sentients of the galaxy found the need for a Bureau ofSabotage.

name: The Dosadi Experiment
summary: The novel is set in a distant future when humans are part of an interstellar civilization called the ConSentiency composed of many species. A secret, unauthorized experiment by the Gowachins was carried out with the help of a contract with the Calebans. They isolated the planet Dosadi behind an impenetrable barrier called "The God Wall". On the planet were placed humans and Gowachin, with an odd mix of modern and old technology. The culture of ordinary day to day power in Dosadi is very violent. Among other tools, addictive psychotropes are used for handling power among hierarchies in organisations. Senior Liator Keila Jedrik starts a war that will change Dosadi forever. Jorj X. McKie is a Saboteur Extraordinary, one of the principals of the Bureau of Sabotage, and the only human admitted to practice law before the Gowchin bar as a legum (lawyer). While meditating in a park in BuSab headquarters McKie. is mentally contacted by the Caleban Fannie Mae, a female member of a species of unparalleled power from another dimension whose visible manifestation in this universe is the star Thyone in the Pleiades cluster. This gives them the ability to swap bodies and thus by using a hole in the contract sealing Dosadi they can escape via jump gate. Once free, by legal manoeuvring the Dosadi population is unleashed upon the Con Sentiency for good or ill, whilst the people who set the project in motion try to deal with the consequences, having sent McKie there hoping a solution more in their interest could be found. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback, paperback and e-book. name: The Transparent Society
summary: Brin argues that a core level of privacy - protecting our most intimate interactions - may be preserved, despite the rapid proliferation of cameras. He feels that this core privacy can be saved simply because that is what humans deeply need and want. Brin: Privacy is only possible if freedom (including the freedom to know) is protected first. He argues that it will be good for society if the powers of surveillance are shared with the citizenry, allowing "sousveillance" or "viewing from below," enabling the public to watch the watchers. It will be tempting to pass laws that restrict the power of surveillance to authorities, entrusting them to protect our privacy -- or a comforting illusion of privacy. By contrast, a transparent society destroys that illusion by offering everyone access to the vast majority of information out there, Brin says. He admits that such a mostly-open world will seem more irksome and demanding; people will be expected to keep negotiating the tradeoffs between knowing and privacy. It is the only condition under which citizens may have some chance of catching the violators of their freedom and privacy, says Brin. He says there is no power-equalizer greater than knowledge, and that privacy is a "contingent right," one that grows out of the more primary rights, e.g. to know and to speak. The key question is whether citizens will be potent, sovereign and knowing enough to enforce this deeply human want, he says. This means they must not only have rights, but also the power to use them and the ability to detect when they are being abused, he adds. It's the same trend promoted by Adam Smith, John Locke, the US Constitutionalists and the western enlightenment, who held that any elite (whether commercial, governmental, or aristocratic) should experience constraints upon its power. According to Brin, that will only happen in a world that is mostly open, in which most citizens know most of what is going on, most of the time. The only way to protect privacy is to be open and honest about what you are doing, he argues, and to share your information with the public in a way that is open and transparent. The idea is to make it easier for people to make informed decisions about what they want to do and what to do with their lives, and not just rely on the help of others to tell them what is happening to them. The goal is to create a society that is more free and open.

name: The Poisoned Chocolates Case
summary: Sir Eustace Pennefather is a known womanizer whose divorce from his current wife is pending. He receives a complimentary box of chocolates through the post. A few hours later Joan Bendix is dead, whereas her husband, who has eaten far less of the chocolate, is taken seriously ill and hospitalized (but later recovers) The police can establish a few facts beyond any doubt: that the parcel was posted the previous evening near The Strand; that the poison that was injected into each of the chocolate is nitrobenzene; and that the accompanying letter was typewritten on a piece of stationery from the manufacturers. At the very end of the novel, however, there is no doubt as to the identity of the perpetrator. The murderer seems to feel safe with no need to cover up their tracks any further. The members of Roger Sheringham's Crimes Circle go about individually solving the case. After a week has passed, they present their findings on consecutive nights to their colleagues. Not surprisingly, they come up with various suspects: Sir EustACE's estranged wife; the father of a young lady whom Sir Eastace intended to marry after his divorce got through; one of Sir Estace's discarded mistresses; and some more. While these discussions are going on, the murderer appears to feelsafe with noneed to coverup their tracks. The author has no intention of giving up on the mystery of the poisoned box of chocolate and the mystery will only get worse as time goes on. The book is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book. name: Oedipus at Colonus
summary: Oedipus kills his father and marries his mother. He is told by an oracle that the outcome of the conflict will depend on where he is buried. He asks to see the king of Athens, who sympathizes with him and offers him his burial site, which will ensure victory in a future conflict with Thebes. The chorus sings about the glory and beauty of Athens. The king of Thebes threatens to use force to bring OedipUS back to Thebes, who calls for Poseidon to condemn Creon, telling him, "I knew [your city] would never harbor a father-killer... so exposed as the mate of his own mother" The chorus then calls for OedIPus to come from Thebes to sacrifice to Poseidon, who comes from a city that practices nothing without law. The play ends with the chorus singing about the beauty and glory of Athens and the glory of Poseidon's love for his wife, Antigone, and their children, Eteocles, Ismene and Polyneices, and Oedipsus and his daughters, Laius and Agamemnon. It was first performed at the Theatre of the Clouds in Athens in 4th century BC, and is considered one of the best-known plays of all time. It is now considered to be the most famous play in the history of the ancient Greek drama, along with Sophocles's "The Idiot's Guide to the End of the World" and "The Marriage of Aphrodite and Psyche" The play is set in the city of Colonus, Greece, during the time of the Trojan War. The plot involves the death of Oedippus' father and the burial of his mother in a place sacred to the Furies, or Erinyes. The story is told in the form of a play by Sophocleus and is written in the first person by Euripides, who is also the author of the play's libretto, "The Death and Arrival of Laiu" (4th Century BC) The play also includes the story of the birth of the first son, Theseus, and the birth and death of Theseus' daughter, IsMene. The final scene is set during the reign of the king Theseus in the year 476 BC, in which he is crowned king of the Athens and is given the title of "King of Athens" by the people of the city.

name: Vurt
summary: Vurt tells the story of Scribble and his "gang", the Stash Riders, as they search for his missing sister/lover Desdemona. The novel is set in an alternate version of Manchester, England, in which society has been shaped by Vurt, a hallucinogenic drug/shared alternate reality, accessed by sucking on colour-coded feathers. Through some (never explained) mechanism, the dreams, mythology, and imaginings of humanity have achieved objective reality in the Vurt and become "real" Before the novel begins, Scribbles and his sister-lover take a shared trip into a vurt called English Voodoo, but upon awakening Scribble finds his sister has been replaced by an amorphous blob that Mandy, a fellow Stash Rider, nicknames "The Thing from Outer Space" From that point on, Scribble is on a mission to find another copy of the rare and contraband Curious Yellow feather so that he can exchange The Thing for Desdemonia. The Thing from outer space is a rare and rare Curious Yellow Feather, which can only be obtained by sucking a particular colour of Vurt feather. The Curious Yellow feathers are found in Vurt in a variety of ways, including by sucking them from different colours of the drug, such as red, blue, and yellow. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, and is available in hardback and e-book. It is available to pre-order now for £12.99.
