name: Fast Food Nation: The Dark Side of the All-American Meal
summary: Schlosser describes the evolution of fast food and how it has coincided with the advent of the automobile. He explains how the McDonald's Corporation modeled its marketing tactics on The Walt Disney Company, which inspired the creation of advertising icons such as Ronald McDonald and his sidekicks. Schlosser concludes that, given the swift, decisive and effective action that took place as a result of this interest and intervention, many of the problems documented in the book are solvable, given enough political will. A later section of the book discusses the fast food industry's role in globalization, linking increased obesity in China and Japan with the arrival ofFast food. The book also includes a summary of the McLibel Case. In later editions, Schlossers provided an additional section that included reviews of his book, counters to critics who emerged since its first edition, and discussion of the effect that the threat of BSE had on US Federal Government policy towards cattle farming. In the U.S., 80% of sponsored textbooks contain material that is biased in favor of the sponsors, and 30% of high schools offer fast foods in their cafeterias. In his examination of the meat packing industry, Sch Losser finds that it is now dominated by casual, easily exploited immigrant labor and that levels of injury are among the highest of any occupation in the United States. He notes that practices like these were responsible for the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE, aka Mad Cow Disease, p. 202-3), as well as for introducing harmful bacteria into the food supply, such as E. coli O157:H7 (ch. 9, "What's In The Meat"). Schlosseser also recounts the steps involved in meat processing and reveals several hazardous practices unknown to many consumers. He discusses his findings on meat packing companies IBP, Inc. and on Kenny Dobbins. He sees that reductions in corporate taxation have come at the expense of school funding, thereby presenting many corporations with the opportunity for sponsorship with those same schools. According to his sources, 80 per cent of sponsored books are biased against the sponsors of the schools they sponsor. He concludes that many of these problems can be solved with political will and swift and decisive action by the federal government. He also discusses the tactic's ills: the exploitation of children's naïveté and trusting nature, and that the tactic would instill brand loyalty that would persist through adulthood through nostalgic associations to McDonald's. He suggests that if the worst were to happen and the entire base were entombed in the mountain, anthropologists of the future would discover random fast food wrappers scattered amongst military hardware.

name: The Dice Man
summary: The book tells the story of a psychiatrist named Luke Rhinehart who, feeling bored and unfulfilled in life, starts making decisions about what to do based on a roll of a dice. Along the way, there is sex, rape, murder, "dice parties", breakouts by psychiatric patients, and various corporate and governmental machines being put into a spin. There is also a description of the cult that starts to develop around the man, and the psychological research he initiates, such as the "Fuck without Fear for Fun and Profit" program. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced at $24.99. For more information on the book, or to order a copy, visit www.simonandschulder.com or call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). name: The Search for the Dice Man
summary: The book is set 20 years after the end of The Dice Man. Larry Rhinehart has grown up to become a hotshot investor on the stock market. He gets approached by the FBI, who are trying to trace his father's location, and find out whether he's alive or dead. Larry naturally refuses to have anything to do with the FBI. He soon starts to pursue his own investigations. Along the way, what he sees and hears change his views somewhat. By the end it is he who is trying to convince Luke, his father, to accept more chance into his life, rather than the other way round. He is financed in this by his fiancée's father, who wants to put the whole dice business to rest. It takes a long time - a whole book in fact, but Larry eventually does complete his quest. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, and comes out in paperback on Friday, September 14. name: Anna Karenina
summary: The novel is divided into eight parts. Its epigraph is Vengeance is mine, I will repay, from Romans 12:19, which in turn is quoting from Deuteronomy 32:35. The novel opens with a scene introducing Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky ("Stiva"), a Moscow aristocrat and civil servant who has been unfaithful to his wife Darya Alexandrovna, ("Dolly"). Stiva's childhood friend, Konstantin Dmitrievich Levin ("Kostya"), arrives in Moscow with the aim of proposing to Dolly's youngest sister, Princess Katerina Alexandrovne Shcherbatskaya ("Kitty") Levin discovers that Kitty is also being pursued by Count Alexei Kirillovich Vronsky, an army officer. At the ball, Vronski dances with Anna, choosing her as a partner over a shocked and heartbroken Kitty. Anna, shaken by her emotional and physical response to Vronssky, returns at once to Saint Petersburg. During the overnight journey, the two meet and Vronsky confesses his love. Anna refuses him, although she is deeply affected by his attentions to her. Although she initially tries to reject him, she eventually succumbs to his attention. Anna returns to her husband Alexei Alexandrovich Karenin, a senior government official, and their son Sergei. On seeing her husband for the first time since her encounter with Vronky, Anna realises that she finds him repulsive. Anna is uneasy about leaving her young son, Seryozha, alone for thefirst time. She also talks openly and emotionally about Stiva’s affair, convincing her that Stiva stills loves her despite the infidelity. Kitty, just eighteen, is in her first season as a debutante and is expected to make an excellent match with a man of her social standing. Kitty is very struck by Anna's beauty and personality, and becomes infatuated with her. When Levin proposes to Kitty at her home, she clumsily turns him down. Levin, crushed by Kitty's refusal, returns to his estate farm, abandoning any hope of marriage. Anna begins to spend more time in Saint Petersburg, spending time with Princess Betsy, a fashionable socialite and Vronskai's cousin. Kitty realises she is suffering because of Vronskys and Levin, whom she had hurt and had hurt in vain. Levin cares for her sister by referring to her infidelity, saying she could never love a man who betrayed her.

name: Adventures of Wim
summary: Adventures of Wim is a new interpretation of the story of Wim. The book is made up of sections taken from other, fictional books. The preface to the book claims that it was written in Deya, Majorca, in 2326. Wim, also known as "He of Many Chances", proves to be an inefficient saviour, as God sends him on a quest for Ultimate Truth. After a long and arduous search, Wim finds ultimate truth (in a tomato), and with it the cure for the sickness of the human condition. He is pronounced to be the saviour of the Montauk nation by his tribe's navigator, and educated in their ways. Sadly, the humans steal him away and attempt to educate him in more useful skills, such as American Football. The screenplay is possibly in there as a result of Luke Rhinehart's continuing frustration in trying to get The Dice Man turned into a good movie. It is a multi-faceted and whimsical account of 'one of the greatest figures in the 20th and 21st Century' The Gospel According to Luke (Luke Forth, not Luke Rhinhart) and the screenplay of a movie. The Book of the Die and Whim: Montauks for "Wave Rider" and "Wim" (in Adventures of Wim) or "Whim" or 'Wim' or 'Whim' (in The Book Of The Die And Whim) is a book about a boy named Wim, who is born of a virgin mother and is named "wim" in the book. It was written by Luke Forth, and published by Simon & Schuster in 1994. It has been adapted into a film, which is due to be released later this year, starring Tom Hanks and Amy Adams as well as a host of other actors and actresses. The film will be based on the book, and will be directed by Quentin Tarantino. It will be released in UK cinemas on September 25th, 2014, with a UK release date of September 27th, 2015, and a US release date on September 28th, 2016. The UK release dates for the film are yet to be announced. The U.S. release date for the movie is still to be confirmed, but it is expected to be in time for Christmas 2014. The movie will be filmed in the UK and the U.K. for release on September 29th, and the UK on September 30th, 2017.

name: High Fidelity
summary: Rob Fleming is a London record store owner in his mid-thirties whose girlfriend, Laura, has just left him. Rob, recalling his five most memorable breakups, sets about getting in touch with the former girlfriends. Eventually, Rob's re-examination of his failed relationships and the death of Laura's father bring the two back together. Their relationship is cemented by the launch of a new purposefulness to Rob's life in the revival of his disc jockey career. Also, realizing that his fear of commitment and his tendency to act on emotion are responsible for his continuing desires to pursue new women, Rob makes a symbolic commitment to Laura. The film is out now on Blu-ray and DVD. For more information on the film, go to the film's official website or go to www.thefilmproject.com. It is based on a true story that took place in London in the late 1990s and early 2000s, and was written by Rob Fleming and directed by David Walliams. name: The Red House Mystery
summary: The setting is an English country house, where Mark Ablett has been entertaining a house party. Mark's long-lost brother Robert, the black sheep of the family, arrives from Australia and shortly thereafter is found dead, shot through the head. Tony Gillingham, a stranger who has just arrived to call on his friend Bill, decides to investigate. He plays Sherlock Holmes to his younger counterpart's Doctor Watson; they progress almost playfully through the novel while the clues mount up and the theories abound. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £16.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or go to www.hodgerandstroughton.com. The film was directed by David Lean and the film is based on a true story. The movie was shot in London and London.

name: Hans Brinker, or The Silver Skates
summary: In Holland, poor-but-industrious and honorable 15-year-old Hans Brinker and his younger sister Gretel, yearn to participate in December's great ice-skating race on the canal. Hans' father, Raff Brinker, is sick and amnesiac, with violent episodes, because of a head injury caused by a fall from a dike, and he cannot work. Hans offers his own money, saved in the hope of buying steel skates, to the doctor to pay for his father's operation. Touched by this gesture, Dr. Boekman provides the surgery for free, and Hans is able to buy good skates for both himself and Gretel to skate in the race. Gretel wins the girls' race, but Hans lets a friend — who needs it more — win the precious prize, the Silver Skates, in the boys' race. Mr. Brinker's operation is successful and he is restored to health and memory. The Brinker parents live a long and happy life. Hans goes to medical school and becomes a successful doctor, and his daughter Gretel also grows up to enjoy a happy adult life. Dr. boekman is also changed, losing his gruff ways, thanks in part to being able to be reunited with his lost son through the unlikely aid of Mr. and Mrs. Brinkers' savings, thought lost or stolen ten years ago. The book is about a young boy and his sister, who are forced to work hard to support the family and are looked down upon in the community because of their low income and poor status. It is also about a boy and a girl who have to work to support their family and have to support each other. The film is about two young people who are in love and want to make a difference in the lives of the people around them. It was written by J.K. Rowling and is published by Simon & Schuster, with an estimated running time of 2 hours and 40 minutes. It has been praised as one of the best books of the year by critics and audiences alike, and has been described as a "masterwork of storytelling" and a "must-see" book for children and adults alike. The movie was released on November 14, 2013. It will be released on DVD on November 25, 2013, and on Blu-ray and DVD on December 11, 2013 in the U.S. and in the UK on the same day.

name: Dreamcatcher
summary: Dreamcatcher is set near the fictional town of Derry, Maine. It is the story of four lifelong friends: Gary Ambrose "Jonesy" Jones, Pete Moore, Joe "Beaver" Clarendon and Henry Devlin. The friends save Douglas "Duddits" Cavell, a young teen with Down syndrome, from a group of sadistic bullies. The four go on a hunting trip together each year, and plan to visit Duddits on their return from this year's trip to the Hole-in-the-Wall. While on the trip, Jonesy finds a disoriented and delirious stranger wandering in the woods during a blizzard, and talking about lights in the sky. The man exhibits dyspepsia and extremely foul flatulence but claims that these are the result of eating berries and lichen while he was lost. Beaver and Jonesy notice large numbers of animals, all with a similar reddish discoloration, migrating. The stampeding animals all have similar symptoms caused by infection with an extraterrestrial macro virus. Eating or inhaling the red mold causes large worm-like aliens, called byrum, to infest the host. The byrum are red, lamprey-like creatures with multiple rows of razor-sharp teeth. When an infestation is sufficiently established, the host develops a form of telepathy with other infested individuals. The friend name the byrum "shit weasel" because it exits the body through the anus, killing the host, and the friends name it "The Ripley" because of its extreme resilience to destruction. Colonel Kurtz states that the Grays have tried several times in the past century to gain control of the earth, but have failed. The Grays are outside a crashed spacecraft, sending messages that they come in peace and are helpless to try to fool the Army. Several helicopters are sent to wipe out the byrus, but they mainly succeed in wiping out the soldiers exposed to the attack. Meanwhile, all people in the area who have been affected by the fungus are rounded up by the Army, with the intention that they will later be executed by the army. The last person to discover this is Beaver, who uses the last of his strength to discover being killed by the last byrum to save his friends from being executed by his last byrus. The story ends with Beaver trapping the trapped creature inside the toilet lid, and falling to the floor, freeing the creature, which then attacks him.

name: Long Voyage Back
summary: The story concerns a hypothetical World War III between the USSR and the United States. One family and some friends try to run away in a sailboat. The story describes their battles with nuclear winter and fallout, and with the ensuing collapse of civilization. The book was written in the 1980s, and was published by Simon & Schuster in 1988. It is published in hardback, with a cover price of $16.99. It was published in the U.S. by Simon and Schuster, and published in Europe by Simon and Schuster, Inc. in 1988, and in the UK by Macmillan, in 1989, and 1994. It has been published in English by Simon&Schuster since 1988, as well as in English and German by MacMillan, and has been translated into Spanish and Italian. The novel was originally published in 1987, and it has been republished in English in 2009 and 2010, with an updated cover. The original version of this article stated that the USSR would win in a nuclear war. In fact, the average Russian doesn't have a gun, so they can't all shoot each other and the army for food.

name: Foucault's Pendulum
summary: The plot of Foucault's Pendulum revolves around three friends, as relevant to the rule of three, named Belbo, Diotallevi and Casaubon. After reading one too many manuscripts about occult conspiracy theories, they decide they can do better, and set out to invent their own conspiracy for fun. A number of sub-plots are woven into the grand theme of The Plan, and the novel brings out the credulity inherent in all people. The book opens with the narrator hiding in fear after closing time in the Parisian technical museum Musée des Arts et Métiers. He believes that members of a secret society have kidnapped Belbo and are now after him. Most of the novel is then told in flashback as Casaubson waits in the museum. The novel ends with CasaUBon and Amparo also attending an occult event in Brazil, an Umbanda ritual, where she falls into a deeply disturbing trance and shuns spiritual and religious experiences. It is then revealed that the two men have fallen in love and eventually have a child together, but the two fall apart and he returns to Italy to work for a respectable publishing house. The Plan is published by Mr Garamond (his name refers to French publisher Claude Garhisamond) and is available for pre-order on Amazon.com for £16.99. name: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang
summary: Commander Caractacus Pott is an inventor who buys and renovates an old car. The car, a "Paragon Panther," was the sole production of the Paragon motor-car company before it went bankrupt. After the restoration is complete, the car is named for the noises made by its starter motor and the characteristic two loud backfires it makes when it starts. At first Chitty-Chitty-Bang-Bang is just a big and powerful car, but as the book progresses the car surprises the family by beginning to exhibit independent actions. This first happens while the family is caught in a traffic jam on their way to the beach for a picnic. At the car's direction, Commander Pott pulls a switch which causes it to sprout wings and take flight over the stopped cars on the road. They make for the French coast and land on a beach near Calais. They explore along the beach and find a cave boobytrapped with some devices intended to scare off intruders. The family detonate the cache of explosives and flee the cave. Chitty flies the family away to parts unknown, and the book implies that the car has yet more secrets. The Potts stay overnight in a hotel in Calais. While the family sleeps, the gangsters break into the children's room and kidnap them and drive off towards Paris. The gangsters are planning to rob a famous chocolate shop in Paris using the children as decoys. The Pott children overhear this and manage to warn the shop owner, Monsieur Bon-Bon. The police arrive and the gangster are taken away. As a reward Monsieurs wife shares the secret recipe of her world famous fudge with the Potts and the two families become good friends. The book ends with Chitty and Mrs. Pott returning to the U.S. to visit their relatives. The novel is published by Simon & Schuster and is available in hardback and e-book. name: Oliver Twist
summary: Orphaned almost from his first breath by his mother's death in childbirth and his father’s unexplained absence. Oliver is meagerly provided for under the terms of the Poor Law and spends the first nine years of his life at a baby farm in the 'care' of a woman named Mrs. Mann. Around the time of Oliver's ninth birthday, Mr. Bumble, a parish beadle, removes Oliver from the baby farm and puts him to work picking oakum at the main workhouse. One day, the desperately hungry boys decide to draw lots; the loser must ask for another portion of gruel. The task falls to Oliver, who at the next meal tremblingly comes forward, bowl in hand, and makes his famous request: "Please, sir, I want some more." A great uproar ensues. The board of well-fed gentlemen who administer the workhouse hypocritically offer five pounds to any person wishing to take on the boy as an apprentice. A brutal chimney sweep almost claims Oliver, however, when he begs despairingly not to be sent away with "that dreadful man", a kindly old magistrate refuses to sign the indentures. Oliver eventually decides to run away, and, "He remembered to have seen the waggons, as they went out, toiling up the hill," until a well-placed milestone sets his wandering feet towards London. During his journey to London, Oliver encounters Jack Dawkins, a pickpocket more commonly known by the nickname the "Artful Dodger", although Oliver's innocent nature prevents him from recognising this hint that the boy may be dishonest. In this way, Oliver unwittingly falls in with an infamous Jewish criminal known as Fagin, the so-called gentleman of whom the Artful dodger spoke. He believes they make wallets and handkerchiefs because they are of no income. Later, Oliver realises that their real mission is to pickpocket an old gentleman named Charley Brownlow. When he finds his handker Chief missing, he pursues him and takes him to the judge's court. The judge clears the boy of crime, but is reluctant to believe he is a pick pocket. Others join in the chase and Oliver is taken and taken before the magistrate Curiously, Mr Brownlow has second thoughts about the book. The boy is taken to the police and is taken into custody. The book is published in 1837 by Bentley's Miscellany, but when originally published in Bentley's miscellany the town was called Mudfog.

name: East of Eden
summary: The story is primarily set in the Salinas Valley, California, between the beginning of the 20th century and the end of World War I. Some chapters are in Connecticut and Massachusetts, and the story goes as far back as the American Civil War. Adam Trask's life is seen in a long, intricate flashback. Cathy Ames is described as having a "malformed soul"; she is cold, cruel, and utterly incapable of feeling for anyone but herself. She leaves home one evening after setting fire to her family's home, killing both of her parents. She renames herself "Kate" and embarks on a devious – and successful plan to ingratiate herself with the owner, murder her and inherit the business. The boys, particularly Aron, are horrified that their father is now a laughingstock in the town of Salinas, laughing at everyone around him and wandering around town late at night. The popular and beloved and beloved Samuel Hamilton finally passes away and is mourned by the boys and their beloved mother. Adam becomes inspired by the memory of Samuel Hamilton's inventiveness and loses all of the family's fortune in an ill-fated business venture. During one night of wandering around the town, Caleb decides to become an Episcopalian priest. He takes on the role of priest and takes the town around him to talk about his human failings, shuns everyone else and takes to the streets at night to talk to people. He is eventually arrested and jailed for a crime he didn't commit, but he is released and goes on to have a successful career in farming. He eventually becomes a successful and beloved inventor and farmer, but his life is turned upside down by the death of his father, who left him $50,000 each. He becomes a widower and father to two sons, Caleb and Aron &ndAsh; echoing Cain and Abel &ndASH; who are oblivious of their mother's situation. Adam is so ecstatically happy with his new life that he does not realize there is any problem. Shortly after Cathy gives birth to twin boys, she shoots Adam in the shoulder and flees. Adam recovers, but remains in a deep and terrible depression, but is roused out of it enough to name and raise his sons with the help of his Cantonese cook, Lee, and his neighbor Samuel Hamilton. Lee tells about how his relatives in San Francisco, a group of Chinese scholars, spent two years studying Hebrew so they might discover what the moral of the Cain & Abel story actually was. Their discovery that the Hebrew word "Timshel" means "thou mayest" becomes an important symbol in the novel.

name: The Old Man and the Sea
summary: The Old Man and the Sea is the story of a battle between an old, experienced Cuban fisherman and a large marlin. The novel opens with the explanation that the fisherman, who is named Santiago, has gone 84 days without catching a fish. Santiago uses all the strength he has left in him to pull the fish onto its side and stab the marlin with a harpoon, ending the long battle between the old man and the tenacious fish. While Santiago continues his journey back to the shore, sharks are attracted to the trail of blood left by the Marlin in the water. By nightfall, the sharks have almost devoured theMarlin's entire carcass, leaving a skeleton consisting mostly of its backbone, its tail and its head. A group of fishermen gather the next day around the boat where the fish's skeleton is still attached. One of the fishermen measures it to be from nose to tail. Tourists at the nearby café mistakenly take it for a shark. The boy brings him newspapers and coffee. The old man wakes, and they promise to fish together once again. Upon his return to sleep, Santiago dreams of his youth—of lions on an African beach. The book is about a young Cuban fisherman named Santiago who is considered "salao", the worst form of unlucky. Santiago is so unlucky that his young apprentice, Manolin, has been forbidden by his parents to sail with the oldMan and been ordered to fish with more successful fishermen. Santiago tells Manolin that he will venture far out into the Gulf to fish, confident that his unlucky streak is near its end. On the eighty-fifth day, Santiago sets out alone, taking his skiff far onto the Gulf. He sets his lines and, by noon of the first day, a big fish that he is sure is a marlin takes his bait. The first, a great mako shark, Santiago kills with his harpoons, losing that weapon in the process. He makes a new harpoon by strapping his knife to the end of an oar to help ward off the next line of sharks; in total, five sharks are slain and many others are driven away. But the sharks keep coming, and by nightfall the shark's carcass is almost devouring the marincass. When Santiago reaches the shore before dawn, Santiago struggles on the way to his shack, carrying the heavy mast on his shoulder. Once home, he slumps onto his bed and falls into a deep sleep.

name: The Children of Men
summary: The novel opens with the first entry in Theo's diary. It is the year 2021, but the novel's events have their origin in 1995. In 1994, the sperm counts of human males plummeted to zero and mankind now faces imminent extinction. The last people to be born are now called "Omegas". "A race apart," they enjoy various prerogatives. In 2006, a man called Xan Lyppiatt, Theo's rich and charismatic cousin, appointed himself Warden of England in the last general election. He is called a despot and a tyrant by his opponents, but officially the new society is referred to as egalitarian. Theo is approached by a woman called Julian, a member of a group of dissidents calling themselves the Five Fishes. The group wants Theo to approach Xan on their behalf and ask for various reforms, including a return to a more democratic system. During their discussions, and as Theo prepares to meet with Xan, the reader learns how the UK is in 2021. The country is governed by decree of the Council of England, which consists of five people. Parliament has been reduced to an advisory role. All convicted criminals are dumped at a penal colony on the Isle of Man. There is no remission, escape is almost impossible, visitors are forbidden and prisoners may not write or receive letters. Every citizen is required to learn skills, such as husbandry, which they might need to help them survive if they happen to be among the last human beings in Britain. Foreign workers are lured into the country and then exploited. At 60, which is the age limit, they are sent back ("forcibly repatriated"). British Omegas are not allowed to emigrate so as to prevent further loss of labor. Elderly/infirm citizens have become a burden; nursing homes are for the privileged few. The rest are expected and sometimes forced to commit suicide by taking part in a "Quusus" (sanctioned mass drownings) at the age of 60. Twice a year, the state has opened "pornography centres" for healthy women under 45 to submit to a gynecological examination, and men must have their sperm tested to keep them alive. The youngest generation are described as spoiled, over-entitled and egotistical due to their youth and the luxurious lifestyle they are treated to. They are violent, remote and unstable, and regard non-Omega (elders) with undisguised contempt. The latest trend in London is to have elaborate christening ceremonies for newborn pets.

name: The Spy Who Came in from the Cold
summary: Alec Leamas is the Station Head of the British Secret Intelligence Service in West Berlin. He is recalled to the Circus in London by Control, chief of the Circus. Control asks Leamas to stay "in the cold" for one last mission: to turn (defect) and provide false information to the East German Communists that would implicate Mundt as a British double agent. Leamas believes helping Fiedler destroy Mundt is a worthy act. Meanwhile, in England, George Smiley and Peter Guillam appear at Liz Gold's apartment claiming to be friends of Alec, question her about him, and offer her financial help. Liz Gold is invited to East Germany for a Communist Party information exchange. The power struggle in the Abteilung comes into the open when Mundt orders Fiedlers and Leamas arrested and tortured. They are released, and Fiedrer and Mundt are summoned to present their cases to a tribunal convened in camera, in the town of Görlitz. At the trial, Leamas documents a series of secret bank account payments that Fieder matches to the movements of Mundt. He admits that Control gave him all the information he needed to frame him as a double agent, and offers to return for Liz's freedom. Realising that the operation is now blown, he assaults her the night before he assaulted the grocer. She admits that she had promised Leamas not to look for him when he disappeared. She also admits that he had said good-bye to her the day before he disappeared, and that he also had said he would not look for her when he returned to London. The novel ends with Liz Gold calling the unsuspecting Leamas's attorney as a surprise witness for the defence for the prosecution of the Mundt’s trial. It is the last novel in the series by the author, who has since moved on to a new project with the University of California, Los Angeles. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99. name: The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter
The Great White Hope
summary: The Great White Hope explores how segregation and prejudice created the demand for a "great white hope" who would defeat Jack Johnson. The play is often described as being thematically about racism, but this is not, it seems, entirely how Sackler viewed his work. In a comment, reflecting on both the racist theme dealt with in the play and Sackler's notion that the play is about a man fighting society, Muhammad Ali apparently commented to the actor, "That's my story. You take out the issue of white women and replace it with theissue of religion. That's my stories!" He was fighting being drafted into the army at the time on grounds of being a conscientious objector. Ali was being drafted to serve in the U.S. Army at that time and was being treated as a "citizen" by the Army Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) The play ends with a speech by Sackler about the role of race in society and how it has changed over the years. The final performance of the play takes place on November 11, 2013. The show is directed by Michael Aronofsky and will run until November 14, 2013, at the Palace Theatre in New York City. For more information on the play, go to www.thegreatwhitehopetheatre.org. For additional information about the show, visit The Great White Hopetheater.org or go to http://www.the greatwhitehopeta.org/. For more on the history of Jack Johnson, visit the Jack Johnson Museum at the University of New York. for more information about Jack Johnson and his life and career, visit www.jackjohnson.com. name: The Postman
summary: Despite the post-apocalyptic scenario, and several action sequences, the book is largely about civilization and symbols. Each of the three sections deals with a different symbol. In the third section, as the Postman joins forces with the Cyclops scientists in a war against an influx of "hypersurvivalists", he begins to find traces of them. The final scenes give the impression that the three symbols may rally together in an effort to revive civilization. Many times through the book, curses are uttered which damn Holn for his actions. Nathan Holn was an author who championed an extreme, violent, misogynistic and hypersurVivalist society. Holn is said to have himself been hanged in the novel, but in the time following what should have been a brief period of civil disorder, followers of Holn prevented the U.S. from recovering from the limited war, and the plagues that followed. The Bear Flag of California is the symbol that they rally behind: the symbol of California. The book was written in the early 1990s and published by Simon & Schuster, with a print run of 1,000 copies. It is now published in hardback with a hardback cover and a hardcover edition of 2,500 copies. The hardback has been published in the UK and the US with a cover price of £12.99, with the UK paperback version of £16.99. The US paperback edition has been released in the late 1990s. The UK paperback edition of the book has a cover of £14.99 and the UK edition of £15.99 (with a paperback copy of £18.99). The US edition has a front cover of the same price, but the front cover has a different front cover and the back cover has an image of a man in a postal uniform. The author has no idea who the man in the postman uniform is, but believes that he is a real postman. The novel was published in 1998 and has been translated into several languages, including English, German, French, Spanish, Italian, and Spanish. It was published by Macmillan, which published it as a trade paperback in 1999. It has been optioned for a limited number of editions, and is available in hardcover and e-book editions, with prices ranging from £8.99 to £15, with an MSRP of £10.99 for the hardback version of the novel being £10, and £15 for the paperback edition.

name: The Phantom of the Opera
summary: Christine Daaé is the daughter of a famous fiddler. Her father tells her many stories featuring an "Angel of Music" Christine is eventually given a position in the chorus at the Paris Opera House. She begins hearing a beautiful, unearthly voice which sings to her and speaks to her. The Voice, however, belongs to Erik, a physically-deformed and mentally-disturbed charismatic genius who was one of the architects who took part in the construction of the opera. He has been extorting money from the Opera's management for many years. After the chandelier accident, Erik kidnaps Christine to his home in the cellars and reveals his true identity. He plans to keep her there only a few days, hoping she will come to love him, and Christine begins to find herself attracted to her abductor. But she causes Erik to change his plans when she unmasks him and, to the horror of both, beholds his face, which according to the book, resembles the face of a rotting corpse. To save them and the people below, Erik threatens to destroy the entire Opera using explosives, killing everyone in the floors above. If she refuses to marry him, Erik doesn't drown them in the water, stating that he doesn't want to drown them. To rescue them, Erik uses an old acquaintance of his, known only as "The Persian", in an attempt to rescue her. Christine agrees to go with him, but she pities Erik and will not go until she has sung for him one last time. She then realizes the ring has slipped off her finger and fallen into the streets somewhere, and begins to panic. The two leave. But neither is aware that Erik has been listening to their conversation or that it has driven him to jealous frenzy. Christine continues to refuse, until she realizes that an old friend, Raoul, promises to take Christine away where Erik can never find her and to take her even if she resists. Raoul tells Christine he shall act on his promise the following day, to which Christine agrees. But both are unaware that Erik is listening to them and that he has driven them to jealous frenzies. Christine then realizes that the Voice is not real and that Raoul has been lying to her about his love for her and that she must go with Erik the next day. But the two leave together and Christine realizes that he is not the Phantom of the Opera, but the Viscount of Chagny.

name: Murder on the Orient Express
summary: Hercule Poirot boards the Orient Express in Constantinople. On the second night he gets a compartment to himself. The next day he awakens to find that Mr. Ratchett is dead, having been stabbed twelve times in his sleep. He finds several more clues in the victim's cabin and on board the train, including a linen handkerchief embroidered with the initial "H", a pipe cleaner, and a button from a conductor's uniform. All of these clues suggest that the murderer or murderers were somewhat sloppy. However, each clue seemingly points to different suspects, which suggests that some of the clues were planted. As the evidence mounts, it continues to point in wildly different directions and it appears thatPoirot is being challenged by a mastermind. A critical piece of missing evidence, the scarlet kimono worn the night of the murder by an unknown woman, turns up in the luggage of M. Bouc and Dr. Constantine in the restaurant car. The first explanation is that a stranger–some enemy ofRatchett's murder was on the train at the last stop, murdered for reasons unknown, and escaped unnoticed. The second is that the victim and several others failed to note that the train had crossed into a different time zone just just before 1:00 am, because everyone thought that the crime occurred an hour earlier than everyone thought, because the victim had left the train earlier than the others. The third is that PoiroT must surely be aware that this does not explain the circumstances of the crime, but does not fully explain the reasons for it. The final chapter is about the death of the American heiress Daisy Armstrong, who was kidnapped and murdered by a notorious fugitive from the U.S. Five years earlier, Cassetti kidnapped three-year-old Daisy Armstrong and fled the country with the money. The shock sent her into premature labour, and both she and the baby died. Daisy's mother, Sonia, was pregnant when she heard of Daisy's death, and her husband, Colonel Armstrong, shot himself out of grief. Although Cassetti was caught, his resources allowed him to get himself acquitted on an unspecified technicality, although he still fled thecountry to escape further prosecution for the crime. The book ends with a scene in which a woman in a scarletkimono retreats down the passage in the distance, and he sees nothing except the back of her retreating down the passageway. It is the last book in the series.

name: Equus
summary: Martin Dysart is a psychiatrist in a psychiatric hospital. He meets Alan Strang, a troubled young man who is obsessed with horses. Dysart begins to jog Alan's memory by filling in blanks of the dialogue, and asking questions. Alan's sexual training began with his mother, who told him that the sexual act was dirty, but that he could find true love and contentment by way of religious devotion and marriage. During this time he also begins to show a sexual attraction to horses, desiring to pet their thick coats, feel their muscular bodies and smell their sweat. Alan also envisions himself as a king, on the head of Equus, destroying their enemies by both destroying their bodies and getting naked with them. The play ends with Alan having sex with Jill Mason, who had taken an interest in him, after which he runs into his father, who tries to justify his presence in the theater, when he realized that his father was lying when he said that he was lying about being in the movie. The two men have sex, but Alan breaks it off when he realizes his father is lying and that he is not the one who ran into the movie theater, but his father. In the end, Alan realizes that sex is a natural thing for all men, even his father—even if he is lying about his father being lying about what he is doing, and they have sex again, despite his father's attempts to stop them. It is the last scene of the play, in which Dysart hypnotizes Alan, and during the hypnosis, reveals elements of his terrifying dream of the ritual murder of children. The film ends on a cliffhanger, with Alan's father telling him that he has to kill his son to break free from the chains of existence, and that the only way to do so is to kill him. The movie was released on September 14, 2013. The book is available on Blu-ray and DVD. name: American Psycho
summary: American Psycho is about the daily life of wealthy young investment banker Patrick Bateman. Bateman narrates his everyday activities, from his recreational life among the Wall Street elite of New York to his forays into murder by nightfall. The novel maintains a high level of ambiguity through mistaken identity and contradictions that introduce the possibility that Bateman is an unreliable narrator. Whether any of the crimes depicted in the novel actually happened or whether they were simply the fantasies of a delusional psychotic is deliberately left open. The book ends as it began, with Bateman and his colleagues in a club on a Friday night, engaging in banal conversation. In the book, Bateman's control over his violent urges deteriorates. His murders become increasingly sadistic and complex, progressing from simple stabbings to drawn out sequences of torture, rape, mutilation, cannibalism, and necrophilia. He begins to experience bizarre hallucinations such as seeing a Cheerio interviewed on a talk show, being stalked by an anthropomorphic park bench, and finding a bone in his Dove Bar. These incidents culminate in a shooting spree during which he kills several random people in the street, resulting in a SWAT team being dispatched in a helicopter. In a later chapter, he calls his attorney, Harold Carnes, and confesses all his crimes to the answering machine. Carnes tells Bateman that he is too much of a coward to have committed such acts and claims that he had dinner in London with Paul Owen a few days before. In another section, he confronts Carnes about the message only to find Carnes is amused at what he considers to be a good joke. He runs into a real estate agent showing the apartment to prospective buyers; the real-estate agent appears suspicious of Bateman, as though meant to hide a bad odor. He ends the book as it started, with the book ending as it beginning, with him and his colleague in a nightclub on a Saturday night. In an earlier section, the book is broken up by chapters in which he directly addresses the reader in order to critique the work of 1980s Pop music artists. He introduces stories about serial killers into casual conversations and on several occasions openly confesses his murderous activities to his coworkers, who never take him seriously, do not hear what he says, or misunderstand him completely—for example, hearing the words "murders and executions" as "mergers and acquisitions" Bateman revisits Paul Owen's apartment, where he had killed and mutilated two prostitutes, and enters the perfectly clean, refurbished apartment, which shows no trace of decomposing bodies but is filled with strong-smelling flowers.

Gideon Barr marries an Englishwoman to provide himself an "air of permanence" as Rajah and we see much of the later portion of the story through Amelia Barr's eyes. Amelia Barr is fictional, but largely based on Margaret Brooke, wife of the second Rajah, and her book "My Life in Sarawak". name: Creatures of Light and Darkness
summary: The Universe was once ruled by the god Thoth, who administered the different forces in the Universe to keep things in balance. At some point, Thoth had awakened a dormant, malevolent force on a distant planet. This dark force, called the Thing That Cries In The Night, is so powerful and malevolent that it nearly obliterated Thoth's wife and threatens to consume the galaxy. Thoth works to contain and destroy the creature, and in so doing, neglects his duties in maintaining the Universe. The Angels become rebellious and use the power vacuum to fight amongst themselves for dominance. Some of the surviving Angels either hide among the peoples of the Universe as mysterious "immortals", but others—Osiris and Anubis—take over the House of Life and House of Death, respectively. Osiris cultivates life where he can, while Anubis works to destroy it. Plenty and famine, proliferation and plague, overpopulation and annihilation, alternate in the Worlds of Life between the two Stations, much to the detriment of those who inhabit them. The geography of this universe contains several curious places: The planet Blis is filled to bursting with people who are inexhaustibly fertile and do not know death. One man agrees to commit suicide in front of an audience, for money to be given to his family, because most people on Bliss have never seen a death. He does so by self-immolation, after receiving the Possibly Proper Death Litany (also called the Agnostic's Prayer). * On fog-shrouded D'donori, warlords raid each others solely to capture prisoners, who will be vivisected by town scrier. On an unnamed planet, the sea is above the atmosphere, or the normal planet cannot survive on a normal planet. In a cave, a dog worries a glove that has seen better centuries. On another planet, drug-maddened priests worship a pair of old shoes and casten spearmen protect and protect and castrated priests worship and protect them. Here the Prince Who Was a Thousand keeps Nephthys, his wife, who was disembodied and disembodied, and who was also disembodied. He also revives the personality of his wife and keeps her safe on a special world known only to him, where the seas are above the Atmosphere, not below them. He scatters Set's weapons and armor across the Universe for safe-keeping in the event that Set can ever be found.

name: The Handmaid's Tale
summary: The novel is set in the near future in the Republic of Gilead, a country formed within the borders of what was formerly the United States of America. It was founded by a racist, homophobic, christian, nativist, theocratic-organized military coup as an ideologically driven response to the pervasive ecological, physical and social degradation of the country. The story is presented from the point of view of a woman called Offred (literally Of-Fred, however not a patronymic as some critics claim) The character is one of a class of individuals kept as concubines ("handmaids") for reproductive purposes by the ruling class in an era of declining births. The book is told in the first person by Offred, who describes her life during her third assignment as a handmaid, in this case to Fred (referred to as "The Commander"). If Offred fails to become pregnant on this, her third attempt, she will be declared an "unwoman" and discarded. Interspersed in flashbacks are portions of her life from before and during the beginning of the revolution, when she finds she has lost all autonomy to her husband. The novel concludes with a metafictional epilogue that explains that events of the novel occurred shortly after what is called the "Gilead Period" They created a "probable" order for Offred's narrative to be recorded onto tapes, and these tapes were recorded onto a cassette tape called "Probable Order for The Handmaid's Tale" Professor Pieixoto, Professor Knotly, and "a colleague", Professor Wade, discovered these tapes and recorded them onto a tape called 'probable order for the Handmaids' The tapes were later discovered to be a "transcription of a symposium" written some time in the distant future (2195) according to the speaker's "keynote" Professor Knotley, Professor Piexoto, and Professor Wade recorded these tapes on a tape recorder called 'Probable' The tape was later found to have a hidden audio file of the symposium, and the tapes were used as the basis for the novel. The tapes have been released to the public and are available for download on the Internet. name: My Left Foot
summary: Christy Brown was diagnosed with cerebral palsy when he was four months old. He discovered his creative and artistic talents, becoming devoted to literature, writing and painting. At the age of 18, Brown went to Lourdes in France, where he met individuals whose handicaps were even worse than his. For the first time in his life, he begins to experience energy and hope. He begins to accept himself as the person he is and do the best with what he has. The autobiography makes reference to its own creation. The final pages tell of Robert Collis reading the first chapter of the book to the audience at a fundraising event. The chapter was warmly received by those in attendance. It is from this incident that the book received its title. Brown was his very first patient at this clinic. Collis was also a noted author so he provided supervision of Brown's writing. name: Lady Windermere's Fan
summary: The play opens in the Windermeres' residence in London. Lady Windermere is upset over the compliments her husband continues to pay her. The Duchess of Berwick informs her that her husband may be betraying her marriage by making repeated visits to another woman, a Mrs Erlynne, and possibly giving her large sums of money. After an unsuccessful attempt to make peace with his wife, Lord Winderere summons the courage to tell the truth to her. He reveals that there is nothing untoward in his relationship with MrsErlynne and that she will be attending the ball that evening. The play ends when Mrs ErLynne arrives at the party, where she is greeted coldly by LadyWindermere, spoiling his plan. In Act II, the play's central character is convinced to return to her husband and persuade her husband to reveal the truth about his affair with another woman to save his wife extreme humiliation. In the final act, the audience is shown a scene in which LadyWinderere is convinced she has made the right decision, but is convinced by some part of her plot that she is in fact in fact pregnant with her husband's child. The audience is then shown a brief monologue in which she reveals that she had previously made a similar mistake herself twenty years earlier. The show ends with a scene where the audience sees a young Lady windermere giving birth to her first child, a son, who is later named after her husband, Prince Edward Winderermere. It is the first time the audience has seen the play in its entirety, and it is the only time the play has been performed on stage. The production is directed by David Walliams, who also wrote the libretto for the film version of The Winter's Tale, which was released in 1998. The musical was directed by William Makepeace Thackeray, and is based on a novel by the same name. The cast of the play includes: Lady Windermere, Lord Darlington, Lord Augustus Lorton, and Lord Augustus, as well as the Duke of York, the Earl of Northumberland, the Marquess of Pembroke, and the Earl and Countess of Wessex, among other prominent members of London society. name: The Pearl
summary: Kino, a young, strong, poor pearl diver, lives in a small town, La Paz, with his wife Juana, and his baby son, Coyotito. When the baby is stung by a scorpion, Kino must find a way to pay the town doctor so he will cure him. Kino discovers an enormous pearl while out diving with Juana and he is ready to sell it for money. Sadly, other forces work against Kino. The pearl is dropped and hidden from view, but Juana shows him that she has found it. When they go back to the town, they find their home has been set on fire and Kino and Juana spend the day hiding in the house of Kino's brother Juan Tomás and his wife. They find a cave near a natural water hole, where the exhausted family hides and waits for the trackers to catch up to them. The trackers find the water hole and decided to rest there for the night, but Kino realizes that something is wrong, he climbs back up to the cave to discover that the man's shot had killed Coyotimo. Kinos then returns to La PAZ, mourning, no longer wanting the pearl, with Coyotino's dead body. Kinesis: Kino throws the pearl back into the ocean and it then sinks to the bottom of the sea. name: Barchester Towers
summary: Barchester Towers concerns the leading clergy of the imaginary cathedral city of Barchester. The much loved bishop having died, all expectations are that his son, Archdeacon Grantly, will succeed him. Instead, owing to the passage of the power of patronage to a new Prime Minister, a newcomer, the Evangelical Bishop Proudie, gains the see. Mrs Proudie exercises an undue influence over the new bishop, making herself as well as the bishop unpopular with most of the clergy. Even less popular is the bishop's newly appointed chaplain, the hypocritical and sycophantic Mr Obadiah Slope, who decides it would be expedient to marry Harding's wealthy widowed daughter, Eleanor Bold. A massive misunderstanding occurs between Eleanor and her father, brother-in-law, sister and Mr Arabin: they all believe she intends to marry the oily chaplain Mr Slope. The brilliant Reverend Francis Arabin is a considerable scholar, Fellow of Lazarus College at Oxford, who nearly followed his mentor John Henry Newman into the Roman Catholic Church. The Signora drops a delicate word in several ears and with the removal of their misunderstanding MrArabin and Eleanor become engaged. The old Dean of the Cathedral has died, Mr Slopes campaigns to become Dean, but Mr Harding is offered the preferment, with a beautiful house in the Close and of garden. However Mr Harding considers himself unsuitable and, with the help of the archdeacon, arranges that Mr Arab in be made Dean. With the Stanhopes' return to Italy, life in the Cathedral Close returns to its previous quiet and settled ways and Mr Harding continues his life of gentleness and music. The younger of Dr Stanhope's two daughters causes consternation in the Palace and threatens the plans of MrSlope. Mr Sloped is drawn like a moth to a flame and cannot keep away. The Bishop also orders the return of the prebendary Dr Vesey Stanhopes from Italy. Dr Stan hope has been there, recovering from a sore throat, for 12 years and has spent his time catching butterflies. The young Signora is a crippled serial flirt with a young daughter and a mysterious Italian husband whom she has left. The bishop considers her an unsafe influence on her daughters, her servants and Mr SlOPE. The older Signora has a mysterious husband and has left her husband, who she has met in Italy. Mr Sharpe is the son of the Signora's former husband.

name: Our Man in Havana
summary: The novel, a black comedy, is set in Havana during the Fulgencio Batista regime. James Wormold, a vacuum cleaner retailer, is approached by Hawthorne, who offers him work for the British secret service. Because he has no information to send to London, Wormold fakes his reports using information found in newspapers and invents a fictitious network of agents. Some of the names in his network are those of real people (most of whom he has never met) and some are made up. Wormold only tells his friend and World War I veteran Dr. Hasselbacher about his spy work, hiding the truth from Milly. In retaliation for the failure, Carter kills Wormold's friend at the club bar. To avenge the murder of Dr. hasselsbacher, wormold follows Carter to a local brothel and kills him with Segura's pistol. He sends the agent list as a microdot photograph on a postage stamp to London but it proves blank when processed. They are summoned back to headquarters where Beatrice is posted to Jakarta and Wormold is considered. Despite the deception, some of his information is valuable and he needs to be silenced from speaking to the press so they offer Wormold a teaching post at headquarters and recommend him for an OBE. Milly is surprisingly accepting of their decision, surprisingly accepting their decision to go to a hotel paid for by Wormold’s scam earnings. Afterwards, Milly comes to a decision and is a Swiss finishing school of finishing school and is surprisingly accepted by the Swiss. name: On Numbers and Games
summary: A game in the sense of Conway is a position in a contest between two players, Left and Right. Each player has a set of games called options to choose from in turn. Games are written {L|R} where L is the set of Left's options and R is theSet of Right's options. All numbers are positive, negative, or zero, and we say that a game is positive if Left will win, negative if Right will win or zero if the second player will win. Games that are not numbers have a fourth possibility: they may be fuzzy, meaning that the first player will wins. * is a fuzzy game. A more extensive introduction to On Numbers and Games is available online. The game {0|0} is called, and is the first game we find that is not a number. It is the only game that has no element that is negative or positive, and is called -1. It's also the first games that are fuzzy, and are called -0. It has a maximum score of 1. It can be played by any player who has no options to have lost the game. The maximum number of options a player can choose from is 0, and this is the maximum number that can be chosen to win the game by a player who does not have any options to lose the game but has played a turn. This defines the game {|}, which is called 0. Given this game 0 there are now two possible sets of options, the empty set and the set whose only element is zero. This is the game 1, and the game  -1, and it is called 1/0/1/0 or -1/1/. It is also the name of the game in which a player must play a turn but has no Options to have won the game, which is -1 /1/2 or -0/2. It may also be called -2, -3, -4, or -5, and these are the names of the games in which no options are available to the player who must play. The games are played by players who have no options at all, so there are no games at all. The empty set is now the only set of options we can provide to the players. The set with no members is called the set without any members. It contains the set 0, which has no members and is known as the set that is empty. It also contains the only element that has a negative number, and that is the number zero.

name: P.S. Your Cat Is Dead
summary: New York actor Jimmy Zoole is feeling depressed and unstable when he happens across a cat burglar, Vito, in his apartment. Vito once had a wife who left him after she discovered he was gay, and took their child with her. Jimmy questions his own orientation as his relationship to Vito takes on a homosexual dimension, and decides to use his prisoner to exact revenge on his former lover. In the end, Jimmy and Vito are able to sell a stash of stolen drugs and run away together. The film was released on New Year's Eve, 2013, and was directed by Tom Hanks and co-written by Peter Travers. It is based on the novel by Tennessee Williams, which was first published in 1881 and was adapted into a play in 1883. It was the first film by the playwright to be released in the United States, and the first of a series of films based on Tennessee Williams' works. name: Treasure Island
summary: The novel opens in the seaside village of Black Hill Cove in south-west England in the mid-18th century. The narrator, James "Jim" Hawkins, is the young son of the owners of the Admiral Benbow Inn. An old drunken seaman named Billy Bones becomes a long-term lodger at the inn, only paying for about the first week of his stay. Jim quickly realizes that Bones is in hiding, and that he particularly dreads meeting an unidentified seafaring man with one leg. Some months later, Bones is visited by a mysterious sailor named Black Dog. While Jim cares for him, Bones confesses that he was once the mate of the late notorious pirate, Captain Flint. Bones drops dead of apoplexy (in this context, a stroke) on the spot. The pirates, led by Pew, find the sea chest and the money, but are frustrated that there is no sign of "Flint's fist". Customs men approach and the pirates escape to their vessel (all except for Pew, who is accidentally run down and killed by the agents' horses).p. 27-8: "...{Pew} made another dash, now utterly bewildered, right under the nearest of the coming horses. The rider tried to save him, but in vain. Down went Pew with a cry that rang high into the night; and the four hoofs trampled and spurned him and passed by. He fell on his side, then gently collapsed upon his face, and moved no more." —Stevenson, R.L. Stevenson, in his letters and in the related fictional play Admiral Guinea, near Barnstaple, Devon.p. 34: Jim takes a mysterious oilskin packet to Dr. Livesey, as he is a "gentleman and a magistrate, and he, Squire Trelawney and Jim Hawkins examine it together. They find it contains a logbook detailing the treasure looted during Captain Flint's career, and a detailed map of an island with the location of Flint’s treasure marked on it. Jim warns the captain of the schooner, Alexander Smollett, of the impending impending mutiny of the crew. After the treasure is recovered, the captain mutiny is also mutinyed and the crew is killed. The novel is divided into 6 parts and 34 chapters: Jim Hawkins is the narrator of all except for chapters 16-18, which are narrated by Doctor Livesey.

name: Seven Brothers
summary: At first, the brothers are not a particularly peaceful lot and end up quarreling with the local constable, jury, vicar, churchwarden, and teachers. When they are required to learn to read before they can accept church confirmation and therefore official adulthood, they escape. Eventually they end up moving to distant Impivaara in the middle of relative wilderness, but their first efforts are shoddy. Next spring they try again and manage to kill a hostile herd of bulls. They learn to reading on their own and eventually return to Jukola. In the end most of them become pillars of the community and family men. Still, the tone of the tale is not particularly moralistic. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99 with p&p of £12.99. name: Steppenwolf
summary: The book is presented as a manuscript by its protagonist, a middle-aged man named Harry Haller, who leaves it to a chance acquaintance, the nephew of his landlady. In his aimless wanderings about the city he encounters a person carrying an advertisement for a magic theatre who gives him a small book, Treatise on the Steppenwolf. This treatise, cited in full in the novel's text as Harry reads it, strikes him as describing himself uncannily. It is a discourse of a man who believes himself to be of two natures: one high, the spiritual nature of man; while the other is low, animalistic, a "wolf of the steppes". This man is entangled in an irresolvable struggle, never content with either nature because he cannot see beyond this self-made concept. The next day Harry meets a former academic friend with whom he had often discussed Oriental mythology, and who invites Harry to his home. While there, Harry is disgusted by the nationalistic mentality of his friend, who inadvertently criticizes a column Harry wrote. In turn, Harry offends the man and his wife by criticizing the wife's picture of Goethe, which Harry feels is too thickly sentimental and insulting to Goethe's true brilliance. This episode confirms to Harry that he is, and will always be, a stranger to his society. The Magic Theatre is a place where he experiences the fantasies that exist in his mind. They are described as a long horseshoe-shaped corridor that is a mirror on one side and a great many doors on the other. Then, Harry enters five of these labeled doors, each of which symbolizes a fraction of his life. After attending a lavish masquerade ball, Pablo brings him to his metaphorical "magic theatre," where concerns and notions that plagued his soul disintegrate while he interacts with the ethereal and phantasmal. After a second meeting, Hermine introduces Harry to the indulgences of what he calls the "bourgeois" She teaches Harry to dance, introduces him to casual drug use, finds him a lover (Maria), and, more importantly, forces him to accept these as legitimate and worthy aspects of a full life. Hermine promises a second meet, and provides Harry with a reason to live (or at least a substantial excuse to continue living) that he eagerly embraces. Hermines alternately mocks Harry's self-pity and indulges him in his explanations regarding his view of life, to his astonished relief.

name: Goldfinger
summary: Fleming structured the novel in three sections: "Happenstance", "Coincidence" and "Enemy action" Goldfinger described Bond's three seemingly coincidental meetings with him. Bond is tasked with finding out how Auric Goldfinger is smuggling gold out of the country. The gold is finally sold in India at a vast profit. Bond foils an assassination attempt on Goldfinger by Jill Masterton's sister, Tilly, to avenge Jill's death at Goldfinger's hands. Bond and Tilly are put to work as secretaries for Goldfinger and several gangsters. They are recruited to assist in "Operation Grand Slam" – the stealing of the United States gold reserves from Fort Knox. Bond manages to break a plane window, causing depressurisation that sucks Oddjob out of it. At gunpoint, he strangles Goldfinger, who has managed to hijack a BOAC jetliner. At the Canadian coast, where they are rescued by a nearby weathership, he is killed by Oddjob. Bond wakes up to find he has been captured by Goldfinger who has captured him. Goldfinger escapes in the hijack, but Bond is drugged before his flight back to England and wakes up in a coma. He survives by being cut in two by a circular saw. Bond offers to work for Gold Finger, a ruse that Goldfinger initially refuses, but then accepts. The novel was released in paperback on November 14, 1998. It is the 50th anniversary of the first appearance of James Bond in a Bond film. The film was directed by Roger Michell and co-written by Ian Fleming and Peter Morgan. It was the first Bond film to be published by Vertigo, a division of U.S. publisher Simon & Schuster, and was released on November 25, 1998, in the UK. The UK release date was November 28, 1998; the U.K. release date is November 30, 1999. The US release date for the UK release was November 29, 1999; the UK publication date of the book was November 30th, 1998 (the UK release day for the US release of the film was November 27, 1998). The UK publication dates for the book are November 28 and November 31, 1999 (the US release dates are November 30 and November 29th, 1999 respectively). The US publication date for this book is November 28th, 2000 (the British publication date is September 28, 2000). It is published in the US under the title "Bond: The First Adventure"

name: Ironweed
summary: Francis Phelan is an alcoholic vagrant originally from Albany, New York. He left his family after accidentally killing his infant son while he may have been drunk. The novel focuses on Francis's return to Albany, and the narrative is complicated by his hallucinations of the three people, other than his son, whom he killed in the past. It features characters that return in some of Kennedy's other books. It is set during the Great Depression and tells the story of Francis's life in New York during the 1930s. It was published by Simon & Schuster on September 25, 1939. It has been published in hardback and e-book editions since 1939, with an estimated run-time of 2.5 hours. It will be published in paperback on October 1, 2009. It can be pre-ordered on Amazon.com for $16.99. For more information on Ironweed, visit www.simonandschulder.com. For additional information on the book, visit the publisher's website. For further information about the book and the author, visit http://www.samaritans.org/book/ironweed-by-james-jennifer-kennedy.

name: Girl, Interrupted
summary: Susanna Kaysen, 18, is admitted to McLean Hospital, in Belmont, Massachusetts, after attempting suicide. Susanna is diagnosed with borderline personality disorder, and her stay extends to 18 months. Fellow patients Polly, Cynthia, Lisa, Lisa Cody, Georgina and Daisy contribute to Susanna’s experiences at McLean as she describes their personal issues and how they come to cope with the time they must spend in the hospital. After leaving McLean, Susanna mentions that she kept in touch withGeorgina and saw Lisa, who was about to board the subway with her son. She also introduces the reader to particular staff members, including Valerie, Dr. Wick and Mrs. McWeeney. She suggests that sanity is a falsehood constructed to help the "healthy" feel "normal." She also questions how doctors treat mental illness, and whether they are treating the brain or the mind. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, and is available in hardcover, paperback and e-book. For help in Australia, call the Young England Samaritans, on 8457 909090.  For help abroad, visit the European Hospital and Europe and Europe and the UK Hospitals on-Line and England and Scotland. In the U S. and Europe, call 1-844-457-9090, or the National Health Institute on 8457 9090, or the UK Hôtel Spa and Hospital and Conference Center on the East Coast on the East Coast on the East Coast.  In the UK and the Middle East, contact the National Health Service on 0800 908 9090 or the National Psychiatric Service on 0800 9090.

name: Small Gods
summary: The Great God Om tries to manifest himself once more in the world, as the time of his eighth prophet is nigh. He is surprised, however, when he finds himself in the body of a tortoise, stripped of his divine powers. Brutha is gifted with an eidetic memory and is therefore chosen by Vorbis, the head of the Quisition, to come along on a diplomatic mission to Ephebe. Om manifests himself within the citadel and attempts to grant BruthA the honour of establishing the Church's new doctrines. In the book's conclusion Bruth a becomes the Eighth Prophet, ending the Qu Inquisition and reforming the church to be more open-minded and humanist. The last moments of the book see Bruths death a hundred years to the day the day after his journey across the ethereal desert towards judgement. It is also revealed that this century of peace and bloodshed was originally meant to be a century of war and bloodshed which the Monk Lu-Tze changed to something he liked better. The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced £16.99, and is available now in hardback and e-book versions for £12.99. name: The Sum of Us
summary: The plot revolves around the comfortable relationship between widower Harry and his gay son Jeff. Harry unconditionally loves his Rugby-playing son, and even takes an active part in Jeff's search for Mr. Right. Jeff's new boyfriend, Greg, who is closeted from his own homophobic father, finds it difficult to relate to Harry's well-meaning matchmaking ways. Harry, via a video dating service, finds a woman that he likes, a divorcee named Joyce, who may not be so understanding after spying a gay magazine in Harry and Jeff's house. Unfortunately, Harry suffers a massive stroke and is disabled, leaving him unable to speak or walk. Jeff cares for him as best as he can, taking him to the park for an outing one day. Jeff and Greg meet up in the park and agree to try and rekindle their romance, while Jeff's Dad, although unable to talk, gives his overwhelming approval. The film is out now on Blu-ray and DVD. For more information on the film, visit the official website or go to www.thefilmproject.org.uk or the official Facebook page of the film company, The Film Project, which is based on a book by the same name.
