For the full version of this article, visit the Film Project on the website.

name: Jingo
summary: The island of Leshp, which had been submerged under the Circle Sea for centuries, rises to the surface. Its position makes the island a powerful strategical point for whoever lays claim to it, which both cities do. In Ankh-Morpork, a Klatchian Prince named Khufurah is parading through the city when an assassination attempt occurs, and the Prince is wounded. The attempted assassination breaks off relations with Klatch as the Prince's brother effectively declares war on the city. At this point, Havelock Vetinari resigns and Lord Rust takes command of the city, and Vimes stands down as Commander of the Watch. Vimes then recruits the Watch into his own private army regiment, reasoning that, as an official noble, he is entitled to do so by law and by Lord Rust's command. Meanwhile, Nobby and Sergeant Colon have been recruited by Vet inari and his pet inventor, Leonard of Quirm, on a secret mission of their own, unknown to Vimes. They end up in Leonard's "Going-Under-the-Water-Safely Device" and discover that LeshP is actually floating on top of a huge bubble of gas (suggested to be methane or some other poisonous gas), and that the gas is escaping from said bubble, meaning that Leschenp will, ultimately, sink back under the sea again. The three also head to Gebra, where they discover that Carrot has convinced the two armies to get together and play a game of football. In the end, Carrot and the Klatchians win the game, but as Leshenp has vanished back to sea again, the treaty was to be signed in a non-existent territory and thus the charge of treason is invalid. Since Carrot was speaking to the King of Ankh Morpork of all places, the charge is not invalid, but of "reminding him of his old rank of Commander" Vimes is informed that the rank of Duke was the same as that of the old Duke. He objects, claiming that only a King can make a real Duke, but then remembers that he is not the real King. He is then reminded that the Duke is the only person who can make such a real claim, and so he is forced to give up his claim to the title. He then goes on to become the new Duke, and claims that the title of Duke is only a title that can only be given to a man who is a member of the Royal Family.

name: The Pursuit of Love
summary: Linda, the second Radlett daughter, is Fanny's best friend and the main character of the novel. The early chapters recount the Radlett children's bizarre upbringing, including their contrasting obsessions with hunting and preventing cruelty to animals. As Linda grows older she is increasingly consumed by a desire for romantic love and marriage. After nine years of marriage, Linda leaves Tony for Christian Talbot, an ardent Communist. During the London Blitz, Fanny, Louisa, and their children are living at Alconleigh, along with Matthew, Sadie, Emily, Davey, "the Bolter," and her new lover Juan. Fanny is also expecting a baby, and Linda and Linda give birth on the same day. Linda dies in childbirth, as the doctors had warned, and around this time, Fabrice is killed in the war, and Fanny and Linda adopt him and name him Fabrice in a Cold Climate (1949) and Don't Tell Alfred (1960) The sequels to the novel, Love Love Love, were published in 1960 and 1961. The sequels were also published in 1962 and 1963. The novels are available in hardback and paperback, with prices starting at £12.99 (including p&p) and £16.99 for a copy of the book with a Kindle download of the first two chapters for £9.99. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, a division of Penguin Books, and is published in the UK by Chatto & Windus, a subsidiary of Penguin Group. The UK edition of the books comes with a free hardback of the same name, as well as a hardback hardback version of the second edition with a different cover and a paperback edition of £10.00 (both with the same cover). The UK editions of the two books are published by Penguin Books and the US edition by HarperCollins, and the UK edition by Penguin Random House, respectively. The U.S. editions of both books come with a paperback of the third and fourth editions, and a hardcover of the fourth and the fifth editions of "Love Love Love" (both published by Macmillan). The book was released in the U.K. in the United States in the summer of 1966. It is published as a double entendre, with the first and the second being released in Australia in the spring of 1967. The first two volumes are available as hardback, and both are available online for £14.99 each.

name: Moonraker
summary: Sir Hugo Drax is the product of a mysterious background, unknown even to himself (allegedly) As a supposed British soldier in World War II, he was badly injured and stricken with amnesia in the explosion of a bomb planted by a German saboteur at a British field headquarters. After extensive rehabilitation in an army hospital, however, he eventually returned home to become a major aerospace industrialist. After building his fortune and establishing himself in business and society, Drax started building the "Moonraker", Britain's first nuclear missile project. After a Ministry of Supply security officer working at the project is shot dead, M assigns Bond to replace him and also to investigate what has been going on at the missile-building base. All of the rocket scientists working on the project were German. He also uncovers clues concerning his predecessor's death, concluding that the former Security Chief may have been killed for witnessing a submarine off the coast. He now means to destroy London with the very missile he has constructed for Britain, by means of a Soviet-supplied nuclear warhead that has been secretly fitted to the Moonraker. Gala Brand, a beautiful Special Branch agent working undercover as Personal Assistant to Drax, is caught. She soon finds herself captive at a secret radio station (intended to serve as a beacon for the missile's guidance system) in the heart of London. While attempting to rescue her in a car chase, Bond is also captured. Drax tells Bond that he was never a British soldier and has never suffered from amnesia. The amnesia story was simply a cover he used while recovering in hospital, in order to avoid allied retribution, although it would lead to a whole new British identity. He remains a dedicated Nazi, bent on revenge against England for the wartime defeat of his Fatherland and his prior history of social slights suffered as a youth growing up in an English boarding school before the war. He plans to play the stock market the day before to make a huge profit from the imminent disaster. He and his henchman attempt to escape by all along, only to be killed as the vessel flees through the very waters onto which the moonraker has been re-targeted. After this first (supposedly un-armed) test firing, Bond and Gala escape and escape the proper coordinates to redirect the gyros into the sea. Bond meets up with Gala expecting her company—but she reveals that she is engaged to be married to a fellow Special Branch officer.

name: Sophie's Choice
summary: Sophie's Choice is narrated by Stingo, a novelist who is recalling the summer when he began his first novel. Stingo is drawn into the lives of the lovers Nathan Landau and Sophie Zawistowska, fellow boarders at the house. Sophie is a beautiful, Polish-Catholic survivor of the concentration camps of World War II. Nathan is a Jewish-American – and, purportedly, a genius, but he is a paranoid schizophrenic who is self-medicating with drugs, including cocaine and benzadrine, that he supposedly obtains at Pfizer, his employer. The story progresses as Sophie tells Stingo of her past, of which she has never before spoken, and how she chose to sacrifice her seven-year-old daughter, Eva, in a heart-rending decision that has left her in mourning and filled with a guilt that she cannot overcome, Stingo writes in the book. The novel ends when Stingo discovers that Sophie and Nathan have committed suicide by ingesting sodium cyanide, and he is devastated, he writes in a letter to Stingo's father. The reader also learns what became of Sophie's daughter, named Eva, only at the end of the book does the reader also learn what becameof Sophie's son, who was interned by the Nazis in the Lebensborn program, in which he would be raised as a German child. He writes: "He could have been fantastically brilliant at anything he might have tried out … But he never got his mind in order." Stingo also learns that Nathan's brother, Larry, is not a cellular biologist, although, as Larry says, "he could have be fantastically Brilliant at anything" Stingo and Sophie attempt to flee to a peanut farm in Virginia which his father has inherited. On the way there, Sophie reveals her deepest, darkest secret: on the night that she arrived at Auschwitz, a sadistic doctor made her choose which of her two children would die immediately by gassing and which would continue to live, albeit in the camp. She failed in her attempts to seduce Höss in an effort to persuade him that her blond, blue-eyed, German-speaking son should be allowed to leave the camp and enter the LeBensbornProgram. She fails in this attempt and, ultimately, she never learned of her son's fate. The book ends with Stingo proposing marriage to her, but Sophie disappears, leaving only a note in which she says that she must return to Nathan.

name: Season of the Jew
summary: In this story of New Zealand and Te Kooti's War during the year beginning November 10, 1868, the narrative coalesces around the development of its protagonist, George Fairweather. Fairweather paradoxically finds his feelings of humanity expanding to include Englishmen, colonials and Māoris, coupled with a growing resentment of racism and injustice. In the end he almost throws his future away by struggling to save a Māori boy, Hamiora (reminiscent of Melville’s Billy Budd), unjustly charged with treason. With the hanging of Hamioro, November 10,. 1869, and the conclusion of Fairweather’S desperate attempts first to prevent and then to mitigate it, the book ends. The problem of Te Kootsi is not resolved, except in the brief epilogue, further revealing the depths of Fair weather’'s ambivalence about the historical figure of TeKootsi, Fairweather's hated and admired nemesis and one-time friend. The book ends with Fairweather trying to prevent the hanging, and his desperate attempts to prevent it. It is published by Simon & Schuster, priced $24.99. For more information on the book, go to www.simonandschuster.com. For information about the book and its author, visit http://www.simonsandschweizer.com/te-kooti-war-1868-and-the-year-beginning-of-November-10,1868. For details on the author and his book, visit www.samaritans.co.uk/tekootis-war. For the full story of the story and the events surrounding it, visit: www.susanandshreveport.org.uk/. For more on the story, visit susanswerve.com or go to: http://susannewspaper.com/. For the complete story, see: http:/www.sanswerreporter.org/2013/11/10/new-zealand-tekootsi.html#storylink=cpy. The story is about a former British officer in his early forties, who leaves the service under a cloud, turns landscape painter and cultivates an air of worldly detachment. Yet he finds himself drawn by love and humanity back into the world of colonial New Zealand. He is described as “A composite character... yet still far from fictional”

name: The White Plague
summary: John Roe O'Neill's wife and children are killed by an IRA bomb on May 20, 1996. Driven halfway insane by loss, his mind fragments into several personalities that carry out his plan for him. He plans a genocidal revenge and creates a plague that kills women. He then releases it in Ireland (for supporting the terrorists), England (for oppressing the Irish and giving them a cause), and Libya (for training said terrorists) He demands that the governments of the world send all citizens of those countries back to their countries, and that they quarantine those countries and let the plague run its course, so they will lose what he has lost. If they do not, he has more plagues to release. After releasing the plague, he goes to Ireland to hide, planning to offer his services as a molecular biologist in the hopes of sabotaging whatever work is done there on finding a cure. To travel to the lab at Killaloe, he is forced to walk with a priest, a boy who has taken a vow of silence due to the death of his mother, and Joseph Herity, the IRA bomber who detonated the explosive that killed O’Neill’s wife and kids. Their purpose is to confirm his identity, either through Herity's indirect questioning, or the possibility that he will confess to the priest when confronted with the pain his revenge has caused for the boy. Meanwhile, law and order has broken down in England and Ireland, and the old Irish ways are coming back. Local IRA thugs appoint themselves "kings of old", and others recreate ancient Celtic pagan religions centered on the rowan tree. The IRA has effective control of Ireland, but as the governments grow certain that O'Neil is there and essentially in custody, they consider wiping out the three targeted countries to end the lingering threat. When he arrives in Ireland,. he is suspected of being O'Neal (whom the investigatory agencies of theworld have deduced is responsible). To travel with a Priest, aBoy who has taking a vow to silence due. to the deaths of his parents, and a bomber who detonates the bomb that killed his wife and. children. The purpose of the trip is to find out if he is the bomber or if the priest will ask him to reveal his identity or if he will be forced to do so himself. The priest asks him to travel with the boy, and he reveals his identity. The boy is then forced to reveal that he was the bomber.

name: The Pilgrim's Progress
summary: Christian is the protagonist of the allegory, which centres itself in his journey from his hometown, the "City of Destruction" ("this world"), to the "Celestial City" ("that which is to come": Heaven) atop Mt. Zion. Christian is weighed down by a great burden, the knowledge of his sin, which he believed came from his reading "the book in his hand," (the Bible) This burden, which would cause him to sink into Tophet (hell), is so unbearable that Christian must seek deliverance. He meets Evangelist as he is walking out in the fields, who directs him to the 'Wicket Gate' for deliverance, which Christian thinks he sees. Christian leaves his home, his wife, and children to save himself: he cannot persuade them to accompany him. After Christian is relieved of his burden, he is greeted by three shining ones, who give him the greeting of peace, new garments, and a scroll as a passport into the Celestial City — these are allegorical figures indicative of Christian Baptism. Christian spends his first stop for the night at the House Beautiful, which is an allegory of the local Christian congregation. As night falls Christian enters the Valley of the Shadow of Death, where he is in the middle of the gloom and terror. When the sun rises on a new day he meets Faithful, a former resident of the City of Destruction, who accompanies him to Vanity Fair, where both are arrested and detained because of their disdain for the wares and business of the fair. Faithful is put on trial and executed as a martyr, taking Christian to the place of Faithful and Hopeful, also a resident of Vanity Fair. Christian finally reaches the "place of deliverance" (allegorically, the cross of Calvary and the open sepulcher of Christ), where the "straps" that bound Christian's burden to him break, and it rolls away into theopen sepulchre. This event happens relatively early in the narrative: the immediate need of Christian at the beginning of the story being quickly remedied. In the Second Part, Good-will is shown to be Jesus himself. Christian makes his way from there to the House of the Interpreter, where the pictures and tableaux that portray or dramatize aspects of the Christian faith and life are called "emblems" Roger Sharrock denotes them "emblem" as a reference to the Bible, Heb. 6:11-18.

name: The Santaroga Barrier
summary: A psychologist, Gilbert Dasein, is hired by corporate interests to investigate a town in a valley where marketing seems totally ineffective. The last few psychologists sent in have all died in accidents that are (seemingly) perfectly plausible. Complicating matters further still, the psychologist's college girlfriend, Jenny, has returned to Santaroga. Santarogans aren't hostile, they just won't shop there; neither are they xenophobic, instead appearing maddeningly self-satisfied with their quaint, local lifestyle. Their newspapers are vaguely subversive with their folksy, enlightened commentary on world affairs. Their dinner conversations knowledgeably reference great theories of psychology, politics, and cognitive science. As Jenny tries to convince him to settle down with her there, he wonders whether he'll live long enough to decide. The film is out now on Blu-ray and DVD. For more information on the film, visit the film's website or watch the trailer here: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/29/the-film/santaroga-the-book/index.html#storylink=cpy. name: Orlando Furioso
summary: The action of Orlando Furioso takes place against the background of the war between the Christian emperor Charlemagne and the Saracen King of Africa. Orlando has been tempted to forget his duty to protect the emperor through his love for the pagan princess Angelica. When Orlando learns the truth, he goes mad with despair and rampages through Europe and Africa destroying everything in his path. The English knight Astolfo journeys to Ethiopia on the hippogriff to find a cure for Orlando's madness. He flies up to the moon (in Elijah's flaming chariot no less) where everything lost on earth is to be found, including Orlando's wits. Orlando joins with Brandimart and Oliver to fight Agramante, Sobrino and Gradasso on the island of Lampedusa. There Orlando kills King Agramantes. The epic contains many other characters, including the paladin Rinaldo, who is also in love with Angelica; the thief Brunello; and the tragic heroine Isabella. They too have to endure many vicissitudes. Ruggiero and Bradamante are the ancestors of the House of Este, Ariosto's patrons, whose genealogy he gives at length in canto 3 of the poem. The poem ends with Ruggierso slaying Rodomonte in single combat. The author explains that love is itself a form of insanity, and that Orlando falls out of love withangelica. He also explains that Orlando's love for Angelica is the reason he is so mad, and the reason why he kills her. He explains this at the same time that Orlando is cured of his madness by Astolfe's flying chariot, which takes him to Ethiopia to find his wits in a bottle and makes Orlando sniff them, thus restoring him to sanity. It ends with Orlando and Angelica on their way to Cathay, where they meet Medoro and fall in love, and elopes with him toCathay. They also have to avoid the enchantments of his foster father, the wizard Atlante, who does not want him to fight. Finally, Ruggiereo converts to Christianity and marries Bradamante, and accuses him of being a traitor to the SarACen cause. The pair are eventually freed from Alcina's magic island and the pair are married. The story ends with the wedding feast and the wedding of Bradamrante and Ruggierio, who are later to become the first Christians.

name: The Anatomy of Melancholy
summary: The Anatomy of Melancholy is an especially lengthy book, the first edition being a single quarto volume nearly 900 pages long. Much of the book consists of quotations from various ancient and mediæval medical authorities, beginning with Hippocrates, Aristotle, and Galen. The text is divided into three major sections plus an introduction, the whole written in Burton's sprawling style. Most modern editions include many explanatory notes, and translate most of the Latin. The Anatomy concludes with an extensive index, which, many years later, The New York Times Book Review called "a readerly pleasure in itself" The first section focuses on the causes and symptoms of "common" melancholies, while the second section deals with cures for melancholy. The third section explores more complex and esoteric melancholy, including the melancholy of lovers and all varieties of religious melancholie. The author also included a great deal of Latin poetry in the Anatomy, and many of his inclusions from ancient sources are left untranslated in the text. The first edition was a single four-volume volume nearly900 pages long; subsequent editions were even longer. In attacking his stated subject, Burton drew from nearly every science of his day, including psychology and physiology, but also astronomy, meteorology, and theology, and even astrology and demonology. Burton defined his subject as follows: "Melancholies are not the same as melancholy, they are the opposite of it." The author's note to the Reader includes not only an author's notes, but a Latin poem ("Democritus Junior to His Book"), a warning to "The Reader Who Employs His Leisure Ill", an abstract of the following text, and another poem explaining the frontispiece. The following three sections proceed in a similarly exhaustive fashion: the first section focus on the Causes and Symptoms of " common" melanchols, the second sections deals with cure for melancholy, and the third section deals in more complex ways with more complex melancholian symptoms. In the introduction to the book, Burton also includes a poem, a warning, and a poem explaining how to take care of one's health. The book concludes with the Index, which most modern editions have translated and include many explanations of how to use the index, as well as an explanation of how the index was created. It is published in two volumes, one in English and the other in Latin, and is available in many editions, including many modern editions.

name: Piers Plowman
summary: The poem is part theological allegory, part social satire. It concerns the narrator's quest for the true Christian life, from the perspective of mediæval Catholicism. The poem begins in the Malvern Hills in Malvern, Worcestershire. In the early part of the poem Piers, the humble plowman of the title, appears and offers himself as the narrator’s guide to Truth. The latter part of. the work, however, is concerned with the Narrator's search for Dowel, Dobet and Dobest. Between these symbols of heaven and hell is a "fair field full of folk", representing the world of mankind. The narrator's dream-visions and an examination into the lives of three allegorical characters, Dowel ("Do-Well"), Dobet (" do-Better"), and Dobst ("do-best") lead to the poem's conclusion. It is written in the form of a single word: "Dowel" or "Dobet". The poem was written in 1847. It was published in 1849. It has been translated into English as "The Dream of Dowel" and as "Do-Best" by William Makepeace Thackeray (1849-1955) and as "The Dream Of Dobel" by William Makepeace Twentieth (1854-1954). It was written by a man named Will, and published by the London School of Poetry in 1853. It concerns the narrator 's quest for the true life, and an examination into the lives of three allegory characters, Dowal, Dobel and Dobet. The work was written in the period between 1847 and 1854. It also occurs in 1855 and 1856. It contains a number of short stories, including "D Dowel", "Dobest" and "Do-Better", as well as a short story called "Doubts" about the meaning of the word "doubts". It was written by Will Will, who was a member of the Church of England.

name: Red Storm Rising
summary: Islamic terrorists from Azerbaijan destroy a Soviet oil-production facility at Nizhnevartovsk, Russia. The Politburo instead decides to seize the oil fields in the Persian Gulf by military force. According to the Carter Doctrine, any attack on the Gulf is an attack on strategic interests to the United States, necessitating a military response. To prevent a combined reaction by NATO, the Soviets launch a KGB operation to carry out a false flag operation framing West Germany for an unprovoked attack on USSR. Afterwards, the USSR plans to invade Europe in response to that “attack’s’. The Soviets advance at great cost, having dramatically underestimated NATO defensive firepower. The Soviet Navy is able to act as an offensive weapon contrary to pre-war NATO expectations, becoming a major strategic threat against resupply convoys coming from North America with both aircraft and submarines. In West Germany, the battle becomes a war of attrition that the Soviets expect to win through slow and sustained advances. The more competent CinC-Southwest and his second-in-command, General-Colonel Pavel Leonidovich Alekseyev take over on the German front. As the OMG (Operational Manoeuvre Group) forces start to deploy, NATO looks likely to lose all of the Weser River River to the Soviets. When a Soviet attack on east of Germany (Operative River) fails, NATO loses all of its most effective cruise missile bases. The U.S. Marines take this opportunity to stage an amphibious assault on Iceland backed by NATO navies, retaking the island and closing the Atlantic to Soviet forces. Simultaneously with the sudden reversal, the remaining Soviet naval cruise missile fleets are wiped out. The USSR is essentially wiped out in the Atlantic, opening the opening to direct attacks against its strategic areas and the free flow of convoys across the Northern Atlantic and the Northern Pacific. It is essentially a victory for the USSR, with the remaining bomber fleets virtually wiped out and the remaining naval missile fleets effectively wiped out across the northern Atlantic and Northern Pacific areas. It was a sudden reversal with the suddenly sudden reversal of the USSR's strategic and strategic and Northern Atlantic, and the sudden loss of the Northern Northern and Northern Northern convoys in the Northern hemisphere. It would be a surprise if the Soviets had managed to win the war in the Pacific theater or the Mediterranean region, as the Soviet Navy was able to protect its submarine fleet in costal waters behind minefields and ASW assets.

name: The Joy of Work
summary: The book is a response to Norman Solomon's 1997 book, The Trouble with Dilbert. Adams concludes that it is the 'proximity' of sensitive subjects to negative concepts that causes "people who are angry for no good reason (nuts)" to take offence. The 'Final Postscript' is a page dedicated to his cat 'Freddie', who died as the book was in its final stages. The last words in the book are "That [pet ownership], my friend, is joy". Scott also writes "The third part of the book is made entirely out of invisible pages. If the book seems heavier than it looks, that's why." The book is published by Simon & Schuster, priced at £20 (including Kindle) and is available to pre-order now. For confidential support call the Samaritans in the UK on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or see www.samaritans.org for details. The second part is an analysis of humour and how to write funny material. The third part is a look at how to deal with superiors, meetings and co-workers. The book also includes a section devoted to how to find happiness at the expense of your co-worker. It is written in the style of a comic book, and includes a number of examples of how to make people laugh. It was written by Scott Adams and is published in the form of a three-part book, with the first part written by Adams and the second by Adams himself. The final part is written by the author and Adams himself, and is titled ‘Office pranks: How to avoid work whilst having fun’.

name: Lady Chatterley's Lover
summary: The story concerns a young married woman, Constance (Lady Chatterley), whose upper-class husband has been paralyzed due to a war injury. Her sexual frustration leads her into an affair with the gamekeeper, Oliver Mellors. The class difference between the couple highlights a major motif of the novel which is the unfair dominance of intellectuals over the working class. The novel is about Constance's realisation that she cannot live with the mind alone; she must also be alive physically. This realisation stems from a heightened sexual experience Constance has only felt with Mellors, suggesting that love can only happen with the element of the body, not the mind. The book is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99. For more information, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or go to www.hodgerandstroughton.com. In the U.K. call the National Suicide prevention Lifeline on 0800 909090. For the UK and Scotland and the Europe, call the helpline on 0800-9090 or visit  www.sophisticationlifeline on behalf of the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline.

name: A Staircase in Surrey
summary: In The Gaudy Duncan Patullo returns to his old college, after a long absence. The discovery of a lost masterpiece by Piero della Francesca proves crucial to the college's future fortunes. The character of the provost of the college is said to have been based on that of Henry Chadwick, Dean of Christ Church, Oxford during Stewart's own time there. Fantasy writer and Oxford don J.R. R. Tolkien appears as the elderly "Professor Timberlake" in this novel. In The Madonna of the Astrolabe Patulla copes with his ex-wife, the undergraduates' production of Tamburlaine, and the problems of raising enough money for the urgently-needed restoration of the crumbling Great Tower. The second novel, YoungPatullo, tells the story of their former relationships and Patulli's undergraduate career. The third novel, The Madonna Of The Astrolabes, is set in the 1930s and 1940s and is about the life of a young playwright at Oxford. The fourth and fifth novels are about the 1960s and 1970s and the lives of the young playwrights at Christ Church. The sixth and seventh novels are set during the 1980s and 1990s and tell the stories of two young men at the college. The final novel is a novel about a young woman who becomes a playwright and becomes a successful author. The last novel is about a man who loses his wife and returns to Oxford to complete his education. The novel is called The Madonna And The Madonna, and is published by Hodder & Stoughton, priced £16.99. For more information on the book, visit www.hodderandstoughton.co.uk or www.hodgemstroughton.com. name: The Sorrows of Young Werther
summary: The majority of 'The Sorrows of Young Werther' is presented as a collection of letters written by Werther, a young artist of highly sensitive and passionate temperament. In these letters, Werther gives a very intimate account of his stay in the fictional village of Wahlheim (based on the town of Garbenheim, near Wetzlar) He is enchanted by the simple ways of the peasants there. He meets Charlotte, a beautiful young girl who is taking care of her siblings following the death of their mother. Despite knowing beforehand that Charlotte is already engaged to a man named Albert, he falls in love with her. His pain eventually becomes so great that he is forced to leave and go to Weimar. He suffers a great embarrassment when he forgetfully visits a friend on the day when the entire aristocratic set normally meets there. After composing a farewell letter (to be found after he commits suicide), he writes to Albert asking for his two pistols, under a pretence that he was going "on a journey". Lotte receives the request with great emotion and sends the pistols. Werther then shoots himself in the head, but does not expire until 12 hours after he has shot himself. He is buried under a linden tree, a tree he talks about frequently in his letters, and the funeral is not attended by clergymen, Albert or his beloved Lotte. He had realized even before this incident that one of them — Lotte, Albert, or Werther himself — had to die. Every day serves as a torturous reminder that Lotte will never be able to requite his love. He visits her one final time, and they are both overcome with emotion after Werther's recitation of a portion of "Ossian" Werther had realized before this event that one, or both, of them, would have to die, and he wrote to Albert to ask for his pistols. Lotte and Albert are now married, and Werther and Lotte have a close friendship. He spends the next few months cultivating a close friend with both of them. Out of pity for her friend and respect for her husband, Lotte comes to the decision that Werther must not visit her so frequently. After this, he suffers more than he did before, partially because Lotte is now married. He then writes to Lotte asking for her hand in marriage, and she sends him two pistols. He dies 12 hours later, and is buried in Weimar, where he had been staying with his friend Wilhelm.

name: The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling
summary: Squire Allworthy and his sister Bridget are introduced in their wealthy estate in Somerset. Allworthy returns from London after an extended business trip and finds a baby sleeping in his bed. After searching the nearby village, Mrs Wilkins is told about a young woman called Jenny Jones, servant of a schoolmaster and his wife. Jenny is brought before them and admits being the baby's mother but refuses to reveal the father's identity. The plot then turns to Mrs Partridge, wife of the schoolteacher, who has discovered that Jenny gave birth to a bastard and had mistakenly thought that she had left their service of her own free will. Tom, who goes from 14-years-old to nineteen-years of age by the end of Book III, gets into trouble for killing a partridge on a neighbour's land. In fact he did it at the instigation of Black George, Allworthy's gamekeeper, but he refuses to tell Mr Allworthy who his partner-in-crime was. He is beaten by his master, Mr Thwackum, who resides at the house with another schoolmaster, a philosopher called Mr Square. Tom confesses that he sold the horse and gave the money to Black George and his family, now in financial straits after being dismissed. Tom is given over to Molly, the second of George's daughters and he feels obliged to offer her his protection. She throws herself at Tom and he falls in love with her. Tom speaks to Sophia Blifil about her father and she persuades her father to drop any charges and to drop him. Tom gets her pregnant and he is given to a local beauty, Molly, who falls for his heart but he is then given to another beauty, Sophia. Tom falls in favour with Sophia and she speaks to her father about dropping him and he does so. Tom resolves to have Black George employed by Mr Western speaking to the girl's father to persuade her to get rid of the small bird of Sophia's. Mr Western speaks to Mr Western and the girl gets pregnant and gets her husband to get her out of the canal so that Tom can retrieve the bird. Tom and Sophia fall in love and he gets her to give birth to another girl, Molly. Tom then gets into a car accident and is taken to hospital where he is treated by a local doctor. The doctor introduces the captain to Bridget in hopes of marrying into Allworthy’s wealth. After the marriage, Captain Bl ifil begins to show a coldness to his brother, who eventually feels obliged.

name: Richard III
summary: The play begins with Richard describing the accession to the throne of his brother, King Edward. Richard plots to have his brother Clarence, who stands before him in the line of succession, conducted to the Tower of London over a prophecy he fed to the King. Richard next ingratiates himself with "the Lady Anne" – Anne Neville, widow of the Lancastrian Edward of Westminster, Prince of Wales. Despite initially hating him, Anne is won over by his pleas of love and repentance and agrees to marry him. Queen Margaret, Henry VI's widow, returns in defiance of her banishment and warns the squabbling nobles about Richard. The atmosphere at court is poisonous: the established nobles are at odds with the upwardly mobile relatives of Queen Elizabeth, a hostility fuelled by Richard's machinations. Richard orders two murderers to kill Clarence in the tower. Clarence wakes and pleads with the murderers, saying that men have no right to obey other men. When the murderers arrive, he reads their warrant (issued in the name of the King), and exits with the Keeper, who disobeys Clarence and leaves the two murderers the keys. He recalls the unity of Richard of York, bidding his brother Gloucester to go to his brother Edward and weep. Sardonically, Gloucester says: "We will millstones on this murderer, echoing a millstone, and we will weep and think on this" He recalls Richard's words: "I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter. What, though I kill'd her husband and his father?" Richard confides to the audience that he will discard her once she has served her purpose. The murderers arrive and kill Clarence, but Clarence does not believe him. He imagines dying and being tormented by the ghosts of his father-in-law (Warwick, Anne and Edward's father) and brother- in-law. Under the water Clarence sees the skeletons of thousands of men "that fishes gnawed upon. He also sees gems, anchors, heaps of pearl, inestimable stones, unvalued jewels. All of these are &# 34;scatterd in the bottom of the sea. He adds that some of the jewels were in the skulls of the dead. The dream includes extremely visual language describing Clarence falling from an imaginary ship as a result of Gloucester, who had fallen from the hatches, striking him. Richard exults in having won her over despite all he has done to her.

name: The Fall
summary: The novel opens with Clamence sitting in the bar, Mexico City, casually talking to a stranger. He tells us that he used to lead an essentially perfect life in Paris as a highly successful and well-respected defence lawyer. The vast majority of his work centred around "widow and orphan" cases, that is, the poor and disenfranchised who otherwise would be unable to provide themselves with a proper defence before the law. However, late one night when crossing the Pont Royal on his way home from his "mistress," he comes across a woman dressed in black leaning over the edge of the bridge. He had only walked a short distance when he heard the distinct sound of a body hitting the water. The sound of screaming was Despite ClamENCE's view of himself as a selfless advocate for the weak and unfortunate, he simply ignores the incident and continues on his path. The feeling of resentment gnaws at him and he runs through his mind what he thinks he should have done — namely strike his interlocutor when he suddenly punches him in the side of the head. Later, he returns to his car and drives away, utterly humiliated, and explains that "a hundred times" that he thinks what he should do is not to run away, but to strike the motorcyclist who had run him off the road and run away from him. The laughter is thus alarming because it immediately reminds him of his obvious failure to do anything whatsoever about the woman who had presumably drowned years before. He turns around to discover that the laughter, of course, was not directed at him, but probably originated from a far-off conversation between friends — such is the rational course of his thought. He later elaborates that his failure to doing anything was most probably because doing so would have required him to put his own personal safety in jeopardy. This implies that the laughing originated within himself, adding another dimension to the inner meaning of the scene. That evening on the Pont des Arts represents, for Clamences, the collision of his true self with his inflated self-image, and the final realization of his own hypocrisy becomes painfully obvious. A third and final incident initiatesClamence's downward spiral. One day while waiting at a stoplight, he is trapped behind a motorcycle which has stalled ahead of him and is unable to proceed once the light changes to green as a result. Other cars behind him start honking their horns, and he politely asks the man several times if he would please move his motorcycle off of the road so that others can drive around him.

name: The Golden Hour
summary: The Golden Hour tells the story of Rowan and Nina's adventures the summer after their mother's death. Nina seems interested in using the machine to escape her troubled life. Rowan, Xanthe and Xavier time-travel to the French Revolution to save Nina, meeting various historical characters along the way. Nina ends up in New York at their bakery visiting their mom. The Golden Hour is published by Simon & Schuster at $24.99. For more information, visit the Golden Hour website or go to http://www.goldenhour.com/. The book is also published in hardback and is available on Kindle and other e-book formats for $3.99 to $4.99, with the option to buy the book for $5.99 with the purchase of the book, or $6.99 without the purchase, both prices include the book's Kindle edition and the Kindle version. The film is directed by John Cusack and is written by David Walliams. It is the first time the author has been involved in a feature-length film.

name: The Man Who Fell to Earth
summary: Thomas Jerome Newton is a humanoid alien who comes to Earth seeking to construct a spaceship to ferry others from his home planet, Anthea, to Earth. Anthea is experiencing a terrible drought after many nuclear wars, and the population has dwindled to less than 300. Like all Antheans, he is super-intelligent, but he has been selected to complete this mission for his strength, due to the harsh climate and gravity of Earth compared to the cold, small Anthea. Getting to Earth via a lifeboat, Newton first lands in the state of Kentucky but quickly becomes familiarized with the environment and aspires to become an entrepreneur. He rises as the head of a technology-based conglomerate to incredible wealth. This wealth is needed to construct his own space vehicle program in order to ferry the rest of the Anthean population. Along the way he meets Betty Jo, a simple Kentucky woman. She falls in love with him. He does not share these feelings, but takes her, and his curious fuel-technician Nathan Bryce, as his few friends while he runs his company in the shadows. He creates a recording of alien messages which he hopes to be broadcast via radio to his home. His secret identity as an alien is discovered by Nathan Bryce and he is relieved to reveal his identity to someone for the first time. The story of Newton's blinding reaches the press in a frenzy and then is used by the Republican Party to depict the Democrats as being corrupt, and leads to their seizure of power, which is to inevitably lead to apocalypse. Newton, in a final confrontation with Bryce, is bitterly unable to continue his spaceship project due to planetary alignments having changed during captivity and the troubles of his blindness. However, the CIA arrests Newton, having followed him since his appearance on Earth and having recorded this private conversation with Bryce. They submit him to rigorous tests and analysis, but ultimately find that, despite much conclusive evidence of his alien identity, it would be pointless to release the results because the public would not believe the truth. Such claims would also reflect poorly on the Democratic Party, responsible for the capture. The CIA releases Newton, but no sooner than he tries to exit his building, the FBI, uninformed by the CIA that Newton is exempt from further tests, commences their own brief examinations. Their final examination is ultimately an X-ray of Newton’s skull, through his eyes. He tries to stop them to no avail and is blinded. He hopes to make use of their superintelligence to influence Earth to peace, prosperity, and safety from the apocalypse.

name: The Quiet Earth
summary: John Hobson is a geneticist involved in a project concerned with manipulating DNA. He awakes in his hotel room in Thames, New Zealand after a nightmare of falling from a great height. Upon getting up he finds the electricity off. It is quiet outside, with nobody in sight. Hobson checks the time in his car, finding the vehicle's clock is also frozen at 6:12. The town's shops are locked and unattended, with no sign of people. Investigating a car sitting at an intersection, Hobson sees that the driver's seatbelt is still fastened. Telephones are dead and there is only static on the radio. All humans and animals have disappeared. Some force has altered the clocks to show the same time and then stopped them, suggesting an intelligence behind the event, which Hobson dubs 'the Effect' Apirana Maketu, a Māori and a lance-corporal in the New Zealand Army. Api heard the same sound that Hobson heard – albeit earlier in the day and coming from the side of the lake Hobson was standing on. It's present only in certain places, and is stronger at night. The soldier is both relieved and worried to find Hobson has experienced the same dread. The two men seem to share a flash of recognition. Neither can account for this, as they have never encountered each other before. They arrive at the nation's capital to find it devoid of life, and Hobson and Api set up dwellings in a hotel and hunt for survivors. A transceiver is set up for the scientist's studies and he plans to run tests to see if he can determine the nature of the Effect and the reason why he andApi survived. A search of Gisborne and the East Coast yielded nothing, and a visit to the power station at Tokaanu led him to believe the electrical grid was knocked out by a massive surge. The film is set in New Zealand in the 1980s and 1990s. It was released on September 11, 2013. It has been released on Blu-ray, DVD and Blu-Ray, and on DVD on September 14, 2013, and 10th September 2013, respectively. The book is available in English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, Australian and New Zealand, and in the UK. For more information on the book, visit www.amazon.com/The-Effect-New-Zealand-The-Book-And- DVD.

name: The Phantom Tollbooth
summary: Milo is a boy bored by the world around him; every activity seems a waste of time. He arrives home from school one day to find a mysterious package that contains a miniature tollbooth and a map of "the Lands Beyond". Attached is a note, "FOR MILO, WHO HAS PLENTY OF TIME". He assembles the tollbooths, takes the map, drives through the toll booth in his toy car, and instantly finds himself on a road to Expectations. He pays no attention to his route and soon becomes lost in the Doldrums, a colorless place where thinking and laughing are not allowed. However, he is found there and rescued by Tock, a "watchdog" with an alarm clock attached to him, who joins him on his journey. Their first stop is Dictionopolis, one of two capital cities of the Kingdom of Wisdom. They visit the word marketplace, where all the world's words and letters are bought and sold. After overcoming various obstacles and their own fears, the questers reach the Castle in the Air, where the two princesses welcome Milo and agree to return to Wisdom. The armies of Wisdom welcome the princesses home, King Azaz and the Mathemagician are reconciled, and all enjoy a three-day carnival celebration of the return of Rhyme and Reason, the Princesses of the land. They eat subtraction stew, which makes the diner hungrier. When the group leaves, Tock carries them through the sky because, after all, time flies. Milo is somewhat disappointed but finds that the world he lives in is beautiful and interesting. He awakens the next day full of plans to returning to Wisdom, but when he returns from school the Tollbooth has vanished. A new note has arrived, which reads, " FOR MILO,. WHO NOW KNOWS THE WAY." Milo is back in his own room, and discovers he has been gone only an hour. The Humbug appoints Milo as a guide, and he, Milo, and Tock set off for the Matemagician's capital of Digitopolis to obtain his approval for their quest. Along the way they meet such characters as Alec Bings, a little boy who sees through things and grows until he reaches the ground, and have adventures like watching Chroma the Great conduct his orchestra in playing the colors of the sunset. In the Mountains of Ignorance, the three intrepid journeyers contend with lurking, obstructionist demons like the Terrible Trivium and the Senses Taker.
